LENGTH: 1534 words

HEADLINE: La Guardia's Legacy: A Duty to the Needy;
Federal Welfare Shift Spotlights Unusual Amendment to State Constitution

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

 BODY:
One warm summer day, a prominent Republican stood before a group of civic-minded people, some of them pillars of his party, and told them that the welfare system was "unworkable and cumbersome."
If the welfare system were fixed, he predicted optimistically, not only would the old, the sick and the needy be better off in the long run, but government would save money and the overall economy would get better. 
 The time was July 1938, the place Albany. The Republican was not a supply-sider caught in a time warp. He knew nothing of country clubs. Perhaps recalling his tenement childhood, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia of New York believed that government had a sacred duty to protect the unfortunate.
And so, in a gesture that reverberates six decades later as the welfare system is being overhauled, he urged the Committee on Social Welfare at the New York State Constitutional Convention to adopt an amendment declaring that the state had an obligation to care for its sick and needy.
"I can't come up here each year to the Legislature and beg for money," Mayor La Guardia said.
The Mayor had a good friend on the committee: Adrian P. Burke, a young lawyer from New York City who was active in charities that aided children. Sometimes, the two would visit children's shelters together, with results that were at once comic and touching.
"The children were very much attracted to Fiorello," Mr. Burke, now 92, recalled in an interview last week from his retirement home in Lauderhill, Fla. Perhaps, Mr. Burke said wistfully, it was because the Mayor had a squeaky voice and was not that much taller than the children.
As Mayor La Guardia spoke to the social welfare committee, the setting was full of political paradox. Republicans were in the majority at the convention, but that was not necessarily to his advantage. Many in his own party distrusted Mr. La Guardia, who was liberal and only nominally a Republican, having been elected on a fusion-reform ticket intended to clean up a mess left by the colorful but corrupt Mayor James J. Walker.
Mr. Burke, a Democrat, liked what Mr. La Guardia said. So did another Democrat, Senator Robert F. Wagner of New York, who was not on the committee but whose opinion counted a lot.
The members of the social welfare committee were considered more liberal than the other convention delegates. "We were very anxious to have a liberal approach to social welfare," Mr. Burke recalled. "We felt the children were not getting what they deserved."
In Mr. Burke's recollection, the 11 Republicans and 6 Democrats on the committee were leaning toward a sweeping social-welfare amendment anyhow, and probably would have passed one even without Mr. La Guardia's high-pitched entreaties.
In any event, Mayor La Guardia got his wish. The amendment was proposed by the social welfare committee, adopted by the delegates and a few months later was approved by the voters.
Section 1 of Article 17 of the Constitution reads: "The aid, care and support of the needy are public concerns and shall be provided by the state and by such of its subdivisions, and in such manner and by such means, as the Legislature may from time to time determine."
There is no comparable language in the United States Constitution, and in few, if any, other state constitutions. No one yet knows exactly what the words will mean for the state and for New York City now that Congress has passed and President Clinton has signed legislation that would end some Federal welfare grants, deny some benefits to legal immigrants and impose five-year limits on assistance to adults.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani predicted recently that the Federal changes, coupled with the new burden on the state and the chain-reaction effect on the city, could cost the city more than $700 million annually six years from now.
"The city of New York is really just a better place than a lot of other places in terms of caring for people and understanding the worth of human beings," Mr. Giuliani added.
City officials have predicted that the fundamental questions of who is needy and what is adequate minimal state support will wind up in court.
That may be, but in 1977 the state's highest tribunal, the Court of Appeals, declared that while the Legislature could determine how the needy should be helped (and by how much), the Constitution barred simply cutting off aid.
The court looked not just to the language of Article 17 but to the intent of the delegates to the 1938 convention, particularly that of the members of the Committee on Social Welfare, and held that they had deemed state aid to the needy to be "a fundamental part of the social contract."
Mr. Burke agreed wholeheartedly and expressed pride for his role in the amendment's passage. "We were way ahead of all the other states," he said.
Mr. Burke said that he was fairly well off in the 1930's -- "I had a job," he said, "and if you had a job in the Depression you were rich" -- but that he and every other person on the committee had felt the Depression, if not through personal suffering, then through the hardships of relatives, friends or neighbors. So, of course, had the voters.
One member of the committee was Aaron L. Jacoby. Orphaned as a child, he grew up to become active in Brooklyn Democratic politics. He was executive director of the Brooklyn Hebrew Orphan Asylum in the 1930's and was active in several other child-care agencies. He served on the Public Service Commission in the 1950's and died in 1987 at the age of 94.
When Mr. La Guardia took office in 1933, there were, by some estimates, more than 1.5 million New Yorkers on some form of public assistance. Teachers remarked that many young children seemed dazed and distracted in school, as though old before their time. They were undernourished.
The amendment that Mayor La Guardia wanted (and two related ones specifying that nothing could be done to prevent the Legislature, or local governments, from caring for the needy) were among nine put to the voters on Nov. 8, 1938.
The voters re-elected Gov. Herbert H. Lehman over his Republican challenger, Thomas E. Dewey, and approved six of the nine proposed amendments, including the social welfare package.
Mr. Burke became a power in city and state Democratic politics and served on the Court of Appeals.
Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was once his law clerk and, he recalled in a recent interview, would sometimes point to the 1938 amendment when pressuring the Legislature to come up with more money for relief programs.
Mayor La Guardia had predicted that passage of the welfare measures, along with protections against child labor and a reliable system of unemployment insurance, would mean that "the next constitutional convention will spend very little time on the question of relief."
He was wrong. The next constitutional convention, held in 1967, spent a lot of time talking about welfare. Dr. Henrik N. Dullea, the vice president for university relations at Cornell who wrote his doctoral thesis on the 1967 gathering, noted that the convention adopted an amendment calling for the state to take over local welfare programs in the decade beginning in 1970.
But Republican leaders urged rejection of some amendments, contending that they would cripple state finances. Some voters may have been uneasy over a proposal to repeal a ban on aid to church-related schools.
Whatever the reasons, the voters rejected the convention's recommendations, although some were later accomplished gradually through legislation.
The 1967 convention was called by the State Legislature. The people themselves get a chance every 20 years to summon a convention. Their next chance is in 1997.
Gov. George E. Pataki has argued that the courts should not compel society to care for the needy, saying that it is a moral, not a legal requirement, to do so.
The Governor is now studying the new welfare proposals, keeping a watchful eye on the clause and what impact it may have on New York's ability to care for the poor.
"New York State has a proud history of caring for the needy," said Zenia Mucha, the Governor's communications director. "And we will not turn away from that. The courts in interpreting that phrase may, in some cases, have gone beyond what is reasonable in terms of providing for the needy."
Now and then, experts on government complain that New York State's Constitution, its fourth since the Revolutionary War, is absurdly long and detailed -- the width of ski trails on Whiteface Mountain is specified, for instance -- and should be streamlined.
Mr. Burke, his memories of his countrymen's poverty undimmed by age, said he thinks the social welfare amendment will remain, as a symbol of a progressive state. "Everybody likes kids," he said. "They need a lot of help, I can tell you."
Mr. Cuomo said he hoped the amendment survived, not just because it bespoke generosity "but because it's just simple intelligence" to help people who are poor and jobless not by choice but by circumstance.
Asked for a prediction on what might happen in states whose constitutions do not have such an amendment, Mr. Cuomo said, "No sane American wants to see a child starve."

HEADLINE: Political Briefing;
THE CAMPAIGNS FOR CONGRESS

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

 BODY:

California
G.O.P.'s Candidates Worry About Dole
The newest Field Poll shows President Clinton with a 22-point lead over Bob Dole in California, a survey that is likely to feed nervousness among Congresional Republicans. If the top of the ticket staggers, the effect on Republican turnout can be significant in the struggle for Congressional control, in which California could play an important role. The outcome could be disastrous for Republicans if the Dole campaign decides to cut its losses and pull out of that expensive state, redirecting its time and money to more winnable regions. 
 "It could mean 2 to 3 percent at the margin in some of these close races," said Thomas Mann, a Brookings Institution expert on Congress. "And for the really close ones, that could well be enough to tip it."
The Dole campaign has tried to reassure Republicans that it has no such plans. Gov. Pete Wilson said in a recent interview that Mr. Dole had assured him that he would not write off California. Still, there are lingering memories of 1992, when President George Bush won only 33 percent of the vote in California.
Craig Veith, spokesman for the National Republican Congressional Committee, said, "Our candidates and members set out from the beginning, regardless of the condition of the Presidential race, to run their races." Mr. Veith added that they were raising the money to make sure their message got out.
Jim Whitney, his counterpart at the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, said, "Having Clinton run that strongly helps Democrats across the state."

Minnesota
Resurgent Wellstone Leads in New Poll
Senator Paul Wellstone of Minnesota was widely considered one of the most vulnerable Democratic incumbents around, but a new survey shows him with a 9-point lead in his rematch with Rudy Boschwitz, the Republican challenger.
The survey came after a wave of Republican attacks, hammering Mr. Wellstone as an outside-the-mainstream liberal on issues like welfare. (Mr. Wellstone was the only Senator seeking re-election this year who voted against the welfare overhaul.) But the poll showed that Mr. Wellstone, who was running essentially even with Mr. Boschwitz back in May, now leads him, 46 percent to 37 percent.
The welfare issue, which some Republicans had predicted would be devastating to Mr. Wellstone, ranked fourth when voters were asked to name the race's most important issues. Ahead of welfare were taxes, spending and the deficit; the economy and jobs, and health care.
The poll was conducted for The St. Paul Pioneer Press, KARE-TV News and Minnesota Public Radio from Sept. 1 to 3. It was based on a survey of 803 adults and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.

Arizona
Inquiry Is Sought On Forged Signature
Representative J. D. Hayworth, an Arizona sportscaster turned Republican firebrand, and a man who delights in poking at Democrats from the floor of the House, is embroiled in a dispute back home over a forged signature on an election document. Democrats contend that he ought to be thrown off the ballot over it.
The fight began after Democrats noticed that Mr. Hayworth had filed two copies of an "Affidavit of Qualification," a form that all candidates are required to file with the state. The first was filed June 27, the day it was due, the second a week later. Democrats noticed that Mr. Hayworth's signature was notably different on the two and hired a handwriting expert who declared that the first signature was a fake.
Mr. Hayworth apologized for the forgery and said it was done without his knowledge by an errant staff member. Democrats contend an apology is not enough, and are pushing for an investigation.
Partisan tempers are running high in this fight for Arizona's Sixth District, a largely rural, heavily Mormon district that covers the northeastern third of the state. Steve Owens, a Phoenix lawyer and former top aide to Vice President Al Gore, is the expected Democratic nominee.

Texas
A Familiar Name Upsets Democrats
Representative Jack Brooks had the kind of name recognition in Texas that comes with 42 years in the House. That explains why Texas Democrats are upset with the sudden reappearance of the name, "Jack Brooks," on the ballot in the Ninth Congressional District.
It is not the old Jack Brooks, who was once the chairman of the Judiciary Committee and was defeated by Steve Stockman, a Republican, in 1994. It is G. Jack Brooks, 58, a heavy-equipment operator who told newspapers in Texas that he was running to make a statement about "this crazy government."
Democrats are worried that voters will think that this Jack Brooks is the old Jack Brooks, and thereby dilute the vote for Nick Lampson, the Democrat who won the party's nomination in a primary in the spring.
"This doesn't pass the smell test," said Jonathan Brown, press secretary for Mr. Lampson. "There's no question that Steve Stockman is the most endangered Republican in the House and far too much is ascribed to coincidence here."
Spokesmen for Mr. Stockman said their campaign had nothing to do with Mr. Brooks's entering the race; Mr. Brooks, who is running as a Democrat, has also denied that anyone in either camp urged him to make the race.
The imbroglio reflects the upheaval in Texas as a result of a recent redistricting decision, in which Federal judges threw out the results of the party primaries and opened the Nov. 5 election to more than one candidate from both parties. A runoff will be held Dec. 10 if no candidate wins a majority.

Florida
Turnout of Voters Remains Very Low
 Florida has registered more new voters than any other state under the Motor Voter law, but officials discovered last week that big registration gains do not necessarily translate into big turnout.
Florida's registration rolls have swelled by more than 1.3 million voters since 1994, but only 25.6 percent of the state's voters cast ballots in the primary on Tuesday. That was the lowest turnout since at least 1970. ROBIN TONER

HEADLINE: Union Members March On a Rescheduled Day

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
With thousands of hospital aides, teachers and electrical workers as well as a re-election-minded Mayor stepping down Fifth Avenue, yesterday's union parade was in many ways like Labor Day parades of old, but with a new date and theme as part of labor's efforts to gain members and clout.
The dozens of New York unions sponsoring the parade rescheduled it for the first Saturday after Labor Day to attract more marchers and spectators. With the parade's slogan "America Needs a Raise," the unions adopted a theme designed to warm the public to labor and show that unions are out to help not just their members but all workers. 
 Noting that unions have fought for a higher minimum wage and health insurance for all Americans, Brian McLaughlin, president of the New York City Central Labor Council, said, "We see ourselves as advocates of all working people in the city, whether they know it or not."
As head of the federation of city unions, Mr. McLaughlin sought to organize the largest parade in years to demonstrate that New York labor, like the A.F.L.-C.I.O. under its new president, John J. Sweeney, was on the mend and could capture the public's imagination.
Despite the threat of rain, the parade was indeed the largest in years. Labor leaders and several police officials said the parade, which lasted for 5 1/2 hours and stretched 25 blocks, had more than 200,000 marchers.
The parade consisted of members of more than 100 unions, including steamfitters, asbestos workers, theatrical stage employees and even some of the city's 35,000 workfare employees. Seeking to publicize their cause, more than 50 workers on a 14-month strike against The Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News also marched.
As high school bands, bagpipe-playing construction workers and a dozen floats inched past St. Patrick's Cathedral and the Disney store, thousands of spectators stood behind police barricades, occasionally cheering, but it was unclear whether they were buying labor's new message.
But one group -- politicians -- seemed to be paying close attention to labor as they maneuver for union support during elections this November and next.
At a union breakfast at the Intercontinental Hotel before the parade, the room overflowed with elected officials paying tribute to labor: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani; State Comptroller H. Carl McCall; Mark Green, the city's Public Advocate; Peter F. Vallone, the City Council President; seven members of Congress; four borough presidents, and more than a dozen City Council members and state legislators.
Mr. Giuliani stood out as one of the few Republicans at the breakfast, although Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross later joined the parade and Gov. George E. Pataki signed union hats and met construction workers at their block party on East 76th Street.
Several labor leaders had kind words for the Mayor, demonstrating that Mr. Giuliani had maintained good relations with labor despite bitter negotiating battles.
"He's someone who works with us," said Stanley Hill, executive director of the 120,000-member District Council 37, the largest union of municipal workers.
Mr. McLaughlin praised the Mayor for promoting economic development but faulted him for vetoing a so-called living wage bill that would raise wages for low-paid employees who work for city contractors.
"We agree with him on some things, and we have had some big disagreements with him on others," Mr. McLaughlin said.
In his tribute to labor, Mr. Giuliani noted that his grandmother was able to retire with dignity and some savings thanks to contracts won by her union, the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union.
"The fairness and equity workers now have did not happen by accident," he said. "It happened because of the labor movement."
Near 44th Street and Fifth Avenue, where the marchers set out, Mr. Giuliani was occasionally booed. One heckler yelled, "Don't sell our city hospitals, you bum."
But once the parade moved north of 59th Street, there was steady applause for the Mayor. Everywhere were signs promoting labor's pet causes: "Downsize Newt," "Don't Privatize City Hospitals" and "Broom Closets and Stairwells Are Not Classrooms. Let's Rebuild NYC's Schools."
Leading the parade was its grand marshal, Thomas Van Arsdale, an electrical workers' official and former president of the Central Labor Council.
"This is beautiful," said Billy Giel, a 38-year-old Teamsters member from Matawan, N.J., who was driving the boilermakers' float. "More people are getting involved now in the union, even white-collar workers. They're all feeling pushed by downsizing."
Wearing a T-shirt and cap emblazoned with the word UNITE, for the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, Claudia Braithwaite, a retired jewelry worker, said, "I'm here to show my respect for labor, and what it's done for workers. It's not doing that well, though. It's still having problems with sweatshops."
Mr. McLaughlin, who also serves as a Democratic member of the State Assembly from Queens, had pushed to reschedule the parade after disappointing turnouts at recent parades. Labor leaders agreed to change the date because many union members are on vacation during Labor Day. Concerned that Fifth Avenue had few shoppers on Labor Day, union officials also wanted the parade to be on a day when the avenue was full of shoppers and museumgoers.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Officials on parade: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani (center) with Ted Jacobson, secretary of the New York City Central Labor Council (left), and Brian McLaughlin, the labor council's president. Right, a member of the Iron Workers Union joined the ranks filing by. As a belated Labor Day parade went up Fifth Avenue, union members shouted support for Jimmy Hoffa Jr. or Ron Carey for Teamsters president. (Photographs by Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hard Times, Not Paradise, For Young Cubans in U.S.

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

 BODY:
They were lost in the Florida Straits, drifting atop rope-lashed planks of wood and sagging rubber dinghies. But as they pitched across the shark-infested waters, the 139 Cuban teen-agers who had abandoned family and country kept their hopes alive with visions of life in the United States.
There would be Reeboks and blue jeans, they told one another, and cities where the food would never run out. There would be sports cars to drive, grand houses to furnish and places where people could speak without fear. 
 The teen-agers clung to those dreams during the days at sea and through the months in detention camps, until the Clinton Administration admitted them in the winter of 1994, resettling them with foster families in nine states across the country.
"For us, America was like paradise, a place where your life was ready-made," said Antonio Serrano-Velot, who was 17 when he left Cuba.
But 20 months later, the story of the Cuban teen-agers is mostly one of dashed expectations and disappointed dreams, both for the immigrants and for some of the Cuban exiles who fought for their admission.
Nearly a third of the teen-agers -- most of whom were high school dropouts and many of whom had rebelled against authority in Cuba -- have been expelled or suspended from school here for offenses that include fighting, truancy and carrying weapons to class, a survey of refugee resettlement agencies shows. A quarter have been arrested on charges that include assault, drug possession and car theft. About 15 percent have run away from their new homes. And while some have excelled, earning school honors and job commendations, most have bounced from foster family to foster family, challenging authority at every turn.
"I had so many dreams," said Maikel Romero, 17, who wept when the New Jersey foster family he had grown to love kicked him out for fighting with another Cuban boy, "and nothing has turned out like I thught."
A look at the rocky resettlement of the Cuban teen-agers provides a rare glimpse of the complexities involved in assimilating minors who come to the United States without parents or guardians. Since 1980, about 11,000 refugee minors have been placed through programs financed by the Federal Office of Refugee Resettlement, a division of the Department of Health and Human Services.
By most accounts, those programs, which were developed for the Vietnamese boat children of the late 1970's, have worked well, and the young foreigners have thrived here, completing high school and finding steady work.
But the programs have required fine-tuning to address the needs of the 139 Cuban teen-agers, who set sail at various times in the summer of 1994. All were picked up by United States Coast Guard ships and taken to the Naval Base in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, where they remained in the camps until being brought to the United States.
Although adjusting is difficult for most foreign minors, refugee experts say it has been particularly trying for the Cubans, who quickly rebelled against the highly structured programs that suited the Vietnamese.
The reasons for the difference are hard to assess, the experts say, but they note that the Cubans spent their childhoods breaking rules, whether by stealing from Government stores, working the black market to feed their families or protesting against President Fidel Castro.
It was perhaps inevitable, the experts say, that young people who grew up resisting authority would continue to do so in the United States, especially when their golden visions failed to materialize.
Accustomed to spending their days at the beach and their nights partying with friends, many of the teen-agers resisted attending class or obeying family curfews. They wanted to work and live independently, not to study and live with foster families.
"They risked their lives to get here, expecting to get houses and lots of money and to live on their own," said Rosa Torres, a social worker assigned to counsel the 11 Cuban teen-agers who were resettled in and around Washington. "Instead, they were told to follow rules they had never followed at home: to go to school, to follow family rules, to respect authority. And many of them just wouldn't do it."

The Inexact Science Of Resettlement
But if the Cubans were not ready for America, neither were the foster programs entirely ready for them.
Most refugee workers were accustomed to Vietnamese children who had been sent to the United States by their parents to study and work, and who usually excelled in school and quickly adjusted to family life. But many of the Cubans left without their parents' knowledge. Those whose parents did know were sent with an emphasis on work -- to make money they could send home.
In the rush to find homes and schools for the teen-agers, many refugee workers never learned that the tattered Cuban economy, which often pays Government doctors less than waiters can earn at foreign-managed hotels, had spawned a generation of young people who would probably rebel against full-time education and structured family living.
To make matters worse, the programs placed the teen-agers in states where operating costs were low, like Michigan, and most of the Cubans ended up living with foster parents who did not speak Spanish. Florida, which has a shortage of foster families, took none.
The Federal Government is now planning to re-evaluate its placement procedures.
"The reality is that we have not come together as a resettlement community and looked at all the factors that determine where a refugee should go," said Lavinia Limon, director of the resettlement office.
But for the struggling teen-agers, perhaps most painful was discovering that they had given up everything for a fantasy.
Long before the rafts set sail from Havana, the teen-agers had spun together a patchwork vision of truth and myth gleaned from letters received from Cuban exiles in Miami, shortwave radio broadcasts and pirated American movies. To them, the United States was a glittery city with tropical climes, where everyone was rich, spoke Spanish and embraced new Cuban immigrants.
Instead, the teen-agers ended up in cities like Rochester and Newark, where some classmates shouted out anti-immigrant slurs. And instead of finding high-paying jobs, the young Cubans washed cars or sorted chicken parts in poultry plants.
"I didn't come to America," said Yoduel Robles, 18, who was expelled from school and found only minimum-wage work. "I came to Virginia."
Members of the Cuban exile community, who had fought their own battles to acclimate to America, vigorously supported the teen-agers at first, lobbying the White House to get them admitted to this country.
But once the teen-agers arrived and word spread of their troubles, some Cuban exiles reconsidered their welcome, refusing to open their homes to young people they viewed as delinquents damaged by years of living under Communist rule.
They said the teen-agers reminded them of some of the Cubans who came to the United States in the 1980 Mariel boatlift, which brought 125,000 Cubans to the United States, among them several thousand criminals and psychiatric patents.
"The Mariel experience made a lot of people gun-shy," said Raul Sanchez, a Cuban-American restaurant owner in Washington who hired one of the Cuban teen-agers but chose not to be a foster parent. "People were worrying that they would be taking criminals into their homes."
Diego Amador, a member of the Cuban American Association in Lansing, Mich., took in a 16-year-old, Adrian Castellanos, who has twice been named the employee of the month at a local McDonald's.
But he said no one should be surprised that Cuban-American families were reluctant to take the rest of the teen-agers. "It breaks my heart to say it," Mr. Amador said, referring to the teen-agers, "but some of my people are garbage."

Hoping to Escape Lives of Desperation
What the teen-agers hoped to find in the United States was simple: a better life.
In Cuba, Mr. Romero, who was a high school dropout, stole bread from a Government bakery whenever he was hungry, which was almost every week. His father, who worked a jackhammer and never earned enough to feed his family, told his son he would never eat stolen food.
But when his stomach ached from hunger, he ate the bread, too. The son saw his future in his father's face and jumped on a raft in the summer of 1994. He was resettled in New Jersey.
Mr. Robles, then 17, had six months to go on a two-year prison term for posting anti-Castro fliers when the warden offered him a weekend's leave, he said. He took a boat to the United States and was resettled in Virginia.
Mr. Serrano fled with a sister after his brothers were imprisoned for stealing food. Mr. Serrano survived the trip and was also placed in Virginia, but his sister drowned.
"They said it was a place where you didn't need to steal to live," said Mr. Serrano, who is now 19. "I wanted that more than anything."
At first, things were just as the teen-agers had imagined.
Their new homes were filled with wonderful technology -- stereos with remote controls, televisions with huge color screens and machines that answered the telephone when no one was home. The streets were clogged with cars, and the stores were filled with Levis, gold jewelry and a dizzying array of foods.
Confronted with such abundance, two brothers in Phoenix hoarded bread and hunted rabbits in the desert, convinced that the city would soon run out of food. In Richmond, Mr. Serrano once bought a can of dog food for lunch. He was eating it when his foster mother snatched the can from his hands. She was horrified, but Mr. Serrano knew then that he had really arrived. Imagine, he marveled, a country with so much food that it packaged some for pets. "At home, we barely have enough for people," he said.

Restrictions And Rebellion
But the free world, the Cubans discovered, was not so free.
"Here there are so many laws, laws against drinking, against smoking, against going to bars," complained Jacinto Infante, 18, who was resettled in Lansing. "In Cuba, a 14-year-old boy is a man, and you can do those things."
But when the teen-agers tried to live in the United States as they had in Cuba, there was trouble. Mr. Serrano, who started smoking when he was 12, was suspended from school for refusing to stop. Mr. Robles was expelled for cursing at a teacher and disrupting class.
In Washington, some teen-agers threatened social workers with knives. Mr. Romero was thrown out of two foster homes for fighting and skipping school.
"It's so hard for us to adapt to this new life," Mr. Infante said. "We come from an entirely different system, one that teaches you to rob, to fight, to do anything to survive."
But the social workers struggled to guide even the most rebellious teen-agers because behind the angry faces they saw lonely young people who were terrified that they would never fit in.
In New Jersey, one boy so missed his mother that he recorded their monthly phone conversations and replayed the tape before he fell asleep. Mr. Serrano wept as he relived his sister's drowning. Desperate to fit in at school, the teen-agers adopted the clothes and idols of their classmates.
"Oh, man!" Mr. Romero would say over and over, wearing his silver-rimmed sunglasses and his Red Sox baseball cap flipped backward. But some students laughed at his stilted English. "Go back where you came from," they yelled.
As the months passed, refugee workers saw that they had to adjust the programs. They moved teen-agers from foster homes into subsidized apartments, freeing them from family rules. They shifted some young people to part-time adult education, giving them more time to work. And for those who refused to work or to go to school, the officials terminated financial support.
"Now we see some progress," said Bach-Cuc Tran, director of the refugee minor program in Lansing, echoing the views of her colleagues.
Refugee workers say that the young people have not been in the United States long enough to find their way and that some may never find it. But they see hope in the success stories -- like the Michigan teen-ager who is starting community college this fall.
Mr. Robles, who was expelled from high school, has thrived in his adult-education program and now works part time as a cook. "It's not what I thought, no money falling from the sky," he said. "You can get ahead, but you have to work."
Mr. Serrano quit school and dropped out of the foster program that supported him. He now works at a poultry factory and lives with a sister. "I have work and I have food," he said, "which is more than I had at home."
Mr. Romero, who is now living with his third foster family, is starting his sophomore year in high school and hopes to join the military when he graduates. In a recent letter to his sister, he promised, "One day when people speak of me, they will speak of me with pride."

"You can get ahead, but you have to work." (David Scull/The New York Times) (pg. 34)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1831 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: CAMPAIGN FINANCE;
LOOPHOLES ALLOW PRESIDENTIAL RACE TO SET A RECORD

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Even though Republicans and Democrats strongly argued for campaign finance reform this year, both parties are taking advantage of a variety of loopholes to get around Federal campaign spending limitations, making the 1996 Presidential race the most expensive in history.
These loopholes are allowing corporations to pour money into the Presidential race at record levels -- at far more than the $5,000 legal limit. This year each party expects to raise $120 million to $150 million in private donations -- in addition to the $172 million in Federal money given to both parties. By November, some experts say, campaign spending may well surpass $600 million -- money spent by the parties, by the candidates' campaigns and by outside organizations, like labor unions or advocacy groups, on the candidates' behalf. 
 The biggest force behind the surge in fund-raising is the growth of what are known as soft-money donations, money from rich individuals and corporations that goes to the parties, not to the candidates. Critics say that soft dollars have become a backdoor source of money in the Presidential race that is easy to raise, hard to trace and makes a mockery of laws designed to prevent corporate influence peddling in Washington.
"The parties find it is a lot easier to raise $100,000 in soft money with one phone call to a corporation than to try to collect $1,000 donations from individuals," said Ellen Miller, executive director at the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonprofit research group.
"Soft dollars are like cyberspace accounting -- it's hard to follow where it goes," Ms. Miller added. "This is classic 'wink and a nod' behavior. Soft money barely makes the letter of the law. And within the spirit of the law, it's a joke."
The power of soft dollars came into play at the recent Democratic National Convention. At a luncheon paid for by the Public Securities Association, a Wall Street trade group, and several Wall Street firms, the Democratic Party honored members of its "Business Council," those who gave $10,000 or more, with a chance to meet with Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin. Many executives having lunch with Mr. Rubin were from businesses directly affected by Treasury decisions.
In addition, the executives were approached for even more money. Mr. Rubin gave a brief speech extolling the Clinton economic plan and criticizing Bob Dole. He was followed by Terry McAuliffe, a Democratic Party official, who praised Mr. Rubin as "the greatest fund-raiser in the history of the planet." Then, after explaining that "by law, Bob can't raise $1," Mr. McAuliffe exhorted the crowd to donate even more.
Under laws enacted in 1974, individuals can give only $1,000 to a Presidential candidate and corporate political-action committees are limited to $5,000 donations. To offset the loss of that private financing, money from the Federal Government was made available to candidates starting in 1974. This year, each candidate will receive $74 million for the general-election campaign and $12 million for the convention.
But, a glaring loophole remained -- corporations and individuals were allowed to give unlimited amounts to the national parties for activities like voter registration, television advertising and get-out-the-vote campaigns. This soft money is supposed to promote the party, and not specific candidates, but many see this as a distinction with little difference.
The $10,000-a-ticket 50th-birthday dinner for President Bill Clinton last month raised money for the Democratic Party. But, said one prominent Democratic fund-raiser, who spoke on the condition of anonymity: "You can spend $10,000 to wish happy birthday to Clinton, and it doesn't violate Federal rules."
Soft money was slow to catch on in the mid-1980's, and only became a force in the 1990's. Now, "the soft money numbers are off the charts," said Charles Lewis, executive director of the Center for Public Integrity, a nonprofit research group.
"This money is disbursed silently and mysteriously," Mr. Lewis added. "It is hard to track where it goes, but it supports the candidates. That's why it's called soft money, because it is so squishy. It can grease the skids in Washington for some powerful companies, while the average citizen doesn't have access."
Between Jan. 1, 1995, and June 30, 1996, both parties already exceeded previous soft-dollar records, and fund-raising is still in full swing.
The Democratic Party has raised $70.3 million in soft dollars so far -- more than twice the $34.5 million it raised in the entire 1992 Presidential race, according to the Center for Responsive Politics. By the end of June, the Republican Party raised $83.9 million in soft dollars, almost double the $49 million raised in 1992.
Party fund-raisers, while decrying the amounts spent this year, say both parties are caught in a financial version of an arms race -- each wants a financial war chest as big as their opponent's. Bipartistan legislation that would have barred political parties from handling soft money was killed in Congress this year.
"I have no reason to feel uncomfortable with soft dollars," said Howard Leach, finance chairman of the Republican National Committee. "All the parties do them and, unless the rules are changed, they will continue. I, personally, would like to see campaigns cost less money and run for a shorter period. But, since our opponents are running an expensive campaign, we have no alternative but to buy high-priced media like they do."
David Eichenbaum, communications director for the Democratic National Committee, said: "There is no question, there need to be changes in how campaigns are financed. But, until the overall system is changed, we are not in a position to say 'We won't raise money.' We want a level playing field."
The growth of soft money is the inevitable outcome of two clashing factors: the $1,000 individual limit and $5,000 corporate limit on contributions to candidates that were set two decades ago and have not kept pace with inflation and the rising cost of waging a media-driven Presidential campaign.
"The dollar limits are constant, but the cost of campaigning has gone up," said Kenneth Gross, a Washington attorney and former chief of enforcement at the Federal Election Commission. "The only outlet is an increase in soft dollars."
Already, some in the political process say the effect of soft dollars is corrupting. "There is just too much money being raised," said Alfred C. DeCotiis, a lawyer from West Orange, N.J., who has raised more than $5 million for the Democrats. "As a practical matter, if you write a large check, you get to be well known in the party and you get a certain amount of access."
Added Senator Bill Bradley, a New Jersey Democrat: "Money is distorting democracy now. Money not only determines who wins, but often who runs. If you've got a good idea and $10,000 and I've got a terrible idea and $1 million, I can convince people that the terrible idea is a good one."
Corporations, who often give money to both parties to insure access regardless of who wins, say that soft dollars are a way to get their message before influential politicians.
Some of the biggest soft-dollar donors are corporations with pressing issues in Washington. Telecommunications companies, whose fates are being rapidly reshaped by deregulation, are top givers. This industry has given $4.6 million in soft dollars, so far, $2.5 million to Republicans and $2.1 million to the Democrats.
Tobacco companies, under assault from an increasingly hostile Clinton Administration, also write big checks. They have also given $4.6 million to both parties, $3.9 million to the Republicans and $714,000 to the Democrats.
One of the big telecommunications donors is AT&T, which has given $743,000 in soft dollars, almost equally split between the parties.
"Government can change how you live and how you work," said Gerald Lowrie, senior vice president of the Federal Government Affairs for AT&T. "If you ignore who is in office, it can be at your peril."
Darienne Dennis, director of communications for Philip Morris, which sells tobacco, food and beer, said: "Philip Morris supports those who share our thoughts. We have a responsibility to our employees and shareholders to be in the political process and we are happy to do so."
Philip Morris, is the biggest soft-dollar donor to the Republicans, having given the party $1.6 million so far. The Democrats received a more modest $350,000 from the corporation.
Soft dollars, however, are only one of several ways to raise money while getting around the donation limits.
Each party has set up a compliance committee, with a budget of about $6 million, to pay for the cost of complying with Federal election laws. Individuals can make an additional $1,000 donation to one of these committees.
The two recent conventions saw the establishment of tax-deductible accounts for corporate donations to help offset the cost of running the political gatherings. About $25 million was raised for each convention by local host committee -- in addition to the $12 million in Federal money given to the parties.
"It seems like $12 million in public funds would be enough to buy a lot of balloons," said Mr. Lewis, of the Center for Public Integrity. "But the parties have turned the conventions into Olympic sponsor-fests."
A new wrinkle in loopholes opened just two months ago when the United States Supreme Court ruled that under the constitutional protection of free speech political parties could set up "independent committees" to solicit even more donations, as long as the fund-raising and the activities it financed were not co-ordinated with the Presidential campaign.
Previously only lobbying groups, like the National Rifle Association or Americans for Term Limits, could set up such independent committees to benefit candidates. It is still too early to determine how big this loophole will be for the parties.
Then there are "in kind" donations of office space, phone banks and other equipment by businesses, which are difficult to value. AT&T, for instance, provided office space to the Republicans at their San Diego convention; Xerox provided photocopiers and General Motors provided cars to the Democrats in Chicago.
On top of all this, special-interest groups are spending their own money to support their favorite candidates -- money not regulated by the Federal Government. The big giver this year is the A.F.L.- C.I.O., the labor organization, which has endorsed Bill Clinton and has earmarked $35 million for a "grass-roots" campaign for pro-labor candidates.
"If you look at it, any spending limits that were put into the law are just not effective," said Herbert Alexander, head of the Citizens Research Foundation at the University of Southern California. "Soft money, labor money, compliance money and independent committees. It's all related to getting a Presidential candidate elected."

HEADLINE: What's New at G.M.? Cars, for a Change

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
GENERAL MOTORS, once one of America's most successful corporations, developed a reputation in the 1980's as a confused car-making bureaucracy that rolled out one look-alike product after another with little fanfare and modest sales success.
Now it is making a big attempt to get back on track. In one of the most ambitious new-car changeovers in a generation, the world's largest auto maker is preparing to introduce 15 all-new models in the next few months, replacing everything from its 14-year-old Buick Century to its Dustbuster-shaped mini-vans. The changes involve 10 assembly plants, 31,000 factory workers and hundreds of suppliers that will produce cars accounting for 40 percent of G.M. sales. 
 It is also trying out a marketing program borrowed from Procter & Gamble, whose former chairman, John G. Smale, served a stint as G.M.'s chairman until last year. He decreed that G.M. needed to better distinguish its seven brands, like Cadillac and Saturn, and 82 models of cars and trucks. As a result, G.M. has a platoon of recently hired recruits who know plenty about marketing baby wipes, pencils and Listerine, but are just getting their feet wet at selling Oldsmobiles, Cadillacs and Buicks.
At stake is whether G.M. can rebuild its core business of selling cars and vans in the United States. John F. Smith Jr., the affable finance man who was rushed in to rescue the company four years ago, must prove that he can successfully design, build and sell cars and mini-vans to a public that has lost much of its loyalty to G.M.'s brands.
While Mr. Smith and his team of lawyers and financial engineers get high marks for resuscitating G.M.'s balance sheet and turning impressive profits in the company's lending, satellite communications, electronics and other operations outside the car business, he has yet to prove he can remake the company into an auto-making star.
"It's a huge year for us," said G. Richard Wagoner Jr., the president of G.M.'s North American operations. "This year is basically all hands on deck to get the products out."
With nearly $170 billion in sales last year, G.M. is bigger than AT&T, I.B.M., Microsoft and Federal Express combined. And with more than 700,000 employees, it has twice the payroll of the United States Postal Service. Turning around such a Goliath is an enormous, complicated task given G.M.'s tendency for manufacturing glitches, ho-hum marketing and spotty quality.
"They will have a very tough time launching all those vehicles," said Alexander Trotman, chairman and chief executive of the Ford Motor Company, which has substantially overhauled its product line. He added, "It took 90 years to get where they are, and I don't think it's a five-year change" to turn it around.
G.M.'s task is especially difficult because it will be rolling out its new models over the next six months just as it tries to reach a new national labor contract with the United Automobile Workers union. G.M. has had rough labor relations. A 17-day strike in the spring virtually shut down G.M.'s North American auto production, and another disruption could turn this fall's introductions into a chaotic mess of shortages on dealers' lots and missed opportunities.
G.M.'s vehicle introductions must be successful if the company is to meet Mr. Smith's objective of earning profits equal to an average of 5 percent of sales in good years and bad. Although G.M. earned a staggering $6.88 billion last year, the most in corporate America, its profit margin worldwide was only 4.1 percent. While Mr. Smith has not announced a profit target for each year, G.M. needs roughly to double its current margins in good years if it has any hope of hitting the 5 percent average.
The prospects for G.M.'s shares also hang on the new models. The stock has fallen 3.3 percent over the last year, to $47.75 on Friday, while the Standard & Poor's 500 has climbed 15 percent.
Meeting the profit targets and bolstering the stock price won't be easy. G.M. has chosen to keep prices low in many segments, preferring to sell practical value instead of pricey sizzle. That leaves cost-cutting and increased efficiency as its chief means of raising profits. It is a delicate balance of manufacturing vehicles for less money while raising quality, and could lead to a showdown with the U.A.W. The union has been resisting every attempt by G.M. to buy less costly parts from nonunion suppliers.
"We need to be competitive in our plants, and that's the way we're approaching this," Mr. Smith, the chairman, chief executive and president of G.M., said this summer. "We've got to keep enough flexibility that we can go in and fix the weak plants."
Yet G.M. needs concessions from the U.A.W. if it is to remain competitive with domestic and foreign rivals. Ford and Chrysler buy a much larger proportion of their parts from outside suppliers that often are not unionized. The difference in outside purchases has given Ford a cost advantage over G.M. of $440 a vehicle, and Chrysler a $600 advantage, according to a study this summer by Harbour & Associates Inc., an automotive production consulting firm.
THE new models coming out this autumn are off to an uneven start. Automotive reviewers have been impressed with the design of some of the vehicles they have seen so far, notably G.M.'s five new 1997 mini-vans, two of which are for export. "We have some questions about rear-seat comfort, but beyond that they're just superb," said David E. Davis Jr., the editor of Automobile magazine and a driver with 40 years of experience in evaluating new cars.
The 1997 Pontiac Grand Prix, a sporty midsize sedan that turns heads in parking lots and is the first of the 15 models to go on sale, looks to be a hit. Starting at $18,579, the car, with its swooping lines and "wide track" stance, is getting a warm reception. Bob Carpenter, the general sales manager at a Pontiac dealership in Dallas, said he had been selling them as fast as they rolled off the trucks.
The problem is that they are not arriving faster. Whereas Ford cranked up its new full-sized pickup truck in six weeks, G.M. is taking six months to bring Grand Prix production to full speed at its Fairfax assembly plant in Kansas City, Kan. "We're not going to be able to get enough," Mr. Carpenter said.
G.M. officials say they made a deliberate decision to assemble the new vehicles slowly at first. The hope is to maintain quality levels and break G.M.'s almost Soviet-style emphasis on production quotas, a holdover from the 80's that fostered a move-the-metal culture that paid too little attention to quality, particularly for new models.
"We are going to be methodical and very attentive to every detail," said Harry J. Pearce, the company's vice chairman. "It would be very inappropriate to base an assessment on one arbitrary variable, time."
The complexity of some of the new-model introductions is partly responsible for the slowness. Most auto makers try to avoid putting many models in one factory, particularly one that has just been modernized. But G.M. plans to build all five new mini-vans in a rebuilt factory in Doraville, Ga., that used to make midsized Oldsmobile sedans.
When Donald E. Hackworth, a G.M. group vice president, rattles off the planned output at Doraville, he sounds like someone describing an entire car line instead of the output of a single factory. "We build left-hand drive and right-hand drive, long wheelbase and short wheelbase, and four different engine families, including diesel, both manual and automatic," he said.
If G.M. someday succeeds in producing all of these mini-vans quickly and with high quality, it will reap large savings from the economies of scale. But for now, the mini-vans are inching along the assembly line at the rate of one every 12 minutes, so as to familiarize workers with the many different procedures needed to build such a variety of vehicles. The plan, Mr. Hackworth said, is to reach 60 mini-vans an hour this winter.
But the Doraville plant also has some labor tension. The U.A.W. is quietly fuming that G.M. has hired outside companies to manufacture the seats, install engine brackets and apply a protective coating for the shipment of export models, a union official said. Negotiations on these issues will proceed after a national labor contract is concluded, but the workers there have already voted overwhelmingly to go on strike if talks cannot settle the disputes.
The gentle pace of production, combined with the prospect of labor troubles, has troubled financial experts like Scott Merlis, an auto analyst in Westport, Conn., who have begun to reduce slightly their estimates of the company's third- and fourth-quarter earnings. Every month of low production means another month without a full return on the billions of dollars that G.M. has invested in developing the new models. And every month that passes before the new models are widely available leaves an opening for Japanese auto makers to hurry their own vehicles into production.
Indeed, John A. Casesa, an auto analyst at Schroder Wertheim & Company, worries about Japanese auto makers reaching the market first in large quantities with cars like the 1997 Toyota Camry, an acclaimed new version of the midsize sedan that goes on sale tomorrow. The Camry has been significantly redesigned to compete at low prices with some G.M. models.
Maryann N. Keller, an auto analyst at Furman Selz, a New York investment and brokerage firm, is particularly critical of the slow Grand Prix introduction. "It's crazy -- it makes absolutely no economic sense," she said. "I don't know how they can ever make money on the program -- dealers want it now."
She pointed out that auto makers can charge the most money for a car in the first year of production, when customer interest is highest. "Sporty cars are cars of passion," she said. "There's an element of 'Gosh, it's new! I've got to have it now.' "
Mr. Hackworth, who oversees the G.M. group responsible for mini-vans and midsize and luxury cars, defended the Grand Prix introduction by pointing out that the company had continued to keep cars flowing to dealers by building some 1996 Grand Prix models in the summer even as production of '97 models began.
MR. WAGONER said all of G.M.'s new models would help the company's profits more than the models they replace. He contended that G.M. could start making new models quickly, as it did with the redesigned but not entirely new Saturn coupe this summer. But the company has given itself a far more ambitious test with the production of so many all-new models in Doraville and elsewhere.
"At Saturn, we're basically just changing the product, not changing the plant location," he said.
Yet G.M. is highly sensitive about the arrival of the Grand Prix and other new models. It has stopped releasing weekly production information on new models, breaking an auto industry tradition and making it harder for parts suppliers to forecast the need for their products.
Some analysts are more forgiving than Ms. Keller of G.M.'s deliberate pace in building new models. This year's factory changeovers, they point out, are going faster so far than the glacial, problem-ridden start of production two years ago of the Chevrolet Cavalier and Lumina.
"There's no question that General Motors can do better," said Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds. "There's no question that this year is also an order of magnitude better than the launches of the last two or three years, and you have to walk before you can run."
G.M. plans to build up large-enough stocks of new models to introduce them at a rate of roughly two a month over the next half-year. When it does begin promoting them, it will rely on a new team of marketers, many from outside the auto industry. Their job is to bring new clarity to the public's impressions of brands like Buick, Oldsmobile and Chevrolet that have been muddied over the last two decades by too-similar cars and advertising.
The first G.M. division to emphasize brand management was Pontiac. The division's executives were among the earliest to spot where the power lies on G.M.'s board, modeling their efforts more than four years ago on Procter & Gamble's brand-management approach.
Through new designs and relentless repetition in advertisements, Pontiac has tried to convince the public once again that it is synonymous with excitement. The goal is to produce such loyalty to Pontiac that buyers are willing to pay extra for its cars, said Bill Heugh, brand manager for the Pontiac Grand Prix.
"One way you can measure brand equity is to answer the question: Does the market let you charge a premium for your product, or does it force you to discount it with constant rebates and other incentives?" Mr. Heugh said when the Grand Prix was introduced earlier this summer.
Because many G.M. executives lack experience with strong brands, the previously tradition-bound G.M. has made some surprising moves to bring in expertise. Just a few months ago, Robert P. Baird was in charge of selling Baby Fresh baby wipes at Scott Paper. Now he is the brand manager in charge of persuading as many customers as possible to plant themselves in the seats of the latest Cadillac Sevilles and Eldorados.
Cadillac buyers and babies have something in common, Mr. Baird said in a recent speech in Chantilly, Va. "I've found out that whether it's baby wipes or luxury cars, there's one thing that's universal -- if given a choice, everyone would rather have heated seats," he said.
The new brand managers face G.M. bureaucrats and car dealers who refuse to allow the death of any of the company's seven car and truck lines. The result is that the brand managers must persuade the public this autumn that there is a difference not only between a Chevrolet mini-van and a Ford mini-van, but also among a Chevy, a Pontiac and an Oldsmobile.
G.M. executives say that cars that look alike when lined up will seem quite different when advertised with separate slogans and displayed in separate showrooms. Four of G.M.'s new midsize sedans looked fairly similar when displayed together in January at the Detroit auto show. But Vincent Barabba, G.M.'s head of market research, said they would look different in showrooms.
"You can create a lot of difference in how a customer feels about a vehicle from how you position them," he said.
SOME experts are more skeptical, saying that while G.M. may have strengthened its brand images, its 82 models are still too many and the company will inevitably end up dissipating its advertising budget trying to promote them all. Ms. Keller at Furman Selz was particularly critical of the four midsize sedans -- the Buick Century, Chevrolet Malibu, Oldsmobile Cutlass and Pontiac Grand Prix -- that will soon compete in a market segment that is shrinking steadily as more and more Americans buy Jeeps and other sport utility vehicles. G.M. will introduce two other midsize sedans next year, the Buick Regal and Oldsmobile Intrigue.
"They may be different from one another, there just may not be any market for them, or certainly not as big a market as was hoped for," Ms. Keller said.
Even if G.M. has found a winning strategy for designing, building and marketing cars, it faces rocky labor relations. G.M. has had eight local strikes in the last three years, including the 17-day walkout in March at two brake factories in Dayton, Ohio, that crippled assembly plants across North America. Ford has not had a local strike in a decade and is counting on that record to quickly bring out the Expedition, a large sport utility vehicle that will compete in a segment G.M. has had to itself with the Tahoe, Yukon and Suburban.
"One of the secrets of our profit success this year is how quickly we can get the Expedition launched," John M. Devine, Ford's chief financial officer, said at the company's annual meeting last spring in Kansas City, Mo. "You have to have a good relationship with the U.A.W."
All of this adds up to a difficult but surmountable challenge, G.M. officials contend. "In an organization as large and as complex as G.M., it's naive to think you can make changes" quickly, Mr. Pearce said. "We're making what I would call consistent, steady progress."
G.M. executives are reluctant to predict what will happen to the world's largest auto maker if they fail. If the new models turn out to be duds, or if G.M. executives lock themselves into too generous a labor contract, G.M.'s trucks, foreign auto sales and satellite communications business will help keep the corporation soundly profitable as long as the American economy thrives.
But with North American automotive operations still accounting for more than two-thirds of the corporation's sales, G.M. must develop successful models now or the next recession will be a horrible experience indeed.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 15, 1996, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about General Motors' lineup of new cars misstated the relative size of the G.M. work force and that of the United States Postal Service. G.M.'s work force of more than 700,000 employees is slightly smaller than that of the Postal Service, not twice as big.

HEADLINE: Sunday September 8, 1996: TEACHING;
A Day in the Life of Ivan Subovitch

 BODY:
The first annual Substitute Teacher Appreciation Week begins today, honoring those who, in its founder's phrase, "get no sick days or respect." Is it really that bad? To find out, we called Paul Emus of Imperial Beach, Calif., a typical sub whose four years in various southern California school districts inspired "Not Young Enought to Know Everything," a self-published book of tips for fellow sufferers. Emus admits to being ambivalent about sub life; intrigued, we asked him to blend his experiences into a composite day. A composite worst day. 
 5:30 A.M. The phone clangs. On most mornings, it's an automated substitute-procurement system, which, HAL-like, tells Emus to press 1 to accept a job, 2 to decline. Today it's Carmen, a friendly sub procurer from San Isidro Middle School. Emus likes Carmen. He takes the job.
 7:30 A.M. Emus arrives at San Isidro in his Volkswagen van. He packs a TV, a VCR and - as emergency entertainment - a karaoke machine. San Isidro, near Tijuana, is so tough that subs there receive an extra $15 "combat pay." With wary affection, Emus describes its students as "little gangsters."
 8:30 A.M. In homerooms, Emus, a sturdy sixfooter, discovers there is no seating chart, a vital tool of keeping unfamiliar students in order. When he tries to seat them, chaos erupts, and Emus starts ejecting students. But in the end it is Emus who is expelled, for losing his temper during the uproar. "I was actually, uh, relieved," he recalls later. "We all have bad days."
 Noon. Emus pulls afternoon duty at Chula Vista High. At lunchtime he escorts his students to the cafeteria but he doesn't join them because school chow has made him ill several times. Instead Emus retreats to his van for a lonely yet economical lunch: canned fruit cocktail.
1 P.M. Assigned to physical-education class, Emus leads 50 students outside but he fails to notice that one of them has taped the locker-room door so that it does not lock. When he returns an hour later, he finds the contents of all the locker bins on the floor and graffiti on the walls.
 2:45 p.M. One more chance of venue: Bonita High, an academically sound school in a community known for its high concentration of millionaires. A nice opportunity ... except that when Emus tries to discipline certain "spoiled" students, they ignore him, flaunting their family wealth and connections. After school, Emus loads up his van, noticing with resignation that most students drive cars nicer than his.
9:30 P.M. In bed, Emus contemplates life. "You can't be a substitute forever," he sighs, citing his average annual earnings of $13,000. (He makes ends meet in the National Guard.) Yet the alternative - one of the full-time teaching jobs he has applied for - may involve too much commitment. "I try not to worry," Emus says. "I go home, get a good night's sleep." Good idea. Work resumes at 5:30 sharp.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Manhasset, L.I.;
A Prosperous Enclave of Gracious Living

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
FROM the crest of Manhasset Avenue, it is possible to view two features that help make well-to-do Manhasset -- a blue-chip area that, by tradition, includes most of five incorporated villages.
On one side, beneath an overpass, Long Island Rail Road tracks lead to Manhattan, a brisk 28-minute commute on spiffy express trains that run, after one stop in Great Neck, uninterrupted to Penn Station. 
 Down a sweeping entrance road on the other side, the clock tower of Manhasset High School, one of Long Island's most highly regarded public schools, rises from a handsome campus. Members of the Class of 1996 were accepted at 171 colleges rated highly competitive by Barron's College Guide. Ninety-five percent of the class is going on to higher education.
"There is no doubt our schools and our commute to the city are two of our best points," said Diane Harragan, the president of Blaich House and Home Realty.
But in Manhasset, she and others said, there is much more.
An air of unquenchable prosperity, subdued but unmistakable, pervades distinct neighborhoods where roomy, sturdily constructed, single-family houses, many built during the 1930's or earlier, have been upgraded, expanded and improved.
Homes built by William Levitt before World War II give a strong unifying element to the Strathmores and Strathmore Vanderbilt unincorporated areas where "every house is magnificent and very different," said Carole Belley of Lovejoy Real Estate. The homes are grander than those that Mr. Levitt went on to build in Levittown. Scrupulously maintained, early-19th-century homes rise from landscaped splendor in older villages, where colonials, Dutch colonials and Tudors shine.
THEN there is Manhasset Bay, where sailing is a passion. Private clubs include the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club and the Port Washington Yacht Club for sailors, boaters, tennis and dining. For golfers, the Plandome Country Club has an 18-hole course. One village, Plandome, has its own dock and a village green with tennis courts.
The 36-acre Long Island Science Museum on the Leeds Pond Preserve offers educational programs emphasizing field and lab studies on its wooded grounds.
And the Miracle Mile, a regional shopping hub on Northern Boulevard, features the tony 193,000-square-foot, 50-store Americana at Manhasset shopping plaza, including Giorgio Armani and Barneys, on one end and stores like Lord & Taylor and Barnes & Noble on the other.
But on nearby Plandome Road, where a new clock tower on a commercial building is a recent adornment, Manhasset's traditional downtown shopping area and its enduring hometown feeling have not been eclipsed.
Longtime Plandome Road staples include Wright Hardware, which was opened in 1921, and the Manhasset Theater triplex moviehouse, which, with its Art Deco design, opened in 1935.
Annie V. Holdreith, a sales agent at O'Connell Real Estate, said Manhasset reminded her of a New England village. But the economy, she and others said, is tied to that other island.
"Other towns can be affected by the Long Island economy," Ms. Holdreith said. "Here, we are driven by the Manhattan economy because of all the people who work in the city."
"For Sale" signs are never posted here, but about 160 Manhasset homes were on the market this summer. Realtors said strong demand had grown even stronger in the last year. Young families, people who grew up in the area and people moving up from Queens or less exalted parts of Nassau County were among the prome buyers, they said.
While Manhasset is overwhelmingly white, a black community has deep roots in an area once known as the Valley. The AME Zion Church on Community Drive, built in 1833 and now a Town of North Hempstead designated historic landmark, served free blacks and Matinecock Indians before the Civil War and still holds services.
North Shore University Hospital is also on Community Drive, as are a number of commercial buildings.
Manhasset has a full array of civic organizations, Protestant and Catholic churches and Jewish synagogues. The Friends Meeting House on Northern Boulevard, an old Indian trail, marks a Quaker presence that dates to the 17th century.
The nearby Onderdonk house, built in 1836, is a town landmark and a leading example of Greek Revival architecture. It was the home of Judge Horatio Gates Onderdonk, grandson of Adrian Onderdonk, the town's first Supervisor.
Home prices tend to be lower in unincorporated areas of Manhasset, though the Whitney estate and other grand properties are in these areas south of Northern Boulevard. But in general, prices tend to be higher in the villages of Plandome Heights, Munsey Park and Flower Hill, and highest in the villages of Plandome and Plandome Manor.
House rentals, when they can be found, range from $2,000 to more than $3,000 a month for a three-bedroom house. They are far higher for larger homes. The 200 or so Condominiums on Shelter Rock and Searingtown Road sell from about $400,000 to $800,000.
Stone Hill, a housing development planned on the former William S. Paley estate on Shelter Rock Road, will offer custom homes for around $1 million. Nearby, homes at the Grace Wood development on the former W.R. Grace estate start at $750,000. New houses start at $1.3 million in a small development on Manhasset Woods Road.
IN a recent directory of America's 300 richest towns published by Worth magazine, Plandome Manor, Plandome, Flower Hill and Munsey Park were in the top 50. Plandome Heights ranked 150th, and the unincorporated area of Manhasset was 226th. The ratings were based on average household income and housing value.
A part of the Village of North Hills is in the Manhasset school district. Shelter Rock, a large glacial boulder with a ledge that once sheltered Matinecock Indians from wind and rain, is there.
Many Manhasset children attend private schools, but the general feeling here is that Manhasset public schools, with about 2,300 students, are equal or superior to them.
Seventy percent of the 176 graduates of Manhasset High School's Class of 1996 earned Regents diplomas. Advanced-placement courses, honors classes and advanced research programs are offered. More than 80 percent of students participate in extracurricular programs. And there are 65 athletic teams.
The middle school, for the seventh and eighth grades, is in the high-school complex. There are two elementary schools for kindergarten through sixth grade, the Munsey Park School and the Shelter Rock School.
St. Mary's Roman Catholic School on Northern Boulevard teaches kindergarten through 12th grade and also has pre-kindergarten programs. About 97 percent of graduates in the Class of 1996 are going on to college. Eight hundred and fifty students attend the high school. Tuition is $4,200.
College preparatory courses are offered in English, computers, business, social studies, math, science, foreign languages, religious studies, art and music. The ice hockey team won a state championship this year.
Sister Mariette, the assistant principal at St. Mary's, said the school attracted students from diverse economic and cultural backgrounds. About 450 pupils attend elementary classes. Extended-day programs through the eighth grade run to 6:30 P.M. Tuition ranges from $2,100 to $2,600.
The name Manhasset, first applied between 1835 and 1845 to an area previously known as Little Cow Bay, was derived from the Indian word Manhansett, meaning "island neighborhood." The Manhansetts also inhabited Shelter Island.
The Matinecocks called the Manhasset area Sink Sink, meaning "place of many stones." By the 17th century, the British and Dutch were disputing ownership. In 1640, English settlers from Lynn, Mass., sailed into Cow Bay, now Manhasset Bay, but were chased off by the Dutch. They sailed on to Southampton.
On the eve of the Revolutionary War, residents of the north shore of Hempstead split with their Loyalist neighbors to the south. Many joined the Continental Army or local militias. In 1784, in a reflection of the split, the State Legislature formed the northern area into the Town of North Hempstead. The town hall, not built until 1907, is on Plandome Road in Manhasset, opposite a park where the old Plandome Road School once stood.
A trestle crossing the valley brought the Long Island Rail Road to Manhasset in 1897. But not until 1924, when a new station was dedicated at its current site, did downtown Manhasset begin to grow. By the 1930's, Manhasset was already established as a prosperous commuter town. Another station is in Plandome.
Manhasset housing prices soared in the mid-70's and have been climbing, with few pauses, ever since. "In the early 1970's, you could get together $25,000 and move here," said Charles M. Studness, a Manhasset resident. "Now entry people need a lot more resources."

BUDGET BUZZ: There was shock in Manhasset last May when the annual school budget, normally a shoo-in, was unexpectedly rejected by a vote of 961 to 895. The following month it passed easily, 2,144 to 1,216, with just a little less than $200,000 trimmed from the original $43,722.252 proposal. But there is a sense in the community that the original budget rejection and an earlier voter spurning of an $8 million plan for a new Manhasset Public Library last year is a sign of purse-tightening in the highly taxed, conservative area. "I don't know why it was defeated," said Charlotte A. Lee, an investment banker who is financial secretary of the 50-year-old library's board of trustees. "It was a great idea and a great location." A $13 million building plan failed two years earlier. Now the library is falling back on its own resources to build a 250-square-foot expansion. On Sept. 25, the mood of Manhasset voters will be tested again in a referendum on a $21.5 million proposal to reconstruct, enlarge and improve public school buildings.

HEADLINE: Laud Limits on New York Business Districts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thank you, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, for turning your attention to New York City's business improvement district programs (news article, Sept. 5). I am perplexed by the lack of city control over tax assessment monies given to the districts. 
 The business improvement district for Madison Avenue, which personally concerns me as an art gallery owner, is an oxymoron.
Madison Avenue does not have to be improved; the businesses are the improvement. With its international flavor, the avenue is the most elegant of the city.
Most shops have their own garbage pickup, maintain their sidewalks and have private guards.
I do not deny that an improvement district may function in other areas, but I question their budgets and excessive executive salaries.
Must things arrive at crisis before we are aware of the potential for fraud and misuse of funds? I fear that without surveillance the surtax on real estate, paid mostly by the shops, may be again raised to feed the further expenses of the district fiefs.
 
ELAINE ROSENBERG
New York, Sept. 5, 1996
