HEADLINE: Huddled Masses in the Schools

BYLINE: By Frank Padavan; Frank Padavan, a Republican, represents northeastern Queens in the New York State Senate.

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
New York City's students went back to school this week, taking their seats in overcrowded classrooms -- and in closets and locker rooms and spaces carved out of auditoriums. What is to blame for the congestion? You need not look much further than the huge and continuing increase in the population of immigrant students.
In the past 10 years, school enrollment has soared from 850,000 to 1.06 million, a rise of 200,000. When classes began on Wednesday, the system counted 134,875 students who had entered the United States in just the past three years. 
 The Board of Education has long been aware of this mounting crisis. Three years ago, at hearings I conducted in the State Senate, Robert Tobias, director of strategic planning, projected that 383 schools would have to be built by 2003, at a cost of $10 billion, to accommodate the expected rise in immigrants. At the time, only 25 schools were under construction.
Immigration is a national problem, of course, with enormous local consequences. Yet the response from the Federal Government has been virtually nonexistent. Congress, which has never moved aggressively to combat illegal immigration, recently decreed that legal immigration should remain at its historically high levels. It is unlikely to pass a bill allowing states to withhold public education for illegal immigrants; and even if it did, it is most unlikely that President Clinton would sign such legislation.
I do not advocate pulling children out of public schools, regardless of where they were born. But Congress should at least recognize its responsibility to provide financial aid to New York City and the handful of urban centers that have been bearing most of the burden of immigration, both legal and illegal. To date, efforts to compel Congress to share the costs have been uniformly unsuccessful. In lawsuits brought on behalf of New York and other states, the Federal courts have held that Congress has no constitutional obligation to contribute to immigration-related local costs; conversely, the courts have said that while Congress can deny immigrants financial support, New York State cannot.
President Clinton has recently proposed a change that would allow states to redirect Federal education dollars from programs to new classrooms. The change could have a major impact on New York City's overcrowding, without imposing a significant burden on Federal taxpayers.
But first, the city must recognize the need. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani must acknowledge that the immigration of the 1990's has added to the city's burden, especially in education. Gov. George E. Pataki should join the Mayor and let Congressional leaders know that New York City needs this kind of help. Politics should not be a factor here, since the affected cities and states represent a bipartisan collection.
New York City's members of Congress must recognize that the quality of life enjoyed by the immigrants they represent will be determined by the caliber of their education. And not just immigrants: all neighborhoods, all groups are imperiled by overcrowding in the schools. So is the city's ability to contribute productive employees to the work force. In the end, the region's economic future is at risk. The stakes are too high to ignore.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Okinawans Send Message to Tokyo and U.S. to Cut Bases

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: NAHA, Okinawa, Sept. 8

 BODY:
In a referendum aimed at sending a message to Washington and Tokyo, citizens of Okinawa voted today by an overwhelming ratio of 10 to 1 in favor of a reduction in the American military bases on this island in the south of Japan.
But the message was muted by a low voter turnout of 59.5 percent. Saying a high turnout would be needed for the ballot to be influential, the Okinawa government and other opponents of the bases mounted an energetic campaign to get people to the polls by arguing that this would be a historic opportunity for people to take their future into their own hands. 
 Okinawa's Governor, Masahide Ota, a leading opponent of the bases, argued that despite the low turnout, 53 percent of the 910,000 registered voters favored the base reduction.
"It's the first time Okinawan people have displayed their will on their own," he said at a news conference tonight.
It is not clear how much impact the results will have. The referendum is not legally binding, and the bases are a national matter, not a local matter, to be decided by the Governments of the United States and Japan.
Officials of both Governments say they knew even before the referendum that Okinawans disliked the bases, and in April officials proposed a plan to close some of them, including a noisy helicopter field.
"The issues are there anyway, whether or not there is a referendum," a United States official said before the balloting. He and a Japanese official said the preliminary base reduction plan was not likely to change much by the time the final plan was issued in November.
Still, the results today suggest that people here are not satisfied with the reductions announced so far. The plebiscite will also serve to keep the spotlight on the issue and keep up the pressure on Washington and Tokyo, some analysts say.
"The result shows that the people back Ota's stance," Muneyuki Shindo, a professor of government at Rikkyo University in Tokyo, said tonight, "and I think the Tokyo Government will have no choice but to respond to that."
Koichi Kato, secretary general of the Liberal Democratic Party, which is the center of Japan's governing coalition, said the Government would strive for more base cutbacks.
"A majority of the voters cast ballots and we take this seriously," he the Kyodo news service quoted him as saying.
But Naoyoshi Sunagawa, general secretary of an organization representing those who rent their land to the bases, said that because of the low turnout and the vague way the question on the ballot was worded, the referendum result cannot be read as an endorsement of Governor Ota's campaign to eliminate all bases by 2015.
"It shows that the base reduction should be conducted in a realistic way," he said.
Governor Ota will meet with Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto on Tuesday and is expected to hear about programs to help support the economic development of Okinawa, which is the poorest prefecture in Japan.
Mr. Hashimoto, who is expected to call for a parliamentary election this fall, wants to keep the Okinawa situation in check. He particularly wants Governor Ota to sign leases allowing for the continued use by United States forces of some privately owned land on Okinawa. Mr. Ota tonight declined to say whether he would sign.
Today's vote took place almost exactly a year after the rape of a 12-year-old Okinawan schoolgirl, who was abducted by three American servicemen subsequently convicted for the attack. The crime unleashed pent-up fury at the bases, and that outcry led to the base reduction plan announced in April.
The referendum was the first ever held by a prefecture in Japan and is part of a budding movement toward local ballots in a nation long controlled by the central Government. Last month, the town of Maki held the nation's first official local referendum, also nonbinding, in which voters rejected plans for a nuclear plant in their town.
While many people welcome these moves toward local autonomy, officials in the central Government are increasingly worried that important national facilities like military bases, power plants and waste incinerators will never find homes if local voters can reject them.
The question of local determination is a poignant one for Okinawa, a sun-dappled chain of islands that has long been subject to rule by others. Once an independent kingdom, Okinawa was annexed by Japan in the 1870's, and many Okinawans feel that they are treated as second-class citizens. The islands were occupied by the United States from the end of World War II until 1972, two decades after the occupation of the rest of Japan ended.
Now, despite the fact that Okinawa accounts for less than 1 percent of the land area of Japan, it is home to 75 percent of the United States bases and well over half of the 47,000 American servicemen in Japan.
On the main island of Okinawa, bases take up 20 percent of the land. That has subjected residents to crime, noise and dangers from accidents like plane crashes.
The referendum here was different from the typical plebiscite in that it was not intended to tell the local government how to act. It was aimed at giving momentum to the prefectural government's campaign to rid the island of bases.
The final tally was 482,538 or 89.1 percent, in favor of a base reduction, 46,232, or 8.5 percent, opposed and 12,856 invalid ballots.
A lopsided vote in favor of base reduction was expected, so instead of the margin, many people were focusing on the turnout. This was especially so because some groups favoring the bases or those opposed to holding the referendum, including the local branch of the Liberal Democratic Party, Japan's largest political party, urged people to stay away from the polls.
The turnout of 59.5 percent was lower than the 66 percent turnout in the election for the prefectural assembly earlier this year and lower than the 62 percent turnout in last year's gubernatorial election, when Mr. Ota was re-elected. In Maki, where the nuclear referendum was held last month, 88 percent of the registered voters cast ballots.
Some people apparently did not vote today because of worries about the economic impact of base closings. Even though cities with bases are most subject to the noise and dangers from them, they are also most economically dependent on them.
In the village of Kin, where the rape of the schoolgirl took place, the turnout was only 52 percent, and 20 percent of those who voted opposed the base reduction, twice as many as for the prefecture as a whole.
Others said they had not voted because the question on the ballot was vague and poorly phrased. People were asked whether they agreed with or were opposed to a consolidation and reduction of the American bases and a review of the Status of Forces Agreement, which specifies the rights of American military personnel in Japan.
But the question did not specify how much or how quickly the bases should be cut back or how the forces agreement should be modified. And it did not allow for people to vote separately on the two issues.

HEADLINE: Aristide, Out of the Limelight, Keeps Place in Haiti's Heart

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
He has been out of office since his term expired in February, and nearly two years have elapsed since 20,000 American troops landed here to restore him to power. But Jean-Bertrand Aristide's hold on the imagination and aspirations of his countrymen seems as strong as ever.
Each morning, supplicants gather outside the gates of the compound near the airport where the former President and his new wife now live, quietly and comfortably. Politics in this country continues to be defined by whether you are for or against him, and walls all over the capital are still filled with paintings of his smiling face or graffiti urging his return to power. 
 But Mr. Aristide, 43, is maintaining a low profile these days. He has traveled to Europe and Japan since leaving office and will soon embark on a college lecture tour in the United States. Here at home he has made an effort to stay out of the public eye and to build the sort of domestic life never available to him in the past.
"He is his same calm self," said William L. Swing, who as the American Ambassador here continues to see the former President often. "He is listening to his classical music, doing a lot of reading, and writing. But he really hasn't been out a lot."
Two weeks before he left office, Mr. Aristide, a former Roman Catholic priest, married Mildred Trouillot, 33, a Haitian-American lawyer who had been one of the legal advisers to his Government. They are expecting their first child in the fall, and while Mr. Aristide has not talked much in public about the pregnancy, his transformation from Catholic priest to expectant father in less than two years fascinates the Haitian public.
Initially, some of Mr. Aristide's more ardent followers worried that his marriage to an American-raised descendant of a prominent light-skinned family here might weaken his commitment to Haiti's poor. But Mr. Aristide said that neither his marriage nor impending parenthood should be any cause for concern to the peasants and slum-dwellers who voted him into power in 1990 and remained loyal to him during his three years in exile.
"Frankly, I feel the same," he said during an interview at his home here. "A human being is a human being, and when someone is attacked or hit, I feel that I too am attacked or hit, and when they are hungry, I feel that I am hungry.
"Some people think I will be different, and they are surprised, or happy, to see that I am the same man, ready to listen to people and share their concerns when they are facing problems. Being a priest one day, a President the next day, being a former President today -- it all means giving to someone and wanting to serve."
Though Mr. Aristide has moved from the presidential palace to a spacious, whitewashed residence in the suburb of Tabarre that is guarded both by United Nations troops and private bodyguards, petitioners continue to flock to his door for assistance or favors. During a typical day, he said, he receives visitors "from early in the morning until late at night, and then my personal day will start."
Among those who have sought his counsel is his successor as President, Rene Preval, a friend who in the past was so close that people often referred to them as twins. "We talk as often as is necessary," Mr. Aristide said. "It can be more than once a day, or it might be every couple of days."
In mid-July, the Haitian Government uncovered what it described as an assassination plot against the two men organized by former military officers. Mr. Aristide, who survived numerous such attacks when he was a parish priest, made it clear that he remains fatalistic about such threats, his newly enriched life as a family man nothwithstanding.
"I always said my life was for my country and my people, and I gave that life years ago," he said. "I have had to assume that responsibility."
This spring, there were indications of a rift between the current and former presidents, with Mr. Aristide subtly undermining the economic privatization plan that the United States and other foreign aid donors were pressuring Mr. Preval to carry out. But when Mr. Aristide returned from his trip to Japan this summer Mr. Preval made a point of going to the airport to embrace him.
The focus of most of Mr. Aristide's attention is the Aristide Foundation for Democracy, a nonprofit organization "which seeks to deepen the roots of Haitian democracy by increasing popular participation," according to its charter. At its church-like auditorium just down the road from Mr. Aristide's home, the group has organized seminars on political issues, sports, music and theater programs for children, and literacy classes for adults.
The foundation's latest program is its most ambitious: a savings and loan association intended to encourage small-scale business and agricultural projects among the poor. In less than a week this summer, more than 12,000 people enrolled as members before registration was closed, contributing a minimum of $7.00 in return for the right to borrow money at interest of 1 percent a month.
Mr. Aristide remains involved with Lafanmi Selavi, the charity for orphaned and abandoned street children that he founded when he was a parish priest. He also is sponsoring a project to give poor children a radio outlet of their own and allow them, as he put it, "to tell Haiti what they think of life, so that we listen to them, and not only them to us.
"These kids are like my sons or little brothers," he said. "As the father of Lafanmi Selavi, I try to educate my sons, and my daughters too, from the streets in order to see them assume their own responsibilities in the future."
But Lafanmi Selavi, which means "the family is life" in Creole, has also become the focus of a heated political controversy here. Mr. Aristide's critics, who have become bolder and more outspoken since his departure from office, have accused the organization of siphoning off millions of dollars from aid that Taiwan offered the Haitian Government for a road-building project.
"There is nothing, nothing, nothing true about those allegations," Mr. Aristide said. An agreement with Taiwan called for Lafanmi Selavi "to receive money to pay the companies to build the road" and oversee its construction, he said, but all money was to be channeled through the Haitian Government, which "still has to pay the money that they owe" to contractors.
"Lafanmi Selavi has not made money on this," said Laura Flynn, an aide to Mr. Aristide. "At this point, it is actually out money."
Mr. Aristide's opponents have also suggested that his foundation is less a genuine grass-roots self-help organization than a political vehicle intended to help him mount another run for the presidency when Mr. Preval's term expires in 2001 (the Haitian Constitution forbids a President from succeeding himself). But he scoffed at that notion, arguing that the foundation is engaged in the same kind of work for the destitute and the oppressed that has interested him all his life.
"If some people for their own reasons are frightened because they see poor people getting together in a peaceful way, sharing hope, that is their right, to be afraid," he said, chuckling. "And it is our right to assure them that we are the same as always: always nonviolent, always together, always open."

HEADLINE: Workfare Cuts Costs but Tracking New Jobs Poses Problems

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has often described his workfare program -- by far the largest in the nation -- as "saving the lives" of people on welfare by putting them to work. But while the program has helped New York City slash its welfare spending, it has not demonstrated that it can rebuild the futures of men and women on welfare.
According to city records, less than one-tenth of those who have spent time working for their benefits in the workfare program have reported to the city that they have found full-time jobs. 
 By contrast, nearly two-thirds of the 122,700 people who have been in the workfare program since it began in early 1994 have left it a few months later, disappearing from the city's books. Though they have given up their welfare benefits, saving the city $175 million in this year alone, they left behind no indication of whether they have gained either real jobs or the "renewed self-worth" the Mayor says workfare provides.
The remaining 35,000 people are still in the workfare program, cleaning streets and parks, doing clerical work and assisting janitors in city buildings, all in exchange for their welfare benefits.
The city has made no effort to track the progress of the 89,000 people who have left the workfare program. As a result, it does not even know what has happened to the 11,700 people who have reported finding real employment. Some of the private companies who have hired large groups of former workfare participants for real jobs say they are happy with the program, but report that only a few workers have kept their "permanent" jobs longer than a few months.
City officials argue that the majority of those who have left the program probably have jobs, noting that the homeless rate has not significantly risen in the last year and a half, while the crime rate has fallen. But they concede that they really do not know what has happened to most of those who have left workfare.
"Where else could they have gone?" asked Richard J. Schwartz, the Mayor's senior adviser and the architect of the workfare program. "If they weren't finding work, the evidence of that would be out on the streets of the city, in plain sight to everyone, but that simply isn't the case, because the program works."
He said that in the course of assembling the workfare program in a few months, the city has not been able to track the progress of everyone who has left. "That's a completely unrealistic expectation of how welfare and workfare can be administered," he said, adding that the city eventually plans to make a survey of those who leave workfare to determine what happens to them.
City officials declined to provide a list of people who have left workfare, saying interviews with those who have left would violate privacy clauses of the state social-services law. Asked for data, several welfare advocacy groups said they did not keep records of people who have already left workfare.
The effect of workfare on its participants is becoming an issue of great concern around the country the recent passage of the new Federal welfare law, which requires a quarter of adults on welfare to be working within two years, and half of them within five years. Those who favor such provisions say working for benefits prepares welfare recipients for the private workplace, forcing them to face the fact that in five years, most will be cut off from assistance under the new law.
The new law "emphasizes work and independence, to give people on welfare a chance to draw a paycheck, not a welfare check," President Clinton said last month in explaining his decision to sign the bill. "It gives us a better chance to give those on welfare what we want for all families in America, the opportunity to succeed at home and at work."
But there is no evidence from the nation's largest experiment with workfare that any such preparation is taking place. Only a few hundred of the 35,000 people now in the workfare program are receiving any kind of job-specific training, and city officials have expressed more concern about reducing the number of people of welfare than in learning what happens to those who leave.
"They don't want to know the answer to that question, because it would destroy the myth that people are going from welfare to work," said Stephen DiBrienza, chairman of the City Council's General Welfare Committee and a frequent critic of the Giuliani administration's welfare policies. "It is an absolute myth."
Faced with the small number of people reporting leaving workfare for jobs, Mayor Giuliani has now begun saying that permanent employment is not necessarily the point of the workfare program.
"Frankly, the workfare program in and of itself is a valuable program, whether it leads to permanent employment for every single person," the Mayor said on his weekly radio show last month. "To say to somebody that in exchange for your welfare check, you have to do something that improves the quality of life for your fellow citizens, that's what the social contract is all about."
Workfare, in fact, has been more valuable to the city by helping to push recipients off the welfare rolls before they even participate in the program. In the year and a half since the Mayor instituted his welfare changes -- which along with workfare have included a tough new eligibility screening program and finger-imaging for participants -- 166,000 people have left the welfare rolls. Half of those people never entered the workfare program, forced out because they did not meet the new requirements or dropping out voluntarily.
Many of those people already had jobs or found jobs quickly when faced with the threat of spending 26 hours a week in the workfare program. Mr. Schwartz said 27,000 people gave up their welfare benefits once they were told to report to workfare jobs; 22,000 of those said they already had jobs or had found new ones. That number is almost twice as high as the 11,700 who have reported finding real jobs after participating in the workfare program, formally called the Work Experience Program and known as WEP.
The program has also proved useful to the Mayor in his effort to improve city services while the budget and the number of city employees has been reduced. He called a news conference last week, for example, to claim that the city's parks were cleaner than they have been in years, a fact that he and Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern attributed in part to the 5,200 workfare participants now picking up trash and doing other chores for the Parks Department.
Performing such tasks, however, is often more valuable to the city than it is to the long-term careers of the workers. Critics of the program say the administration's decision to use the workers for city services rather than to provide them job training will mire them in a future of menial work.
"If workfare is going to be effective, it has to be redesigned as a training program," said Mark Cohan, a lawyer with the Center on Social Welfare Policy and Law, a Manhattan-based organization that assists lawyers for welfare recipients. "At the moment, there is absolutely no evidence that WEP has been effective in moving people from welfare to work."
Currently, Mr. Schwartz said, about 1,500 people are involved in small pilot training programs in city parks and in building maintenance, learning skills like plumbing, carpentry and specialized cleaning. But for the most part, it is the fact of their working, rather than any specific skills, that is the prime benefit to the 35,000 people in workfare, he and the Mayor said.
"It's a lot better than their staying at home, just collecting a check at home," Mr. Giuliani told the First New York Conservative Democratic Club in Forest Hills, Queens, at a recent political meeting. "It's a lot better for us, and most importantly, it's a lot better for them. It keeps them in the work force, it makes work discipline and the work ethic a part of their life. And frankly it gives them something worthwhile to do."
Though New York City's workfare program is far larger than comparable programs around the country, its results so far in finding employment have been similar. A 1993 national study by the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, which was financed by the Rockefeller Foundation, found "little evidence that unpaid work experience leads to consistent employment or earnings."
Prompted by such concerns, the city last year set up a program called Business Link, which is intended to connect workfare participants with large businesses that have openings for full-time employees. The businesses get a tax credit for hiring welfare recipients.
Mr. Schwartz said about 4,200 people had left workfare for real jobs through the Business Link program and through hiring by city contractors, but he said he could not disclose the names of most of the companies because not all wanted to be identified as hiring welfare recipients.
Beverly Butler, a spokeswoman for Gap Inc., said the clothing store company had hired about 300 people from the workfare program in various jobs in its stores in Greenwich Village in the last year. She said the company liked the program and planned to expand its use of it citywide later this year.
But while the company provides training, health benefits and better pay than welfare checks, only 30 or 40 of the people involved have stayed on as full-time employees. The rest have quit, she said, a rate of turnover similar to the Gap's regular hiring.
Borg-Warner has hired about 600 people from workfare to work as security guards and in other positions in the company's Wells Fargo security division, said a spokeswoman, Lynn Gloveka. More than 25 percent are still in permanent positions after a training period, she said.
But Mr. Schwartz said focusing on permanent employment missed the point of the workfare program. When President Franklin D. Roosevelt created the Works Progress Administration, Mr. Schwartz said, the purpose was simply to get unemployed people working again.
"The W.P.A. was never judged by the standard of how many people found permanent work," he said. "The standard was getting people back into the work force immediately, and that's exactly what New York City is doing today. These people are working again and that will give them the best type of preparation."

HEADLINE: Arthur S. Flemming, 91, Dies; Served in Eisenhower Cabinet

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Arthur S. Flemming, who was Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare from 1958 to 1961 under President Dwight D. Eisenhower and held other high posts in government and education, died on Saturday in the Washington House, a retirement home in Alexandria, Va., where he spent his last few years. He was 91 and had been a longtime resident of Alexandria.
The cause was acute renal failure, his son Thomas said. . 
 Mr. Flemming, a Republican, devoted his career largely to the theory and practice of government service and to the Methodist Church and to education. He was the United States Commissioner on Aging from 1973 to 1978 and chairman of the bipartisan, six-member United States Commission on Civil Rights from 1974 to 1981.
Over the years, he worked for Democrats as well as Republicans. President Clinton, who awarded him the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1994, said yesterday: "Arthur Flemming was a close friend to me and the First Lady. He transcended party, generation and race in search of consensus on some of the great issues of our day."
Mr. Flemming was not always so warmly viewed from the White House. In 1981, he was dismissed from the civil rights post by President Ronald Reagan and replaced with a conservative Republican, Clarence M. Pendleton Jr. On the day he was dismissed, Mr. Flemming warned publicly that the Reagan Administration was drifting back to a philosophy of "separate but equal" in school desegregation cases. A spokesman for the commission, Charles Rivera, linked Mr. Flemming's dismissal to his strong advocacy of civil rights.
A stooped man whose voice sometimes trembled with emotion when he spoke of civil rights issues in those days, Mr. Flemming was a familiar figure on the Washington scene even before President Eisenhower appointed him to his Cabinet.
When he joined the Cabinet, he was an educator -- having just stepped down as president of Ohio Wesleyan University -- with much interest and experience in manpower and labor-management problems. When he resigned from the Cabinet at the end of the Eisenhower Administration, Mr. Eisenhower said that "dramatic progress" had been made while Mr. Flemming was Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in improving the health, education level and economic security of the country.
In leaving office, Mr. Flemming warned that the United States would have to make "a far greater investment in the field of education than the nation has been willing to recognize" to meet its basic educational needs in coming years. He left behind a detailed accounting of those requirements in the form of three studies, prepared by the Office of Education, that had been undertaken at his direction more than a year earlier.
Mr. Flemming was president of Ohio Wesleyan University from 1948 to 1953 and again in 1957 and 1958, president of the University of Oregon from 1961 to 1968 and president of Macalester College in St. Paul, Minn., from 1968 to 1971. His church work led him to become president of the National Council of Churches from 1966 to 1969.
Mr. Flemming started out in Washington as an instructor in government and a debating coach at American University from 1927 to 1930, and he was on the editorial staff of what is now the U.S. News and World Report magazine for some years in the 1930's. In 1939, a Democratic President, Franklin D. Roosevelt, appointed him as a Republican member on the Civil Service Commission, where he remained until 1948. In the mid-1950's, before joining the Cabinet, he was director of the Office of Defense Mobilization.
Arthur Sherwood Flemming was born and reared in Kingston, N.Y., and went on to receive a bachelor's degree in 1927 from Ohio Wesleyan University, a master's degree in 1928 from American University and a law degree in 1933 from George Washington University.
In addition to his son Thomas, of Alexandria, he is survived by his wife of 61 years, the former Bernice Moler; two other sons, Harry, of Alexandria, and Arthur H., of South Pasadena, Calif.; a daughter, Elizabeth Speece of Delaware, Ohio; a sister, Elizabeth Sherbondy of Pittsburgh; 12 grandchildren, and 12 great-grandchildren. Another daughter, Susan Parker, died in 1993.

HEADLINE: In Westchester, Welfare Meets Managed Care

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER 

DATELINE: YONKERS, Sept. 4

 BODY:
When Isabel Briceno showed up with her feverish 1-year-old, Selena, and a Medicaid card at the emergency room of St. Joseph's Medical Center, she got two surprises.
Staff members told her she had come to the wrong place for a minor ailment like Selena's ear infection. Then she learned that Medicaid would not have paid for the visit anyway. Tiny Selena, it turned out, had been placed by Westchester County in a health maintenance organization, and so was a trailblazer in the latest growth area for managed care: welfare clients. She could have skipped the emergency room and simply seen a family pediatrician. 
 In the era of managed care, life has changed for Ms. Briceno's daughter and the rest of Westchester County's 32,000 recipients of Aid to Families With Dependent Children, who are now required to join H.M.O.'s. And soon it will be the same for 2.5 million of the 3.6 million Medicaid recipients throughout New York State.
Interviews with doctors, health administrators and families in Westchester's program -- the first in the state -- indicate that welfare recipients, accustomed to dreary waits in crowded emergency rooms and clinics, have warmed to the managed care concept of a steady family doctor. There are signs that managed care has begun to improve the quality and consistency of their care. And officials project that it will save Westchester more than $8 million a year.
Although many Americans spurn managed care because it limits their choice of doctors and specialists, Medicaid recipients, by and large, seem to like H.M.O.'s because they never had much choice to begin with, and had no one to monitor their care over time.
"For Medicaid patients, it's 500 percent better," said Dr. Elio J. Ippolito, a veteran family doctor in Tarrytown. "They get good regular care from a good group of doctors."
For these patients, managed care has pried open the doors of many family doctors, pediatricians and specialists who once refused to take them because Medicaid reimbursements are so low -- as little as $7 a visit. Janet Foley, a 25-year-old welfare recipient from Eastchester, said her enrollment in the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York gives her access to a better pediatrician for her 2-year-old, Karen, than the medical office she had visited as a Medicaid client.
"It was a storefront type of place and they rushed everyone through," she said. "The doctor didn't even take off her diaper to check whether she had diaper rash."
If patients are pleased, so too are welfare officials, for whom a primary appeal of managed care is cost. Dr. Barbara A. DeBuono, the state's Health Commissioner, and Mary Glass, the county's Commissioner for Social Services, say that managed care has saved up to 12 percent of the money Westchester spends on medical care for the poor, in part by reducing emergency room visits. Ms. Glass said the county would spend $58 million this year on managed care for welfare recipients, while a pure Medicaid program would have cost $66.5 million.
Encouraged by such savings, New York State, eager to shave $1 billion to $2 billion a year from an annual Medicaid budget of $22 billion, will require all its counties and New York City to start enrolling their welfare recipients early next year.
But Westchester's program may not be a prototype for the rest of the state, particularly New York City, cautions Dr. James R. Tallon, president of the United Hospital Fund, which studies health issues. The county has a rich supply of doctors, a comparatively well-regarded bureaucracy and a manageable welfare caseload. Some New York neighborhoods have virtually no private doctors, leaving the poor little choice but emergency rooms for basic care. And the scale of the city's caseload threatens to make enrolling patients in managed care a bureaucratic nightmare.
To test such criticism, the state, which is waiting for a Federal waiver before beginning the mandatory managed care program statewide, is closely watching a demonstration project that has enrolled welfare clients in southwestern Brooklyn.
If the experience of other states is any guide, speedily shifting tens of thousands of the poor and uninsured off Medicaid and into privately run health care plans can be an open door to trouble. Tennessee, a pioneer in shifting poor residents into managed care, grappled with marketing abuses that potentially could have cost it millions and denied coverage to legitimate applicants.
And critics of managed care say it limits patient choice and constrains doctors, who must clear many of their treatment decisions with the company. Under managed care, each recipient chooses or is assigned a primary doctor who not only provides basic treatment but also controls the number of costly visits to specialists and hospitals.
Welfare clients in Westchester, the experts say, seem to be receiving more preventive care because the H.M.O.'s, eager to meet state standards, have kept track of such fundamentals as immunizations, prenatal visits and pap smears.
"With Medicaid you're on your own," said Mark Santiago, director of marketing for Health Source, one of the county's managed care providers.
Anecdotal evidence also suggests there has been a small decline in the numbers of welfare families seeking care for routine ailments in emergency rooms, where a single visit costs Medicaid $125. Those recipients who do show up for relatively minor problems are told they will not be treated unless they receive authorization from the primary doctor in their H.M.O.
"We get a few every day where authorization is not given because the H.M.O. does not feel it's an emergency case," said Michael Spicer, executive vice president of St. Joseph's.
From the doctors' point of view, managed care for welfare clients has also been a windfall, bringing new patients. Dr. James Sayegh of Yonkers, who spurned low Medicaid fees but says he can live with his H.M.O. fees, has had to hire an associate and a nurse to accommodate hundreds of new H.M.O. patients.
But there is some dissatisfaction. Four of six managed care plans that Westchester uses do not pay a doctor for each visit, but instead pay a small monthly fee whether or not the doctor sees the patient. While the fee is ultimately higher than what Medicaid pays, some doctors say it encourages a kind of assembly-line processing of patients. There is no time to schmooze.
"Patients understand that I can't give them all a lot of time because I'm not reimbursed to give them a lot of time," Dr. Ippolito said. "The shy patient may lose out. If they want to complain about the weather or Aunt Millie, I can't listen to them."
The fees doctors receive from managed care plans run less than $10 per month for an adult patient. Dr. Ippolito told of visiting a diabetic patient in the hospital each day for a month, and receiving in return a total of $10 from managed care. If the patient had not been in managed care, Dr. Ippolito said, he would have charged $50 for each visit and received something closer to $1,500.
Managed care proponents stress that doctors receive their monthly fee for each patient no matter how few times they see that patient. And Toni Chagnon, president of Genesis Health Plan, which has 6,400 of Westchester's welfare clients, points out that her plan, which is solely for Medicaid-eligible patients, pays doctors monthly fees that are comparable to those paid by H.M.O.'s dealing with private paying patients.
Moreover, the two H.M.O.'s that pay doctors for every visit rather than a monthly fee also pay rates competitive with commercial insurance plans. The Oxford health plan pays a doctor $54 for an initial visit; Independent Health Plan pays $51.
Westchester County pays an H.M.O. $328 and up per month for each infant under 6 months, a minimum of $70 for people 20 and under, and $191 for adults between the ages of 21 and 64. Those fees cover routine checkups, specialist visits, and hospitalizations as well as eyeglasses, hearing aids, prescription drugs, lab tests, X-rays and transportation to doctor's offices.
Linda Samuels, a deputy commissioner for social services in Westchester, said that some critics complain that the program "is more generous than the average person gets in their health plan."
"But that is the way Medicaid has been for many years in New York State," she said.
Despite the gains made by managed care, most private doctors continue to spurn welfare clients. Dr. Tallon, of the United Hospital Fund, said there was a suspicion that economic and racial discrimination might play a role. "Some doctors don't want poor people in the waiting room," he said.
Independent Health, one of the health plans used by Westchester's welfare families, acknowledges that it has made acceptance of Medicaid clients voluntary for its participating physicians.
"No one is a winner if you force physicians to see welfare recipients when they don't want to," said Barbara Pike, Independent's assistant director of marketing.
While doctors may get paid more than they did with Medicaid, the heart of the county's cost-saving strategy has been to use managed care organizations to reduce emergency room visits. The H.M.O.'s have negotiated steep discounts with hospitals for nonessential emergency room visits and they telephone patients who make such visits to remind them to call their primary doctor first.
Dr. Karen Costley, medical director of Ossining Open Door, a clinic that is part of the Health Source network, said the county's plan still did not provide a sufficient deterrent for patients to forgo the emergency room.
"The E.R.'s feeling is that medically, legally, a patient is presented to our door, we have to care for them," she said. "And then there's the managed care plan which says we're not going to pay to see a patient that we paid primary care physicians to manage. So it becomes a battle between the managed care plan and the E.R., and the patient usually gets what they want."
Still, patients accustomed to showing up in an emergency room and waiting have had to adapt to a system built on appointments, and that has not always worked out so well. Dr. Costley says Open Door's "no-show rate" is 20 percent.
"Our patient population has other life priorities that just doesn't allow them to keep their appointments," Dr. Costley said. "There's a lot going on sometimes and we don't always get calls canceling."
For many welfare recipients the changeover to managed care has been no more upsetting than switching membership cards. A welfare client like Milagros Lebron, 52, of Yonkers, chose her plan, Health Source, because Dr. Sayegh, the doctor she has seen for her high blood pressure, is part of that network and so is her neighborhood pharmacy. Ms. Briceno, a Peruvian immigrant, chose Community Choice Health Plan so she could stay with her doctor, Syed Shariff.
"He's a very good doctor," Ms. Briceno said. "When I take the baby, he checks her real good, like the urine, and he gives her a lead test."

HEADLINE: Campaign Trail;
THE PRESIDENTAL RACE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

 BODY:

If It's Tuesday . . .
Many a campaign-addled pol, on the fifth speech of an eight-speech day, has mounted the dais to express delight at being in Cincinnati when he was actually in Columbus. Only a master orator can convince the audience that he meant to say it.
Ladies and gentlemen, the platinum-tongued President of the United States:
"I want us to have an education system in which, by the year 2000, in Covington, Ky., and every --" Bill Clinton said midway through his boilerplate stump speech on Aug. 31. Then as his audience, the good citizens of Covington, Tenn., began to register dismay, he halted. 
 But only briefly.
"Now wait a minute," the President continued, barely skipping a beat. "In Covington, Ky., in Covington, Tenn., Covington, Mass., in every single Covington in America, every single one, every child will have access not only to computers . . ." And on he went.
There are 10 cities and counties in the United States named Covington, including one each in Tennessee and Kentucky (but, alas, not in Massachusetts). Luckily for Mr. Clinton, he was not speaking in Memphis.
 
Dole Rescued by Blowout
When a military helicopter assigned to the White House overturned and burst into flames in Orlando, Fla., on Friday, no one made any wry references to a crash-and-burn Clinton campaign. But then, Mr. Clinton has a yawning lead in the polls, and funereal analogies hardly seem apropos.
Not so the campaign of Bob Dole. And when Democratic operatives got a look at his political schedule last week, they could hardly wait to seize on its symbolism. Mr. Dole, they gleefully pointed out to reporters, planned to hold a town meeting at a New Jersey company that makes life rafts, inflatable vests and other emergency survival gear.
The distance from that tidbit to news stories about a "sinking" Dole campaign whose advisers were "jumping ship" was short indeed, the Democrats reasoned. And in fact, one New Jersey newspaper suggested before the event that Mr. Dole was going to the factory at a time when he was "in deep water."
But the press never got a chance. On Friday, the day of the planned visit, the remnants of Hurricane Fran skirted into New Jersey. The event was called off.

Ripe for Comment
When not preparing remarks for "Washington Week in Review" or writing thoughtful analyses, political journalists while away long hours in the air between campaign stops with stimulating parlor games.
They squat on plastic meal trays during takeoff, using the force of jet engines to surf down the plane's main aisle. Or they play Seat-O, in which a stash of dollar bills goes to the lucky flier whose seat number matches the serial number of a bill drawn at random. Or they sing over the intercom system.
Most of all, they roll oranges up and down the aisle. Sometimes they scrawl comments on the fruit and roll it into the first-class cabin, where the candidate is expected to roll back a response.
The Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, Jack Kemp, received so many missives that he banned orange-rolling last week, saying he had run out of citrus replies. Reporters responded a few flights later by rolling a watermelon into his cabin, calling it "an orange with dynamic scoring." The term, embraced by Reagan-style conservatives like Mr. Kemp, loosely embodies the argument that tax cuts generate still more tax revenue by stimulating economic growth.
Mr. Kemp returned the melon with an inscription. "We're all supply-siders now," he wrote.

Wild About Harry?
And the resounding leader in four new Presidential opinion polls is . . . Harry Browne!
Who?
The Libertarian Party says Mr. Browne, its Presidential candidate, trounced President Clinton, Bob Dole and Ross Perot in four August polls -- not of registered voters, but of Internet surfers.
Mr. Browne collected at least a third of the vote in each survey, including 40.2 percent in a poll conducted on the popular "Politics Now" Web site managed by several leading newspapers, a news magazine, a network and the analytic weekly magazine National Journal. Mr. Clinton was second in two polls; Mr. Dole in the other two.
There is a caveat: the polls were not scientifically conducted. Rather, they measured the sentiments of Web-cruisers who visited the sites and chose to register their sentiments with a mouse click or two, or perhaps three. Still, the surveys may reflect the decidedly free spirit among many Internet users, who have campaigned hard against Government controls on cyberspace.
No word on how Mr. Browne's running mate, a software company owner named Jo Jorgensen, fares against Al Gore and Jack Kemp.

Sound Bite
"My wife, Elizabeth, has traveled to the scenes of many natural disasters these past five years. That doesn't include my campaign, of course." -- Bob Dole, speaking to the National Guard Association on Sept. 1. MICHAEL WINES

GRAPHIC: Photo: Harry Browne, the Libertarian Party's candidate, with his wife, Pamela, was nominated in July. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Essay;
Helping the Black Jews

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Maybe, as readers of I Kings 10:13 surmised, King Solomon had an affair with the Queen of Sheba before her return to Arabia. Or perhaps, after the destruction of the Temple in 586 B.C.E., a tribe of Israelites fled to Africa.
Whatever the origin of Ethiopian Jewry, thousands of Africans who believed in Judaism -- relying on the Bible, without benefit of Talmud, and stricter than the most orthodox on certain rituals of purity -- kept their faith for more than two millennia. 
 Threatened by war, persecution and starvation, 50,000 trekked across deserts or were ransomed by Israel and airlifted with U.S. help to the place these gentle people maintained was the Promised Land. The State of Israel extended full citizenship under the Law of Return.
What a heartwarming story. Five years after Operation Solomon, how has it worked out?
Not as well as it should have. Although most live in far better conditions than the misery they fled from, they are poorer than other recent immigrants. Half are unemployed.
Mistakes made in America by social engineers were made anew in Israel. Misguided government policy encouraged segregation, and ahead loomed urban ghettos, welfare dependency and a black underclass.
Dissatisfaction flared last year after health officials, fearing the high incidence of H.I.V. infection in Africa, were revealed to have been disposing of blood from Ethiopian Jewish donors. A demonstration in front of Prime Minister Peres's residence made headlines and elicited apologies, but the far greater offense to Ethiopian Israelis was ignored.
Over half the blacks in Israel are under 18, which should offer a tremendous opportunity to teach and uplift a new generation -- but the kids are not getting the equal-opportunity education they deserve.
That upsets Micha Odenheimer, a California-born rabbi who heads the Israel Association for Ethiopian Jews at 34 Ben Yehuda Street in Jerusalem. "We still have time to turn this all around," he insists, "if we go all out to educate the children."
He's pressing for Head Start programs, tutoring, and free books and software to give blacks a fair chance at academic, not only vocational, achievement. No more shunting black kids to the worst schools in the poorest neighborhoods. His goal is to raise the percentage of Ethiopians matriculating beyond high school from 8 percent to at least the national average of 38 percent, which the rabbi says is doable in the next few years.
When applied early, such affirmative action works. And a nation with universal military service has an edge in integrating, instilling pride and advancing members of a minority racial group; E.J. officers in the Israeli Defense Forces will be a leadership cadre later.
An unexpected ally in this campaign to prevent an underclass is the new Prime Minister, who likes to refer to Ethiopian Israelis as "this precious part of the Jewish people." Mr. Netanyahu sees that part not as any Jewish white man's burden but an opportunity for his nation to light a candle in the race-relations darkness.
The diplomatic advantage of a multiracial society is obvious (Israel's new consul in Chicago is a young woman born in Ethiopia). But the equal-opportunity potential for Israel -- small enough to be a laboratory, steeped in the tradition of education -- would be to serve as a model for race relations in the coming century.
The world could use an example of racial diversity within religious and national unity. Science could do with a rebuttal to hypotheses of genetic inferiority. Blacks and Jews in the U.S. need every bridge they can build; success of Ethiopian Israelis (don't call them "felashas") would blunt the wedge threatened by the Qaddafi-Farrakhan connection.
That's why, in the week that Jews believe they are inscribed in the Book of Life, I hope that Rabbi Odenheimer's inexpensive cause is enlivened. Though primary responsibility lies with the new Israeli Government, Mr. Netanyahu should set up a channel for outsiders to participate.
This will not get the media attention of a handshake with Yasir Arafat or a standoff with Syria. But years from now, Israel's obeisance to equality for its African-born children could sparkle, in Shakespeare's simile, "like a jewel in an Ethiope's ear."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE THIRD PARTY;
Perot Urges Redesign of Tax System

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

 BODY:
Ross Perot took on taxes last night, exhorting a national television audience to "get rid of the I.R.S. and create a new tax system that works."
"As your President, we will get rid of the I.R.S. and the tax code, and replace them with a fair, paperless, modern system," the Reform Party presidential candidate vowed in a half hour "infomercial" on NBC. 
 To warm up his audience, expected to be in the millions, Mr. Perot charged that Republicans and Democrats refuse to reform the tax system because they are beholden to "special interest groups who buy tax breaks with their campaign contributions."
"The professional politicians in Washington buy our votes with our tax money; this is called pork," Mr. Perot said. "Then, they pass legislation which plunges us deeper in debt, while at the same time promising us tax cuts to get our votes."
Saying that "democracies always collapse over loose fiscal policies," Mr. Perot quoted an 18th-century Scottish historian, Alexander Tytler, as warning that "a democracy can only exist until voters discover that they can vote themselves money from the public treasury."
Since 1913, when the Internal Revenue Service was created, Federal tax regulations have increased from 400 pages to 80,000 pages, he said.
"It is estimated that the time spent preparing tax returns each year costs us $300 billion," he continued. "In 1960, we operated the entire Government of the United States for only $100 billion."
Backed by multicolored graphs and charts, Mr. Perot continued: "Americans spend more than five billion man-hours each year preparing income tax forms. That is more hours than we spend each year manufacturing cars in the U.S.A."
To redesign the American tax system, Mr. Perot said he would bring together a panel of leading tax experts to evaluate and to run computer models on several proposed tax systems, including the flat income tax idea proposed earlier this year by Steve Forbes during the Republican primaries. At the completion of the study, Mr. Perot said, proposed changes would be put before the American people "in plain language."
Mr. Perot, a self-made businessman, said an overhaul of the tax system would have to go hand in hand with a balanced budget amendment.
For his panel of tax experts, Mr. Perot proposed several people associated with the Concord Coalition, a non-profit group dedicated to balancing the Federal budget.
Hewing to a conservative fiscal line throughout his paid address, Mr. Perot attacked the 15 percent income tax cut proposed by Bob Dole, the Republican candidate. Saying it did not "make any business sense," he asked, "Shouldn't we first cut spending, and then cut taxes?"

HEADLINE: Governor Raises Possibility Of Fed Interest Rate Increase

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
The drop in the unemployment rate to 5.1 percent in August raises the risks of unacceptable wage inflation, Laurence H. Meyer, one of the newest members of the Federal Reserve Board, warned this evening.
"That makes a difference," Mr. Meyer said, referring to the decline of three-tenths of a percentage point reported on Friday that carried the jobless rate to a seven-year low. 
 In a speech to the National Association of Business Economists here, Mr. Meyer, one of the Fed's seven governors, did not overtly indicate that he was now concerned enough about inflation to vote for a tighter monetary policy when the Fed's policy-making committee meets on Sept. 24. But various members of the audience sensed that the central bankers were leaning toward raising short-term interest rates.
"The governors are pretty concerned at this point," said David W. Berson of the Federal National Mortgage Association and the association's president.
In his first public statement since taking office in June, Mr. Meyer referred to Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, when he told the association's members "there is no question that the latest data reinforced the sense that chairman Greenspan expressed a couple of months ago that we are in a circumstance in which a prudent central bank must exercise heightened surveillance of the inflationary risks and stand ready to respond if necessary."
Those remarks were inserted in a speech that had been written before the employment report was released on Friday. The figure also showed strong job growth and a surge in hourly earnings.
Mr. Meyer said in answer to questions from reporters after his speech that inflation was not yet accelerating, but he added that the Fed must not "sit around" and wait for it to happen before taking action.
Rather, he said, the central bank's role is to prevent revived inflation.
In his remarks, Mr. Meyer said, "growth itself does not cause inflation."
Mr. Meyer, a professional economist who ran his own St. Louis consulting firm for 14 years, said, though, that the economy showed other signs of a desired cooling from an unsustainable 4.8 percent rate of expansion in the second quarter.
"If you look at the demand-side indicators, they look pretty weak," he said.
Summing up the current challenge to monetary policy, Mr. Meyer said that the Fed must be vigilant in sustaining progress made against inflation, now about 3 percent, a figure that he believes is overestimated by about 1 percentage point.
As a result, he said, he is paying close attention to forecasts of short-term growth as an indicator of inflationary pressures and on labor costs as a key factor in transmitting those pressures to prices.

HEADLINE: PRO-HUSSEIN KURDS TAKE ANOTHER CITY IN NORTHERN IRAQ

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Thousands of Kurdish civilians and hundreds of armed guerrillas fled Koi Sanjaq in northern Iraq today as the Kurdish faction that has been backed by President Saddam Hussein's forces mounted an eastward offensive and overran the city.
Officials of a rival faction, the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, which had controlled the city, said tonight that their forces had abandoned Koi Sanjaq in the face of an overwhelming attack by the forces of the Kurdistan Democratic Party, which together with Iraqi troops captured the regional capital of Erbil eight days ago. 
 In Sulaimaniya, the Patriotic Union's last major stronghold, there was a mood of despair tonight. Officials of the losing faction accused their rivals of having once again employed Iraqi armor and artillery, and they and residents expressed fear that their rivals would now turn their sights on Sulaimaniya.
Kurdistan Democratic Party officials and the Iraqi Government denied that Iraqi forces had taken part in the assault today.
[In Washington, Pentagon officials played down the significance of the attack today in the north and said that the United States was unlikely to be drawn into any fighting between the rival Kurdish factions. At the same time, the United States warned Baghdad that it risked new attacks if it tried to repair air defenses in southern Iraq that American missiles struck last week. Page A10.]
Foreign aid workers who visited Koi Sanjaq before it fell also said they had seen no evidence of Iraqi involvement.
Reporters who tried to reach the battle zone from the east were prevented from doing so by the Kurdistan Democratic Party forces, and those who reached the area by a circuitous route were warned by the fleeing Patriotic Union fighters against trying to reach Koi Sanjaq.
But it was evident at least that the Kurdistan Democratic Party, led by Massoud Barzani, was capitalizing on its crushing victory a week ago to press its advantage against what are now clearly the fearful forces led by Jalal Talabani.
And on the defeated side there remained a conviction that their rivals' advance would consolidate a return of President Hussein's control over the region, where the United States and its Western allies created a safe haven for the Kurds in 1991 after the Persian Gulf war.
"Today he has Koi Sanjaq," one fleeing guerrilla, Mohammed Ghareib, said. "Tomorrow or the day after, he'll take Sulaimaniya. And then maybe we'll have to run all the way to Iran."
The two Kurdish factions, longtime political rivals, agreed to share power when the United States and its allies created the safe haven. But as international attention waned they began to fight over dwindling resources, and a bitter feud erupted over lucrative black-market trade.
As the Kurdistan Democratic Party forces advanced this afternoon, the residents and then defenders of Koi Sanjaq, a city of 50,000, took flight by car and cattle truck and on foot, climbing by road across a steep mountain range and seeking refuge here and in towns to the north.
At a crossroads called Bestana at the foot of the high ground, sweat-stained guerrillas still clutching their Kalashnikov rifles said they had no choice but to retreat as Mr. Barzani's forces mounted their attack, first overrunning Degala, 30 miles southeast of Erbil, then continuing toward Koi Sanjaq.
Sulaimaniya, the last large city in the hands of Mr. Talabani's group, lies some 75 miles southeast of Koi Sanjaq and outside the protected zone patroled by the United States and its allies. There are few natural barriers between the cities.
Officials of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan noted with apprehension tonight that when Iraqi forces entered Sulaimaniya in 1991 to suppress a Kurdish uprising, their initial advance followed the same route as today's offensive.
That Iraqi advance sent hundreds of thousands of Kurds fleeing into the mountains of Turkey and Iran, prompting the United States and its allies to undertake a relief operation and to compel Iraq to withdraw its units.
Even today, foreigners who work for several private aid organizations left Sulaimaniya out of concern over the Barzani faction's advance, and United Nations agencies based here decided to suspend their operations for at least two days.
The failure of the United Nations and the international community to respond forcefully to the fighting has angered many people here, some of whom staged demonstrations outside the local United Nations headquarters. As they traveled in the region today, some United Nations guards found themselves the targets of verbal abuse, an international relief worker said.
"They are very apprehensive because of the Iraqis," the relief worker said about the local population. "They think that if they come here, it is the end of the world."
Tonight, hundreds and perhaps thousands of people in Sulaimaniya had begun to flee as rumors swept the city that Mr. Barzani's forces, along with Iraqis, were on the way. With the main escape route to the north at risk of being cut off by a further advance, some may again see Iran as an attractive refuge.
Patriotic Union officials said the offensive today began at 4 A.M. They said that after capturing Degala, little more than a crossroads, by late morning, the Kurdistan Democratic Party forces -- which they said were supported by Iraqi tanks and artillery -- captured Koi Sanjaq, 25 miles away, by early evening. The Patriotic Union officials said the attackers had then continued to the top of the mountain range that separates that city from the long valley in which Sulaimaniya lies.
As the forces advanced, the Kurdistan Democratic Party's radio station told residents of Koi Sanjaq that they had no cause for alarm and urged them to stay in their homes. But nearly all of the town's residents apparently chose to flee rather than risk being caught in the fighting.
Not only Patriotic Union officials but also every fleeing guerrilla who was interviewed insisted that Iraqi forces had taken part in the attack. Some of the guerrillas said they had seen Iraqi T-72 tanks, which the Kurdistan Democratic Party forces do not have, and they said they had come under fire with multiple-rocket-launcher artillery, which is also not in the Kurdistan Democrats' arsenal.
The Patriotic Union also declared last week that a smaller offensive by the Kurdistan Democratic Party east of Erbil had included Iraqi forces, an assertion that the United Nations and the United States said they have no evidence to support.
But a Patriotic Union official tonight suggested that the rival group's forces might have gone to new lengths to conceal the Iraqi presence. He said his organization had information that the Kurdistan Democrats had ordered 30,000 outfits of Kurdish clothing that he said would be given to Iraqi troops.

HEADLINE: Believe It: People Get Signals on the Economy;
Perils of Inflation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Labor Market Tightens but Pay Gains Stay Slim" (Business Day, Sept. 5), on the dangers of lower unemployment and higher wages, advances two very debatable conservative ideas without much challenge. 
 First, you refer to states' "natural rate of joblessness, defined as the lowest level that allows for wage stability."
But of course there is no "natural" rate of joblessness.
In 1994 and 1995, conservative economists treated the public to a steady diet of long admonitory talks about the nonaccelerating rate of unemployment, and assured us that inflation would spiral out of control if unemployment dipped below 6 percent.
It has been below that figure for more than a year now without any sign of inflation. Judgments about the best rate of unemployment are, within fairly wide boundaries, political ones.
Second, you imply that higher wages are a danger to the economy. Elsewhere in your reporting, you have noted that most Americans have seen their real wages decline steadily for more than 20 years.
Why doesn't that count on the balance sheet?
Isn't it possible that higher wages, which are admittedly not in the short-term interest of employers, are in fact in the best interest of most Americans and in the long-term interest of the economy as a whole?
Such questions need to be widely addressed.
 
TED LIAZOS
New Haven, Sept. 5, 1996
