HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Dole Focuses On Georgia And Florida, Talking Taxes

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Sept. 9

 BODY:
With bolts of lightning jabbing the air around him, Bob Dole's effort at showcasing his personal side here today was short-circuited by an electrical storm. But before the charcoal skies opened up and drenched the 300 people who had gathered at a backyard fish fry to hear him, he asserted he was excited about the Presidential race.
"I know the press, 'Why are you so confident, you're behind in the polls?' " he mimicked. "What polls? The poll I take every day, I'm one to nothing ahead." 
 Mr. Dole, the Republican Presidential nominee, campaigned today in Florida and Georgia, two Southern states that should be safely in his column two months before the November election. But state polls show him running only slightly ahead of President Clinton, and most national polls show him trailing Mr. Clinton by double digits.
Mr. Dole's task over the last few weeks has been to visit states like these and generate positive local media coverage. The format is dubbed "Listening to America," in which Mr. Dole is to reveal his personal side -- and plug his tax-cut proposal -- with a group of hand-picked supporters who ask friendly questions.
But there were several messages out of the campaign today. Aides put out a statement warning the Clinton Administration not to take undeserved credit for success in Iraq before such claims are warranted -- a statement muted by Mr. Dole's passing up the chance to make it publicly himself.
And he was vocal about a proposal he has yet to firm up, telling his audiences both here and in Georgia that he would soon be announcing an expansion of the G.I. bill.
In addition, William J. Bennett, the former drug policy director, was to travel with Mr. Dole to lend an air of authority to the candidate's proposed drug war and to help convey the moral high ground that the Dole campaign claims in the character war. But floods kept Mr. Bennett from reaching Mr. Dole's plane in Washington, and he arrived here only to be rained out.
As Mr. Dole left here tonight for Baton Rouge, La., he placed a call to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, in Washington for a meeting with President Clinton. Mr. Dole's press secretary, Nelson Warfield, said the call was just between "old friends touching base."
In Florida, Mr. Dole promoted his tax-cut plan as being aimed at "Main Street, not Wall Street." He spoke in the backyard of a house assessed at $425,000, according to The St. Petersburg Times, in the Snell Isle area.
Mr. Dole's campaign is looking ahead to the Presidential debates, which the two campaigns plan to discuss on Thursday. Mr. Dole told reporters he was pleased that the White House had signed up former Senator George Mitchell of Maine to play him in practice sessions with Mr. Clinton.
"We're pretty good friends," Mr. Dole said of the former majority leader. "Maybe he'll help me out."
The Dole campaign has asked Senator Fred Thompson of Tennessee, a jolly Southerner and former actor, to play the part of Mr. Clinton.
At a "listening" session in Fayetteville, Ga., about 30 miles from downtown Atlanta, Mr. Dole said, "I believe education must be the centerpiece, or the keystone, or call it what you will, of the new Dole-Kemp administration."
But the specifics of his plan for a new G.I. Bill were for another day. Standing on a dusty platform in front of a $129,000 house under construction, Mr. Dole's setting was to reinforce his theme that his tax-cut proposal would help "Main Street America" buy houses by keeping interest rates "low and stable."
Aides said the idea behind the "listening" sessions was to show Mr. Dole not in a blue suit and not in front of a podium -- his standard portrait for the last three decades as he represented Kansas in the Senate. But as he took questions from about a dozen of the 60 supporters, he seemed preoccupied with his Senate career, suggesting at one point that he left Capitol Hill in June because voters no longer trusted politicians.
Mr. Dole recalled his tenure as chairman of the Senate Finance Committee in trying to create enterprise zones. He then veered to farming and noted that he had served on the Senate Agriculture Committee longer than anyone else, leading him to conclude, "So I understand a little about peanut programs and other things I know are very important."
Mr. Dole also painted a bleak economic outlook in his continuing effort to convince voters that, despite relatively positive economic indicators, they are not as well off as Mr. Clinton would have them believe.
"What we have now is stagnating wages, we have job insecurity, the slowest expansion since the last century," Mr. Dole said. "We've had over 270,000 layoffs in the first half of 1996 -- that's 20 percent higher than the same period a year ago and the biggest job loss of this decade."
Afterward, as he shook hands with people in the crowd of about 150 who were roped off to the side of the platform, a man asked him why interest rates were the lowest they had been in seven years. Mr. Dole did not respond.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE THIRD PARTY;
Perot Attacks Political Process as 'Destructive'

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Beleaguered by low standings in public opinion polls, Ross Perot blasted American politics today as "negative, bitter, mean-spirited and destructive."
"I ask the American people to refuse to be manipulated by dirty negative politics and propaganda in 1996," Mr. Perot, the Reform Party Presidential candidate, said in his bitterest attack yet on politics in the campaign. 
 On arriving here today from Texas, Mr. Perot was greeted with a local poll that matched his nationwide decline during the last two months. Conducted by EPIC/MRA, the poll indicated that Mr. Perot's support among Michigan voters had tumbled from 19 percent in July to 10 percent in August to 4 percent last week. In the latest New York Times/CBS News trial heat, which was conducted Aug. 10-18, Mr. Perot stood at 8 percent.
"It doesn't appear that Perot is catching on the way he was four years ago," said Karlyn Bowman, a resident fellow in public opinion at the American Enterprise Institute. "He may get a bounce when he announces his Vice President, but I doubt it."
Mr. Perot said today that he would announce his Vice-Presidential selection on Tuesday, in a 30-minute "infomercial" that will be broadcast on CBS at 8 P.M. Eastern time.
That candidate "has the background, the experience and the qualifications," Mr. Perot said after his speech here before the Economic Club of Detroit.
Returning repeatedly in the speech to lambaste the American political process, Mr. Perot used harsh language to contrast his sharply differing views of the world of business and of politics.
"Business is conducted on a rational basis and has generally accepted ethical standards," the self-made billionaire said before a generally supportive audience of about 1,000 business people. "Politics is not conducted on an ethical basis, and there are no rules of conduct or ethical standards. War has rules. Mud-wrestling has rules. Politics has no rules. If you question that, watch television."
"In business, you have to deal with reality," Mr. Perot said, his voice rising. "In politics, you don't deal with reality. You have a blend of magic acts and illusions. Now you see it, now you don't."
"In politics, people get selected and promoted on the basis of their acting ability and their appearance," said Mr. Perot, who has been repeatedly caricatured by cartoonists this summer as a jug-eared bantam running for President. "In business you select the best-qualified people to deliver results and you promote them based on performance."
While the major party politicians sing and dance at their conventions, Mr. Perot said, Americans face "the mother of all bankruptcies."
Rattling off statistics, Mr. Perot said the Federal Government has $1.7 trillion in unfunded pension liabilities and a mushrooming debt that was last clocked at around $5 trillion.
"If a fighter pilot saw these numbers on his instrument panel, he would eject -- we cannot eject," Mr. Perot said solemnly, re-using a laugh line that drew applause last week at an American Legion convention.
"Think about where the Mississippi River is, way over there on the east side of the United States," said the candidate, who spoke at a convention center on the shores of the Detroit River. "All the Federal income taxes collected west of the Mississippi River go just to pay interest on the debt.
"Neither of the two parties has the will to deal with these problems. Asking the Democrats and the Republicans to solve these problems is like going to a heart surgeon that just lost his last 32 patients and suggest that he do heart surgery on you."
Mr. Perot's message of fiscal responsibility struck a favorable note among many at the luncheon.
"This is the first political candidate that I've ever been excited about," said Suzanne Meyer, the owner of an engineering and architectural firm. "The main problem facing our nation is our deficit. We will go bankrupt at this rate."

HEADLINE: Netanyahu Needs Arafat as a Partner

BYLINE: By Stephen P. Cohen; Stephen P. Cohen is president of the Institute for Middle East Peace and Development.

DATELINE: MONTREAL

 BODY:
The next time President Clinton and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu meet -- as they did yesterday in Washington -- Yasir Arafat should be present. The partnership for peace must be forged.
The handshake between Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Arafat last week on the Gaza border was admittedly more symbol than substance. But the meeting was a highly significant event in Israeli political life, in the history of Mr. Arafat's movement and in the peace process itself. 
 When the main Israeli opponent of the 1993 Oslo accords meets the treaty's main Palestinian beneficiary, a new legitimacy emerges not only for the two leaders but also for the treaty itself. The debate that defined Israeli politics for 20 years has concluded: There is a Palestinian interlocutor, and it is Yasir Arafat.
For Mr. Arafat, who flashed a grin of satisfaction when he shook Mr. Netanyahu's hand, the meeting asserted the permanence of the change of Israeli-Palestinian history he made with Yitzhak Rabin and Shimon Peres. For Mr. Netanyahu, whose face showed grim discomfort, the encounter was a price of taking over the stewardship of the Rabin-Peres peace. He required the handshake to complete a transfer of power not to be fully achieved until he assumed the mantle -- and burden -- of this most fateful of Israel's relationships.
Criticized by all and for whom no one has an alternative, Mr. Arafat rallies from one apparent defeat to the next. Throughout, he holds to his "independence of decision," as he puts it, while changing tactics to keep the Palestinian movement alive under his leadership. He and the extremist Hamas have avoided crossing the fine line that separates vicious politics from civil war.
There is victory here as well for Mr. Netanyahu. American pressure, Egyptian warnings and Jordanian worries, even the dire assessments of his security establishment, cannot fully explain his decision to meet Mr. Arafat. Nor does the threat of another intifada, this one of despair, rather than of defiance. The decision flowed from the instincts of a Likud outsider who captured the party first, then the election.
He has now captured the flag of peacemaking for the Israeli right, whether it wants it or not. All the pressures made it easier to justify the handshake that helps solidify his own leadership. His ambition would not sustain a policy of inaction in which peace remained the property of his predecessors. He wants ownership of the process, and that means engaging Mr. Arafat.
But an interlocutor does not a partner make. Not yet. Not until the interlocutors can agree on more than an agenda and a procedure for meeting. Not until there are some first common steps and a strategic direction to the discussions. No doubt, Mr. Netanyahu will delay decisions and emphasize how different his way is from Rabin-Peres. Still, for Israel, and for the United States and the Arab world, there are no other options to progress in peace. Whenever peace seems moribund, the vacuum is filled by new instability.
The challenge now is to recognize that the deal required is not "land for peace" but "sovereignty for security." Can the Israeli right be persuaded to accept the emergence of a Palestinian nation led by Yasir Arafat, not only as interlocutor but as a partner in peacemaking?
It will surely be a kind of Zeno's paradox. Half of the half will go along, then half of that half, but never everyone. Some people most supportive of Mr. Netanyahu were hoping that he would destroy the Oslo pact with sweet words and sharp actions. They will feel betrayed, and the betrayed are the most implacable of opponents. The Prime Minister will require more than the skills of political maneuver. He will require the strength to change and to declare this change.
He starts his stewardship of the peace process with the conviction that he can find a form of Palestinian self-governance in the West Bank and Gaza so tempting that the Palestinians will forgo statehood and Jerusalem for it. Part of the temptation will be economic. Mr. Netanyahu has the opportunity to do much better than his predecessors here.
If he and Mr. Arafat can do without the closure of the West Bank and Gaza as a security and punitive measure, he will be way ahead in assuring peace under the accords. If he permits safe passage from Gaza to the West Bank, allows Palestinian seaport and airport development, the Palestinians will breathe more easily.
Still, that is not the essence. It is true that Israeli leaders are elected to serve the Israeli people, as Mr. Netanyahu says, paraphrasing Menachem Begin. But it is no less true that they also rule the Palestinian people. If Israel, for its own sake and its own interest, needs to relinquish that rule, its leaders will have to face up to the needs of that second nation. The partnership will have to be that Mr. Arafat rules the Palestinians.

HEADLINE: Out of the Rat Race and Into the Kitchen

BYLINE: By SUZANNE KAPNER 

 BODY:
AS a foreign equity trader at a Wall Street firm, Laurie Bloom often worked until 4 A.M. in the international markets. Today, as an apprentice at the Ryland Inn, an acclaimed restaurant in Whitehouse, N.J., she is learning how to cut onions.
After working as the director of engineering for the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, Joe Mullady attends cooking classes at night at the New York Restaurant School in Manhattan. His goal is to open a bed and breakfast with his son, Daniel, 21, who is also a student there. 
 Ms. Bloom and Mr. Mullady are among the growing number of people who are trading the corporate world for the kitchen. They seek creative fulfillment, satisfaction in their work, greater mobility and, if they start their own businesses, control over their lives. All would rather cook or work with food than do anything else.
Most make the switch at considerable financial and personal sacrifice. They either dip into savings, take out student loans or live off a spouse's income for the time it takes to earn a culinary degree and find a job.
And jobs are plentiful. In the next 10 years, restaurants and hotels will need an additional 500,000 chefs, cooks and other kitchen workers -- an increase of 16 percent over current needs, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics.
"Each year we list 8,000 jobs," said Douglas Zander, the dean of enrollment and planning for the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y. "We only have a student population of 2,000. That's four times as many jobs as students."
The first job often means long hours, grueling labor and low pay. Still, those who have made the switch say working 60 hours a week for $8 an hour is worth the sacrifice if they can own their own business or advance through the ranks of the kitchen.
"People are tired of accommodating themselves to the traditional workplace," said Paula Rayman, an economist at Harvard University. "They may take a passionate hobby like cooking and turn it into a career."
Until recently, cooking was hardly considered a serious career move. Wayne Nish, the chef and owner of March on the East Side of Manhattan, remembers working as a cook while studying architecture at Cornell University in the 1970's.
"The only high-end restaurants I knew were French, and they didn't hire Americans," he said. Most cooks at the time fit the hash-slinger stereotype, he said, adding, "I couldn't imagine going into a career like that." He was a printer for five years until he could no longer resist the lure of the kitchen and enrolled in the New York Restaurant School in 1982.
During the 1980's food took a place somewhere between fashion and entertainment, spawning its own celebrities like the chefs Wolfgang Puck and Paul Prudhomme. Culinary studies began to be taken seriously.
"The power of advertising didn't hurt," said Douglas Friedman, who quit a 14-year career in the chorus of Broadway musicals and used his savings to attend the French Culinary Institute in Manhattan. Now in his first job, he is an assistant chef at Petrossian at $300 a week.
"They do a very good campaign," he said of the school's ads, which feature such well-known chefs as Andre Soltner, who teaches there.
But it doesn't take long for an aspiring cook to learn that the kitchen is anything but glamorous.
"It's a real eye-opener," said Jude Quintiere, a former television producer who took out a home equity loan to study at the French Culinary Institute in 1991. He went on to study pastry at Peter Kump's New York Cooking School, and then started a bakery, which he later sold.
His annual salary at first was about two-thirds the $52,000 he made in television, and he paid $500 a month in student loans. He and his wife, a doctor, depended on her salary for living expenses. Mr. Quintiere now earns $40,000 a year as head pastry chef at Firebird, a new restaurant in midtown.
Anne Rosenzweig was an anthropologist before she became a chef and opened Arcadia and the Lobster Club in Manhattan. Learning about food in other cultures sparked her interest, and led to apprenticeships in several New York kitchens. She agrees that the glamour factor is overrated.
"When it's 100 degrees in the summer and the air-conditioning in the kitchen blows and the waiter spills a bottle of wine on a customer, it sure would be nice to be out in the bush in Kenya doing field research," she said. "But I still feel it's one of the great all-time jobs. You get a chance to remake yourself every day. You can try new things, you're not limited and you have the instant gratification from the customer. How many people have a job like that?"
If culinary school enrollment is any indication, more people want jobs with those criteria and are willing to pay thousands of dollars to attend prominent schools in the hope that it will lead to the kitchen of a notable chef.
Geoffrey Silagy, who left his job as a foreign correspondent for Australian radio, paid $18,000 for a nine-month certificate in culinary arts from the French Culinary Institute. A two-year culinary arts degree at a state school would have cost him $16,000.
"What you pay for is their network," he said, which he credits for placing him at Verbena, in the Gramercy Park area, as an unpaid apprentice.
Newcomers to the kitchen often work for nothing for a few months to gain experience with prominent chefs, said Molly Chang, the school's director of marketing. From there, they often become prep cooks, working for an hourly wage. Low-level chef positions pay about $22,000, and with a few years' experience sous-chefs can earn $35,000 to $70,000. Executive chefs have earning potential in excess of $80,000.
"I'm willing to suffer for a few years to have my own place," said Mr. Silagy, who relies on his wife's salary and health benefits.
He was among 325 graduates this year, three-quarters of whom were embarking on a second career, said Sarah Cirrincione, the director of admissions at the French Culinary Institute.
At the New York Restaurant School, about 60 percent of the new students are switching careers, compared with about 40 percent four years ago, said Stephen Tave, director of admissions. They will pay $15,000 for a nine-month certificate in culinary arts, or $10,000 for a pastry arts certificate. Students who continue for another seven months can earn an associate of occupational studies degree, for a total of $25,000.
The Culinary Institute of America added a four-year program to its two-year degree in 1994, in response to the demand for chefs skilled in management and accounting. About 1,200 students enroll each year and pay $24,000 for a two-year program in culinary or pastry arts. About 150 go on to enroll in the four-year program.
Culinary Institute programs are full time, which can require students to give up jobs, take out loans and, in many cases, leave friends and family to move into dormitories. It's that type of commitment that often enables career changers to excel in their new field.
"The shining stars, the ones who got the highest grades and go on to successful careers, are often career changers," said Mr. Zander, the Culinary Institute dean. "They're serious about their purpose. They have to give up something to come here."
After 12 years in the computer business, Mark Metcalfe is finishing a two-year degree at the Culinary Institute, but has commuted almost every weekend to Virginia, where his wife lives. He could have gone to a less expensive school in Virginia, but he was attracted to the Culinary Institute's facilities, which include 36 kitchens, and its 50-year-old reputation.
"Leaving my wife was the hardest part about the whole thing," he said. "But we talked about it for six months first."
Some chefs, like Ms. Rosenzweig, forgo classes and head directly to the kitchen. Ms. Bloom, who works as an unpaid apprentice at the Ryland Inn, taught herself to cook and then convinced Craig Shelton, the Ryland chef, that she was proficient enough to be of use in the kitchen.
But it is difficult to land apprenticeships without some formal training. "Chefs want people who've gone to cooking school and have some experience," Mr. Friedman said. "Otherwise, you're worthless to them. How much time can they spend teaching you?"
But after cashing in 401(k)'s or dipping into savings, many career changers find that a smaller salary is only one adjustment in their lives. After coming close to the apex of their first career, it can be hard to adjust to life at the bottom.
Ms. Bloom said that as a trader, her word was law. "Now, if I say something in the kitchen, I'm nobody," she said. "You think cutting an onion is a basic thing. There are 100 ways you could cut it."

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
High-tech features bring a turnaround to a downtown building, after five vacant years.

BYLINE: By Mervyn Rothstein 

 BODY:
A LITTLE more than a year after the Rudin Management Company began spending $15 million to renovate a vacant 400,000-square-foot office building at 55 Broad Street, installing the latest telecommunications equipment, more than 60 percent of the downtown building, now known as the New York Information Technology Center, is spoken for.
William C. Rudin, president of Rudin Management, said that 37 leases had been signed and that 12 leases were out for signing, for a total of 250,000 square feet. Half the signed tenants have moved in, Mr. Rudin said. 
 These are among the most recent leases:
Sun Microsystems Inc., the developer of the Java computer language, has taken 7,000 square feet on the third floor for its professional services group -- its customer-assistance unit. Sun also has space in Manhattan at 1 New York Plaza, between Park and Broad Streets downtown, where it has recently completed an expansion. Kathryn Ridley of the real estate group at the company's headquarters in Mountain View, Calif., said 55 Broad Street had been chosen "because of its high-tech emphasis."
Cornell University has leased 5,541 square feet on the third floor for a Theory Center office, which Mr. Rudin said would be linked by fiber optic cables to the Cornell Theory Center in Ithaca, N.Y., home of the world's fastest general-use supercomputer. Larry Bernard, a Cornell spokesman, said the Manhattan space would be used to create an environment for virtual reality and to demonstrate to the Wall Street community the various uses of the supercomputer.
Prosoft, a company based in Buena Park, Calif., that specializes in Internet training, has leased 5,500 square feet, also on the third floor, for a training center. "New York City's Economic Development Corporation guided Prosoft to the building and was very supportive," Mr. Rudin said.
Mr. Rudin has frequently credited Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Downtown Revitalization Plan -- which provides tax abatements to encourage development -- for contributing to the leasing success. The building is eligible for the abatement, so tenants will save thousands of dollars in taxes.
Mr. Rudin said the five-year leases had average annual rents "in the high teens" a square foot, "with no free rent."
The 30-year-old building, at Beaver Street south of the New York Stock Exchange, had housed the offices of Drexel Burnham Lambert. But after that investment banking concern went bankrupt, the building remained vacant for more than five years and a moribund downtown real estate market had diminished hope that it would come to life again.
Now, Mr. Rudin said, the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council has leased 2,000 square feet on the third floor. "The council has created Thunder Gulch, a consortium of artistic not-for-profit organizations, providing a residence facility for artists to become facile in new-media technology so they can provide on-site artistic content to tenants," he said.
In addition, he said, two current tenants, N2K and K-2 Design, have signed up for additional space. K-2, which has 5,700 square feet, is taking 2,500 more. And N2K (for Need to Know), which operates a music-entertainment site on the Internet and was the building's first tenant, "has already doubled its space to 21,000 square feet and is negotiating to double it again," Mr. Rudin said.

Kaplan Not Straying Far
After considering moving its United States corporate headquarters out of Manhattan, Kaplan Educational Centers, the test-preparation and educational services company, has decided to stay.
Kaplan, a subsidiary of the Washington Post Company, has leased about 46,000 square feet, part of the 21st and all of the 22d and 23d floors, at 888 Seventh Avenue, a 45-story, 866,000-square-foot office building at 57th Street. Kaplan will be moving from 810 Seventh Avenue, at 52d Street, and 444 Madison, at 49th Street, where it occupies a total of about 38,000 square feet, and is relocating down the block from Newsweek, another Washington Post subsidiary, which is at Broadway and 57th.
Financial details of Kaplan's new 10-year lease were not disclosed, but the asking annual rent for the space was $29 a square foot.
"The people who own Kaplan really wanted to take a hard look at moving outside New York," said Scott Gottlieb, who represented Kaplan with Michael Laginestra and Alan Desino, his colleagues at the Edward S. Gordon Company, and with Peter Riguardi and Edward DiTolla of Colliers ABR. "They didn't feel that New York was necessarily the right place for them, so they looked at New Jersey and Westchester."
But after going through the process, Mr. Gottlieb said, "they realized that the depth of talent they require wasn't easily accessible in New Jersey and Westchester, and they decided -- based on the talent pool in New York, the variety of people and backgrounds -- that they belonged here and wanted to stay in midtown."

A Midtown Space Half Full
Almost 40,000 of nearly 80,000 square feet of space formerly occupied by Dow Jones & Company at 420 Lexington Avenue, the Graybar Building at 42d Street, has been sublet. The space became available when Dow Jones moved several divisions, including the advertising departments of Barron's Financial Weekly and The Wall Street Journal, to 1155 Avenue of the Americas, at 44th Street.
Dimac Direct, a mail-order company, sublet 21,086 square feet; Akam Associates, a residential property-management concern, took 8,640 square feet; Quantum Management, an executive recruiting company, leased 6,415, and GRS Systems, a video production company, took 3,730. Financial details of the leases, which expire in July 2001, were not disclosed, but asking annual rents for the space were $26 a square foot.
James P. Quinn of Cushman & Wakefield, who represented Dow Jones, said "serious discussions" were under way for the rest of the space.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Reaches 8-Week Highs Against Both Mark and Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar hit eight-week highs against both the German mark and Japanese yen yesterday, rising for the third consecutive session on continued expectations of an interest rate increase in the United States.
The dollar's strength was derived indirectly from a falling mark, which suffered from speculation that the German central bank would lower rates again. 
 The mark also fell against the French franc, the Japanese yen, the Italian lira and the British pound as expectations grew that formation of the European monetary union would meet its timetable.
Traders had favored the mark, Europe's strongest currency, when expectations were low on progress toward creating a single European currency.
But a German monetary official said yesterday that his country would meet budget expectations in 1997, which would help it meet strict criteria for joining the monetary union by 1999.
"You had profit taking on the mark, making it a good opportunity to get into the dollar," said Margaret Kudarauskas, a senior foreign exchange analyst at Technical Data in Boston.
In late New York trading, the dollar traded at 1.5112 marks, up from 1.4995 marks Monday. The dollar also traded at 109.80 yen, up from 109.26 yen.
In intraday trading, the dollar reached 1.5117 marks and 109.95 yen. It was the highest level for the dollar since July 16, when it hit 1.5158 marks and 110.26 yen.
The British pound traded at $1.5545, down from $1.5570.
Traders said the dollar benefited from the strong United States jobs data issued Friday, which raised prospects for higher American interest rates, something that could increase demand for American assets.
The dollar also gained from comments by Germany's chief central banker Monday in favor of a stronger dollar and from indications on Monday that France would also meet the budgetary requirements necessary to join the monetary union.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, were: 1.2359 Swiss francs, up from 1.2228; 5.1555 French francs, up from 5.1110; 1,520 Italian lire, up from 1,510; 1.3700 Canadian dollars, unchanged.

HEADLINE: Gas Tax Could Help Our Cities

BYLINE: By Felix G. Rohatyn; Felix G. Rohatyn, a managing director at Lazard Freres, investment bankers, was chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation from 1975-93.

 BODY:
A decade ago, in response to the abysmal state of New York City's public school buildings, the Municipal Assistance Corporation, with the support of Mayor Edward I. Koch and Gov. Mario Cuomo, committed $400 million of its surplus funds to creating a new School Construction Authority. This became the cornerstone of a five-year, $4.5 billion construction program aimed at providing decent schools and allowing for increasing enrollments over the next few years.
Yet today the system is more overcrowded than ever. The buildings are often decrepit and, in many cases, dangerous for the children and the teachers. In part, this is the result of poor management by the construction authority, and could be helped by holding year-round classes and moving students to less-crowded schools around the city. 
 But most of the problems are the result of the city's and the state's budgetary constraints and their limits on the ability to issue additional debts.
In 1994, Ramon Cortines, then the Schools Chancellor, and the city's Commission on School Facilities and Maintenance Reform, led by Harold O. Levy, submitted a $7.5 billion five-year capital request. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, struggling with the city's budget gap, gradually reduced this to $2.9 billion.
This summer, Mayor Giuliani and Peter Vallone, the speaker of the City Council, agreed to provide an additional $1.4 billion to schools over the next five years. This will help, but there will still be a significant shortfall.
Such problems are not limited to New York City or to schools. Practically every large city and state face deteriorating schools, roads, bridges, mass transit systems, sewers and pollution-control plants. Few have the money to make repairs or build anew, and many have legal restrictions on their debt capacity. They need Federal assistance -- specifically, a program that would return an existing source of Federal revenue over to state and local governments.
During the Presidential campaign, the 4.3 cent-a-gallon increase in the gas tax that was included in President Clinton's 1993 budget package has come under attack. Repealing it would be bad energy policy and bad economic policy. But it is worth considering a better use for the gas tax than Federal deficit reduction: making it available to state and local governments for public investment.
Localities could spend the money directly on construction and renovation, or leverage the funds with secured borrowing. State and city governments have been cutting back on public investment because of budgetary problems and legal limits on their abilities to issue bonds.
The income from a 4.3 cent Federal gasoline tax has the benefit of being highly predictable. It would provide about $5 billion to states every year, making it ideal for very long-term bonds issued for public investment.
Nationwide, this could comfortably support from $75 billion to $100 billion in new programs by state and local governments over five years, assuming that they would pay an additional 20 percent to 25 percent of the cost beyond their take of the gasoline tax.
With its share, New York State could generate $5 billion to $7 billion over the period. Each state would decide how best to use the money, but a significant portion would be committed to new schools and education technology.
Such a program could result in more than buildings. It could create at least two million new jobs, public and private. Most would likely be well-paying jobs related to construction; others would be less-specialized jobs that could be opportunities for young people who need a chance to break the cycle of welfare.
Under the new Federal law, finding work for welfare dependents is a hidden time bomb for state governments.
 Yes, the money will be lost to the Federal Treasury. But replacing $5 billion each year in a $1.5 trillion Federal budget is a small challenge compared with the benefits of $100 billion of additional investment in cities over five years. The program would undoubtedly receive strong support from mayors and governors, Republicans and Democrats, business and labor.
A program that would give city and state governments $75 billion to $100 billion would provide only a fraction of the more than $2 trillion needed nationwide for public improvements. But, if successful, the program could be extended and increased over time.
President Clinton has recognized the need for Federal assistance to state and local governments by signing a bill sponsored by Senator Carol Moseley Braun, Democrat of Illinois, providing interest rate subsidies for local school construction. This was a good beginning, but it is not nearly enough.
Mr. Clinton has long called for greater public investment, yet neither party has put forward a program to meet the challenges facing urban America.
Turning the revenue from the gas tax into schools and other badly needed public buildings would be a large part of Bill Clinton's bridge to the 21st century.

HEADLINE: A Watershed Agreement

 BODY:
The formal agreement announced yesterday to clean up the 2,000-square-mile watershed that supplies New York City with its drinking water is a triumph of good sense over seemingly insurmountable grievances. The agreement ends years of upstate-downstate hostility, and if all goes well it will spare the city the need to build a $6 billion filtration system it can ill afford.
Under the plan, the city will spend about $275 million to acquire thousands of acres of land from willing sellers to serve as buffer zones around its reservoirs. It will spend an additional $1.2 billion to upgrade or build sewage treatment plants near streams that feed the reservoirs, repair many of the region's 128,000 septic tanks and underwrite innovative conservation programs. 
 To appreciate the importance of the agreement -- and why it took so long to achieve -- it is necessary to recall some complicated history. New York City has long had the power to regulate development around its 19 upstate reservoirs. But the city did not exercise that power for many years, and local residents naturally got the idea that they could do whatever they wanted. Commercial development proceeded rapidly, water quality declined, and in 1989 the Federal Environmental Protection Agency ordered the city to clean up the watershed or build a filtration plant.
When the city then decided to use its powers to control land use, outraged upstate residents filed a series of lawsuits that effectively blocked any efforts to improve water quality. Enter Gov. George Pataki, who convened all the players -- city officials, environmentalists and representatives of the Coalition of Watershed Towns, which deeply resented what it regarded as the city's highhanded ways. Seven months of hard bargaining were required to reach a conceptual framework, 10 months more to iron out the details.
The agreement, which will be administered by essentially the same coalition of forces, is not wholly satisfactory to some environmentalists, who complain that it allows for too many new sewage treatment plants, thus inviting harmful new development. On balance, however, it is hard to see a serious downside to this deal. The city's huge investment in pollution control will give upstaters an economic transfusion. New Yorkers will continue to receive inexpensive, high-quality drinking water. Water rates might rise a bit, but the ultimate cost to consumers and taxpayers will be far less than the cost of building a filtration plant.
Governor Pataki deserves a lot of credit, as do various environmental groups, city officials and the E.P.A., which kept the pressure on. The watershed residents themselves merit a special bow for sacrificing local commercial ambitions to the larger goal of environmental quality.

HEADLINE: The New Clinton Health Panel

 BODY:
President Clinton had a transparent political motive in announcing that he would appoint a commission to examine how well modern health-care plans treat patients. Florida, where he made the announcement, is full of elderly voters nervous about what health-care reforms mean for them. But whatever the President's motive, the commission is a constructive idea.
The spread of health maintenance organizations, which now cover more than 60 million Americans, has slowed the increase in health-care costs. But the growth of the managed-care approach has created anxiety about whether patients are being denied treatments in order to lower the costs of health-care companies. By riveting attention on quality of care, an impartial commission can calm needless fears and weed out bad practices. 
 Managed care, by charging a fixed fee no matter how much or how little is done for the patient, builds a wedge of distrust because the plan profits, in the short term, by doing less for its patients. So far, studies show that typical managed-care programs have not compromised on quality of care, and in fact have brought forth quality-improving innovations. But some plans have fueled distrust by devoting more attention to managing costs than care. Indeed, there have been cases of egregious shortcuts. State legislatures in turn have overreacted by shackling managed-care plans, driven by potent lobbying by physicians and insurers who profit from traditional systems.
A properly organized commission can prevent the rush to needless legislation and unnecessary regulation, and can help eliminate abuses. Equally important, it can help educate citizens about changes in the health-care system already made or needed in the future. One lesson of the failed Clinton effort at health-care reform was that constructive change cannot take place without wider public awareness and involvement.
Some opponents of the commission have argued that there are already responsible organizations monitoring quality. But most are controlled by the very industry they purport to monitor. Besides, quality assessment is in its infancy. The commission can bring impartial judgment to the task and propel both industry and government to make faster headway. It could also prod all health plans, whether traditional or managed-care, to assume the responsibility of collecting easy-to-compare data on their treatment practices and health outcomes.
The President was thinking about Nov. 5 and Florida's electoral votes when he decided to appoint a panel. But if he appoints the commission judiciously, it could help renew the chances of building an effective and economical health-care system.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Corporations are spending travel dollars cautiously these days.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
AFTER the usual summer slowdown, business travelers will soon be back in force at airports, hotels and rental-car offices -- but apparently not in the record numbers that have marked business and leisure travel throughout 1996. Business travel this fall is projected to drop to its lowest level in at least five years, according to a forecast from the Travel Industry Association of America, based on a telephone survey of 1,500 adults in the United States.
Only 24 percent of travelers said they were somewhat or very likely to travel for business this fall, compared with 26 percent last fall and 29 percent in 1992, the highest level since the association began tracking business travel. 
 "This is the result of a cautious corporate climate," said William S. Norman, the president of the association, "characterized by leaner staffs and executives who have saturated schedules, compounded by the fact that they have absorbed more of the business travel demands since downsizing began."
But with 60 percent of American travelers likely to take a pleasure trip this fall, the same as last fall, airlines, hotels and travel agents warn that he who hesitates in making reservations may have to settle for a second choice.
 
Gains for T.W.A.
The crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 on July 17, which killed all 230 people aboard, appears to have had little if any adverse economic impact on the airline. Not only did average seat occupancy, or "load factor," rise to 74.5 percent in July from 71.8 percent in July 1995, the number of miles flown by paying passengers also increased 12.8 percent. And August was similarly strong for T.W.A. Passenger volume last month increased 9.8 percent over August 1995, while the carrier's 74.2 percent load factor was up slightly from 74.1 percent over August 1995.
Even though Flight 800 had been Paris-bound, T.W.A.'s international traffic increased by 10,200 last month, to 225,400 passengers from 215,200 the previous August.
While T.W.A. lags well behind AMR's American Airlines and UAL's United Airlines in the percentage of business travelers, in large part because of its smaller route system and fleet, many business travelers to the Midwest fly T.W.A., which has its main hub in St. Louis. And a T.W.A. spokesman, John McDonald, said the carrier had not noticed any falloff among business travelers since the July crash.
Jack O'Neill, corporate vice president of airline partnerships at Maritz Travel Company in Fenton, Mo., the nation's fifth-largest travel agency, said Maritz's bookings on T.W.A. rose almost 10 percent last month over the previous August. The reason, he said, was that there had been a strong demand for travel all this year. "But the business community also realizes that T.W.A. has always had a strong record on safety and maintenance," he added.
Meanwhile, T.W.A. recently added nonstop flights between its St. Louis hub and Austin, Tex.; New Orleans, and Hartford. In each case, flight times are designed primarily to enable travelers to get to those cities and back on the same day.
 
Confess, and Win
It is not every day that honesty about one's dishonesty can result in a free round-trip ticket for two to Rio de Janeiro, plus a five-day stay at a luxury Rio hotel. And in this case it is not even necessary to return the loot. Read on.
To celebrate its 50th anniversary, the Saison Group's Inter-Continental Hotels and Resorts is declaring an amnesty and a contest for guests who may have taken a keepsake from any of its hotels from April 1946 to April 1996. Keepsakes range from the familiar ashtrays, towels and tableware to patio furniture, art work and a large carved wooden Tiki, a representation of a Polynesian god, that once guarded the swimming pool in a South Pacific hotel.
Guest must enter by Dec. 31 and need only submit a photo and brief description of their ill-gotten gains, along with the approximate date, place and circumstances. For a copy of the official rules, write to: Souvenir Sweepstakes Rules, Suite 2120, 380 Lexington Avenue, NewYork, N.Y. 10168.
 
Airlines Update
Western Pacific Airlines, the low-cost airline whose 15 planes are adorned with the logos of gambling halls, hotels, rental cars, the Simpson cartoon characters and Colorado Technical University, recently inaugurated nonstop service between Colorado Springs and Orlando, Fla. The carrier, which has been operating for a year and a half, serves 22 cities and has nonstop service between Colorado Springs and Newark, Washington, Los Angeles and San Francisco.
On Nov. 15, America West Airlines will begin daily nonstop service between Phoenix and Miami and Las Vegas, Nev., and Miami.
In an effort to beef up its schedule for business travelers, Continental Airlines will begin three nonstop flights a day on Oct. 1 between Houston and Chicago's Midway Airport, and will add a fourth daily flight on Oct. 27. Also on Oct. 27, Continental will add another daily flight between Houston and Chicago's O'Hare International Airport, bringing its total on that route to 11.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Fall as Yield Hits 7.11%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities sagged yesterday after comments by Federal Reserve officials led to heightened anxiety over how much the Fed is likely to increase rates.
With inflation and retail numbers only a couple of days away, traders were doubly apprehensive. The price of the 30-year bond dropped 15/32, to 95 19/32; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, climbed to 7.11 percent, from 7.07 percent on Monday. 
 Traders said that the gains by the market over the last two sessions had left it ripe for consolidation, and comments made by Janet L. Yellen, a Federal Reserve governor, in a Reuters news wire interview yesterday, supplied an excuse for some to take profits. Ms. Yellen basically said that the economy had entered an inflationary danger zone, with the labor market quite tight. While she did see economic growth slowing, she said the timing and the extent of the slowdown were uncertain.
Her comments reinforced beliefs that the central bank is likely to raise interest rates when its policy-making committee meets in two weeks. Later she was on the wires again saying that her mind was not made up as far as tightening credit and that her earlier comments did not represent a change in her view. But some analysts said the anxiety raised by the first remarks remained.
Ken McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a market research analysis firm, said that Ms. Yellen's comments afforded the market an excuse to sell after two strong days.
Mr. McCarthy also noted that another Fed governor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, was also quoted on the wires yesterday afternoon; he said that the jury was still out on an interest rate increase.
"He left the impression that he's not convinced that inflation is a problem," Mr. McCarthy said. "Right now the market is trading technicals and waiting for Thursday and Friday's releases of economic numbers, with the focus on Friday, when August consumer price and retail sales data are due.
"I sort of got the feeling on Monday that market sentiment had moved from a 50-basis-point rate increase to maybe 25 basis points after last Friday's employment report," Mr. McCarthy continued. "But with comments by Yellen and Lindsey, a number of people are again beginning to think 50 basis points. Personally, I don't think the Fed will move on Sept. 24, when the Federal Open Market Committee meets. I still don't think there is enough evidence of inflationary pressures." A basis point is one-hundredth of a percent point.
Economic data released yesterday included the July wholesale trade report, which showed huge sales increases in both nondurable and durable goods. The upward revisions to productivity and the downward revision to unit labor costs provided signs that wage costs were not as big a threat in the second quarter as had been originally perceived.
Other data yesterday included the Lynch, Jones & Ryan Inc. Redbook retail sales report. Many expected to see the index up between half a percent and nine-tenths of 1 percent for the first week of September. The index came in lower than expected, up one-tenth of 1 percent from August, but it was not enough to halt the selling pressure.
The Chase Manhattan Bank priced $1.52 billion of asset-backed securities yesterday. Divided into two parts, the triple-A rated securities, which are backed by auto loans, were priced by a group of underwriters led by Chase Securities.
The largest portion of the offering includes $1.478 billion of class A securities that are priced with a 6.61 percent coupon to yield about 6.72 percent, 42 basis points over a comparable Treasury. The remaining $45.73 million of class B securities, rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard & Poor's, with a 6.76 percent coupon, were priced to yield 6.87 percent, or 57 basis points above a comparable Treasury.

HEADLINE: Tax Money Flowing Again, California Pares Class Size

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 10

 BODY:
While overcrowding in classrooms has characterized the start of the school year across the country, California is bucking the trend by rushing to pare class size by next semester.
Financed by a windfall of tax money from an improving state economy, California is asking its 5,000 elementary schools to cut the size of the classes for one teacher in the primary grades, kindergarten through third, to 20 pupils from the state average of 30 by next February. If they do, they will qualify for an extra $650 per child. 
 The $1 billion program, signed into law in July by Gov. Pete Wilson, is the result of a 1988 voter initiative that requires additional money be spent on education during periods of state budget surplus. This year's was the first surplus since then.
"Putting fewer students in classes is a very exciting change for California," said Delaine Eastin, the state superintendent of schools. "It's what the people have wanted for a very long time and I honestly think it is the best investment for this money at this time."
The biggest obstacles are recruiting about 20,000 new teachers and finding enough empty classroom space in schools already crowded.
The first classes to be reduced in size are first and second grades; educators say the importance of individual instruction in reading is paramount for later success in school. Once those classes are cut, schools can then reduce teacher loads in kindergarten and third grade.
California's initiative follows years of shrinking education budgets and years of declining student performance. The state dropped from the fifth highest spending per pupil in the nation in the mid-1960's to 42d last year. And, with an influx of students who speak English as a second language, the state saw its fourth graders tie with Louisiana for last place in the reading test given as part of the 1994 National Assessment of Educational Progress.
Here in the sprawling 650,000-student Los Angeles Unified School District, all 425 elementary schools are scrambling to meet the deadline.
Gledhill Elementary School, a predominantly Hispanic and Asian school with a large contingent of nonnative English-speaking students in the North Hills section, has already cut the size of many classes.
On a recent day, Luiza Cazazian, a second grade teacher, was leading her students in a writing exercise about why summer is fun. She moved without haste among the raised hands, offer spelling help on things like on Sea World to one child, and then she beamed about how much easier it was to deal with 20 students, instead of 32.
"Last year, I remember doing an assignment like this and I would be at that round table and I would have a line of kids coming to me asking questions, rather than me being able to circulate," Ms. Cazazian said. "It was just too hard. They would just follow me around."
One difficulty with meeting the plan is finding new teachers. The state education department estimates that while nearly 20,000 additional instructors are necessary to meet the goal the state's colleges graduated only 5,000 credentialed teachers last year.
Recruiters in the Los Angeles district have advertised in out-of-state newspapers and held job fairs in Oregon and Ohio. But recognizing that troubled urban schools are tougher to staff than the neighboring schools in affluent communities, the district is expanding an internship program for people with college degrees but no formal classroom training. Gledhill hired five instructors this year under the program.
Among them is Annette Jensen, 38 years old, who had been laid off from her job with a food manufacturer. She now teaches first and second grades, sharing a classroom with another instructor. In her previous job, she developed tomato sauces for Nestle, and she looks forward to the time when she can use her science background to teach lessons on seeds, nutrition and plants.
"I had a three week intern-training program in classroom management during the summer, and I'm starting school-year courses next week," Ms. Jensen said, referring to the district's once-a-week night classes for interns. "Certainly this is not an occupation that is easy to go into, but there is great support."
Another obstacle size is the lack of vacant schoolrooms.
At Gledhill, a first grade class and special education course meet simultaneously in a tiny auditorium, with a a chalk board and bookcase temporarily serving as a room divider.
To cope, California schools have ordered nearly 8,000 prefabricated classroom structures, financed under a $200 million school expansion plan. But with such limited notice, many new buildings will not arrive until well after the February deadline, and perhaps not until summer.
In meantime, many schools are converting teacher lounges and cafeterias into classrooms or pairing teachers together. A few schools like Woodlawn Avenue School in Bell, Calif., southeast of downtown Los Angeles, have neither extra rooms or a grassy field for a portable classroom, and may need a waiver to reduce their tiny playgrounds beyond the size mandated by the state.
There is some debate over the costs of reducing class size. In 1988, a report by the Federal Department of Education said that money could be better spent on things like improving teaching methods.
But more current research contradicts this assertion, said Barbara Nye, the director of the Tennessee State University Center of Excellence, in Nashville, and the principal investigator on a study of the effects of reducing class size. The Tennessee study was conducted from 1984 to 1989 and compared student achievement in classes with 25 pupils against those with 17, between kindergarten and third grade.
It showed that by the third grade, students in small classes scored at the 62d percentile on a reading achievement test, seven points higher than children in the larger classes. By eighth grade, students who began their career in smaller classes passed the state's competency test at a higher rates, three percentage points, than students from larger elementary school classes.
"When people say reducing class sizes is expensive, I say it is an inexpensive replacement for remediation and learning difficulties," Ms. Nye said. "It is one of the most cost effective move to reduce educational costs."

Children in one class had a music lesson yesterday. (Ed Carreon for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Not Perfect, but Right

BYLINE: By Anthony Lake; Anthony Lake is President Clinton's national security adviser.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
This Saturday, the people of Bosnia will go to the polls to elect their national representatives. These elections are an essential step in bringing democracy to Bosnia. They are what the people want, and what Bosnia needs, to help its hard-won peace endure.
We should not, and we do not, expect the election to be perfect. Bosnia is only beginning to recover from four years of devastating war. But Bosnians, with the help of the international community and the NATO-led military force, have made important progress in creating the conditions for successful elections. 
 Freedom of movement is improving. Last week in the American sector alone -- the area around Tuzla in the north -- more than 100,000 people crossed the internal boundary between the Serb Republic and the Muslim-Croat federation, bringing the six-month total to more than 1.3 million crossings. And to allow more voices to be heard, a wide range of media outlets are operating, including more than 100 independent newspapers, dozens of radio stations and a nationwide independent television network.
Thirteen major parties representing all views are running slates of national candidates, and dozens more are taking part in individual races. Local election committees have been established to oversee voter registration. Some 70 percent of Bosnian refugees living outside the country have cast absentee ballots.
The overwhelming majority of Bosnians, whether Serb, Croat or Muslim, believe the elections are important. In a recent United States Information Agency poll based on nearly 4,000 face-to-face interviews throughout the country, more than 90 percent of respondents in each ethnic group said they intend to vote. Some 96 percent in each group said they believed they could vote for the party of their choice without fear of intimidation. And 83 percent of Muslims, 65 percent of Croats and 89 percent of Serbs said they believed it was better to vote now than to wait for improved conditions, because delay would only strengthen the forces of separatism.
These people know that the elections will allow the structure of a unified Bosnian state to come to life -- a parliament, a presidency and a constitutional court that will represent the interests of all Bosnians, including the hundreds of thousands of refugees and displaced people.
The elections will enable government agencies to operate again, hastening the day when Bosnia will function as a normal, stable nation. These institutions will require practical, daily interaction among Bosnia's Muslims, Croats and Serbs. That is the best way to break the status quo of division, weaken the forces of extremism and bring Bosnians together to rebuild their land.
Those who argue that elections would hasten partition fail to explain how delaying elections could make things better. Besides, those of us who wave democracy's banner around the world cannot say that if you fear the results of an election, you should not hold it.
Of course, the elections are just one part of the hard work needed to create a unified, peaceful, democratic Bosnia, and the Bosnians still have a long way to go.
Democratic institutions like the parliament and courts must be nurtured with the help of international advisers. A military balance of power must be achieved through the American-led program to equip and train the armed forces of the Muslim-Croat federation. A civilian police force must be trained. Refugees who fear returning to their homes, or who have no means to get back, must be helped, and economic reconstruction must be fostered.
The United States is committed to these efforts. As we continue to do our part to help realize the promise of the Dayton accords and to overcome the remaining serious challenges, we should not undervalue how far we have come. One year ago, war was raging in Bosnia, the worst bloodshed in Europe since World War II. Today, there is peace. Marketplaces are full of life, not death. Playgrounds belong to children, not to snipers. Women are no longer prey to mass rape and terror. Once-divided families are being reunited, and some refugees are slowly making their way back. Basic services -- running water, electricity and shelter -- are steadily being restored.
 But just as voters in a democracy are free to make their own choices, so must the people of Bosnia choose their future for themselves. In sending American troops to Bosnia, President Clinton made clear the point of this extraordinary international effort: to give the Bosnians breathing room to rebuild their lives and their land -- and to give peace a life and logic of its own. He made equally clear what is not the point: to take on responsibilities that are not ours or to create in Bosnia an unsustainable dependence on the United States or other outsiders.
After so much bloodshed and loss, there can be no guarantee that Bosnia's Muslims, Croats and Serbs will join together, and stay together, as citizens of a shared state with a common destiny. The whole point of the Dayton accord was to give them a chance to try. This weekend, the Bosnian people are putting their faith in the ballot over the bullet.

HEADLINE: Watershed Protection Agreement Is Praised

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Federal officials yesterday strongly endorsed a comprehensive water-protection agreement reached by New York City, the state, and dozens of communities ringing the city's upstate reservoirs, saying the agreement would put off until at least 2002 a threatened Federal order to build a multibillion-dollar filtration plant.
At a news conference with Gov. George E. Pataki, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and a host of regional politicians, Carol M. Browner, the administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, said the agreement "offers the promise of protecting public health while saving billions of dollars for ratepayers." 
 The prospect of a Federal order to build the filtration plant, projected to cost New York City up to $6 billion, has been a financial sword of Damocles dangling since 1993, when the E.P.A. began to grow concerned with rising development and pollution threats around the city's biggest reservoirs, in the Catskills and the Delaware River Valley.
The city is already under a Federal order to build a smaller $600 million plant for water from reservoirs east of the Hudson River. No other large American city has an unfiltered water supply, but the natural filtering properties of New York City's watersheds had long been considered ample protection.
Standing shoulder to shoulder, Mr. Pataki, the Mayor and officials from several upstate counties and a coalition of tiny rural towns pledged to press their constituents to embrace the plan. They said the benefits would far outweigh the burdens.
The agreement would force upstate communities to abide by new rules imposed by New York City, but would also commit the city to spending more than $260 million to buy thousands of acres within the watersheds and $396 million to support economic development in the Catskills and stanch pollution from sewage plants and other upstate sources.
The agreement -- far thicker than the Manhattan Yellow Pages -- was the result of 10 months of negotiations involving the city, state, Federal officials and lawyers for upstate communities. It mushroomed from a 10-page agreement in principle that was released with much fanfare last November. At that time, it was thought that details could be ironed out in six weeks, said Michael C. Finnegan, Mr. Pataki's counsel and the chief shepherd of negotiations.
Mr. Pataki and Mr. Giuliani said the deal -- after 60 days of public review -- would free the city to buy thousands of acres to serve as a buffer to pollution. The state had previously opposed city plans to buy land, saying they did not preserve the rights of landowners and upstate communities.
The agreement also includes the first changes in 43 years to rules controlling development in the watersheds. When a draft of proposed changes was first released by the City Department of Environmental Protection six years ago, a firestorm of protest -- and a host of lawsuits -- erupted in watershed towns, where the rules were seen as an attack on home rule and a burdensome intrusion. More than a dozen lawsuits would be ended by the pact.
Yesterday, as the plan was unveiled in Mr. Pataki's Manhattan offices, representatives from a sprinkling of Catskills towns sat in a large cluster on one side of an aisle -- resembling a family attending an out-of-town wedding. After decades of fighting New York City in individual battles over land condemnation, a lack of taxes from city-owned land, the deterioration of city-owned sewage plants and bridges, the decision of 34 towns to band into a coalition in 1993 had clearly paid off, said Georgianna Lepke, the Town Supervisor from Neversink.
Deep in the details of the plan were several points that would help her community, Ms. Lepke said. The city's plans to acquire up to 350,000 acres would be limited to "willing buyer, willing seller" purchases, she said, in contrast to decades past, when the city acquired whatever it wanted, flooding dozens of towns and relocating homes and cemeteries.
Several environmental groups joined yesterday in endorsing the plan, including the Hudson Riverkeeper Fund, represented by Robert F. Kennedy Jr., an environmental lawyer. Standing next to Mr. Kennedy, Perry Shelton, the Town Supervisor from Tompkins, marveled at the breadth of support for the plan.
"I remember when I said I wouldn't sit next to an environmentalist," Mr. Shelton said.
Other environmental groups remained skeptical of the plan yesterday, saying that it may still allow too much development in the hills draining into the reservoirs.
"Hopefully, this is the start of meaningful public review," Eric A. Goldstein, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said. The private environmental group, not included in the talks, had criticized the evolving plan for allowing the construction of some new sewage treatment plants in the watersheds. Any increase in sewage treatment capacity potentially spurs new development, and eventually new pollution, Mr. Goldstein said.

HEADLINE: Index of Semiconductor Demand Showed a Slight Rise Last Month

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 10

 BODY:
The semiconductor industry's leading indicator rose slightly last month, reflecting a modest increase in orders, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today.
The association said the book-to-bill ratio, which measures new orders against shipments, rose to 0.90 in August from a revised 0.86 in July. 
 The August figure means that for every $100 in shipments, semiconductor makers received $90 in new orders. A ratio above 1.00 normally means demand for computer chips is expanding while a number below that means that demand is slowing.
Industry analysts had expected the ratio to be between 0.86 and 0.92. The July ratio was revised slightly from 0.85.
The association said new orders rose nine-tenths of 1 percent last month, to $2.84 billion from $2.82 billion in July. The gain was offset by a continuing decline in billings, which fell 3.2 percent, to $3.15 billion in August from $3.26 billion in July.
Compared with last year's levels, August chip orders were off 37.8 percent and billings were down 19.9 percent. The book-to-bill ratio in August 1995 was 1.16.
The semiconductor industry has been hurt this year by a glut in computer chips, particularly in the memory market.
In recent months a number of chip makers have scaled back expansion plans or halted construction of new plants until the market improves.
Analysts say August is usually the weakest month of the year because many manufacturers shut down for vacation. Thus, an increase in orders during August could signal the beginning of a cyclical upturn.
Many PC makers start shipping their products for the holiday season during the last two weeks of September, and most of them practice "just in time" inventory management, ordering semiconductors only days before they are needed on the assembly line.
The association said book-to-bill numbers in the other leading markets -- Japan, Asia and Europe -- remained higher than in North and South America. The final worldwide book-to-bill ratio for July, the latest period available, rose to 0.95 from 0.93 in June. Japan's book-to-bill ratio exceeded 1.02 in July.
