HEADLINE: Who's Punishing Whom?;
Trade Bans Are Boomerangs, U.S. Companies Say

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Corporate America is beginning to grumble. Allied Signal Inc. says the latest sanctions against Iran are costing it several million dollars a year in lost sales of aircraft parts. Caterpillar Inc. is circulating a map that spotlights countries where, it says, American sanctions throw up obstacles to the sale of Caterpillar's yellow tractors and earth-moving vehicles.
Trade sanctions have become ever more difficult to enforce in the world's huge and fluid marketplace, but the United States is invoking them with increasing frequency anyway. It is even adding an onerous new twist: punishing foreign companies for breaching American sanctions. 
 Now corporate America, usually unwilling to go against the nation's foreign policy, is preparing a rare formal protest against the latest trend. What worries many companies is not only the potential loss of customers in the sanctioned countries but also the possibility of retaliation by foreign governments and companies facing penalties under the new strategy of punishing foreigners.
An organization representing 500 of the nation's largest multinational corporations, the National Foreign Trade Council, has been meeting this week on the best ways to reverse or water down the latest sanctions. "We would like to see a more sober consideration of the consequences," said Daniel O'Flaherty, vice president of the council.
The embargo against Iraq is not at issue. Although instigated by the United States, this is an embargo sponsored by the United Nations, in which nearly every nation has agreed not to do business with Iraq until Saddam Hussein bends. American companies lose a market, but so do their foreign competitors, and the playing field remains level.
The issue is unilateral sanctions against a number of countries, like Iran, Libya and Nigeria, under which the Clinton Administration and Congress have closed off a market to American companies, but no other nation participates. As a result, foreign suppliers replace the Americans.
"All of a sudden unilateral sanctions are in vogue again," said Timothy Elder, Caterpillar's manager of governmental affairs, ticking off a half-dozen new ones in the last year. "I have no notion of how much we have already lost in sales, but we will probably crunch the numbers as we get engaged in a public policy campaign against this type of sanction. And we will get engaged."
The United States, as a superpower, has been the world's most frequent user of unilateral sanctions. The practice has been invoked more than 70 times since 1941, when the Roosevelt Administration halted oil and scrap metal shipments to Japan, hoping to curb that nation's military expansion. Pearl Harbor soon followed.
The heyday of the unilateral sanction came in the immediate postwar years, when the American economy was so mighty. But while sanctions against Iran in the early 1950's brought down the nationalist Mossadegh Government, and those against Britain and France in 1956 helped force their withdrawal from the Suez Canal region, such actions gradually lost their effectiveness as other countries became able to supply goods, credit, foreign aid and a marketplace for an offending country's products.
President Jimmy Carter, for instance, embargoed grain sales to the Soviet Union in 1980, hoping to force a Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan. But other nations broke ranks and sold grain to the Soviets, and the Afghan war continued. Like President Carter, Ronald Reagan and George Bush used unilateral sanctions frequently -- ineffectively more often than not, according to the Institute for International Economics in Washington, which compiled a study of their use.
When sanctions were successful, they were rarely unilateral. The ones against South Africa played an important role in ending apartheid, but mostly because other nations followed the American lead. The American ban on sales to the Soviet bloc of high-technology equipment used in advanced weaponry was largely successful, but mainly because the United States was the only source of much of this technology.
Nevertheless, the Clinton Administration, with bipartisan Congressional support, has made the unilateral sanction an important foreign policy tool once again.
"Therein is the great paradox," said Gary C. Hufbauer, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics, who led the study of economic sanctions through the decades. "While unilateral embargoes are less and less of an effective force in an integrated world economy, American enthusiasm for them has not diminished."
Current or recent targets include Iran, Libya, Serbia, Cuba, China, North Korea, Nigeria, Rwanda and Colombia. Legislation now before Congress would ban American investment in Myanmar, formerly Burma, because of its military dictatorship. With the collapse of the Soviet Union, the fear is gone that the Soviets could use an unpopular embargo to gain a foothold in a country like Myanmar, many experts say. And domestic politics clearly plays a role. "Sanctions can provide a satisfying theatrical display, yet avoid the high cost of war," Mr. Hufbauer wrote.
Two recent Government moves have angered American companies by taking the unilateral embargo a step further. Recent acts passed by Congress and signed by President Clinton have upgraded the embargoes against Cuba, Iran and Libya, banning not only American companies from these countries, but also punishing foreign corporations.
Foreign companies could be kept from doing business in the United States or with American companies if they invested more than $40 million in Iranian or Libyan oil or gas ventures. Or they could be sued for damages in American courts if they occupied Cuban properties once owned by American companies. The ban would apply only to properties occupied since the bill's passage, not in the 35 years since Fidel Castro nationalized American operations and the Eisenhower Administration responded with an embargo that applies to Americans to this day.
"The new extraterritorial sanctions may be more effective," a senior Administration official said, explaining the reason for President Clinton's support. "If a French company has to decide between doing business with Iran or the United States, it may prefer the United States."
But American companies are not so sanguine. Some multinationals worry that they may be cut off from further sales to, say, German or Turkish companies if those companies do business in Iran or Libya. That issue came up at a recent gathering of the National Association of Manufacturers.
Other American companies wonder what might happen if a subsidiary abroad somehow breaks the new laws, or foreign governments retaliate against American-owned subsidiaries in their countries.
"What the politicians forget," said Willard Workman, international vice president for the United States Chamber of Commerce, "is that these foreign companies are our customers and suppliers, or they invest in America. We are cutting off our nose to spite our face, presenting ourselves as capricious and unreliable."
So far, the sanctions have had only a modest effect on American business. Unilateral sanctions, by various estimates, have deprived the American economy of less than one-tenth of 1 percent of the nation's annual income in recent years. Like Caterpillar, individual corporations have refrained from publicly estimating the lost revenue from sales and investments that they could not engage in. Few companies, in fact, will attach their names to criticism of sanctions intended by the Administration and Congress to halt terrorism, restore democracy or reinforce human rights.
"We don't lobby against the embargoes, because we understand there are public-policy reasons that go above and beyond the corporate interest to the national interest," said Mark Greenberg, an Allied Signal vice president.
Still, Allied Signal used to supply replacement parts for Boeing 747's owned by Iran, and the company helped with the overhaul of those planes, so the embargo has cost it several million dollars in sales. That is a drop in the bucket for a corporation with $14 billion in annual revenues, but a sting nonetheless -- and one that might prevent Allied from regaining the business if the sanctions are lifted.
"Either the aircraft are not being maintained," Mr. Greenberg said, "or someone else is supplying Iran with the replacement parts. Probably the latter."
Rather than lobby themselves, corporations are turning to their trade associations. The Chamber of Commerce is outspoken. Officials at the National Association of Manufacturers say the organization is "formulating a strategy for dealing with the proliferation of sanctions." President Clinton's Export Council, made up of corporate executives acting as an advisory group, has warned that the costs to the United States in lost business "are clearly quite large."
The National Foreign Trade Council is taking the lead in lobbying against unilateral economic sanctions. Meetings are now in progress to develop a strategy, Mr. O'Flaherty said, and there should be a public announcement soon.
Caterpillar, among the nation's half-dozen largest exporters, is speaking out on its own, rather bluntly. "It is clear the world is not a more dangerous place than in the mid-80's," Mr. Elder said. "But policy makers have kind of decided they like unilateral sanctions. It is a quick and easy thing to do."
Caterpillar's map spotlights not only those countries subject to sanctions but also those denied export aid from the Export-Import Bank and similar help from other agencies. Donald V. Fites, Caterpillar's chairman, in an as-yet-unpublished opinion article, wrote of unilateral sanctions: "The real pressure is on the U.S. companies that not only must cede American jobs to foreign firms, but also risk being branded in other markets as unreliable suppliers."


GRAPHIC: Using economic sanctions to influence the behavior of other countries has a long history, dating back to ancient Athens. But sanctions have had decidedly mixed results. Here are examples from the last four decades.
 
U.S.TRADE EMBARGO OF CUBA (1962-present)
Chart: "Sanctions, Then and Now"
 OBJECTIVE -- Isolate and weaken Fidel Castro's Communist Government and bring about its downfall.
 RESULT -- Cuba's economy is in shambles, but Castro is still in power.
 
ARAB OIL EMBARGO OF U.S. (1973-74)
 OBJECTIVE -- Retaliate for United States support of Israel during the Yom Kippur War.
 RESULT -- Gasoline prices soared as shortages developed. Afterward, the United States continued to support Israel, but also became more attuned to Arab concerns.
 
U.S. GRAIN EMBARGO OF THE SOVIET UNION (1980-81)
 OBJECTIVE -- Force Soviet Union to withdraw its troops from Afghanistan.
 RESULT -- The embargo was lifted by President Reagan after it proved ineffective. The Soviets eventually withdrew, but not because of the embargo.
 
U.S. SANCTIONS AGAINST SOUTH AFRICA (1986-91)
 OBJECTIVE -- End apartheid, the policy of racial segregation.
 RESULT -- Congress formalized South Africa's isolation by passing strict curbs on doing business there. Though not the only factor, sanctions contributed to the election of a black-led Government.
 
WORLDWIDE SANCTIONS AGAINST IRAQ (1990-present)
 OBJECTIVE -- Force Iraq to withdraw its troops from Kuwait and weaken the Government of Saddam Hussein, Iraq's leader.
 RESULT -- Kuwait was freed, but only through military force. Sanctions have hurt Iraq, but Hussein is still in power.
 
U.S. SANCTIONS AGAINST FOREIGNERS DOING BUSINESS IN CUBA (1996)
 OBJECTIVE -- Discourage foreign companies from investing in Cuba, and so further weakening Castro's Government.
 RESULT -- Too early to tell.

HEADLINE: Stocks End Session Mixed; Dow Slips 6.66

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks were mixed yesterday, holding steady against rising interest rates in the bond market while enduring some profit taking from a two-session rally in blue-chip shares.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 6.66 points, to 5,727.18, with investors securing some profits from a combined jump on Friday and Monday of 126.88 points. That 2.2 percent advance had put the Dow within 45 points of its closing high of 5,778.00, set in late May. 
 Most broader measures closed slightly higher yesterday, but the market's moves were restrained by caution in advance of the release later this week of some key readings on inflation.
"The bulk of the market is stepping back and saying, 'Maybe I'll take a little money off the table and see what's going to happen with the inflation numbers,' " said Robert Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Van Kampen American Capital in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill.
Stocks were pressured throughout the day by the bond market, where prices fell after two strong sessions.
Bonds had been improving amid optimism that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates sharply to slow economic growth and keep inflation in check. Part of that enthusiasm was generated by Friday's report on August employment, which showed continued upward pressure on production costs, but fell within the range of expectations.
"The employment numbers weren't high enough to guarantee rates would be increased by the Fed, but it wasn't low enough to say we dodged the bullet completely," Mr. Froehlich said.
Rapid inflation makes the fixed-income payments on existing bonds less worthwhile, forcing down prices to create a bigger yield. As bond prices fell yesterday, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, a key determinant of borrowing costs, rose to 7.11 percent from 7.07 percent on Monday. Whether rates are pushed up by the Fed or by anxious traders, the increase can hurt stocks by slowing consumer spending and raising corporate operating costs.
There was little market reaction to a report showing that the annual rate of workplace productivity rose a half-percent in the April-June quarter. That was a better performance than forecast, but down from a much stronger 1.8 percent advance during the January-March quarter. Greater efficiency means businesses can increase wages without raising prices.
Analysts, though, said investors seemed more concerned with the reports due tomorrow and Friday on the pace of inflation at the wholesale and retail levels during August.
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a slim margin on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 373 million shares, up considerably from Monday's listless pace, which may have exaggerated that session's advance.
The New York Stock Exchange's composite index rose 0.21 point, to 356.49. The Standard & Poor Corporation's 500-stock index rose 0.05 point, to 663.81.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 0.72 point, to 1,149.43, and the American Stock Exchange's market value index rose 3.27 points, to 565.23.
The Dow's biggest decliners were economically sensitive issues, which endured profit taking after strong gains in the last two sessions. Caterpillar slipped 1 a share, to 72 1/2, and Alcoa fell 3/4, to 61 7/8.
Among stocks of Dow component companies, AT&T rose 5/8 a share, to 53 5/8; General Electric rose 3/8, to 86; I.B.M. rose 1/2, to 118 1/8, and Merck rose 1/2, to 67.

HEADLINE: Ex-Reagan Economic Aide Criticizes Dole Plan to Cut Taxes

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
A major architect and defender of Ronald Reagan's 1981 tax cuts broke ranks with Republicans and warned today against the much smaller reductions proposed by Bob Dole, the Republican Presidential nominee.
"I always worry that proposed tax cuts will not be offset by new expenditure cuts," said Murray L. Weidenbaum, who was President Reagan's chief economic adviser during his first two years in office. Ruefully alluding to his own role, Mr. Weidenbaum acknowledged that it was far easier to persuade Congress to cut taxes than to reduce spending, contributing to a very sharp expansion of the budget deficit. 
 "We learned it the hard way," Mr. Weidenbaum, now a professor of economics at Washington University in St. Louis, said in a speech.
Mr. Weidenbaum appeared at the annual meeting of the National Association of Business Economists being held at the Boston Park Plaza Hotel. His remarks, which also included some very pointed criticism of groups representing the elderly for their role in defending Social Security, brought prolonged applause.
Mr. Weidenbaum, an elder statesman among conservative economists and a former adviser to Mr. Dole, said in an interview that he had no role in drafting the candidate's current plan. "My days in politics are behind me," he said after his luncheon address.
Asked about the $500 tax credit for children under 18 contained in the plan, Mr. Weidenbaum said he had taken no economic "notice" of it, regarding this provision simply as an item of "social" policy.
Other conservatives have complained that the child credit does nothing to encourage savings and investment.
But though he did not refer specifically to Mr. Dole's plan in his prepared text, Mr. Weidenbaum left little doubt that he considers the main element a poor idea.
"Surely cutting income taxes alone is not going to energize the economy sufficiently to prevent a rise in the budget deficit," he said. "On the basis of experience -- I also bear the scars of the 1981-1982 cycle -- those deficits can lead to a variety of negative effects. These range from a diminution of investment capital available for private business expansion to scaring the Federal Reserve into tightening the flow of money and credit."
Mr. Dole says that about one-quarter of his tax cuts will be made up by higher economic growth.
Mr. Weidenbaum said cutting taxes, like printing money, was ill advised. "Both responses are clear, simple and -- in today's circumstances -- inadequate or inappropriate. Both are kissing cousins, quick-fix variants of the age-old desire to pump up the economy," he said. Similarly, cutting taxes alone as a means of raising long-term economic growth, Mr. Weidenbaum argued, is just as futile as adding air to a flat tire without first "patching up the holes that are the basic cause of the problem."
Serious efforts to improve the economy, Mr. Weidenbaum contended, include regulatory reform, shifting to a consumption tax in place of the income tax, and slashing unneeded subsidies to business and middle-class consumers.
Mr. Weidenbaum charged in particular that the elderly had been "misled to believe that they have earned the money they receive."
Social Security taxes paid by workers and their employers -- even after an allowance for interest -- "does not begin to cover the monthly benefit payments" for the average retiree, he said. The balance is "a gift" from those still working.
"There's a large but hidden welfare component in the major middle-class entitlements," Mr. Weidenbaum said.

HEADLINE: Productivity Is Revised Modestly Upward

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Companies churned out goods more cheaply and efficiently during the second quarter than first thought, the Government said today, largely because wage costs were not rising as rapidly as estimated.
The Labor Department said productivity outside the agricultural sector rose at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, instead of falling by one-tenth of 1 percent, as was first reported. The revised rate was still well below the 1.8 percent pace of the first quarter. 
 Production was higher than originally estimated and employees worked longer hours. Most important, unit labor costs that account for two-thirds of businesses' production costs went up at a lower 3.2 percent rate instead of the 3.8 percent initially reported.
But the gain in productivity, usually a positive indicator for the financial markets, did not help them yesterday. The bond market slumped after a Federal Reserve policy maker warned that the economy had entered a danger zone, noting labor markets were tight and there was risk of rising inflation. Investors feared that the central bank might raise interest rates in an effort to quell inflation fears.
In an interview, Janet L. Yellen, a Fed governor, said wages and salaries were picking up but that overall compensation, which includes benefit costs, so far were rising moderately.
"We're beginning to see a little bit of an increase in the growth of compensation," Ms. Yellen said, though it was unclear how much growth would slow in the second half and how that might restrain inflation pressure.
But, she warned, "There's definitely a chance inflation will rise."
With the Fed's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee set to meet on Sept. 24 to decide interest-rate strategy, many private economists have been warning that strong growth was causing wage-driven inflation risks to heat up.
"The August canvass suggests that tight labor markets are gradually escalating wage pressures, and that the economy remains on a solid, indeed unsustainably strong growth track," the Mellon Bank said in an economic commentary.
Separately, the Commerce Department said business sales at the wholesale level jumped at the strongest rate in nearly two years during July. That left only a small addition to inventories and created more room to bolster output in the face of strong demand. Stocks of unsold goods on wholesalers' shelves edged up just one-tenth of 1 percent in July, to a seasonally adjusted $259.5 billion after a gain of two-tenths of 1 percent in June.
Sales by wholesalers soared 2.4 percent, to $203.2 billion, in July, the strongest monthly gain since a 2.7 percent jump in August 1994, after a slight June gain of one-tenth of 1 percent.
The economy is generally expected to lose some steam in coming months after expanding at a 4.8 percent annual rate in the second quarter, which was its most vigorous quarterly growth in two years. But the timing and extent of the slowdown is uncertain.
A third report, issued by the Commerce Department, suggested some drag on the economy from a weaker foreign trade performance in the second quarter.
In the three months from April through June, the current account deficit widened to $38.78 billion from $34.87 billion in the first quarter. The main reason was that the overall deficit on goods and services increased to $27.9 billion in the second quarter from $24.2 billion in the first quarter. But measured on a year-to-year basis, the current account deficit declined in the first half of the year by about 8 percent.
The current account is the broadest measure of trade and includes, in addition to hard goods and services, items like investment flows between countries and United States aid and grants.
During the second quarter, investments shifted to a deficit of $1.6 billion from a small surplus of $300 million in the first quarter, as more money flowed out to foreign investors than returned to Americans in the form of profits and dividends from overseas investments.

(Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics); "A Bigger Deficit" tracks the quarterly current account deficit, seasonally adjusted, since 1986. (Source: Haver Analytics)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Dole Is Moving To Add Spark To Campaign

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: MURFREESBORO, Tenn., Sept. 10

 BODY:
Bob Dole moved on three fronts today to reignite his campaign, scheduling a meeting to pacify Congressional Republicans who are fearful of losing their majority, trying new ways to present his economic message and enlisting Colin L. Powell in a new push on the character issue.
Trying to break out of his trailing position in the polls, Mr. Dole, the Republican Presidential nominee, unveiled a new two-minute biographical advertisement that declares there is a "moral crisis" in America and shows Mr. Powell, the popular former general, vouching for Mr. Dole's character. "Bob Dole is the candidate most qualified by virtue of his beliefs, his character and competence to be the next President of the United States of America," General Powell says in the commercial. 
 In his speeches, Mr. Dole is still emphasizing his tax-cutting plan. But in a tacit acknowledgment that it has not inspired voters, he is reaching for new ways to explain it.
In Louisiana this morning, he tried to demonstrate how easy it would be for him to cut taxes and balance the budget, telling an audience that it was a simple matter of trimming 5 or 6 cents from every dollar spent on Government. Still, he admitted this might not sound very interesting, and he said he was going to speak slowly because "it will make your eyes glaze over."
And the former Senate majority leader scheduled an unusual visit to Capitol Hill on Wednesday to quiet Senate and House Republicans, who are starting to talk about their fears of a Dole loss. Congressional Republicans are also plainly concerned that a continuing lackluster Dole campaign will depress Republican turnout and endanger their control of the House and the Senate.
Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the majority whip, for example, was quoted in The Wall Street Journal today as saying, "If we have a meltdown, then I'm going to get worried."
Since the week after the Republican National Convention in mid-August, Mr. Dole has been struggling to get himself on the network news. Part of his problem has been that major events like fighting in Iraq and various hurricanes have blotted out political news coverage, much to the frustration of his staff.
But the Dole campaign has neither been staging big events nor making bold or broad pronouncements that would bring it more attention. Rather, it is putting on small events in small towns, generating local headlines but not national news.
In part, that is because Mr. Dole is trying to stay "on message," drilling his economic plan into each new audience, who, polls show, are largely skeptical of his promise to both balance the budget and cut taxes.
"We're sticking with the economic plan as the backbone of our message," Nelson Warfield, Mr. Dole's press spokesman, said today. "But there are obviously different parts of the package."
The rest of the package is chiefly the character issue. Mr. Dole consistently outpolls President Clinton on matters of trust, but he has also been unable to convert this advantage into any progress in his overall standing in the polls, where he struggling to overcome a double-digit deficit.
"In an era of too much salesmanship and too much smooth talking, Bob Dole is a plain-spoken man," General Powell, the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, says in the new advertisement.
Taking a more direct tack on this, the ad goes on to warn: "There is a moral crisis in America. Drug use is up. The wrong messages are being sent to our youth."
Mr. Dole picked up on the theme here as he addressed a crowd of nearly 1,000 supporters at an open-air plaza this afternoon.
"It all boils down to one word," he said. "Trust. Who do you trust? Who do you trust to lead America? Who do you trust to cut your taxes? Who do you trust to reduce regulation? Who do you trust to reduce drug use in America? Who do you trust to protect our liberty and our freedom and keep our defenses strong? That's what the election is all about. Trust."
(Of course, in typical Dole fashion, he went on to list several other things the election is about: "It's about leadership. It's about family. It's about business. It's about the next century.")
He was introduced to the crowd by Gov. Don Sundquist, who said Mr. Dole "makes decisions on convictions and not convenience."
The new push on character is also evident in the person of William J. Bennett, the former anti-drug chief, Education Secretary and self-described keeper of the nation's values, who has been traveling with Mr. Dole this week. Today at a rally in Baker, La., Mr. Bennett told a crowd of about 300 people sweltering under a blazing sun on the site of a former plantation, "What is more important than the character of our President?"
Mr. Bennett, the author of "The Book of Virtues," plopped himself down earlier with reporters on Mr. Dole's campaign plane. "Virtue is here," he pronounced, going on to describe President Clinton as "one of the most unprincipled major public figures of recent history."
Typically, Mr. Dole tells audiences that the Clinton campaign is misrepresenting his economic plan because it is trying to frighten people. Today in Louisiana, Mr. Dole used the same tactic, warning that a second Clinton term would mean "higher taxes and more teen-agers using drugs, a Government-run health-care system, more liberal judges, an economy producing too few jobs and more and more and more and more government all the way down the line."
He added: "They're going to tax everything, everything, everything! They've got hundreds of ideas that you haven't even heard about on how to get more of your property, more of your money, more authority, and I say, it's time to stop. Let's build a bridge to Little Rock, Ark., and send Bill Clinton back."
But whether Mr. Dole takes up the character charge as directly as Mr. Bennett would like is another question. "You've heard him," Mr. Bennett told reporters. "He says these are not our enemies, these are our opponents." He lamented: "he's not going to do it. I don't think, at all."
Mr. Bennett's presence has also brought to the surface the example of Dick Morris, the President's wayward strategist. While Mr. Dole never mentions Mr. Morris, who resigned after reports that he shared White House details with a prostitute over the last year, it is too tempting for others to resist.
Mr. Bennett, for one, mused on the plane about why the scandal had not agitated the public more, suggesting he might look for ways to stir the pot. And in Louisiana this morning, Gov. Murphy J. Foster noted that the Clintons and Vice President Al Gore called Mr. Morris to console him. "Did they call the man's wife and say we're sorry?" said the Governor. "No. They called him and said we're sorry this happened to you."

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Excerpt From Writings of Nominee

 BODY:
Following is an excerpt from a 1990 article by Pat Choate in the Harvard Business Review. The article was based on Dr. Choate's book, "Agents of Influence" (Knopf, 1990).
Japan's campaign for the United States is completely legal. It plays the American economic game by American rules. It uses the campaign tactics and methods of American politics. It hires Americans to lobby, educate and influence other Americans. It is the highest-stakes political-economic game in the world today, affecting whole industries, billions of dollars, millions of jobs, and, ultimately, the wealth and power of nations. 
 It is also deeply corrosive of the U.S. political and economic system. The revolving door of Washington, D.C., breeds cynicism and mistrust. It ultimately represents a form of political corruption -- completely legal, completely unethical. The problem, of course, is not in Tokyo, but in Washington, D.C.
Americans have all but lost sight of some of the most basic lessons of civics -- chief among them the guiding concept of civic virtue. The value of national service -- for an individual to be of service to the country and to work on behalf of the country's interest -- has been cheapened by a more mundane coin of the realm: personal advancement, self-interest, big money. As a consequence, the United States is not only selling corporate assets and real estate to foreign bidders; also for sale is U.S. integrity and national honor.

LENGTH: 1109 words

HEADLINE: Nation's Capital Ponders A Broken School System

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
The problems of the District of Columbia's school system mirror those of Washington itself, which is struggling to overcome a fiscal crisis created by poor management and its dependence on Federal financing. And the school system is mired in investigations of poor management and potential mismanagement.
The dropout rates at the District's schools are among the nation's highest, and the student achievement rates are routinely lower than the national average. School buildings are so dilapidated that six of them could not open this week because of fire code violations. And school officials have been accused of improperly diverting millions of dollars into other programs. 
 But in a city that is in the throes of an acute financial crisis, and where half the students' families receive welfare, solutions to such problems have been hard to find.
At a hearing on Wednesday on the school system's problems, Andrew Brimmer, chairman of the District of Columbia Financial Responsibility and Management Assistance Authority, said, "The system as it currently exists is clearly broken."
The financial control board has watched over the fiscal management of the nearly bankrupt city since last year, when it was created by Congress.
Abdusalam Omer, the school system's chief financial officer, said at the hearing that bad management over the years had left the system's finances in disarray and the system itself "in a state of crisis."
Mr. Omer, who was appointed by the city's chief financial officer a month ago to bring order to the schools' financial management, said shoddy fiscal practices over the last three years made tracking dollars extremely difficult. He said school officials had diverted more than $12 million from food programs to pay for other things, including salaries for special education personnel, but some of that money could not be accounted for.
Mr. Omer also criticized school officials for what he said were improper priorities. He cited, for example, improving science laboratories when school roofs needed repair.
Franklin L. Smith, the superintendent who was appointed by the school board five years ago, has been accused of mismanagement, and a contract he approved last year is the subject of a grand jury investigation.
Under that $875,000 contract, a 26-year-old insurance broker who was a friend of a school board member ran a program for emotionally disturbed students. Mr. Smith canceled the contract after the program encountered major financial difficulties.
Mr. Smith has also been criticized for failing to have all the schools ready to open this year. Six of the District's 164 schools could not open on Tuesday because they had not met fire code standards. So 3,000 children were diverted to classes in churches, school cafeterias and Southeastern University.
At St. John's CME Church in the southeastern section of Washington, second graders attended classes in surroundings that were in many ways much nicer than their closed school around the corner.
Today, Judge Faye K. Christian of the District of Columbia Superior Court ordered three of the schools to be reopened.
Members of the financial control board have made it clear that they are just as dissatisfied with the District's school board as they are with Mr. Smith. And frustrated parents maintain that the District government, Congress and uninvolved parents all share the blame.
"I just wish they would stop all this confusion and start dealing with the issues," Bessie Best, whose two children attend schools here, said at the financial control board's hearing on Wednesday. "The question should be, 'What about our children?' "
There are bright spots in the District's public schools. Students at Alice Deal Junior High School routinely score high on national standardized tests. The acclaimed Dunbar High School has a strong engineering program. And, under a partnership with the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, students at Hart Junior High School in Southeast Washington wrote a play.
But in general, the District's 80,000 students -- a figure that is itself in dispute -- lag behind national rankings on standardized tests. Nearly 40 percent drop out, one of the highest rates in the country.
Many of the schools they attend are aging and dilapidated. Mr. Smith estimates that it will cost $1.2 billion just to make necessary repairs at all the schools. Although some control board members have questioned that figure, no one doubts that the buildings are in terrible shape.
Mr. Smith himself has been the focus of most of the complaints about the school system. But he says many of his critics are upset that he has challenged the status quo by, among other things, dismissing many principals and insisting that teachers be evaluated according to their students' performance.
He has his defenders, too. Nathan Howard, who works for the Department of Labor and has six children in District schools and two who have graduated, praised Mr. Smith for creating school-based management teams that give principals, teachers and parents more power to make decisions.
"The way to improve schools is to empower parents," Mr. Howard said, "and to have the extended family of the community as support."
Karen Shook, president of the school board, said a lack of money was the school system's biggest problem. The school budget has shrunk to $482 million in 1997, from $517 million in 1991, she said.
But members of the control board said it was how the schools' money was managed, not how much they had, that was the primary issue.
"I'd want to know that any additional money was going to be spent as prudently as possible," said Joyce Ladner, a control board member. "I don't have that sense right now."
At Wednesday's hearing, Mr. Brimmer, the financial control board chairman, chastised Ms. Shook, saying the school board had abdicated its responsibility to supervise the superintendent and to monitor spending and contracts.
The control board can ask the school board to dismiss Mr. Smith and replace him with a manager who would have broad powers to change the system. If the school board does not agree, the control board could carry out the plan after consulting with Congress.
Since most of the District's voters do not have children in the public schools, officials feel less pressure to come up with a real solution, said Delabian Rice-Thurston, executive director of Parents United for the D.C. Public Schools, a community group.
"There's a constituency for the police and a constituency for the trash collectors," Ms. Rice-Thurston said. "But there's no constituency for the children."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE COMMERCIALS;
Dole Campaign Says It Has Hardly Begun to Fight as Clinton Storms the Airwaves

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
The broadcast advertising war between the two major Presidential campaigns is looking more and more lopsided.
The Clinton campaign is relentlessly hammering away at Bob Dole with harsh and repetitive commercials directed squarely toward pivotal voters in critical states. But the Dole campaign has not advertised in three important Midwestern states for two weeks, and it continues gauzily promoting the candidate's biography over his ideas in national spots. 
 Just wait, Dole campaign strategists say. They say they are planning an unconventional advertising blitz in October, promoting Mr. Dole on the economy and attacking President Clinton on crime and drugs -- "burning in our message," in the words of one Dole official.
Another cautioned that "the great majority of the money is budgeted for October." As a result, he said, "the fact that we're not up in a given market or a given state in one week in September should not be taken as a de-emphasis of that state."
Still, counting on a blitz next month amounts to a gamble that the commercials being created by Mr. Dole's newly assembled advertising consultants will be able to overcome months of repetition of basic themes by the Clinton campaign in advertisements that often seem stamped from a single die.
And the Democrats say they do not think the Dole campaign will have much more money than they do to spend in October.
"We're only spending about $100,000 more a week than they are," a Clinton strategist said.
Underscoring its hardball tactics, the Clinton campaign today released a tough 30-second commercial, intended for the female voters who have provided Mr. Clinton with his double-digit lead in the polls. The commercial is being shown in state markets around the country.
The advertisement, produced after Mr. Dole said on Saturday that he opposed the Family and Medical Leave Act, features a couple recounting time spent with their young daughter before she died. A narrator explains how the law enables families to stay home with a sick or newborn child without losing their jobs.
"Bob Dole led a six-year fight against family leave," the narrator says. "Twelve million have used leave, but Dole's still against it."
The mother then provides the closing words: "President Clinton understands the struggles that families go through."
Without addressing the law, the Dole campaign attacked the commercial.
"To imply that Bob Dole would let a child die without her parents at her side shows a moral hysteria so outrageous, so grossly offensive, that it defies description," Christina Martin, a spokeswoman, said.
Clinton officials said they intended to broadcast the spot for up to a month, rather than the usual one or two weeks, running it during daytime programs that appeal to women.
In sharp contrast, looking at the same female voters, the Dole campaign today released a new two-minute commercial that criticizes Mr. Clinton only by implication, never by name. And the commercial, while it tries to raise values as an issue, once again introduces Mr. Dole to voters, sketching him as a war hero. Gen. Colin L. Powell is shown in his speech at the Republican National Convention last month, praising Mr. Dole's "character and competence." The two-minute commercial is scheduled to begin appearing on Thursday on broadcast and cable networks.
It is the second week in a row that Mr. Dole has bought time on a network. National political advertising can be seen as a sign of a weak campaign, because such promotion can be inefficient compared with state-by-state advertising targeted at wavering voters. By advertising nationally, Mr. Dole spends money to promote himself in states like South Carolina that are securely his.
As such states dwindle in number, Clinton strategists say, Mr. Dole may have concluded that a national approach is more effective. Indeed, for two weeks in a row, the Dole campaign has not bought broadcast time in Missouri, Illinois or Wisconsin.
But a Dole campaign strategist said the campaign was not conceding states.
"We're not at the stage of a campaign where you do a real triage," the official said. When a campaign is trying to reach more than 35 percent of the population, he said, a national approach is most efficient.
The Dole campaign will have to overcome images broadcast for months. With no pretense at subtlety, the Clinton commercials have painted Mr. Dole as an aged Washington insider and a lackey of Speaker Newt Gingrich.
Over and over, the Clinton campaign has used an image of Mr. Dole standing with Mr. Gingrich before wallpaper bearing a washed-out image of the Capitol. The two men are shown in slow motion, while jarring piano music plays.
"You'll see it again," a top Clinton strategist said. "It's the only way, in a media-saturated environment, where people can flick to a hundred different channels."
Throughout the campaign, the Clinton advertising team has turned the appearance of defense into fierce attacks on Mr. Dole. One advertisement in July began: "The same old politics -- Dole attacks Clinton." It ended: "The real Bob Dole -- 35 years of higher taxes."
A new 30-second advertisement on the economy, which was also released today, begins: "Bob Dole, attacking the President." It ends: "Bob Dole. Thirty-five years in Washington. Thirty-five years of higher taxes."
Similarly, the Clinton campaign recently turned its defense to a Dole advertisement on drugs into an attack. Since the Dole commercial, was broadcast in only two cities, CNN reported last week that the Clinton campaign had been apparently snookered into a wasteful, disproportionate response.
But campaign officials said they were delighted that Mr. Dole had provided them with a pretext for what they called an effective commercial. The advertisement, among other things, points out that "Bob Dole even voted against creating the drug czar."
Two weeks after it was first broadcast, the commercial was still on the air today.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CHOICE -- Man in the News;
Economist With a Passion for Policy -- Pat Choate

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
Dr. Pat Choate, whom Ross Perot named yesterday to be his running mate, is more accustomed to being the behind-the-scenes adviser whose briefcase is crammed with position papers, whose Rolodex is crammed with important names and numbers and whose job it is to tutor V.I.P.'s on ideas. His ideas.
Dr. Choate (it rhymes with "coat") has had spectacular success pushing his ideas into the mainstream in Washington in the last 15 years. But in his debut as a debate coach, he had only so-so results. The debate was against Vice President Al Gore, and the subject was the North American Free Trade Agreement. Mr. Perot, advised by Dr. Choate, was said to be furious at the way the November 1993 face-off went, and Dr. Choate's star in the Perot firmament was thought to have faded, at least briefly. 
 Before the debate, Dr. Choate had written a book with Mr. Perot that explained why Nafta opponents like Mr. Perot believed that the agreement would lower American workers' wages. The royalties from the book, "Save Your Job, Save Our Country" (Hyperion, 1993), were divided between Mr. Perot's group, United We Stand America, and Dr. Choate's research unit in Washington, the Manufacturing Policy Project.
Dr. Choate is an economic nationalist and almost an economic isolationist; he is suspicious of foreign entanglements. Before fighting Nafta, he attacked Japan's influence on economic policy in this country. As early as 1981, he argued that big public-works programs should be presented to the public as "investments in infrastructure," an approach that was eventually picked up by Democrats.
Dr. Choate is also credited with propelling the idea of competitiveness to the forefront of the policy debate in Washington in the 1980's by drafting speeches for Democrats and bills for Republicans. In the dry-as-a-theorem world of economic policy, he is a rarity; he lectures people with unconcealed passion.
Dr. Choate was born on April 27, 1941, to a sharecropper's family in Maypearl, Tex., about 40 miles south of Dallas. He attended college on an R.O.T.C. scholarship and earned a doctorate in institutional economics at the University of Oklahoma. His research focused on the role of governments and industries in guiding economic development. He was commissioned as an Army officer in 1963 and was discharged into the reserves in 1965.
Oklahoma's first Republican Governor, Henry Bellmon, hired Dr. Choate as an economic planner in 1965. He worked briefly as a regional administrator for the Commerce Department's Economic Development Administration, then left to head the Department of Economic and Community Development in Tennessee. He argued that Tennessee needed foreign investment, which made him some political enemies.
He moved to Washington in 1975 as the director of the Economic Development Administration's Office of Economic Research. "It was like falling into a pot of gin," he said, for he had an $11 million budget and a staff of nine economists. He was ousted in a bureaucratic shuffle during the Carter Administration. After working briefly at the Office of Management and Budget, he went to TRW, the defense contractor.
Dr. Choate lives in Washington with his wife, Kay, and has two stepsons in college. He teaches at George Washington University and has written six books and more than 200 articles. He has a weekly radio talk show called "The Week Ahead," carried on the United Broadcasting Network, which he helped found.
Until yesterday, Dr. Choate was a kind of ambassador without portfolio for Mr. Perot's campaign. Last month, during an appearance in South Carolina, Dr. Choate predicted that Mr. Perot would be in second place in the polls by mid-October.
"The race will be between Clinton and Perot," Dr. Choate said, "and we can say, 'To vote for Bob Dole is to throw away your vote.' "

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;
Clinton Talks of Welfare and Family Leave

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Sept. 10

 BODY:
President Clinton brought his campaign caravan to the Show Me State today to show off an experimental program that helps former welfare recipients move into work and to defend the Federal law that lets families take time off from work for medical emergencies.
The double-barreled day highlighted the two sides of Mr. Clinton's approach on work issues: the hard-headed new law he signed last month overhauling welfare and forcing people to find jobs or lose benefits, and the soft-hearted bill he signed in 1993 that lets employees take leave from work when a child is born or a parent is sick. 
 And though he never mentioned them by name, in both cases Mr. Clinton's targets were clear. The President contended that by signing the welfare bill, he had ended partisan arguments on the topic with the Republicans, and he vigorously defended the Family and Medical Leave law against recent criticism by Bob Dole that it amounted to heavy-handed Government meddling in the workplace.
"I come here today to say to the governors, you asked for this and now you've got it," Mr. Clinton said at a meeting of the bipartisan Southern Governors' Association in Kansas City, Mo., referring to the welfare bill that ends the Federal guarantee of assistance to the poor in favor of block grants to states with wide flexibility to administer programs as they see fit.
But he was quick to add that the bill was only a first step and that it was up to employers to pitch in and help create jobs for welfare recipients who will need them.
"We have to prove all the skeptics wrong," he said, in implicit acknowledgment of the criticism he endured from liberals for signing the Republican-drafted bill. "But one thing I know: I know that the employers of this country want to do this. I believe that every employer who has ever said a disparaging word about the welfare system -- which includes every one of us, including me -- should be challenged to assume the responsibility to help be a part of the solution to this problem."
In an effort to make his point, Mr. Clinton also held a round-table discussion with a group of women formerly on welfare who now hold jobs under a Missouri program that consolidates benefits that would have gone to welfare recipients to instead provide subsidies to employers who hire them. The Administration made the program possible by granting Missouri a waiver from the old welfare law before Mr. Clinton signed the new one.
"I'm convinced that the only way the states are going to be able to really move large numbers of people to work in a short time is with a partnership with the private sector, doing what Missouri has done, using what used to be the welfare check or a food stamp check as an income supplement to a private employer, who can then engage in training and work," Mr. Clinton told the group.
At the same time, Mr. Clinton defended the family leave law, which was the first bill he signed on taking office, and said at round-table discussion that it was "one thing that's become, unfortunately, controversial again in the last couple of days."
On Saturday, at a discussion with Republicans in Pittsburgh, Mr. Dole responded to a question about the problems of small businesses by attacking the leave law, which Mr. Clinton now wants to expand to cover parent-teacher conferences and doctors' appointments with children.
"My view is, why should the Federal Government be getting into family leave?" Mr. Dole said then. "I believe in compassionate leave if there's a birth or a death or there's something that happens in the family, obviously. But I again wonder about the long arm of the Federal Government."
Mr. Clinton took strong issue today with those remarks, saying the law "plainly isn't hurting the economy.
This evening, at a rally in the Gateway Educational Park here, the President asserted: "All the bill says is if you work in a business with 50 or more employees and your spouse is about to have a baby, or you are, or your mama or your daddy's real sick, or your baby's real sick, you can take just a little time off from work without losing your job.
"Now, you tell me, is that anti-business? If it's anti-business, how did this economy produce 10.5 million new jobs? That's more jobs, more job growth, faster rate, than any Republican administration in 70 years."
And his campaign released a new television advertisement attacking Mr. Dole for opposing the bill and featuring emotional testimony from a family that took advantage of it.
Mr. Clinton's ability to blend a carrot-and-stick approach on issues like welfare and work appears to be part of the reason he is running ahead of Mr. Dole in Midwestern swing states like Missouri, which Mr. Clinton won in 1992, and where Mr. Dole must make strong inroads to have a chance of winning.
The President used his stop here today -- part of a three-day trip that will also take him to Colorado, Arizona and California -- to raise more than $1 million for the Democratic National Committee, $500,000 at a luncheon in Kansas City and $600,000 at a dinner in St. Louis tonight.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton greeted children as he arrived in Kansas City to highlight a Missouri program to move people from welfare to work. The campaign trip will also take him to Colorado, Arizona and California. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Israeli Prime Minister Pays Visit, and a Political Debt

BYLINE: By IAN FISHER 

 BODY:
The new Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, paid back a crucial political debt in New York City yesterday when he visited the grave of Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, the Lubavitch leader whose followers in Israel worked diligently toward Mr. Netanyahu's narrow victory in late May.
In a brisk 27-hour visit to New York -- part of his second trip to the United States since his election -- Mr. Netanyahu reached out on several fronts, giving media interviews, seeking investment in Israel and joining Vice President Al Gore and Jack Kemp, the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, for a glittery event last night in Manhattan with a prominent Jewish-American group. 
 But nothing in his brief visit reverberated so soundly as when he slipped off his shoes in a cemetery in Queens to say silent prayers at the grave of Rabbi Schneerson, the rebbe, or spiritual leader, who died in 1994 at 92. Mr. Netanyahu called the rebbe, whose counsel he had sought several times, "the most influential Jew of our time."
The Lubavitchers are a relatively small group of some 200,000 Jews worldwide whose unity in devotion to the rebbe, whom some considered the Messiah, has given them an influence that outstrips their numbers.
"The rebbe's capacity to unite great learning, great sagacity, great understanding with a warm Jewish heart, with a grounding which is unmatched in the Torah -- this unique combination made him, in fact, a unique figure," Mr. Netanyahu said after his visit to the grave in the Old Montefiore Cemetery in Cambria Heights, where he read from the Book of Psalms and lit a candle.
His public bow to Rabbi Schneerson, who led the Lubavitch movement for 44 years, seemed twofold: to thank the Lubavitchers specifically for their get-out-the-vote effort, and to give a more general nod to the ultra-Orthodox factions in Israel from a Prime Minister who is not particularly religious himself.
But his choice to honor the rebbe roiled contention among some American Jews, who saw it as pandering to a group that takes a hard line on peace in the Middle East as well as on other forms of Judaism.
Rabbi Ammiel Hirsch, the executive director of the Association of Reform Zionists of America, which represents 1.5 million Jews, said he had tried repeatedly to arrange a meeting with Mr. Netanyahu. The Prime Minister's refusals, he said, underscore the deep divisions on issues of religion and how to proceed on peace that have not healed since the election.
"We hope that now he appears to have time to visit graveyards that he would also have the time to discuss issues with those of us who are alive and well," said Rabbi Hirsch, who is based in New York.
Several Lubavitchers said Mr. Netanyahu's trip increased the influence of their movement, already powerful politically in Israel.
"This is a very powerful statement to the world," said Rabbi Jacob Z. Goldstein, who is president of Community Board 9 in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, where the Lubavitchers are based.
Mr. Netanyahu began his trip on Monday in Washington, where he repeated in a meeting with President Clinton that he would not cede the Golan Heights to Syria as a starting point for peace talks. In his remarks yesterday at Rabbi Schneerson's grave he echoed the hard-line oratory of Lubavitch speakers -- a view espoused by Rabbi Schneerson -- for retaining Jewish communities in the West Bank.
He said he first met Rabbi Schneerson after he was Israel's delegate to the United Nations in the 1980's, and sought his counsel on several occasions. He remembered especially what he called the rebbe's "penetrating gaze," which he said went right to the essence of things. "The rebbe was able to see the important things in our lives as human beings and as Jews," he said.
Mr. Netanyahu began his day addressing the Association for a Better New York, a coalition of business, labor and political interests. There, he made the case for investment in Israel, saying that he was working to dismantle the state control of businesses that he said had helped strangle economic growth.
In the evening, he was honored at a three-hour gala dinner celebrating the 40th anniversary of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, an umbrella group of virtually every influential Jewish group that is a constant forum for Israeli politicians. In a measure of the group's sway, the event at the New York Hilton in mid-Manhattan was attended by politicians ranging from Mr. Gore and Mr. Kemp to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki.
Mr. Gore and Mr. Kemp peppered their speeches with Hebrew expressions and stressed the close bond between Israel and the United States.

GRAPHIC: Photo: With a portrait of the revered Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson as a backdrop, Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli Prime Minister, spoke at a news conference after his visit to the rabbi's grave. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Flatley Begins His Ranger Metamorphosis

BYLINE: By JASON DIAMOS 

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Vt., Sept. 10

 BODY:
For 13 seasons, Patrick Flatley was an Islander mainstay. Toward the end, some might say he was the Islanders. In all that time, from his rookie season through his maturation into a respected veteran, Flatley was conditioned to despise the sight of a Rangers uniform.
So it may be unthinkable to some that he will soon be wearing one -- as the first former captain of the Islanders to play for the Rangers. 
 "I think when camp gets closer to coming to an end and playing there becomes more of a reality, then I'm sure it will be a little unusual," the 32-year-old Flatley said today, the second day of Rangers training camp. "I think it's going to be exciting on both counts. I don't know what to expect, to be honest with you."
Flatley in anything but an Islander sweater is hard to imagine. And yet here he is, still striving for the one thing in his career that he has always wanted: the Stanley Cup.
The closest he has come was as a 20-year-old rookie. Flatley joined the Islanders after the 1984 Winter Olympics, had a huge playoff run, then watched as Mark Messier, Wayne Gretzky and company ended the Islanders' four-year dynasty and began one of their own in Edmonton.
Those first few years with the Islanders remain the fondest, Flatley said today. Those years and the team's Cinderella run to the conference semifinals in 1993. Flatley was the last link to the Islanders' glory days as the once-proud organization fell to the depths it is currently mired in. Flatley's body seemed to begin to fall apart, too, although he disagreed.
"Look at the injuries I've had," he said. "I don't think broken bones are your body breaking down. That's just bad luck. Last year was a groin. But look around the league. Eighty percent of the league had groin injuries last year."
Flatley wanted to come back to Long Island -- even though the Islanders have absolutely no shot at winning the cup. The Islanders did not want him back. They tried to get him to retire. They bought out the final year of his contract for $700,000. Youth movements have little room for thirtysomethings, especially after 8-goal, 17-point, 56-game seasons.
Then again, the Rangers, with all their talk about youth over the summer, did not figure to have a place for Flatley, either. It was something of a surprise last Friday when the Rangers signed him for one year at between $200,000 and $300,000.
Money, of course, had a lot to do with it. That and the fact that the Rangers are short on right wings.
"We didn't have a lot of depth as far as a guy like Patrick Flatley is concerned," said Coach Colin Campbell. "He comes highly recommended by a number of people we contacted. And in these days of economic restraint, the price was right."
And, Neil Smith, the Rangers' president, said last weekend: "It's not as if he's taking somebody's job. He's got a lot to prove."
Flatley said today that anything he has left to prove is to himself. And he added, "I want to decide when I want to retire."
Somewhere in his heart, he hopes it will be after he has had his opportunity to skate around the ice with the Stanley Cup raised over his head -- whatever uniform he is wearing.

SLAP SHOTS
MIKE MILBURY resumed his hard line with the restricted free agents ZIGMUND PALFFY and TRAVIS GREEN on Tuesday, saying he was prepared to let both players sit out the season. Milbury said Tuesday night that he was annoyed that neither player's agent had returned his phone calls from late last week, although later that night Green's agent, DON MEEHAN, did leave a message for Milbury. "It's not only me," Milbury said, "the ownership is ready to let them sit." . . . After Tuesday's session, Coach COLIN CAMPBELL headed to Philadelphia to watch Canada's 4-3 overtime victory in the World Cup of Hockey finals. Campbell said that from what he had seen so far in the World Cup WAYNE GRETZKY "still has it" after "a lot of people thought he was finished last year."

HEADLINE: Minnesotans Decide to Hold Rematch of 1990 Senate Contest

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Minnesota voters yesterday set up a rematch between Senator Paul Wellstone, a Democrat, and Rudy Boschwitz, the two-term Republican he ousted from office six years ago.
In Rhode Island, where Senator Claiborne Pell, a Democrat, is retiring after six terms, State Treasurer Nancy Mayer easily won the Republican primary, and Representative Jack Reed won the Democratic nomination to succeed Mr. Pell. 
 In the third Senate contest on a busy primary day, former Representative Dick Swett narrowly defeated John Rauh, a businessman, for the Democratic nomination in New Hampshire. Mr. Swett will challenge Senator Robert C. Smith, a first-term Republican viewed as vulnerable by the Democratic Party.
The voting came as Democrats, riding high on President Clinton's double-digit lead in the polls, have set their sights on recapturing control of Congress. Republicans hold at 53-to-47 Senate majority.
In other primaries, two New England governorships were at stake, while Arizona and Wisconsin chose Congressional nominees.
In Minnesota, Senator Wellstone swamped three rivals with 88 percent of the vote, while Mr. Boschwitz drew 80 percent against four challengers.
The Republican National Committee has already jumped into the race, running an advertisement featuring photographs of the Senator mixed with those of criminals. Mr. Boschwitz has disavowed responsibility for the ads, but Mr. Wellstone said it shows where his challenger's support comes from.
"When I think of all the big interests that are lined up behind Rudy Boschwitz, it will be a tough race," Mr. Wellstone said in a telephone interview from Washington.
Mr. Boschwitz, at a victory party in a Minneapolis hotel, said his campaign is "about the farmers of Minnesota who have the capacity of feeding the world. It's about the single mother in Minneapolis who wants work, not welfare."
Mr. Wellstone is the only Senator seeking re-election who voted against the welfare bill signed by Mr. Clinton last month.
In Rhode Island, Ms. Mayer has also received help from the Republican National Committee as she seeks to become the state's first female member of the United States Senate. The committee has spent hundreds of thousands of dollars on television ads labeling Mr. Reed an "ultraliberal" who has failed to back balanced budget and welfare measures.
Mr. Reed, in his third term in the House, has called the ads distortions and has demanded that Ms. Mayer ask the committee to stop broadcasting them, but she has refused.
"I have been trying to talk about the real issues, providing opportunities for working families, making sure our economy works for those families," Mr. Reed said after his primary victory.
Ms. Mayer, the state Treasurer for four years, said she planned to run on her record of "getting things done, of being a fiscal watchdog, of treating everyone's money as if it were my own."
Mr. Reed won 87 percent of the vote to beat one rival, while Ms. Mayer got 77 percent against two challengers.
It is Rhode Island's first open Senate race in two decades; the state's other Senator, John H. Chafee, a Republican, has been in office for nearly 20 years.
In New Hampshire, with 86 percent of the precincts reporting, Mr. Swett had 28,426 votes or 53 percent, and Mr. Rauh had 25,460 votes or 47 percent.
New Hampshire has not elected a Democrat to the United States Senate since 1975, when John A. Durkin defeated Louis C. Wyman in a special election. But Mr. Smith has drawn heavy criticism for such displays as holding up a plastic fetus and graphic photographs during a speech against partial-birth abortions.
In Vermont, Republicans gave John Gropper, a businessman, the task of challenging Gov. Howard Dean, a popular Democrat whose approval rating hovers at nearly 70 percent. With 49 percent of precincts reporting, Mr. Gropper had 66 percent of the vote, and Tom Morse, also a businessman, had 34 percent.
In New Hampshire's gubernatorial race, state Senator Jeanne Shaheen won a lopsided Democratic primary victory, racking up 88 percent of the vote against two rivals. In the Republican primary, Ovide Lamontagne, chairman of the state Board of Education, won a five-way race, outpolling Representative Bill Zeliff by 48 percent to 43 percent. Gov. Steven Merrill, a Republican, decided not to run again after two two-year terms.
In the Republican primary to succeed Mr. Zeliff, John E. Sununu, son of former Gov. John H. Sununu, who later became President George Bush's first White House chief of staff, led a field of seven; he had 28 percent of the vote, with 91 percent of precincts reporting. The Democratic nominee is Joe Keefe, a Manchester lawyer and state party chariman.
In other contests, James Harsdorf, a Wisconsin dairy farmer and former state senator, won the Republican nomination for the seat held by Representative Steve Gunderson, who is retiring. Supporters of Mr. Gunderson, one of two openly gay House Republicans, mounted a write-in effort but the Congressman did not back it.
Representative Jim Kolbe of Arizona, the other openly gay House Republican, was drawing 75 percent of the vote against one rival in early returns. Mr. Kolbe disclosed his homosexuality this summer when a gay magazine said it planned to "out" him because of his vote against recognizing same-sex marriages.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

G.M. Presents Offer In Labor Negotiations
General Motors made its first comprehensive contract offer to the United Automobile Workers union, as national labor contract negotiations continued at all three Detroit auto makers.
G.M. officials did not release details of their offer. But by making a specific proposal now, G.M. is able to stake out its position before the U.A.W. reaches a deal with Ford, which the union has chosen as its negotiating target to set a pattern for the industry. [Page D2.]
 
Productivity Rose in 2d Quarter
Companies operated more cheaply and efficiently during the second quarter than first reported, largely because wage costs were not rising as rapidly as estimated. A revised report showed that productivity actually rose, instead of falling slightly. [D2.]
 
Demand Grows For Chips
Demand for computer chips rose slightly last month, but was still down from last year. The Semiconductor Industry Association's book-to-bill ratio, which measures new orders against shipments, rose to 0.90 in August from a revised 0.86 in July. [D4.]
 
2 Energy Companies in Venture
The Coastal Corporation and Westcoast Energy said they would combine their natural gas and electricity marketing operations, joining the industry trend toward consolidation. [D2.]
 
Reagan Aide Criticizes Tax-Cut Plan
Murray L. Weidenbaum, a major architect and defender of Ronald Reagan's 1981 tax cuts, broke ranks with Republicans and warned against the reductions proposed by Bob Dole, their Presidential nominee. [D2.]
 
Bonds Fall on Fed Officials' Words
The prices of Treasury securities sagged after comments by Federal Reserve officials led to heightened anxiety over the likelihood of the Fed's increasing interest rates. The yield of the 30-year Treasury bond climbed to 7.11 percent from 7.07. [D16.]
 
The dollar hit its highest levels in nearly two months against the German mark and the Japanese yen, rising on continued expectations of increased American interest rates. [D13.]
 
Stocks were mixed. The Dow industrials fell, 6.66 points, to 5,727.18, but broader indexes were mostly higher. The Nasdaq composite rose 0.72 point, to 1,149.43. [D6.]
 
Village Voice Editor Resigns
Karen Durbin, the editor of The Village Voice, said she was resigning over differences with the weekly newspaper's publisher. Neither Ms. Durbin nor the publisher, David Schneiderman, would explain their differences. [B3.]
 
Out of the Fire, Into the Frying Pan
A growing number of people are trading the corporate world for the kitchen, seeking creative fulfillment, satisfaction in their work, greater mobility and, if they start their own businesses, control over their lives. Though these people may make considerable financial sacrifices, jobs are plentiful. In the next 10 years, restaurants and hotels are expected to need 500,000 more chefs, cooks and other kitchen workers. [C1.]
 
Slowdown Seen in Business Travel
Business travel this fall will drop to its lowest level in at least five years, the Travel Industry Association of America forecasts. Edwin McDowell: Business Travel. [D5.]
 
Soros Backs Change in Drug Policy
George Soros, the billionaire investor, has made personal donations of nearly $500,000 to two ground-breaking state ballot initiatives, in California and Arizona, that would legalize the medical use of marijuana. [A12.]

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE THIRD PARTY;
Perot Chooses An Economist For His Ticket

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 10

 BODY:
For the second time in four years, Ross Perot has chosen a political unknown -- this time, Pat Choate, a Washington-based economist and author -- as his running mate, preparing for what is emerging as a far more difficult bid for the Presidency than Mr. Perot's first race of 1992.
Mr. Perot announced his selection of a running mate, characteristically, on a 30-minute paid television appearance on the CBS television network tonight. Mr. Choate then proceeded to appear alone on Mr. Perot's favored venue, "Larry King Live," the CNN talk program. 
 In selecting Mr. Choate, Mr. Perot turned to someone with a long history of advocating protectionist trade policies. Mr. Choate drew wide and sometimes unfavorable attention with a book, "Agents of Influence" (Alfred A. Knopf, 1991) that offered a harsh depiction of Japanese influence on the American economy.
Mr. Perot introduced Mr. Choate to the nation tonight in the last segment of his televised commercial, first with a video presentation that reviewed Mr. Choate's political resume, and then with a five-minute chat, with each of them settled in brown leather armchairs.
"In Washington today, too many people profit too much from private gains at the public expense to permit real reform," Mr. Choate told Mr. Perot and television viewers. "The only real hope for genuine reform of our government and its policies is this party, the Reform Party."
Beaming at Mr. Choate, Mr. Perot pronounced himself pleased with his running mate's presentation. "Thomas Jefferson," he said, "must be looking down from Heaven and smiling at you tonight."
Mr. Choate's selection came after at least three people, current and former officeholders, turned down a request to join Mr. Perot in his second run for the Presidency. They included David L. Boren, the former Senator who, like Mr. Choate, is from Oklahoma, as well as Representatives Marcy Kaptur, a Democrat from Ohio, and Linda Smith, a Republican of Washington.
Mr. Perot met Mr. Choate in 1991, after Mr. Perot repeatedly and approvingly displayed copies of Mr. Choate's book while campaigning. Since then, Mr. Choate has become Mr. Perot's primary adviser on the subject of trade. The two worked together to produce a quick paperback arguing against United States ratification of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The selection of Mr. Choate suggests that Mr. Perot -- who has seen his signature advocacy of deficit reduction seized by President Clinton and Bob Dole during this election -- will emphasize trade issues as he seeks to carve out political territory in an election that, so far at least, has often seemed to exclude him. The issue of protectionism accounted for a large part of Mr. Perot's appeal in 1992. Its continued political potency was evident in Patrick J. Buchanan's strong showing in the Republican primaries this time around.
But trade issues have not been prominent in the general election campaign. Both Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole favored Nafta, the trade agreement that has become the rallying point for protectionist sentiment in the United States.
Mr. Perot's selection of Mr. Choate comes at a particularly difficult time in his campaign. While Mr. Dole enjoyed extensive network coverage of his selection of Jack Kemp as a running mate in August, Mr. Perot had to pay CBS for a half-hour of network time to announce his choice.
Mr. Perot's first extended television commercial, which appeared last Sunday on ABC, ranked 103d of 107 programs broadcast in prime time that week, according to Nielson Media Research.
In the latest New York Times/CBS Poll, conducted last week, 5 percent of the registered voters who responded said they supported Mr. Perot, compared with 50 percent for Mr. Clinton and 35 percent for Mr. Dole. In the same poll, only 11 percent of registered voters expressed a favorable opinion of Mr. Perot, while 60 percent viewed him unfavorably.
Mr. Choate has fairly extensive experience as a television commentator and as a weekly radio talk-show host.That gives him an edge over Mr. Perot's last running mate, James B. Stockdale, a former Navy pilot who was a prisoner of war.
He displayed that ability today on CNN. Mr. Choate, who has worked for Republican and Democratic Presidents, was never asked, and did not say, whether he was a registered member of a political party, and attempts to reach him tonight were not successful. He handily fielded questions on topics like abortion. ("I have Ross's position," he said. "Let the women decide.")
Still, the selection of Mr. Choate (his name rhymes with "vote") is unusual for a number of reasons, at least as far as traditional politics go. He has no experience in elective politics and a relatively unexplored personal history, which could change should Mr. Perot emerge as a competitive force in the race.
For example, Mr. Choate was dismissed from his job as a vice president of policy analysis at TRW Inc., an industrial conglomerate, after the storm unleashed by the publication of his book about Japan.
Over the years, he has made a series of potentially unpopular observations. "Unless we change things, I think America risks becoming a Japanese economic colony," he told one interviewer in February 1991.
When informed that some Japanese considered his attacks on the country racist, Mr. Choate responded: "For the Japanese to accuse anyone of racism is like a frog calling someone ugly."
Whatever electoral benefits Mr. Choate might ultimately bring to the ticket, his appearance violates a standard that Mr. Perot set for his own employees. Mr. Perot's Electronic Data Systems barred employees from growing facial hair, although it has since dropped that policy, a company official said tonight. Mr. Choate has a beard.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 13, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about Ross Perot's choice of Pat Choate as his Vice-Presidential running mate referred imprecisely to Mr. Perot's relationship with Electronic Data Systems. He sold the company in 1984 and has had no role in it since 1986.

HEADLINE: Business Districts Require Check on Power

 BODY:
To the Editor:
When Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter states that business improvement districts are "creating public policy . . . in a way that is so independent that it can become harmful" (news article, Sept. 5), she makes a colossal understatement. Neither the governor, the mayor, nor the residents who live within a district can stop the property tax revenue that a B.I.D. collects every year. 
 No other entity in our political or economic system has an automatic income stream with virtually no oversight from an outside agency or body. Politicians must answer to the electorate. Commissioners of public agencies must justify their budgets and practices to the elected officials. Even private corporations are accountable to their stockholders.
Further, in a situation without parallel in American history, to dismantle a business improvement district, 51 percent of the actual property owners (not just those who vote) must step forward and vote to repeal the district.
In our day of low voter turnout, such a feat would be equivalent to a candidate's receiving the vote of every voter. Short of this step, or new legislation, B.I.D.'s will continue to take advantage of an unfettered income stream.
To avoid the abuse that results when money and power are concentrated and unaccountable, we must add an effective political check to the legislation that established these entities.
 
DOUGLAS LASDON
New York, Sept. 9, 1996
 
The writer is executive director of the Urban Justice Center, which is representing residents of the Grand Central Partnership district in a voting rights lawsuit.
