HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Mixed as Traders Await U.S. Price-Index Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar reached an eight-week high against the Japanese yen and was mixed against other major currencies yesterday as some traders took profits after a three-day rally, while others waited for fresh data on price increases in the United States.
Analysts said the dollar traded in a tight range in advance of the release today of the Producer Price Index and of the Consumer Price Index tomorrow. 
 A sign of higher-than-expected inflation in the reports for August could prompt the Federal Reserve to increase short-term interest rates, as many now expect. Higher rates generally lift the value of the dollar by making returns more attractive on assets in the United States. The Fed's next rate-setting meeting is on Sept. 24.
In late trading yesterday in New York, the dollar sold for 1.5105 German marks, down from 1.5112 marks on Tuesday. The dollar traded at 110.20 yen, up from 109.80 yen and the highest since mid-July. The British pound fetched $1.5550, up from $1.5545.
"Trading was choppy," said Jack Griffin, vice president at Fuji Bank Ltd. in New York. "It seemed like people were unwilling to hold positions for a long time and were looking to take profits fairly quickly."
Some of the dollar's weakness against the mark resulted from a move to that currency by European traders. Kevin Lawrie, vice president at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh, said many dealers also sold Italian lire to buy marks.
There is continuing concern that Italy, Spain and other countries may have trouble meeting the budgetary and inflation criteria in the plan for participation in the first stage of a single European currency system.
Karl Otto-Pohl, former president of the Bundesbank, was quoted in a German business magazine as saying that inflation in Italy and Spain was too high for those countries to be initially permitted to join the currency union. If they were, he said, interest rates might rise across Europe.
Other late dollar rates in New York yesterday, compared with those late Tuesday, included: 1.2351 Swiss francs, down from 1.2359; 5.1589 French francs, up from 5.1555; 1,524 Italian lire, up from 1,520, and 1.3712 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3700.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
City Schools Learn Harsh Economic Lessons

BYLINE: By WALTER GOODMAN 

 BODY:
The point is made early and often in "Children in America's Schools": Poor children's schools are worse in every respect, or disrespect, than the schools of the well-to-do.
The camera drives home the argument of Jonathan Kozol's 1991 book, "Savage Inequalities." The focus, tomorrow night on PBS, is on Ohio, but the stark and painful contrast can be found everywhere: There are the suburban schools with well-equipped laboratories and a computer for every child, with art and music programs and plenty of sports, with pleasant lunchrooms and prospects of success. And there are the inner-city and rural schools with peeling plaster, leaking roofs, broken windows and cockroaches, with jammed classrooms, outdated textbooks, equipment that seems to have been picked up in a garage sale and hard-pressed teachers, in an atmosphere choked with coal dust and failure. Graffiti on the wall of a beat-up building sends the message from more than one student: "I hate this place." 
 The reason for the difference, in case anybody has not heard, is money. As the middle class has fled the cities and big companies have moved out of communities where they once paid taxes, the children who remain must make do with the leavings. And as long as education is paid for by local property taxes, the disparities promise to continue and probably worsen as growing numbers of children begin school. In Ohio, it is reported, spending for each pupil ranges from $13,752 for the luckiest down to $3,088 a year for the least lucky. If you're poor, get back.
The consequences are predictable: demoralization, dropouts and youngsters graduating without the knowledge or skills for a decent job. The suggestion put forward here that better schools can compensate for single-parent homes and other afflictions may be wishful, but smaller classes and more computers couldn't hurt. So the documentary portion of this two-hour production is welcome for sounding a challenge that is receiving bipartisan inattention in this campaign season.
Unfortunately, it is also a repetitious program, filled with school administrators, teachers and students decrying existing conditions and echoing what Mr. Kozol, also on screen, says with the eloquence of outrage. The producers must assume PBS viewers are slow learners. Critics of the Kozol argument -- yes, they exist -- are not heard from.
The second hour, a sort of town meeting presided over by Bill Moyers, brings together students, teachers, parents and legislators. No tape of their meeting was available for review.

Kathy Slobogin, the reporter, finds rural and urban schools that are doing serious and successful teaching, an argument for the proposition that most children, poor and rich, black and white, can learn. Not that a little more money wouldn't help.

HEADLINE: Brooklyn Union to Lower, Then Freeze, Service Rates for Gas

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
The Brooklyn Union Gas Company said yesterday that it would lower its service rates for natural gas use next year for many of its 1.1 million customers and then keep the rates unchanged for five years.
It is the first time in the country that a large utility has committed itself to freezing rates for more than three years. 
 The rate decreases next year, totaling about $3 million, will mostly affect larger natural gas users like apartment and commercial buildings and stores. Most residential customers will see only a slight decline at most in their monthly bills. And, the utility said, customers who use only small amounts of gas for cooking and heating water would see their bills go up slightly because it is more expensive to service them.
The rate reduction is part of a plan approved by the New York State Public Service Commission that would allow Brooklyn Union to reorganize its gas-distribution operations into a holding company, to be called the KeySpan Energy Corporation, enabling it to increase its investments outside the utility business.
The reduction is aimed at encouraging more customers to switch to natural gas from oil for heating.
It also reflects how utilities throughout the nation are taking steps to lower their rates as states, seeking to open their utility markets to competition, are allowing customers to choose their own suppliers.
Other utilities, including the Consolidated Edison Company, have frozen rates for up to three years on delivering natural gas, but none have made as long-term a commitment as Brooklyn Union, which had already frozen its rates voluntarily for the last two years.
Craig G. Matthews, the president and chief operating officer of Brooklyn Union, acknowledged that its rates had reached levels that made it increasingly difficult to persuade residents and potential larger customers in its service area in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island to convert to gas heating from oil.
"If there is no economic incentive," he said, "no customer will switch from oil to gas."
About 77 percent of the one- and two-family homes in the utility's service area now use natural gas for heating, compared with about 70 percent in 1985. About 45 percent of larger customers like apartment buildings, retail stores and commercial buildings now use natural gas.
Brooklyn Union projected that the average monthly bill for an apartment building would drop next year to $5,917 from $6,827. The bill for a one-family house using gas heat would stay at about $80. But the bill for a small customer who used gas only for cooking would rise to $13.30 from $12.15.
The rate reduction and freeze affect only the service charges by the utility. The cost of gas varies and is passed through to the customer. Thus, customers could still see their total bills go up or down if the cost of gas changes.
Under the plan approved by the Public Service Commission, the utility will also be able to offer new services to its customers, including guarantees on parts contracts and reading gas meters from a central office, and it will be able to charge fees for such services.
John Maniscalco, the executive vice president of the New York Oil Heating Association, an industry trade group that represents sellers of heating oil in the area, said Brooklyn Union's new rates "are going to favor the larger consumer. It's just not fair."

HEADLINE: A Renewed Challenge From Iraq

 BODY:
With the Pentagon reinforcing United States air power in the Persian Gulf, events in Iraq seem to be moving toward an escalation in American military operations. Though Saddam Hussein started the latest conflict, President Clinton owes Americans a clear explanation of how he means to deal with the complex political and military equation in the Persian Gulf before sending more forces into combat. He has not yet made a convincing case for intensified air strikes against Iraq.
Some retaliation against Iraq was justified after its armored thrust into the internationally guaranteed Kurdish region, and its ground fire at American aircraft overflying northern Iraq yesterday should not go unanswered. 
 While we supported Mr. Clinton's actions last week, he does not have a blank check from Congress or the American people to mount military operations without demonstrating that America's national security interests are threatened. It is not clear what would justify the "disproportionate" response that Defense Secretary William Perry ominously threatened yesterday.
Exchanging fire with Iraqi forces is not a policy. In the absence of a clear strategy for dealing with Mr. Hussein and the gulf region, and in the heat of an election campaign, retaliatory strikes could quickly escalate into a confrontation that ultimately damages American interests.
Circumstances in Iraq and the Middle East have changed since an American-led coalition drove Iraq out of Kuwait in 1991. Iraq's conventional military forces, while much reduced from their prewar level, have been rebuilt and could once again pose a credible threat to neighboring countries. Many gulf war allies have seen their resolve to resist Mr. Hussein's belligerence eroded by domestic politics, economic considerations or the passage of time.
Saudi Arabia, a centerpiece of the coalition, faces internal unrest and anti-American terrorist threats under an ailing King Fahd. Turkey is now led by an Islamic Prime Minister eager to improve relations with Iraq. France, Russia and China no longer support military action against Baghdad. Iran, as always, waits to exploit weaknesses in Iraq.
All of this limits what the United States can and should do on its own to deal with Saddam Hussein. The vital American interest in the area is oil. Saddam Hussein cannot be allowed, through conquest or intimidation, to determine the availability or price of much of the global oil supply.
The challenge for Washington is to devise new policies that adequately protect American interests in the region but do not recklessly commit American military forces to combat or inadvertently destabilize other countries, particularly Saudi Arabia and Turkey, where the presence of American forces is a sensitive issue.
So far, Iraq has not threatened Saudi Arabia or Kuwait in its latest military maneuvering. Last week's American cruise-missile strikes against antiaircraft installations in southern Iraq, and the expansion of a no-flight zone there, make it much harder for Mr. Hussein to turn his forces south anytime soon. In that sense, Mr. Clinton has accomplished what should be the primary American objective in the region.
American interests in northern Iraq are far less clear at this point. President Clinton inherited a commitment from the Bush Administration to shield the Kurds from Baghdad's abuses. Mr. Hussein's recent military campaign against one faction of Kurds required a measured response, which Mr. Clinton delivered last week, but America's role must be circumscribed in the tangled world of Kurdish internecine fighting.
Mr. Hussein should be checked when he threatens his neighbors, abuses his countrymen and defies Security Council resolutions. But the American response should be proportionate to the danger and determined by a careful calculation of American interests. Saddam Hussein would like nothing more than to draw the United States into a conflict that could strengthen his hold over Iraq and destabilize the region.

HEADLINE: U.S. Aid to World Birth-Control Efforts Faces Cuts

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Three years after the Clinton Administration lifted a ban on aid for international birth control efforts that include abortion and abortion counseling, the House, the Senate and the White House are at loggerheads over Republican attempts to revive the ban, a dispute that could block passage of the $12 billion foreign aid bill.
If an end to the impasse is not found by this week, foreign aid spending will be conducted under a stop-gap spending measure called a continuing resolution. Besides maintaining a 35 percent reduction enacted earlier this year in American aid to population control worldwide, that measure would sharply reduce American contributions to the World Bank and aid to North Korea that is supposed to keep that country from developing nuclear weapons. 
 As is often the case in family planning programs, the issue in the latest fight is abortion, or more precisely whether American aid can go to private international family planning organizations that use their own funds either to provide abortions in developing countries or to counsel women on how to end their pregnancies.
Last February anti-abortion forces in the House, unable to gain an outright ban on American aid to such organizations, succeeded in slashing contributions from $547 million to $356 million in the 1996 fiscal year budget. The House also won approval of legislation that said American contributions to these family planning programs could not begin until July 1, 1996 -- a nine-month delay -- and that once the programs started, the Government could give out only 6.7 percent of the funds each month over a 15-month period.
The result was an effective 87 percent cut in American family planning aid to international programs and a sea of red tape for American agencies doling out the aid.
"It's really strangled the program and caused enormous administrative burdens," said Dr. Nils Daulaire, deputy assistant administrator for policy at the Agency for International Development, which administers foreign aid. "It's probably been the biggest single cause of increased paperwork on A.I.D. over the last decade."
Mr. Daulaire said the new system has added about $1 million in administrative costs for his agency.
A study conducted this spring by the Alan Gutmacher Institute, the research arm of the Planned Parenthood Federation, estimated that the 35 percent reduction in American family planning contributions would lead to 4 million more unintended pregnancies worldwide, and to1.6 million more abortions.
In June the House passed a version of the foreign aid bill that cut financing by 50 percent to any international family family planning group that conducts abortions, advises on their availability or provides information that could lead a country to change its abortion laws. In July the Senate passed a measure that contains no such restrictions, and so far a House-Senate conference has failed to resolve the differences.
President Clinton has vowed to veto any bill containing the abortion restrictions, but so far the House leadership, pressed by anti-abortion groups like the National Right to Life Committee and the Christian Coalition, has been holding firm.
"What we're trying to get back to is the policy that was enforced for over 10 years under Republican Administrations, under which the U.S. provided almost half of the family planning money in the entire pool, but only gave to groups that stuck with family planning and sterilization and did not promote abortion," said Douglas Johnson, the director of government relations for the National Right to Life Committee.
The fight over funds for family planning organizations that provide abortions or abortion counseling began in 1984 when the Reagan Administration announced at a population conference in Mexico City that the United States would no longer contribute to family planning groups it felt were promoting abortion. That policy was reversed by President Clinton on his second day in office in 1993, and now the Administration and family planning groups are fighting attempts by anti-abortion forces in Congress to reinstate it.
Population stabilization advocates say attempts by anti-abortion forces to reduce funds for international family planning efforts are causing the United States to relinquish its leadership in this area at a time when increased education and family planning efforts are beginning to slow the growth in the world's population.
"The projections right now are that if these family planning efforts can be maintained over the next decade, we will for the first time in human history see an absolute decline in the rate of growth and possibly get to zero growth sometime in the next century," Mr. Daulaire said. He added that restrictions being imposed on family planning programs "put that goal very much at risk."
Two years ago, at a United Nations population conference in Cairo, the United States and 150 other countries pledged to increase global spending on population stabilization to $17 billion by 2000, from about $5 billion. American contributions to international family planning efforts rose steadily during the Bush Administration and in the first two years of Mr. Clinton's term, before being cut in the last fiscal year.
"U.S. leadership is absolutely imperative on this," said Timothy Wirth, Under Secretary of State for Global Affairs. "If you think about the issues that are going to be resounding issues in the 21st century, this is one of the top two or three, if not the biggest."
For their part, anti-abortion lawmakers say these programs promote abortion and represent an attempt by the United States and the Western countries to impose their values on the Third World.
"A lot of this is about cultural imperialism," said Grover Joseph Rees, an aide to Representative Chris Smith, a New Jersey Republican who is a leader of the anti-abortion forces in the House. "It's about using funds that should go to child survival programs or increased education, and instead using them to try to persuade people that they ought to have the number of children we think they ought to have, rather than the number they think they ought of have."

HEADLINE: Adelphi Provost Defends Officials at Regents Hearing, Telling of a 'Survival Mission'

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
Adelphi University was barely muddling along a decade ago, poorly organized and in need of revitalization, a top official of the university testified yesterday.
"The most frequently articulated mission was survival," said Dr. Igor M. Webb, Adelphi's provost and senior vice president. 
 Dr. Webb was recruited in 1986 by Adelphi's president, Dr. Peter Diamandopoulos, to aid in his effort to revive the university. And Dr. Webb was Adelphi's leadoff witness as the school began its defense against allegations of mismanagement.
The New York State Board of Regents is holding hearings in Manhattan on a request to remove Adelphi's trustees, including Dr. Diamandopoulos. The request was made by the Committee to Save Adelphi, a coalition of faculty members, former trustees, administrators, alumni and students, which presented its evidence during 15 days of testimony.
Dr. Webb, citing a 1982 study by Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Company, said Adelphi had an inadequate central administration, "weak faculty self-image," "weak student self-image" and weak trustees.
As a newcomer, he said, "It was hard for an outsider like me to figure out how things got done." Even the Provost's files were not alphabetized, he said.
Among the other problems he said he found were that there was no orientation for students, documentation of peer review for tenure and promotion was "extremely skimpy," there was little evaluation of teaching and "the institution was inbred."
His attempts to make changes soon met resistance, Dr. Webb said.
"There was a somewhat defensive attitude toward an outsider," he said. In trying to impose more evaluation of teachers, he said, "I was absolutely met by a stone wall, and it remains an issue at the school."
In 1989, the faculty voted no confidence in Dr. Diamandopoulos and Dr. Webb, and more recently have called for the resignation of the president and trustees..
The faculty "believed the quality of teaching was high," Dr. Webb said, but he did not. He said the faculty awarded students inflated grades. The students averaged B, but their scores "on all the national examinations is below average," he said.
Dr. Webb also faulted the faculty for a drop in writing scholarly works around 1980 that he termed "striking." To help counter that problem, he said, Adelphi gave the faculty more time by cutting the teaching load to three courses from four.
Dr. Webb said Dr. Diamandopoulos sought to instill in Adelphi "a unifying mission -- the view was that the university didn't have an image."
Dr. Webb extolled as major innovations the creation of the honors college and the adoption of a core curriculum that seeks to give Adelphi undergraduates a cross-disciplinary view of modern issues, knowledge and values. The faculty endorsed the curriculum but has differed with the administration on the honors college by insisting that the faculty continue to play a role in selecting the professors.
Dr. Webb's testimony is to resume today. His cross-examination may return to parts of the Peat, Marwick report that he did not mention. That report called Adelphi "a good regional institution" and counted among its strengths the "academic quality of several of its programs" and the "humane and personal style of its organizational culture."
The report also praised the president at the time, Dr. Timothy W. Costello, for "increasing and maintaining student enrollments" and "creating a collegial campus culture." Under Dr. Diamandopoulos, enrollment has dropped more than a third, and critics say he has polarized the campus.

HEADLINE: U.S. Veterans Give Vietnam Clues About Hanoi's Missing

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, Sept. 11

 BODY:
American veterans of the Vietnam War took another step toward reconciliation with their former enemies today, handing over information about mass graves where 600 North Vietnamese servicemen are thought to be buried.
James Brazee, president of Vietnam Veterans of America, handed his counterpart in Hanoi a North Vietnamese soldier's ammunition pouch and gas mask along with a briefcase packed with papers related to the war that ended 21 years ago. 
 "The issue of those missing is still of primary importance to both sides," Mr. Brazee told Nguyen Trong Vinh, a retired major general and vice president of the Vietnam Veterans Association.
The documents, which included maps pinpointing two burial sites in the central province of Quang Tri, increased to more than 6,000 the number of Vietnamese war dead about whom the American veterans group has provided information.
The group began the drive in February 1994, asking members to turn in battlefield souvenirs to help Vietnam determine the fate of some of its 300,000 missing servicemen.
General Vinh thanked Mr. Brazee for the objects and papers and told him that the body of an American pilot had been recently discovered in Quang Tri, the scene of some of the fiercest battles during the 1968 Tet Offensive.
He said that Vietnamese veterans had provided information that helped the United States clear up 29 cases. He also promised continued cooperation between the two associations.
United States officials list 2,143 American members of the military and civilians still missing in action in Southeast Asia. More than 1,600 of the total were in Vietnam.
More than 3 million Vietnamese and about 58,000 Americans died in the war, which ended in 1975 with a Communist victory over South Vietnam, which was backed by the United States.
The United States and Vietnam normalized relations in July 1995. But economic and strategic ties have been hampered by the festering M.I.A. issue.
Before a visit in July by the American national security adviser, Anthony Lake, Hanoi expressed some irritation in a news briefing over Washington's stress on M.I.A. accounting and said there were other postwar issues that needed to be addressed.
The Vietnam Veterans Association, whose members are on a five-day visit, was due to hold talks in Hanoi on Thursday about the effects of Agent Orange. The herbicide was widely used by the Americans in the war to clear jungles areas used by the Vietcong and North Vietnamese troops.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks To End Direct Aid For Kurds

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
With the allied relief effort in northern Iraq in disarray, the Clinton Administration is looking for ways to end its direct role in providing food, shelter and other aid to the Kurds, leaving it instead to relief groups and international organizations like the United Nations, Administration officials said today.
The officials insisted that the United States would not abandon its commitment to aid Kurdish civilians in the future. And they vowed that American and allied aircraft would continue to patrol the no-flight zone to restrict President Saddam Hussein's military operations north of the 36th parallel. 
 But with a Kurdish faction allied with Mr. Hussein now controlling much of northern Iraq, giving him his strongest presence in the Kurdish enclave since the Persian Gulf war in 1991, the United States has suspended all of its relief efforts in the region. And it appeared unlikely that the United States would resume the direct help it has provided for five years as part of what is called Operation Provide Comfort.
"We now have to look to the international relief organizations to provide the kind of help that Operation Provide Comfort did in the past -- the economic, humanitarian help," the State Department's spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said today. "But we will continue to run the military mission, which has been so effective in containing Saddam Hussein."
Another Administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, went further, saying the United States would not again have as direct or strong a relief role now that Mr. Hussein is wielding greater power over the Kurdish enclave. "It's going to be difficult to have anything like what we did," the official said.
The uncertainty about relief aid underscored the Administration's shifting policy toward the Kurds in wake of the warring between Kurdish factions and the incursion of Mr. Hussein's forces on Aug. 31. Having led the coalition to create a "safe haven" in northern Iraq both as a response to a relief crisis and as a bulwark against Mr. Hussein, the United States has now focused primarily on checking the threat of Iraqi aggression in the south, saying it did not want to intervene in a Kurdish civil war.
"Let's remember what the core of U.S. strategic interests are: to protect Saudi Arabia and Kuwait," Mr. Burns said.
With the Administration shifting its policy and with the balance of power changed in northern Iraq, the rationale for continuing the operations in the north has increasingly become an open question, even for the allies that joined the United States in creating the protected enclave.
In Turkey, which has allowed allied aircraft to operate from Incirlik, Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan met with his Cabinet today to discuss the future of the enclave and the air patrols. "It became apparent that the duties and responsibilities of Provide Comfort have to be looked at again in the light of recent developments," a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry, Omar Akbel, said today.
Britain, the strongest supporter of the American missile strikes in Iraq last week, has also indicated that the relief part of the operation needed to be reconsidered, though it remained committed to the patrols.
The United States, Britain, Turkey and France created the enclave after Mr. Hussein's forces crushed a rebellion by Kurds, prompting an exodus of refugees into Turkey and Iran.
At the height of the crisis in the spring of 1991, the allies established a military presence in northern Iraq and airlifted more than 1.7 million tons of food, medicines, blankets and other materials to help Kurds return to their homes. Since then the United States has gradually reduced its contributions to relief efforts -- from nearly $600 million in 1991 to $71 million the next year to $22 million so far this year.
According to the United Nations, about 650,000 of the more than 3 million Kurds in northern Iraq receive some form of help, mostly food or medicine. The United States oversaw the relief aid, but generally left the delivery of it to organizations like Unicef and to private relief groups.
The operation included the air patrols, a small military force serving as observers in Zakho, Iraq, on the border with Turkey, and the relief aid. When Iraq's forces seized the Kurdish city of Erbil, the distribution center for most of the assistance, the relief aid and the military presence on the ground in Iraq ended. About 15 people working for the United States Government and another 50 Americans working with relief organizations left Iraq.
One official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the United States had already planned on phasing out its direct control over the relief assistance. Iraq's incursion, the official said, forced it do so more abruptly than planned.
Mr. Burns said the United States would continue to offer money to the International Committee of the Red Cross and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. But there will be an interruption of relief assistance as the Administration looks for "a way to do it without a physical United States presence," as one senior official put it.
A White House official said that the United States would shift responsibility for food and medicine, but that one program to rebuild destroyed villages would be discontinued indefinitely.

HEADLINE: Private Program for Troubled Students Echoes Catholic School Plan

BYLINE: By MIRTA OJITO 

 BODY:
Two years ago, Sean Kendell Winn was the kind of student who is at the heart of the plan advocated this week by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to send some public school students to Roman Catholic schools.
A Bronx student who would get into fights and end up suspended, Sean was accepted by a Catholic school in his first year of high school. Almost all expenses were paid by private donors. 
 "My life," Sean said yesterday, "is much nicer now."
Sean, now a 16-year-old junior at All Hallows High School with an 85 average, is a beneficiary of a 10-year-old private program, Student-Sponsor Partnership, which was created for students in grades 9 through 12 by Peter M. Flanigan, an investment banker at Dillon, Read & Company.
The partnership, which has helped 825 students enrolled in 18 Catholic schools to graduate since 1986, bears striking similarities to a proposal recently made by the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York and, since Sunday, backed by the Mayor.
Under the archdiocese's plan, Catholic schools would educate 1,000 of the city school system's worst students, providing both secular and religious instruction. Their tuition would be paid by private businesses.
After some board members cited constitutional concerns about having school employees acting as admissions counselors for Roman Catholic schools, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew said yesterday that the Board of Education would not compile lists of eligible students for the program advocated by Mr. Giuliani -- a decision the Mayor says he understands.
But the Chancellor's spokeswoman said that guidance counselors would continue to advise students to seek scholarships to private schools and would release school records for those who do, much as they have been doing for the Student-Sponsor Partnership for the last 10 years. In that way, the Partnership sees itself as a model for the Mayor's plan.
"We hope that what we are doing could serve as a blueprint for what the Mayor is proposing," said Mayree Clark, the chairwoman of the partnership's board and director of global research at Morgan Stanley.
Ms. Clark said 75 percent of the program's students graduate in four years and 90 percent go on to college. Omar Antigua, a 20-year-old junior at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, is one of them.
"They opened up so many doors for me, I couldn't even begin to count them," said Mr. Antigua, the third child of an unemployed immigrant who reared three boys by herself in a tough Bronx neighborhood. "Where I come from, I'm a rarity."
Mary Grace Eapen, the partnership's executive director, said the program works to make students feel special. "They want discipline, they want order," she said. "They want to have someone in their lives who expects great things from them, and we do."
Applicants learn of the program through their eighth-grade guidance counselors or community leaders, Ms. Eapen said. Once a student decides to apply, school counselors or teachers supply test scores, a list of the student's weaknesses and strengths and an analysis of why the student would probably not succeed were he or she to continue in the public school system.
"Counselors are very vigilant at spotting the kids that could benefit the most from our help," Ms. Eapen said. "They want what's best for their kids and they know we provide it."
Of the thousands of students who apply every year, several hundred are accepted. This year, 345 new students entered the program.
Although the partnership program is similar to the one advocated by the Mayor, it differs in two ways.
First, its eligibility requirements are broader: It considers poverty, poor grades and disciplinary problems as qualifications for entry, not simply whether a student has been identified as one of the school system's worst. Second, it provides mentors to guide students in addition to paying their tuitions.
The partnership has 1,030 students but is short 150 mentors.
Sponsors pay at least $850 in tuition a year for four years. The rest of a student's tuition, which could be as high as $3,800, is paid by parents, who contribute $30 a month, and money raised from foundations and private businesses.
The idea for the partnership came about when Mr. Flanigan realized that it took more than the promise of a bright future to make students finish their education, Ms. Eapen said. More than a decade ago, he promised a class of sixth graders that if they finished high school, he would pay for their college education. Despite the incentive, many students dropped out of school.
The schools, he concluded, were failing the students. About the same time, Mr. Flanigan learned that Roman Catholic schools were more successful in keeping students in the classroom, so he shifted his focus and decided to encourage public school students to attend those private schools.
The partnership tries to match sponsors with students based on shared interests or experiences, sometimes a difficult goal because most of the students are black or Latino while 88 percent of the sponsors are non-Hispanic whites.
But most of the time, despite cultural and economic differences, a bond is forged. It happened to Sean and his sponsor, James C. Jurney, a 26-year-old who went to boarding school, lives at Central Park West and works at Morgan Stanley. Their bond is theater. Sean wants to be an actor; Mr. Jurney is interested in television and films.
"We go to the theater." Mr. Jurney said. "we talk. He tells me about his girlfriends. I'm his big brother. He's a good kid."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sean Kendell Winn, left, and his private sponsor, James C. Jurney, 26, at All Hallows High School in the Bronx, where Sean, 16, is a junior. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)(pg. B3)

HEADLINE: Dow Up 27.74 Points, Aided by Oil Stocks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Stocks rose yesterday as heightened tensions in the Middle East drove up the price of crude oil and the shares of oil companies like Exxon and Texaco.
The Dow Jones industrial average, up as much as 43 points during the day and within 11 points of its closing high, closed at 5,754.92, up 27.74 points. The Dow, which includes four oil-related companies among its 30 blue-chip issues, is up 12.5 percent this year, a far stronger gain than the 8.4 percent increase on the broader-based Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. 
 "The Dow has clearly been leading the S.& P., and oil is heavily weighted in that average," said Dirk van Dijk, chief investment strategist at Dean Investment Associates, which manages $4 billion.
The S.& P. 500 jumped 3.47 points, to 667.28, lifted by energy, health care and bank shares. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 4.52 points, to 1,153.95.
Oil-related stocks, which accounted for 15 points of the gain in the Dow, rose as investors expected that higher prices for crude oil would translate into profit gains.
Texaco gained 1 7/8 a share, to 94 5/8. Exxon rose 1 1/2, to 84 7/8; Chevron climbed 1 1/8, to 61 1/2, and Du Pont, which owns Conoco, rose 7/8, to 85 1/4. Amoco jumped 3/4 a share, to 70 3/8, and Mobil rose 1 7/8, to 118 3/8.
The Pentagon confirmed that Iraq had launched a missile at two American jet fighters, missing both targets. The United States moved more warplanes into the region yesterday, raising concern that escalating military activities in the region could disrupt the shipment of oil.
Higher prices for crude oil were also expected to benefit oil drillers, as the potential gains from costly new exploration increased. Reading & Bates jumped 1 1/4 a share, to 26 3/4; Global Marine climbed 5/8, to 16 1/8, and Halliburton, a provider of oil services, rose 1 1/2, to 55 7/8.
Motorola, the day's most actively traded stock, sank 1 3/8, to 49 1/4, after warning that slow chip sales and a price slump could result in disappointing earnings for a second straight quarter.
But other chip shares shrugged off Motorola's woes, focusing instead on a report on semiconductor sales, released late on Tuesday, which suggested that orders had rebounded in August. The book-to-bill ratio, which measures new orders for chips in North America against deliveries, rose to 0.90 from 0.86 in July.
Intel, the largest chip maker, rose 3/4 a share, to 85; Micron Technology climbed 1/2, to 21 1/2, and Xilinx jumped 1 5/8, to 32 1/4.
United Healthcare rose 1 1/2, to 40 1/8, after being named the leader of three companies picked to negotiate to provide nearly $4 billion in insurance services to the American Association of Retired Persons. The other two companies are the ITT Hartford Group, which rose 1 1/8, to 54 1/8, and Metropolitan Life Insurance, which is closely held.
Those companies' new business came at the expense of Prudential Insurance, whose exclusive contract with the association made up about 10 percent of Prudential's revenue. Prudential, which, like Met Life, is owned by its policyholders, said it would cut 3,500 jobs in the wake of losing the business.
Itron slumped 8 a share, to 21, after it surprised investors by saying that it expects to report a loss in the third quarter because utilities are ordering fewer of its electronic meter readers.

HEADLINE: Foreign Investment Agency Is Rebuffed in House Vote

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
The House dealt a sharp blow today to a Federal agency that provides insurance and loan guarantees to American companies that invest in developing nations.
By a vote of 260 to 157, the House rejected a bill to renew the lending and insuring authority of the agency, the Overseas Private Investment Corporation. The agency's current authorization expires Sept. 30. 
 If the agency's authority is not renewed by then, OPIC will still be able to service its existing portfolio, but it will not be allowed to write any new insurance policies or underwrite new investments. OPIC's most strident critics say they are not ruling out a last-minute compromise, but they also say it is unclear what happens next.
"This was totally unexpected," said Representative John R. Kasich, Republican of Ohio, who is head of the House Budget Committee and a leading OPIC critic. "I can't tell you how it gets resolved."
OPIC's chief executive, Ruth R. Harkin, said she regretted the outcome, but she promised that "we will continue to work with Congress on a measure that will preserve OPIC's ability to create American jobs and U.S. exports."
At issue is how much OPIC should grow, if it should grow at all. Today's surprisingly decisive vote will give the agency's critics great leverage over its future.
OPIC supporters, including many of the nation's top corporations and most powerful labor unions, sought to extend the agency's authority by five years, expand its financing authority to $20 billion from $9 billion, and raise its insurance ceilings to $25 billion from $13 billion.
Proponents say that OPIC pays for itself with fees and premiums -- it is expected to bring in $189 million a year to the Treasury Department -- and that it helps United States exports, creates jobs here and promotes the nation's foreign policy goals in places like Eastern Europe, Asia and Latin America.
But OPIC supporters badly underestimated the influence and anger of an unlikely coalition of critics that included budget-cutting conservatives like Mr. Kasich and the House's only independent, Representative Bernard Sanders of Vermont.
These critics argued that OPIC practiced "corporate welfare" by underwriting the third world investments of such large corporations as Citicorp, the Union Carbide Corporation and the Ford Motor Company. Critics have also contended that private insurers can protect American companies from political risk overseas more efficiently than a Federal agency can.
"With the destabilizing effects of corporate downsizing on American workers and their families, we should not be providing incentives for America's corporate giants to invest abroad," Representative Jesse Jackson Jr., Democrat of Illinois, said in a lively floor debate Tuesday.
Opponents criticized as too risky several OPIC projects, including a soft-drink bottling company in Poland, a travel agency in Armenia, a shrimp farm in Ecuador and a camel-hair processing plant in Mongolia.
Proponents countered that without OPIC, American companies would cede growing markets in developing countries to foreign competitors, a loss that would hurt American exports and undermine Washington's foreign policy. In OPIC's 25-year history, its risk-insurance program has had to pay only 1 percent in claims.
OPIC coverage has become a staple for multinational corporations investing abroad, and last year the agency sold policies covering $8.6 billion in investments.
"This bill will support billions of dollars of U.S. exports and the creation of thousands of jobs at minimal cost to the taxpayer," said Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, Republican of New York, who heads the House International Relations Committee.
Reflecting the shortage of time for this Congress, the sponsors of the bill offered it under an expedited procedure that suspends normal House rules but requires two-thirds approval of all those voting.
In today's vote, 173 Republicans, 86 Democrats and one independent voted to reject the extension; 53 Republicans and 104 Democrats voted in favor of the bill.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
Dole Draws on a Personal Victory to Assure His G.O.P. Colleagues of Political Victory

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Bob Dole returned to Capitol Hill today to reassure those he called "the faint-hearted" that he had the determination to raise himself from the political near-dead because he had once raised himself from the literal near-dead.
Addressing about 120 of his former House and Senate colleagues, Mr. Dole spoke of his 39-month recuperation from paralyzing combat wounds in World War II. He read a letter written in 1945 to his father by an official at the Army hospital in Michigan where Lieut. Bob Dole lay motionless. 
 "At the present time," the official wrote, "it would appear that his recovery is somewhat questionable."
Mr. Dole fought back to become the longest-serving Republican majority leader in Senate history and is now one election away from either becoming President or closing out his life in politics.
Mr. Dole, who is trailing President Clinton by double-digits in the national polls, contended today that he had emerged from "tough spots" before and would do so again this Election Day.
"I want to say to the fainthearted people in this audience -- though there are probably not very many -- don't worry about this election," he said. "We're going to win, we're going to win, we're going to win."
There was also a pragmatic edge to the message from this campaign warhorse, who has been winning elections for nearly half a century. Mr. Dole acknowledged up front that his coattails, if any, might be very short indeed.
"Wherever we can help -- or if we can't help, you can tell us that -- but wherever we can help, we're going to be there," he said.
And he opened a small window onto his view of his responsibility at the top of a flagging ticket, saying that his duty was to remain optimistic.
"Each of us have been in close races, tough races," he said. "The polls go up and down, and people get discouraged. But the candidate can never get discouraged. The candidate has to be optimistic."
Reprising a phrase from his acceptance speech last month at the Republican National Convention in San Diego, he said, "I'm the most optimistic man in America."
Mr. Dole was greeted warmly by the Republican senators and House members who had responded to the campaign's urgent fax message, sent with only one day's notice, to turn out this morning for a display of unity with the top of the party ticket.
Speaker Newt Gingrich and Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, hailed Mr. Dole and his running mate, Jack Kemp. Mr. Lott led the cheerleading, telling Mr. Dole that it was not until he and other Republicans dined with Mr. Dole last Saturday that he realized "there was an aura around Bob."
But in interviews after Mr. Dole's speech today, some of those in attendance expressed concern about the Dole campaign and how to mesh their own campaigns with it.
"I'm assuming our basic message is correct," said Representative Mark E. Souder, a freshman from Indiana, "but the messenger is not connecting."
Mr. Souder said today's event was staged for the media because the Dole campaign and the Republican National Committee were "concerned that Congressional candidates are drifting into independence."
"They know we see the polls," Mr. Souder said.
Mr. Dole smiled through it all, and later on his plane he shrugged off questions about Republicans being worried that he might drag them down in November.
"They're all my friends, you know," he said. "I've lived there for a long time. I didn't see any anxious people there."
As Mr. Dole headed back to the campaign trail after his speech, he found more bad news.
He landed first in Connecticut, where a new state poll by the University of Connecticut and The Hartford Courant showed him trailing Mr. Clinton by 29 points. In neighboring Massachusetts, a new poll by The Boston Globe put Mr. Clinton ahead by 19 points.
In Delaware, where Mr. Dole was defeated in the Presidential primary by Steve Forbes, it was Mr. Forbes was led Mr. Dole's "Listening to America" session today.
Mr. Forbes, who is now an economic adviser to the Dole campaign, said at the outset that he would take all of the questions before Mr. Dole would answer. Several in the audience asked questions, most of which Mr. Forbes answered while Mr. Dole stood to the side. At one point, when Mr. Forbes told one questioner, "Bob will be responding later," Mr. Dole interjected, "Not much later."
After 33 minutes, Mr. Forbes finally yielded the floor to Mr. Dole, who began by referring twice to the fact that by now, it was "dinner time."

HEADLINE: A Backlash-and-Forth Smog War;
Radical Swings in Clean Air Plan in Los Angeles Area

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Flash back to 1992, when hundreds of business executives and union officials joined in a candlelight vigil on the steps of Southern California's pollution-control agency to protest air-quality standards that they said were strangling the economy and killing jobs. Their rare show of unity helped prod the agency to roll back some of the nation's strictest environmental regulations.
Now fast-forward to the hot, smoggy summer of 1996. The Los Angeles area still has the foulest air in the United States. Yet, the once-feared South Coast Air Quality Management District is now bending over backward to be business's best friend, with its "green carpet service" to help companies get permits more quickly and its program to educate violators of the laws instead of fining them. And even though the agency's budget has been cut to $93 million from $113 million four years ago, Jon D. Mikels, its chairman, wants to cut the staff in half over the next decade and eliminate permits required of most small businesses. 
 If it seems to be too good to be true for California industry, it probably is. For, just as a backlash built up in the early 1990's against the state's all-out war on smog, today, a growing chorus of critics is sounding the alarm about the dangers of retreating too far. Last month, leading opponents of the policy change staged a protest that matched the symbolism of the 1992 business-labor march. In response to proposals in the agency's latest long-range plan for a further watering down of air-pollution rules, nine of the 11 members of its scientific advisory panel resigned en masse.
"They've been losing their commitment to meeting air-quality standards," declared Jane Hall, an economist who had served on the panel for 10 years. "It's a pattern that's been building up for the past 18 months to two years, and then this proposed plan was the straw that broke the camel's back. We weren't just going to watch that happen."
The environmental debate here is more than just a local dispute over industrial emissions. California and Los Angeles in particular have long been models for air-quality regulations in other states. For instance, when California adopted its tough rules mandating that auto makers put large numbers of electric vehicles, or "zero emission vehicles," in showrooms, several states adopted similar rules -- and are now expected to follow California's subsequent decision to relax those restrictions.
Similarly, California's proposed rules cutting emissions from architectural coatings and certain solvents are likely to influence regulatory decision making in other states -- and, ultimately, on the kinds of products that reach consumers.
More broadly, the same forces that have been lobbying environmental officials in Southern California are active across the country. As governments struggle to achieve the often incompatible goals of protecting the environment and promoting economic growth, similar skirmishes are bound to break out elsewhere.
In California, the policy battle is far from decided. But in the view of James M. Lents, the air quality district's executive director, the tide may be turning in favor of the environmental purists. "Suddenly, the business climate is getting good again," Mr. Lents said. "People are looking out the window, and the air quality is awful. And they're saying, 'We wanted things easier, but we didn't mean stop cleaning up the air.' We're starting a new cycle."
Even business interests are showing a new environmental consciousness. Robert Wyman, a lawyer who helped lead the charge by major corporations like Unocal, Chevron, Hughes Aircraft and Rockwell to ease the regulations a few years ago, said he thought the scientific advisory council might have been justified in its action. "I think the resignations caught people by surprise, but they were probably right," Mr. Wyman said. "This group of experts had been underutilized."
And Nader Monsour, head of environmental affairs at Southern California Edison, a big utility company, acknowledged that further progress must be made and that some price must be borne. "The air quality has improved, but it really has to improve a lot more; we understand that," he said.
To a large extent, business's concerns are based on practical considerations. The Los Angeles basin -- a region of 13 million people in Riverside, San Bernardino, Los Angeles and Orange counties -- is finding it increasingly difficult to attract companies and good jobs at its eastern end because of heavy pollution, creating fears that the area is doomed to a substandard quality of life.
"The higher paying jobs are going elsewhere because of the air out here," complained Ron Loveridge, the Mayor of the city of Riverside and a member of the agency's board. "The mid- to higher-paying jobs are a real problem for us."
Mainstream environmental groups, emboldened by the panel's mass defection, are warning that the agency's probusiness tilt is threatening the region's long-term environmental health. "For two decades this district was moving forward," said Gail Ruderman Feuer, a senior lawyer here with the Natural Resources Defense Council. "Now we're moving in the opposite direction. It's not subtle."
Some local newspapers have also weighed in with editorials questioning the agency's course. The mass resignation "strikes a blow directly to that agency's credibility," said The Inland Valley Daily Bulletin, a newspaper based in Ontario, 50 miles east of downtown Los Angeles. "The clear, though unstated, implication is that political pressure, not air quality needs, shaped the new plan. That's a question of integrity."
All the criticism seems to be giving the largely pro-business environmental agency's board second thoughts. Several members have appointed an ad hoc panel of specialists to re-examine the new long-term plan.
But the opponents of regulation are, if anything, more vocal than ever. Mike Antonovich, a pro-business Los Angeles County Supervisor who sits on the agency's board, described the departing advisory panel members -- all highly regarded specialists in areas like health care and engineering -- as extremists bent on "shutting down our economy," and he welcomed their resignations as a "breath of fresh air." And Curt Pringle, the conservative Republican Speaker of the State Assembly, has denounced the agency as "the No. 1 job-killing machine in this state" and announced his desire to dismantle it.
Environmentalists complain that the agency has already lost its teeth. It is in the process of reducing the number of stations monitoring air quality to 22 from 35. It has also imposed a hiring freeze, and left the job of chief prosecutor, responsible for finding and citing offenders, vacant since 1991. The number of inspections of businesses has declined to about one-third their level six years ago. Rules on car pooling have been relaxed and other regulations that would have restricted the number of cars entering big shopping centers, theme parks and the like were dropped. Indeed, the burden of cleaning up the air still falls heaviest on industry rather than motorists, even though autos produce most of the harmful emissions.
The long-term air-quality plan unveiled last month strikes many as a boon for business. The plan eliminates 36 regulations proposed in its 1994 plan, cutting the cost to business by more than two-thirds, to $1.7 billion a year from $5.4 billion, by the agency's estimate.
One reason for the reduction is a key change the district's technical experts made in their computer models for estimating future emission levels. In the 1994 plan, they had used as the base for their projections a particularly smoggy day in 1985; in the new plan they changed to a less choking day in 1987.
Mr. Lents, the agency's executive officer, acknowledged that the decision had a big impact on policy-making. "I probably had an intuitive sense that it would come out a little bit easier if we did that," he said.
That computing change was particularly disturbing for Akula Venkatram, one of the scientific advisers who resigned. Mr. Venkatram, an expert on computer modeling at the University of California at Riverside, said: "If it's a new kind of model, that's important, and it should not be presented without extensive peer review, which they never did. I never saw it. Without a review, I'm skeptical."
Among the results of this and other changes in the computer models was a determination that emissions levels did not have to be reduced as much as had been previously estimated. Mr. Lents denied, however, that the changes had been influenced by politics or businesses. He said they simply reflected better science and more accurate measurements.
For all the soul-searching going on, Southern California still has some of the toughest air-pollution standards in the country. The air quality management district enforces three volumes of regulations that cover everything from the grittiest industrial smokestacks to charcoal broilers and printing shops. Restriction on emissions from paints and other kinds of industrial coatings are so strict that McDonnell Douglas must ship some of the commercial jets that it builds at Long Beach, Calif., to Arizona to be painted.
As a result, the quality of the air is improving, albeit from a dismal previous state. The Los Angeles basin failed to meet Federal ozone standards on a total of 98 days last year, a poor record but better than the 158 days that it fell short a decade ago.
Emissions still must be cut by another 60 percent -- at a time when the population is expanding rapidly -- to meet minimum Federal standards by 2010. And the Natural Resources Defense Council estimates that some 8,000 Southern Californians a year die early deaths because of the poor air quality.
To visit the area is to see why. Mr. Lents, the head of the air-pollution control agency, looked at the pall outside his office window in Diamond Bar, a suburb in the heart of the smog belt. He reflected on the ups and downs in the regulatory environment and then observed of the wonderful, craggy but barely visible shapes in the distance: "Many times, I can't even see the outlines of those mountains."

GRAPHIC: Photos: While Southern California still has some of the toughest air-pollution standards in the country, a growing number of critics say that Los Angeles is retreating too far in its war on smog. (Photographs by Luis Sinco for The New York Times)
 
Graph: "Clear Horizons"
 In 1974, lead-free gasoline was introduced in California, and in 1975 the first catalytic converters were installed in new cars and light trucks. Those and subsequent measures helped push down ozone levels substantially, but some anti-smog rules were eased in the 1990's in response to a sharp economic decline and a loss of jobs.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: Political Briefing;
THE STATES AND THE ISSUES

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

 BODY:

California
Democrats Like Look of House Races
Like the outcome of the Presidential race, control of Congress depends in a big way on what happens in California, home to one of every eight members of the House. The Democrats hold an edge of only 27 to 25 in California's 52 House seats, and seldom have so many of those seats been in play this late in the campaign. 
 Democrats think they can pick up half a dozen seats, which would get them nearly a third of the way toward regaining control of the House. Republicans say the Democrats are California dreaming. But the Republicans' own best scenario, a gain of three seats, points to an optimism gap.
Hillary Rodham Clinton is scheduled to campaign today in the 22d Congressional District, where the Democrat, Walter H. Capps, a professor at the University of California at Santa Barbara, is in a tough rematch with Representative Andrea Seastrand, a freshman Republican. The race is considered a good barometer of feelings toward the first Republican Congress in 40 years.
Another tight race is in the 46th District, where the seat has been held for the last 12 years by Representative Robert K. Dornan, the Republican firebrand who ran for President this year. Mr. Dornan, behind in fund raising, says this may be the toughest race of his career.
Mr. Dornan has called on an old Hollywood pal, Charlton Heston, to help him campaign. But Democrats think they have the edge, in part because their nominee, Loretta Sanchez, a financial adviser, more closely matches the demographics of a district that is now 50 percent Hispanic.
Those are only two of the up-for-grabs races in a state where, political strategists say, the environment is much more of an issue than in other places and where the economy has recovered, briskly, and geologic misfortunes are in the rear-view mirror, at least for the moment.
The latest statewide party preference poll gave Democrats an edge of nearly 10 points, and Bob Dole is 22 points behind in a week-old California Field poll. "The only reason Dole is spending money here is because the Republicans are now worried about losing so many Congressional seats," said Julie Buckner, a spokeswoman for the Democratic Party in California.
Republicans are playing down social issues and playing up tax relief and regulatory reform. They remain upbeat, vowing not to lose a single California seat on the way to what Representative Bill Paxon of New York, the chairman of the National Republican Congressional Committee, says will be the first re-election of a Republican House majority in 70 years.
 
Gay Candidates
One Barometer Of Changing Times
Not so long ago, an openly gay candidate running for office in the Bible Belt or any rural area could expect to end up as political road kill. Times may be changing.
In Oklahoma, the Democrats have nominated Paul Barby, a wealthy oilman, rancher and member of the Board of Regents of Oklahoma Colleges, to face Frank D. Lucas, the incumbent Republican in the Sixth Congressional District. Just before Mr. Barby announced his candidacy, he told Democrats by letter that he is a homosexual.
The district is largely rural, taking up the western half of the state, and is full of socially conservative Southern Baptists. But, to the surprise of many of Mr. Barby's supporters, no one has yet made an issue of his sexual orientation. And Mr. Lucas says he will not make any fuss over it.
"Paul Barby has been campaigning all over the district," said Keith Smith, the Barby campaign manager, "and the worst thing that people have said to him is that they are going to vote for him but keep it secret."
Compare the current reaction with that of 1978, when David L. Boren of Oklahoma first ran for the Senate. After his opponent had brought up rumors, Mr. Boren felt compelled to swear on a Bible that he was heterosexual.
In Arizona, meanwhile, there has been no great talk-radio clamor or stump-speech vitriol directed at a six-term Congressman, Jim Kolbe, since he acknowledged a few weeks ago that he is homosexual. Mr. Kolbe, a Republican from the Tucson area, just won renomination with 70 percent of the vote and now has a wide lead in general-election polls.
"In terms of harm, I think it's really negligible," said one Republican official, Michael Hellon, a Tucson businessman. Campaign money, with notes of congratulations for Mr. Kolbe's acknowledgment, has come in, and his decision spurred another Arizona officeholder, Neil Giuliano, the Republican Mayor of Tempe, to announce late last month that he too is gay.
"Thirty or forty years ago if you were divorced, that was a huge issue," Mr. Hellon said. "Now that's not even worth mentioning from an electoral context. I think that is where we are headed on the gay issue."
 
Indiana
Struggling Candidate Blames Dole
Indiana, long known for college basketball and Republican political stripes, appears to be going through a bit of an identity crisis. It's too early to be talking about the fate of Hoosier hoops, but Republicans are in near-crisis mode.
A new Indianapolis Star poll of 1,061 registered voters shows Frank O'Bannon, a Democrat, leading for the first time in the race for governor against Stephen Goldsmith. Mr. Goldsmith, the Republican Mayor of Indianapolis, blames the Dole campaign, saying it has dragged the party down in the state.
"I'm not getting the lift that normally a Republican in a Presidential election year would get," Mr. Goldsmith told The Star. "My numbers are obviously repressed by Dole."
Republicans carried Indiana by wide margins in the last four Presidential elections, but Bob Dole is behind this year. The Star poll had President Clinton leading by 38 percent to 32 percent. TIMOTHY EGAN

HEADLINE: Veto of 'Prevailing Wage' Bill Is Overridden by City Council

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Drawing a clear distinction between its labor and business philosophies and those of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the City Council yesterday voted overwhelmingly to override the Mayor's veto of a bill that would require some city contractors to pay their workers more than double the minimum wage.
The vote, 42 to 5, was only the fifth time the Council has overridden a veto by the Mayor, and it illustrated how much more susceptible to union influence the majority Democratic Council is than the Republican Mayor. Democrats hold 45 of the 51 Council seats. Although the law does not necessarily affect union workers, it was a coalition of nearly 100 labor unions that first urged the Council to adopt the higher minimum wages. 
 The Council's action makes New York one of the first major cities to enact a "living wage" or "prevailing wage" law requiring city contractors to pay workers the standard wage that private-sector workers receive.
When Mr. Giuliani vetoed the bill last month, he contended that it would raise the city's costs and create unnecessary obstacles for companies that want to do business with the city. He has vowed to sue the Council to strike down the law, saying it is inconsistent with the city's general contracting process.
"The Mayor believes this legislation is seriously flawed," said Jack Deacy, a mayoral spokesman. "And he has asked the Corporation Counsel to explore possible legal options for the city."
Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed, a Manhattan Democrat and one of the law's prime sponsors, said: "This shows a basic philosophical difference between the Council and the Mayor. We believe that if you prime the pump and put money in at the bottom, it will work its way up into the economy, and he believes in the Republican trickle-down theory."
Many Council members said they hoped that the law, which affects contractors in security, cleaning, food services and temporary office work, would eventually be expanded to cover all city contractors.
Under the law, the required wage for the four industries will be determined by the City Comptroller. But Council officials estimated that minimum wages would be set at $7.25 an hour for unarmed security guards, $9 an hour for food workers, $11.25 an hour for temporary office workers and $12 an hour for janitors. The Federal minimum wage is now $4.25 and will rise to $4.75 next month and $5.15 next September.
Council officials have said that the law would affect only about 3,500 workers and cost the city about $16 million more a year. But the Mayor has said that broadening the law to cover all contractors could add as much as $500 million to the $4 billion the city spends each year on service contracts.

HEADLINE: Nasdaq Trades Found to Cost Institutions More

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
As criticism mounted against the Nasdaq Stock Market in recent years, the cry was that individual investors had gotten a raw deal there compared with the way they were treated on the stock exchanges. But many assumed that institutional investors, who were better able to negotiate deals and more savvy about trading rules, could do equally well on any market.
Now studies are emerging that challenge that conclusion. They argue that the costs of trading on Nasdaq -- including the market impact of block trades -- are substantially higher than on stock exchanges. 
 It is not clear to what extent that situation is likely to be altered by the reforms now being made at Nasdaq, though those reforms should help. To the extent that the studies are persuasive to institutional investors, they might put pressure on companies to move their listings from Nasdaq to the New York or American Stock Exchanges.
One study, to be published in the Journal of Financial Economics, compares the liquidity of the Nasdaq market with that of the New York Stock Exchange and concludes that the Big Board is much more able to handle block trades -- trades of more than 10,000 shares -- either without affecting the price of the stock, or with a smaller effect.
The study, by Chris Muscarella of Pennsylvania State University and Michele LaPlante of Santa Clara University, examined block trades of the 10 largest Nasdaq issues and compared them with similar issues on the New York exchange. It found that the average block trade on the Big Board caused the price to move about 0.18 percent, compared with 0.32 percent on the Nasdaq.
Such a movement is not large. The difference, or 14-hundredths of a percentage point, would indicate that it costs an institution on average about $140 more to place a $100,000 trade on a large Nasdaq stock than it does on a similar Big Board issue. But over the course of many trades, it could affect fund performance.
The other study was financed by the American Stock Exchange, which will formally release it today as part of a marketing effort aimed at wooing companies to list.
That study was done by the Plexus Group, a consultant to institutional investors that was able to use actual trading records from those clients. Based on 1995 trading, Plexus concluded that all the costs of enacting trades for those institutions -- including commissions and market impact -- came to 1.0 percent for Nasdaq stocks, compared with 0.55 percent for trades on the New York exchange and 0.6 percent for trades on the Amex.
The Big Board and the Amex are auction markets, in which all orders come together on a trading floor, with one specialist overseeing trading in each stock. In contrast, Nasdaq is a dealer market, with many competing market makers. It has been argued that those competing market makers effectively provided greater liquidity than did one specialist, so that the real cost of trading for institutions in Nasdaq stocks might be lower. But the studies both conclude that is not the case.
The differing figures for costs reflect differences in the studies. The first used only very large, liquid stocks, and was for 1990 trading. The second, based on 1995 trading, analyzed trades of all sizes. In addition, the Plexus study included commission charges, which were not considered in the academic study.
Dean Furbush, the chief economist of the National Association of Securities Dealers, which operates the Nasdaq market, noted that there had been numerous studies comparing the various stock markets. "The weight of the evidence shows me clearly that Nasdaq is a competitive stock market for institutional orders," he said.
For the Amex, a conclusion that it is a better trading place than Nasdaq is especially welcome. It is interested in luring a far larger number of Nasdaq companies than is the Big Board, which focuses mainly on the larger companies that trade on Nasdaq. The Plexus study will provide the Amex with ammunition.
The Nasdaq reforms, including some that are already in place and some that will be phased in during 1997, are expected to narrow the spread between the bid price -- the price at which market makers will buy shares -- and the asked price -- the price at which they will sell them. While institutions have often been able to get within the Nasdaq spreads anyway, partly through using electronic trading systems, the reforms could help them to some extent, and thus narrow the exchanges' advantages as shown in the studies.
