HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Case Against a Rate Rise Attracts a Respectable Crowd

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
With unemployment falling to just 5.1 percent and the pace of economic growth this year easily outstripping the sustainable long-term growth rate, the Federal Reserve looks to be on the verge of stepping on the brakes. "The only question left is how much the Fed will raise interest rates," said Bruce Steinberg, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch.
What is missing from the debate, though, is the case for letting the good times roll -- for holding a steady course to see whether the economy can accommodate rapid growth a while longer. And while this remains an outsider's view, it is coming from some very respectable centrist economists. "This is an excellent time to find out how much lower we can push unemployment" without kicking up inflation, argued Robert J. Gordon, an economist at Northwestern University and a leading researcher on the relationship between employment and prices. 
 Even some experts on Wall Street are starting to take these academic arguments more seriously. "Give growth a chance," Christopher A. Low, senior economist at HSBC Markets in New York, wrote in a recent newsletter, contending that the Federal Reserve should not automatically treat a low unemployment rate as a signal that inflation is about to surge. This view cuts across traditional political lines, attracting support from supply-siders on the right to populists in Congress who have long been suspicious of the Federal Reserve.
Still, most analysts on Wall Street are predicting the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates, most likely by a quarter percentage point, at the Sept. 24 meeting of its Open Market Committee. After all, unemployment has apparently drifted below the "natural rate" that computer simulations of the 1970's and 1980's suggested was compatible with a stable level of inflation.
What's more, evidence of incipient cost pressures can now be found in the numbers: "The half-percent increase in wages in August was disturbing," Mr. Steinberg of Merrill Lynch said. The Federal Reserve itself, in a report yesterday, cited rising wage pressures even as overall inflation remained tame. [Page D1.]
So if the Federal Reserve raises short-term rates, will that push the economy into recession? As long as the move is modest, probably not. While demand may be slowing without assistance from the Federal Reserve -- retail sales are nothing to write home about -- even the Fed's most dovish policy makers discount this prospect. Indeed, most analysts say the only remaining obstacle to an increase in short rates is the concern of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, that this close to the election an increase would be perceived as partisan.
But the more hawkish Fed officials want to go further. Those who perceive 3 percent inflation as a greater risk to the economy and society than 5 percent unemployment see a chance here to seize the moment. They take their ideology from those economists who believe that even current low rates of inflation harm the economy by raising effective tax rates on risky investments.
A couple of turns of the interest-rate screw, they figure, would buy some permanent progress on the inflation front. That, in turn, would lower long-term interest rates, which are now more than a full percentage point higher than the recent nadir at the end of 1995, when rates were slightly less than 6 percent. That, they argue, would ultimately stimulate investment.
Hence the current division within the Federal Reserve, to put it in political terms, is between the neoliberal pragmatists inclined toward a token interest-rate increase and the zero-inflation zealots who see a chance to score with a decisive increase of a half-point.
Where does that leave opponents of any increase in interest rates? Far from the levers of power, but well within the economics establishment. There has long been anecdotal evidence that the sustainable rate of unemployment ought to be falling: unions are weak, foreign competition is strong, corporate downsizing is every worker's nightmare. The number of work stoppages, for example, has fallen from nearly 400 affecting 2.5 million workers in 1970 to just 31 last year involving a mere 192,000 workers.
Now, according to William D. Nordhaus of Yale University, there is statistical evidence to buttress the anecdotes. A labor market with 5 percent unemployment today, he argues, behaves much like a labor market in the 1980's with unemployment of 6 percent to 6.5 percent.
This is a tantalizing prospect because there are still millions of people who want full-time jobs who have either dropped out of the official labor force or been forced to accept part-time work. In addition to the roughly seven million people counted as unemployed, more than four million are working part-time because they say it is the best they can get and about two million "discouraged" workers say they gave up looking because the possibilities seemed so bleak.
Mr. Gordon, too, reckons that the sustainable unemployment rate has been falling. This "manna from heaven," he says, explains why the Federal Reserve has thus far been able to wink at relatively low unemployment rates that would have been inflationary in 1989. Today, he estimates, 5.2 percent unemployment -- close to the current rate -- will not add to inflationary pressure.
With economic growth ebbing, but still strong enough to absorb more workers than are entering the labor force, Mr. Nordhaus sees the Federal Reserve's next interest-rate decision as "a tough call." Mr. Gordon, by contrast, takes a position that is effectively the mirror image of the anti-inflation hawks.
Inflation is so low today, he argues, that it would cost little to find out how many more jobs can be created without causing inflationary wage increases. All the evidence, he says, suggests that inflationary expectations are incorporated very slowly into markets. If the Federal Reserve overshoots by allowing unemployment to fall to less than the sustainable rate, the price would be just a few tenths of a percent higher inflation before the error is identified. Mr. Nordhaus added -- in direct contradiction to the zero-inflation crowd -- that "there is no evidence from other countries' experience that inflation below 10 percent has much effect on long-term growth prospects."
Indeed, in an article published last month in "The Brookings Papers on Economic Activity," the economists George A. Akerlof, William T. Dickens and George L. Perry suggest that very low inflation may actually create wage rigidity that impairs economic efficiency. In a well-functioning economy, relative wages have to change between occupations and regions in accord with changing supply and demand. But workers, who may accept eroding real wages as prices outpace their income, will bitterly resist actual cuts in their nominal pay.
And with inflation of less than 3 percent, the argument goes, it becomes difficult to match real wages to market conditions.
The catch to the test-the-waters view, suggests Barry Bosworth, an economist at the Brookings Institution, is that the Federal Reserve would pounce on the first clear sign that it had pushed unemployment below the sustainable rate, increasing rates so quickly that it would make a recession almost inevitable. While the Fed managed to slow the economy in 1994 without pushing the economy into recession, most experience -- including that as recent as 1990 -- shows just how difficult it is to manage a soft landing. And a recession, he argued, "would wipe out years and years of benefits" from taking a bigger whack at unemployment.
A variation on the theme goes like this. If the Federal Reserve does not raise short-term rates by at least a token amount, long-term interest rates will go up in response to lenders' fears that the Fed has lost its determination to contain inflation. Thus the perception that the Federal Reserve is no longer a dependable bulwark against rising prices could itself tip the economy into recession.
So the ultimate question remains: Is the Federal Reserve, casually assumed to be the most powerful agency in the Government, itself a prisoner of the opinion of the markets?

HEADLINE: Ross Perot's Soul Mate

 BODY:
Ross Perot's choice of Pat Choate as his running mate does little to increase his meager Presidential prospects. At least in theory, a Vice-Presidential candidate should be qualified to assume the Presidency. Both Al Gore and Jack Kemp meet that test. But "President Choate"? The words do not ring with plausibility. He was in fact the flinty Texan's fourth choice for the ticket, after three others with broader experience -- a former Senator and two members of the House -- said no.
Even so, Dr. Choate could well enliven the campaign, especially the Presidential debates scheduled for this fall -- assuming that he and Mr. Perot are invited to participate. The nonpartisan debate commission will deliver its judgment on that matter next week. Unlike Mr. Perot's last running mate, the dignified but hopelessly overmatched Adm. James Stockdale, Dr. Choate is the author of six books and a smooth speaker with a string of talk-show credentials. 
 He is especially passionate on two issues that the major candidates are either ignoring or ducking. These issues are, first, the threat to American jobs from multinational corporations and America's trading partners, and second, the destructive influence of big money in Washington.
On both subjects Ross Perot has found himself not only a running mate but a soul mate. Like Mr. Perot, Dr. Choate is an economic nationalist, wary of foreign commercial entanglements, and in 1993 the two men collaborated on a 74-page manifesto called "Save Your Job, Save Our Country," which asserted that the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico would threaten six million American workers. The jobs-vs.-free-trade issue all but vanished when Patrick Buchanan disappeared. With Dr. Choate on board, Mr. Perot is sure to revive it.
Like Mr. Perot, Dr. Choate is eager to confront President Clinton and Bob Dole for their reluctance to address Washington's money-driven political culture -- the influence of lobbyists and big campaign contributors.
In 1990 Dr. Choate combined these two interests in a controversial book, "Agents of Influence," an attack on foreign attempts to manipulate American policy. He was especially rough on former Federal officials who had swung through the "revolving door" and become well-paid lobbyists, particularly for Japan.
The book's suggestion that these lobbyists, whom he named, were behaving unpatriotically earned him many enemies. Its xenophobic tone, combined with his later exaggerations about the dangers of Nafta, also damaged his reputation among economists who had once applauded his earlier and less-fevered writings on the need to shore up America's competitiveness by rebuilding its economic infrastructure.
On balance, it is hard to see what value Mr. Perot has added to his ticket. Dr. Choate's experience is narrow, his name recognition negligible. The most that can be said is that he may sharpen positions Mr. Perot already holds dear. In political and policy terms, he adds no obvious new dimension.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Fed Report Finds Growth Still Modest

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Wages are rising as the economy across most of the nation continues to grow at a moderate pace, but there is little evidence yet of inflation taking root, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The report, based on a survey of businesses by the 12 regional Federal Reserve Banks, was the latest to suggest that the economy remained finely balanced between a sustainable expansion and the onset of inflation. 
 Although many economists still believe the Federal Reserve will nudge up interest rates when its policy-making body meets on Sept. 24, they said today's report did not provide the Fed with the unambiguous case for tightening monetary policy that it would like to have before raising rates, especially in the midst of a Presidential campaign.
Signs of inflation "were varied and generally inconclusive, although there appears to be greater upward pressure on wages than on prices," the Fed report said. "Business activity in most districts is reported to be good and expanding moderately."
Fed officials have indicated over the last week that while they are on heightened inflation alert, they are still uncertain whether the economy is slowing fast enough from its torrid pace in the first half to avert a destabilizing wage-price spiral.
Both inside and outside the Fed, those economists who think the economy will keep growing at a strong pace see a substantial risk of inflation. Those who see the economy slowing, view inflation as less of a threat despite the low 5.1 percent unemployment rate and upward pressure on wages.
After falling early in the day on fears that the Fed report, known as the beige book, would show rising inflationary pressures, the bond market bounced back when the report was made public, with the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond ending the day about unchanged, at 7.11 percent.
The Fed's stance since July has been to lean toward a tightening, and inflation hawks on the Fed's policy-making body have been agitating for a rate increase for several months, arguing that the time to move is before inflation infects the economy. Many economists think the Fed is likely to raise its Federal funds target rate by a quarter-point this month, to 5.5 percent. A rate increase would reverse a series of three cuts that began 14 months ago. The Fed's last move was to cut the Federal funds rate by a quarter-point on Jan. 31.
"We continue to pick up early-warning signs on the inflation front coming through loud and clear in labor market conditions and rising wages," said Stephen S. Roach, the chief economist at Morgan Stanley, who forecasts a continued strong growth rate of 3 percent for the second half. "A failure to move at this juncture, with the unemployment rate as low as it is, and with the economy growing well in excess of the inflation-stable growth rate, would really be irresponsible on the Fed's part."
The beige book is based on anecdotal reports from businesses replying to inquiries from researchers at the Federal Reserve Banks.
"Reports of substantial price increases were notably absent" from many areas of the country, the Fed said. In the regions around New York, Boston, Cleveland and Kansas City, consumer prices were reported to be stable or increasing only slightly. There were some price increases in industrial commodities, but they tended to be restricted to a few markets, the report said. Lumber prices, for example, were higher in the regions around Boston, Richmond, Dallas and Chicago.
"Wage gains have tended to outstrip price increases, however," the report said. In Boston, wage and salary increases were running at 2 to 4 percent, while in Cleveland the increase was 2 to 3 percent.
Companies normally try to pass on the cost of wage increases to consumers of their products through price increases. But intense competition has made it hard for companies to raise prices, forcing them to absorb higher wage rates by improving productivity or biting into their profits. The Clinton Administration's economists have been arguing that since corporate profits are robust, companies have plenty of leeway to absorb rising wages without spurring inflation. A number of outside economists dispute that contention.
The report showed few signs that the economy was cooling off as rapidly as the Fed had expected in July when it forecast a growth rate for the full year of 2.6 percent. The economy grew at a 3.4 percent rate in the first half, and would have to slow to a rate of 1.8 percent in the second half to match the Fed's forecast.
Today's report said the economy was expanding "moderately" in most places, with two exceptions being California and the Far West, where growth was characterized as strong, and in the St. Louis region, where it "continued to moderate slightly."

GRAPHIC: Map/Chart: "Little Inflation, but Signs of Wage Pressure"
 A roundup of regional economic conditions in recent months for the Federal Reserve's 12 districts, according to the quarterly beige book report issued yesterday by the Fed.
 
Boston -- Factories and personnel-supply firms reported solid growth. Retailers said sales were stronger than expected in August.
 
New York -- No signs of increased prices or wages. Retail sales rebounded. Real estate strengthened. Demand lowered for commercial loans.
 
Philadelphia -- Factories reported increases in orders and shipments. Auto dealers saw steady sales.
 
Richmond -- Tight labor markets, rising wages and higher consumer prices reported. Factories rebounded.
 
Atlanta -- Merchants were reported having positive outlooks for the rest of the year, but manufacturers were less optimistic. Rents increased.
 
St. Louis -- Tight labor markets remained a concern for many businesses. Retailers reported improved sales from a year earlier.
 
Kansas City -- Factories and construction showed signs of slowing from the brisk pace of previous months. Rising wages were reported.
 
Dallas -- Scattered rising prices and labor costs were reported. Weakness in housing was offset by increases in commercial construction spending. The energy industry continued to gain momentum.
 
San Francisco -- Grocery prices increased noticeably. Labor shortages and rising wages were also reported. Manufacturing was robust but tempered by weakness in the computer chip industry.
 
Minneapolis -- Commodity prices fell. Intermediate and final goods prices were stable. Construction, oil and mining activity were strong.
 
Chicago -- Wage pressures subsided though labor markets were still tight. Retailers reported improved back-to-school sales.
 
Cleveland -- The cost of new hires accelerated at some companies, leading to concerns about future labor pacts. Wages for existing employees gained 2 to 3 percent.
 
(Source: Bloomberg Business News) (pg. D4)

HEADLINE: Motorola Warns Quarterly Profits Will Shrink

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Motorola Inc. warned Wall Street today that disappointing sales of semiconductors, cellular phones, and paging products were taking a much bigger toll on its earnings than analysts had been projecting for the third quarter.
Motorola, which earned $326 million or 54 cents a share in the second quarter, said that earnings for the quarter ending Sept. 28 could be down "significantly," a word the company has used in the past only to refer to changes of 25 percent or more. Wall Street had been expecting a modest decline to 50 cents a share, based on the consensus of projections reported to First Call. 
 Motorola's shares fell $1.375 to $49.25 as the most active stock on the Big Board today, although most technology shares were modestly higher.
In a conference call with analysts this morning, Motorola said that it had not yet seen an increase in new orders for semiconductors, contrary to the industry trend in August, reported this week by the Semiconductor Industry Association. The trade group said that new orders, while down 38 percent from a year ago, had edged up to $2.84 billion, or 0.9 percent, from the previous month.
The steeper than average slump expected for Motorola's semiconductors reflects the woes of Apple Computer, its major customer in the PC industry, and weaker-than-expected demand for chips from Motorola's own cellular and paging businesses. Up to 20 percent of Motorola's semiconductors are used internally.
Motorola said it expected the semiconductor industry's book-to-bill ratio to be below 1 for the third consecutive quarter. A ratio of less than 1 means that for every $100 of chips sold, chip makers received less than $100 of new orders. In August, the book-to-bill ratio rose to 0.9 from July's revised 0.86 as demand for new chips picked up.
In addition to the industry-wide slump in semiconductor sales, Motorola's earnings decline reflects a persistent price war in several of Motorola's communications markets, and a raft of company problems like delays in getting important new products to market.
"The market is really struggling now to figure out just what Motorola's earning power will be over the next two years," Lior Bregman, who follows the company for Oppenheimer & Company, said.
The warning was an extraordinary move for Motorola, which is based in the Chicago suburb of Schaumburg, Ill. The company prides itself on paying little attention to Wall Street's fascination with quarterly fluctuations in earnings. However, having upset investors in July by announcing second-quarter earnings that were well under projections, the company wanted to avoid a second such shock.
As the world's fifth largest semiconductor company, and a leader in markets like cellular telephones, two-way radio and paging, Motorola has generally been regarded as one of the bellwether stocks of the high-technology sector.
"A lot of this was anticipated but not the magnitude," Rakesh Sood, who follows Motorola for Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco, said.
Motorola said that sales of cellular, paging and other communications-network equipment to phone companies and their competitors remained strong, but equipment like Motorola's cellular phones and pagers were not being sold as rapidly as expected to subscribers to those networks. In many markets, Motorola had bet too heavily on the development of technologies that have yet to be deployed and so fell behind in introducing new products for existing systems.
"There is no indication that competitive pricing pressures are easing," Ed Gams, head of investor relations for Motorola, said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

A Shift in Standard For Environmental Rules
The Clinton Administration said that it would start basing all environmental protection standards on the particular risks that pollution poses to children's health.
The change could lead to tougher rules on everything from soot fouling the air to microbes contaminating water. [Page A14.]
 
Xerox Insurance Sale Is Canceled
Xerox and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said that they were calling off the planned $2.7 billion sale of Xerox's insurance units to Kohlberg. Neither company would say why the sale, for which Xerox had already taken a $1.5 billion charge, was canceled. [D5.]
 
Motorola Warns Of Weak Profit
Motorola's stock fell after the company warned Wall Street that disappointing sales of cellular phones and other products were taking a much bigger toll on its earnings than analysts had been projecting for the current quarter. [D2.]
 
Blow to Overseas Lending Agency
The House rejected a bill to renew the lending and insuring authority of the agency that provides insurance and loan guarantees to companies investing in poor nations. [D2.]
 
Nasdaq Is Said to Cost More
Two studies argue that institutional investors pay higher costs to trade on Nasdaq than they do on stock exchanges. [D6.]
 
New England Life in Software Deal
New England Life Insurance has bought a substantial stake in Meca Software, which produces personal-finance software. [D3.]
 
New Chief at Perot Systems
Morton Meyerson, Ross Perot's business lieutenant since the 1970's, stepped aside as chief executive of the Perot Systems Corporation and promoted the company president to take his place. [D16.]
 
Don't Raise Rates, Some Say
With unemployment falling to just 5.1 percent and economic growth robust, it appears that interest rates will be raised. Still, some economists are urging American monetary-policy makers to let the good times roll.
Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [A1.]
 
F.T.C. Approval for Time Warner
The F.T.C. plans to announce that it has officially approved Time Warner's $6.5 billion merger with Turner Broadcasting. [D17.]
 
New Tack in Mobile-Home Bid
Sun Communities, one of the three mobile-home park operators wooing shareholders of Chateau Properties, said it was willing to offer cash. Its original offer was in stock. [D4.]
 
Net Gatekeeper May Sell Stock
The private company that the Government put in charge of registering Internet names has been exploring the idea of cashing in on its gatekeeping role by selling stock. [A1.]
 
Brooklyn Union to Cut Some Rates
Brooklyn Union Gas said it would lower its gas rates next year for many customers and then freeze them over the next five years, the first time a large utility has committed itself to a cap on rates for such a long period. [B3.]

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Unchanged; Data Awaited

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were virtually unchanged yesterday, as investors remain defensive about two unknowns: inflationary pressure building in the economy and the size of the next interest-rate increase.
Anxiety over coming inflation numbers today and tomorrowheightened recently as Fed officials continued to sound warnings about potential tightening. And with each warning the market sold on fears despite the lack of clear-cut signals. 
 This latest anxiety over inflation was sparked by concerns raised by a Fed governor, Janet Yellen, about tight labor-market conditions and their effect on labor costs.
An inconclusive report on inflation in the latest beige book report yesterday by the Fed on business conditions in its 12 districts could not bring back the market completely, though it did squeeze some short positions out of the market.
By the close of the New York market the 30-year bond was at a price of 95 19/32 to yield 7.11 percent, unchanged from Tuesday.
Greg Jones, an economist with MMS International in San Francisco, said even with a parade of Fed governors sounding the tightening warning, "the market is not fully priced for a 25-basis-point tightening, and it is not even remotely prepared for a 50-basis-point tightening."
"In our view, it is the debate between 25 and 50 basis points that is the more relevant than the debate between steady policy and a 25-basis- point tightening," Mr. Jones said.
A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Mr. Jones added that it was difficult to judge whether supply in the form of two large global offerings by the European Investment Bank and the Tennessee Valley Authority had any impact on prices of Federal Government securities since those offerings also compete for investor dollars. "Any supply is a problem for a market that is already focused on the negatives," Mr. Jones said.
The European Investment Bank priced $1 billion of debt securities, its first global issue ever, through underwriters led by CS First Boston and Lehman Brothers. Rated AAA, the 10-year bonds were given an interest rate of 7.125 percent and priced at 99.979 to yield 7.128 percent. At the same time, the T.V.A. priced 1.5 billion German marks, or about $1 billion, in noncallable 10-year bonds. It was the first time that the Government corporation, the country's largest producer of electricity, issued a global bond in anything other than dollars.
The T.V.A.'s 10-year noncallable mark bond, priced through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Bankhaus A.G. and Deutsche Bank A.G., was given a 6.375 percent coupon and priced at 99.173 to yield 6.49 percent. It too is rated AAA.
Thomas E. Donne, vice president and senior portfolio manager at Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said he saw some short-covering followed by an erosion of prices as the market wondered what kind of information the Fed's beige book would reveal.
"Maybe everyone got a little ahead of themselves in the early part of the session," Mr. Donne said, "but then the beige book came in pretty market-friendly and I think the first comment within the summary was how there were inconclusive signs of inflation. If you read each of the 12 district reports, as I did, they are indeed inconclusive."
Mr. Donne noted that after the release of the beige book, the Chicago Fed issued its Midwest manufacturing index, which is not usually followed. "On days when there is very little information to go on, reports that are not always followed closely suddenly are," he said. The Chicago index showed a rise "for the third straight month to a record high level. Manufacturing remains strong, but there does not seem to be a large increase in wage pressures."
Yesterday was a day that did not give anybody clues, or any reason to expect a surprise in today's Producer Price Index report for August. "I expect the P.P.I. number to be somewhere up around one-tenth of 1 percent, with the core rate pretty much the same, and Friday's Consumer Price Index to be up two-tenths of 1 percent in both the overall and core number," Mr. Donne said.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Behind Rally, an Optimism That Mystifies

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average jumped more than 27 points yesterday, bringing it within a whisker of its record close of 5,778 on May 22 and nearly completing a recovery that wiped out its 6.7 percent decline in July.
But the return to near-record levels is mystifying some stock strategists because market conditions -- including higher interest rates, modest earnings growth, expectations of higher inflation and the slowing of cash inflows into mutual funds -- are not as positive as they were in May. 
 None of these or other factors, including the prospect of a modest rise in interest rates by the Federal Reserve, would be likely to undermine the market alone. But they are all coming together at the same time now; yet the Dow has rebounded.
"All the variables that helped the market are less vigorous," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company. "So I am amazed that the market has held up so well."
One reason for the rebound, which has also brought the broader Standard & Poor's index to within 1.7 percent of its closing high, is that the sentiment of the bull market persists.
This sentiment, said Byron R. Wien, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company, moves investors to "see every dip as an opportunity to buy that has to be broken."
That investor persistence was reflected again yesterday in the Investment Company Institute's estimate that stock mutual funds took in a net $19 billion in cash in August, more than triple a revised $5.8 billion in July, when a plunge, particularly in smaller stocks, scared some investors.
This bull-market view also means that many uncertainties that have made stocks volatile this summer are still seen through rose-colored glasses.
So a strong jobs report for August becomes a reason for a rally, not a selloff. Similarly, the bull-market view has discounted signs of inflationary pressure that some economists see. It even allows modest earnings expectations -- 10 percent growth in 1996 -- to support stocks despite a rise in interest rates and the clear threat that the Fed's policy-making committee will raise short-term rates further at its meeting on Sept. 24.
"In a bull market we look at all of these uncertainties in a glass-half-full, positive way," said Alfred Goldman, director of market analysis at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis.
But looking inside the Dow shows that the return to its May high may reflect less confidence than thought. The Dow stocks that have contributed the most to the index's rebound suggest that many investors have less confidence in continued economic growth than they did in May.
As a result, among the 30 Dow stocks, the issues that have done well over the period include Coca-Cola and Merck, neither of which is likely to see revenues fall sharply in a recession, while the worst Dow performers over the period include General Motors and Goodyear, both highly vulnerable to a recession.
And while the Dow and the S.& P. are doing well, many other indexes that reflect the performance of smaller stocks or specific sectors of the economy are not keeping up. The Nasdaq composite index is still 7.6 percent below its record, and the Chicago Board Options Exchange gaming index, which tracks performance of the casino sector, is 23.8 percent below its peak.
"The big stock indexes are doing better than the average stock," said David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers.
Mr. Metz said the Dow's rally shows that investors have been concentrating on a small segment of stocks. "If you are going to make a mistake, you better make it on a Coke or a Gillette," he said.
But the new mutual-fund data may indicate that a lot of other stocks are still being bought. Bob Adler of AMG Data, which estimates fund flows on a weekly basis, said stock funds that invest primarily in large-capitalization stocks are getting relatively little of the new money. In the latest week for which he has data, ending Sept. 4, those funds basically broke even in terms of inflows.
A large flow of money is going into funds that invest primarily in smaller and riskier companies, Mr. Adler said. The flow of money into such funds plunged in July, with many experiencing outflows, but investment seems to be returning now.
This flow may be one reason that other indexes, like the Nasdaq composite, have risen more than the Dow since the July lows, even though they have not recovered as much of the ground that they lost.
Perhaps the biggest change in the market's environment since May has been in interest rates, which have risen, and the growing consensus that the Fed will have to raise its short-term interest rate target.
The yield on the 30-year bond is at 7.11 percent and the yield on the 2-year note is 6.30 percent. On May 22, the day the Dow peaked, the 30-year bond yield was 6.81 percent, and the 2-year yield was 5.98 percent.
The higher interest rates, Mr. Wien said, have pushed the market to the top of its fair value, and higher rates or a decline in earnings growth would make the market, in his view, overvalued.
According to IBES International Inc., expected 1996 earnings growth on the Standard & Poor's index has dropped 1.3 percent since the May peak of the Dow, to 9.8 percent.
Flows of investor money into stock mutual funds were at a record pace of $23 billion a month leading up to the May peak. Since June that pace has slowed to an average of slightly more than $13 billion a month, including the $19 billion preliminary estimate for August.
But while even $19 billion would be well below the flows of early 1996, such investment would surpass any month prior to this year. And it was enough to help the summer rebound.
One of the more worrisome, but hard to define, changes has been inflation expectations. At the May peak, the Consumer Price Index was up 2.9 percent for the 12 months through April. If the August index, which is to be released tomorrow, rises three-tenths of 1 percent, the index will have moved to a reading of 3 percent in the preceding 12 months.
While the C.P.I. has remained relatively stable, the closely watched Employment Cost Index, which measures wages and benefits, has crept up enough to draw the attention of many analysts. The drop of the unemployment rate in August to 5.1 percent also signals that wage pressures -- and, thus, inflation fears -- should be growing.

HEADLINE: U.S. Has Vital Interest in Stopping Hussein

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your Sept. 8 Week in Review article "How Saddam Hussein Survives by Losing" says that in some lights "it defies common sense" that the United States does not consider assassinating Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader, as a solution to the troubles in Iraq. 
 On one level, one might say, sure, it would be against American law but he is an unstable leader. Why use economic sanctions and cruise missiles when you can just strike at the source?
In reality, the response of John Deutch, the Director of Central Intelligence, to the question "Why haven't we killed Saddam Hussein?" suggests that for decision makers in the Administration it is still common sense that we should not assassinate foreign leaders.
Is your article evidence of the waning of international norms? I prefer to live in the world that we have grown used to, where rules and norms prevent knee-jerk violent responses by powerful states and where even the United States feels compelled to justify its actions to the international community. We are all safer in such a world.
 
DEBORAH AVANT
Washington, Sept. 8, 1996
 
The writer is an assistant professor of political science at George Washington University.

HEADLINE: Airlines and Others Question Aspects of Anti-Terrorism Plan

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
Airline representatives, airport operators and members of Congress expressed reservations today about the Clinton Administration's plans for preventing terrorism. They said they favored re-evaluating aviation security, but raised questions about the cost, practicality and usefulness of many of the proposed steps.
Matching all bags to passengers on domestic flights, as is now done internationally, is a fine idea, James C. DeLong, chairman of the Airports Council International-North America and the aviation director of the new Denver International Airport, testified before the Aviation Subcommittee of the House Transportation Committee. But if it increases the time the average departing passenger spends in the airport to two or three hours from the current 45 minutes, Mr. DeLong said, then airports would have to be three times as big. 
 Running computer background checks on passengers to decide who needs more scrutiny is a good idea, too, said John M. Meenan, vice president of the Air Transport Association, the big airlines' trade group. But, Mr. Meenan testified, the biggest improvements to security would have to be carried out by others, notably by "redeployment of our nation's intelligence resources."
"Countering aviation terrorism, in our estimation, is the responsibility of the Federal Government," he said. He compared improving airport security with trying to stop theft in a home, saying, "Burglar bars and alarms are not a solution to crime, but one of its symptoms."
The subcommittee chairman, Representative John J. Duncan, Jr., Republican of Tennessee, said that security should certainly be re-evaluated, but that he did not believe the country should overreact. The ranking Democrat on the subcommittee, Representative William O. Lipinsky of Illinois, said that in most cases, the cost of the new steps would be justified by the benefits, but that all should be studied for the delays they would impose and the penalties on "efficiency and economy."
Also questioned were the criminal background checks performed on prospective airline employees.
Mr. Meenan said that examination of work history was much more productive, and that checking the backgrounds of employees would not have blocked acts of terrorism like the World Trade Center bombing.
Another witness, David Tomlinson, head of security at BAA P.L.C., the private company that used to be the British Airports Authority, said the British police scrutinize airline and airport employees' backgrounds, not for criminal records but for people who might sympathize with terrorists and provide them with useful information.
Questions about cost were also raised. Republicans said that they had not seen anything in writing from the White House on the $1.1 billion that the President is asking for, about one-third of it for aviation.
Representative Robert L. Livingston, Republican of Louisiana and the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, pointed out on Tuesday that Mr. Clinton had previously asked for a supplemental appropriation of $400 million to $500 million for fighting western forest fires and $250 million for fighting drugs. Congress is also considering requests for supplemental financing for the re-deployment of American soldiers in Saudi Arabia and the continuing peacekeeping operation in Bosnia, which together will run $300 million, Republicans say.
Mr. Livingston and others complained that the Administration had not identified any budget cuts or revenue increases to pay for any of its requests for more money. "He promises everything to everyone with complete disregard for the American taxpayer," Mr. Livingston said.
There is a vehicle handy, though, for supplemental appropriations; with the end of the Federal fiscal year on Sept. 30, Congress is almost certain to face a vote on a continuing resolution or an omnibus appropriations bill for the parts of the Government that have not had their budgets approved for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. As of today, only 2 of 13 appropriations bills have final approval.
Even if there is no immediate appropriation, the House today overwhelmingly approved a three-year, $29.5 billion financing bill for the Federal Aviation Administration that will allow money earmarked for "airport improvements" to be used for security investments. The Senate is supposed to take up the bill next week.
 

CORRECTION-DATE: September 13, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about a hearing on airline security before the House Transportation Aviation Subcommittee misspelled the name of the panel's ranking Democrat. He is William O. Lipinski.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE MONEY;
A Hollywood Production: Political Money

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 11

 BODY:
For President Clinton, Thursday evening will be a memorable one. Barbra Streisand will serenade him under the stars, Maya Angelou will read him poetry, and he will mingle with Hollywood's corporate elite, all this at a breathtaking Mediterranean-style estate overlooking Beverly Hills.
And once the evening is over, the Democratic Party will be $3.5 million richer. 
 When it comes to raising money, especially for Democrats, no one does it better than Hollywood. The open wallets of movie stars and the corporate donations of studio executives make the entertainment industry one of the party's biggest sources of contributions, and of the glamour and celebrities who can draw crowds to Democratic rallies and fund-raising events.
"Politicians and movie stars spring from the same DNA," said Jack Valenti, chairman of the Motion Picture Association of America, the movie industry's trade group, who was once a special assistant to President Lyndon B. Johnson. "Both hope for applause, read from a script and hope to persuade audiences."
And, Mr. Valenti said, "many in Hollywood feel passionate about the same issues as the Democrats."
At Thursday's event, orchestrated by Hollywood's "A list" -- including Ms. Streisand, the record producer David Geffen and the director Steven Spielberg -- more than 700 people will pay as much as $12,500 apiece to hear entertainers like Ms. Streisand, Tom Hanks, the Eagles and the Neville Brothers.
Tickets come in three prices: $2,500, which admits the holder to the estate, Greenacres, former home of the silent-screen star Harold Lloyd, and to the show that will be performed there; $5,000, which provides admission to a cocktail reception and a "preferred" seat, and $12,500, which buys a V.I.P. dinner and a spot close to the stage.
And even those prices pale when compared with the per-person giving at two small dinners where Mr. Geffen was host, at his home, earlier this year. Those affairs, attended by the President and just 12 guests, netted about $2 million for the Democratic Party.
"To understand Hollywood is to understand big money and politics," said Ellen Miller, executive director of the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan research organization. "When we think of the Hollywood heavy hitters, we think of Democrats. The biggest contributing zip code to Bill Clinton is 90210," Beverly Hills's fabled enclave of wealth.
The party has already raised $4.7 million in Hollywood during this election cycle, compared with $890,000 raised there by the Republicans, according to the Campaign Study Group, a consulting firm. Since 1991, when Mr. Clinton began taking aim at the White House, Hollywood has given $18 million to the Democrats, $2.6 million to the Republicans. (Those are sums that have gone to the party itself, not directly to any candidate, who by law can receive only $1,000 from an individual and $5,000 from a corporation's political action committee.)
Indeed, since Bob Dole attacked the film industry last year for producing a "nightmare of depravity," Republicans have found Hollywood so poor a source of financing that they have virtually written it off.
"We are more interested in Main Street than Hollywood," said Howard Leach, finance chairman of the Republican National Committee. "That's where the real majority is."
The connection between Hollywood and Democrats goes back decades and, except during Ronald Reagan's Presidency, has proved hard for Republicans to duplicate. From the days when Lauren Bacall was photographed while draped on a piano played by Harry S. Truman, or when John F. Kennedy associated with Frank Sinatra, Peter Lawford and the rest of the Rat Pack, Hollywood glamour has strolled arm in arm with Democratic politicians.
One of the Democrats' biggest fund-raisers is Mr. Geffen, a founder of the multimedia entertainment company DreamWorks SKG, who says he has raised "many millions" for the party in the last few years. Mr. Geffen's influence is such that he was able to persuade some of Hollywood's biggest names to attend his million-dollar dinners with the President: Steve Jobs, the Apple Computer founder; Steve Tisch, producer; Peter Morton, founder of the Hard Rock Cafe; Edgar Bronfman Jr., the Seagram's heir and studio executive, and Lew Wasserman, former MCA studio chairman.
"The Democratic message of taking care of people who are poor and unemployed has traditionally resonated with Hollywood, and that continues to be the case today," Mr. Geffen said. The only thing he has received in return for his efforts, he said, is a night at the White House and an invitation to a state dinner.
The source of Democratic money in Hollywood falls into two categories: the stars and the studios.
Like other industries, studios have a business agenda and make big donations in part to make sure that their views are heard by officeholders. Their main concern today is intellectual property -- protecting American entertainment products from piracy and copyright infringements abroad. In addition, the industry recoils at attacks by politicians who see Hollywood as a source of moral depravity.
As for the stars, most come from ordinary backgrounds and, despite their wealth and fame, do not identify with the establishment.
"Many have been very fortunate and want to give back something to their community," said Lara Bergthold, executive director of the Hollywood Women's Political Committee, which has raised more than $6 million in the last decade, mostly for Democrats.
In addition to their own giving, celebrities draw crowds and so help raise money from wealthy people who want to be around them.
"People will come to an event with a celebrity connection who might not come to another political event," said Ann Lewis, deputy manager of the Clinton-Gore campaign. "One of our big challenges is to expand our donor base, and celebrities help."
Mr. Clinton first visited Hollywood many years ago, as a rising young Arkansas politician. In 1992, Ms. Streisand's appearance at a glitzy fund-raising event for him -- at the same estate, owned by the supermarket executive Ron Burkle, where Thursday night's affair will be held -- netted $1.2 million in a single afternoon. Ms. Streisand helped raise even more money by attending Mr. Clinton's pre-inaugural ball, where her appearance helped insure that the event would be televised.
The danger for Democrats, some say, is that Hollywood will make the party appear to have lost touch with common people. For that reason, organizers say, Thursday night's event has been closed to the press.
"It's bizarre," said Ms. Miller, of the Center for Responsive Politics. "Democrats have the reputation of being for the working people. When it becomes a party of the stars, people must wonder whether the Democrats have lost their way."
Mr. Geffen, mindful of Mr. Clinton's substantial lead in the polls, disagrees.
"Even back to the Kennedy days," he said, "there was discussion that stars can have a negative influence. But it doesn't seem to be much of a negative when you are winning."
 Because of an editing error, the article also referred incompletely to the use of the contributions. They went to individual candidates as well as to the Democratic and Republican Parties.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up on U.S. Price Data And Hint of German Rate Cut

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose further against most key currencies yesterday, strengthening as stock and bond markets in the United States rallied and a senior Bundesbank official suggested that a German money market rate could fall.
A Labor Department report that showed surprisingly weak inflation at the wholesale level in August initially put pressure on the dollar, as traders sold on the belief that the Federal Reserve might not raise interest rates at its meeting on Sept. 24. Expectations of higher rates had been helping the dollar for a week or so. 
 But buyers quickly stepped in, reflecting strong demand for the dollar and a growing belief that it could be headed even higher. Traders who had bet on a weaker dollar began buying instead.
Late yesterday in New York, the dollar sold for 1.5125 marks, up from 1.5105 on Wednesday. It traded at 110.20 yen, unchanged from late Wednesday. The last time the dollar was at such high levels against both currencies was in mid-July. The American currency also gained against the British pound, which fetched $1.5545, down from $1.5550.
Part of the dollar's strength came from the stock and bond markets, which rose after the report that core wholesale inflation, which excludes food and energy, declined in August for the first time in five months. This suggested that the Fed might leave interest rates unchanged because inflation remained benign.
The dollar also derived strength from weakness in the mark after Klaus Dieter Kuhbacher, a member of the Bundesbank's policy-making council, said that the 14-day securities-repurchase rate had the leeway to fall 20 more basis points from its current low of 3.0 percent. A basis point is one one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The Germans lowered the repurchase rate on Aug. 22, in a move some then viewed as the last in a series of cuts intended to stimulate the economy. Still lower rates could hurt the mark by lowering the return on mark-denominated investments.
Other late dollar rates in New York yesterday, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.2373 Swiss francs, up from 1.2351; 5.1601 French francs, up from 5.1589; 1,521.20 Italian lire, down from 1,524, and 1.3714 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3712.

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
Ethnologists' Data Turn Out to Be Art

BYLINE: By VICKI GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
LITTLE-KNOWN fact of the week: the Brooklyn Museum established the first photographic department in an American museum in 1889, some 51 years before the Museum of Modern Art (which ordinarily gets the credit) had a department of its own. Brooklyn, however, was primarily a museum of natural history and anthropology, where you were as likely to see butterflies and bones as paintings of the American West. The Department of Photography, rich in ethnographic material, was blissfully unaware of art. In 1974, Barbara Head Millstein, the present curator, discovered a closet that had been locked since 1957; inside was the photographic collection, a good deal of which had been magically transformed into art in the interval by changing tastes and markets.
Since anthropologists and ethnologists, inveterate collectors by profession, had long been interested in the relatively accessible study sites of Latin America, photographs of sites and people found their way to Brooklyn. Then in the 1970's, Ms. Millstein, who was blissfully aware of art, began collecting recent work from the region before it became fashionable. One way or another, the museum acquired some telling images: 107 photographic prints and books from the collection are on view until Jan. 19 in "Latin American Photography: A Spiritual Journey," organized by Ms. Millstein with historical material provided by Deirdre Lawrence, principal librarian at the museum. 
 This show of Latin photographers and foreigners who came and stayed a while lacks a few of the great names but introduces some new ones. It makes a case, as might be expected, for a strong spiritual tradition and a more complex argument for a hybrid of Old and New World cultures. Nineteenth-century photographers in Latin America generally focused on monuments, buildings and cities. Foreigners mapped the ancient monuments; as early as 1843, engravings were made after Frederick Catherwood's daguerreotypes of Uxmal, and Alfred Percival Maudslay studied Chichen Itza in 1889.
Toward the end of the century, as anthropology solidified into a science, photographers grew interested in indigenous customs. The Brooklyn Museum's scientists and curators lapped up whatever looked like good evidence of places and people and customs, an impulse that also accounts for the wealth of remarkable colonial art recently on view at the museum in "Converging Cultures: Art and Identity in Spanish America." Much of the art in that show, originally picked up as documentary material rather than art, had been languishing in the museum's basement for years.
In the 20th century, photographers took on art, economic struggle, spiritual matters and psychological life. Hidden in this show -- it is not entirely obvious in many pictures or spelled out in the labels -- is a photographic lesson quite similar to that of "Converging Cultures": that Latin America took extensively from European art but married it to native culture, sometimes an unlikely match. This is clear enough in the near-miraculous interplay of religions. Two small photographs taken by Juan L. Arauz in 1939 picture colonial baroque altars, those prodigal extravagances of saints and angels and gilt and hosannahs that turned the swell of European exuberance into a virtual inundation. In 1991, an American named Peter Kloehn made color photographs of Umbanda altars that adapted this already adaptive style to religions of a different stripe. Umbanda is an African-derived religion brought over by slaves. In one of these altars' tumultuous gatherings, Jesus carries his cross at the peak of the composition; Mary looks suitably motherly; the saints, in brilliant garments, stand by; blacks attend in white suits; North American Indians proudly wear their headdresses, and drums and fancy jugs are thrown in for good measure.
Then there are two girls standing near the door of a Roman Catholic church in feather, embroidery and paper-flower headdresses that are certainly not standard-issue Catholic (Mariana Yampolsky, 1980's); Javier Silva Meinel's recent pictures of Peruvian rituals, said to be tied to Catholicism, one with a man in a trance while an enormous poisonous spider crawls over his face, another of a woman wearing a necklace of fish as she invites the sea to provide a good catch; and Graciela Iturbide's 1980's photograph of a sad Mexican woman holding a baby and wearing a crown of thorns, or her picture of a proud woman selling sisal, which frames her body like a shining pair of wings. A persistent devotion also shines from images of deserted, shuttered or ruined churches impeccably kept up by people who can no longer pray there.
Latin photographic styles tend to be hybrid as well, frequently welding local traditions onto foreign models. Latin America has long had close ties to Europe. From the 19th century on, people traveled or studied abroad, and at least from the 1920's numerous Latin American cities had steady access to European magazines and books. They also saw the imagery of foreigners like Paul Strand who paid lengthy visits.
So Hugo Brehme, a German who lived in Mexico, taught Manuel Alvarez Bravo, the dean of Mexican photographers, and Alvarez Bravo taught his wife, Lola, who taught other Mexican women. (Women are exceptionally well represented in this show, both in quantity and quality.) Alvarez Bravo looked hard at work by Man Ray and other Surrealists, and an elusive Surrealism suffuses many Latin American photographs that do not even tamper with reality, like Iturbide's picture of a woman carrying a chicken past a wall covered with dripped paint that might well be blood, or Renata von Hanffstengel's image of a stairway leading up to a blank wall. Magic realism, you might call it.
Foreigners and natives apparently photographed much the same things. Death looms large in their pictures: Bastienne Schmidt photographed a Colombian exhumation where the mourners were dismayed to find only a heap of clothing in the coffin, Alvarez Bravo depicted the Day of the Dead, Rosalind Solomon pictured a man about to be buried with a bottle of Pepsi.
Insiders and outsiders both seem to have shared a vision of what was significant in these cultures. To a certain extent, they seem to have shared styles as well. But perhaps this is yet another example of borrowed or imposed European traditions thoroughly reconfigured on new soil. The native learns whatever the worldly foreigner has to offer and invents a new world from this knowledge. The outsider looking in at another culture finds it staring back. Sometimes, eventually, it stares him down.

 "Latin American Photography: A Spiritual Journey" remains at the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, through Jan. 19.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Death looms large: "Burial," a 1979 photograph by Rosalind Solomon. (Dean Brown/Brooklyn Museum)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Up Modestly On Price Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices rose modestly yesterday, following the release of data that showed a decline in last month's core wholesale prices. The decline in the core rate served to reinforce the market's perceptions that inflation was not accelerating.
The 30-year bond rose 15/32 , to a price of 962/32 ; the yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, slipped to 7.07 percent, from 7.11 percent on Wednesday. 
 While the stock market initially reacted strongly to the Producer Price Index data, since they show that the economy continues to grow at a fairly moderate clip, the numbers mostly provided the bond market with some relief, because it reduces the likelihood of a large interest-rate increase by the Fed.
Thus, the bond market moved higher on the producer-index data, which was released in the morning, then settled into a narrow price range off the day's highs as traders awaited today's release of the Consumer Price Index for August as well as retail sales data for the month. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg Business News expect the consumer report to show a gain of two-tenths of 1 percent, both in the overall figure and in the core figure that excludes food and energy costs.
The August Producer Price Index rose three-tenths of 1 percent, a higher-than-expected reading led by a 1 percent surge in food prices. But the core numbers -- excluding the volatile food and energy sectors -- showed a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent, precipitating a short cover rally by speculators who had bet that the numbers would be more bearish, then had to scramble to buy securities to limit losses, forcing yields down further.
"While the cost of food cannot be ignored because of its importance as a basic necessity," said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, "it is also true that monetary policy is not known to be an effective tool in controlling the weather. The Fed therefore is likely to be more concerned with the P.P.I.," which, aside from the food number, "is certainly no cause for alarm." Mr. Fine said another favorable factor for the market yesterday was the increase of 21,000 in the weekly numbers of first-time jobless claims, for the period ended Sept. 7, a rise that was higher than expected. But he noted that both the latest weekly level of 338,000 claims and the current four-week average of 328,000, both still suggested firmness in the labor market.
Of major importance to market participants are today's release of retail sales figures and the Consumer Price Index. Retail sales for August are expected to be noticeably stronger, economists said, but considering the slack in sales for both June and July, overall consumer spending does appear to be moderating somewhat from its strong pace in the first half of the year.
Mr. Fine noted that the C.P.I., the Federal Reserve's leading barometer of inflation, was expected to stay subdued and nonthreatening, but that the Fed's goal was to insure that the index remained that way.
With the labor market pushing against technical full employment, and with the economy not yet slowing to the extent that the Fed apparently desires, a raising of short-term interest rates a quarter-percentage point still seems likely, Mr. Fine said, when the Fed's policy-making arm meets on Sept. 24.
"Not to do so," Mr. Fine warned, "with a 5.1 percent unemployment rate and payroll growth continuing unabated risks a backup in bond yields and a market interpretation that the Fed is dragging its heels, and credibility, after all, is the Fed's most important asset."
The results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new one-year bills saw the average rate come in at 5.57 percent, up from 5.36 percent last month. Traders described investor demand as a bit softer than expected, with the total number of bids and retail interest a little less than average. Even though better results were expected, the impact on the market was minimal.
The average rate awarded was the highest since April 27, 1995, when it was 5.90 percent.
Other data released yesterday included the Atlanta Fed's regional index, which featured the component measuring factory activity at 4.0 in August compared with a July reading of -1.2. The prices-paid component was 12.5, compared with 11.5 in July.

HEADLINE: August Producer Price Report Shows Inflation in Check

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Inflation fundamentally remained in check last month, even though hefty increases for food and energy drove producer prices up three-tenths of 1 percent in August, the second-biggest rise this year, a Labor Department report showed today.
Economists and the securities markets largely disregarded these two erratic sectors and dwelled instead on a decline in the rest of the Producer Price Index for finished goods. That, they said, provided fresh reassurance that inflation was not a threat. 
 "The core P.P.I. numbers look fabulous," said Michael L. Penzer, a senior economist at the Bank of America.
The markets also welcomed the department's report this morning that first-time claims for unemployment benefits climbed 21,000 in the week ended Sept. 7, more than offsetting the preceding week's decline.
Bond prices gained across the board, and the stock market posted a moderate advance as operators braced for publication on Friday of figures on consumer prices and retail sales for August.
If today's figures did anything to shift the odds about whether Federal Reserve policy makers would decide to push up interest rates at their meeting the week after next, it was probably in the direction of standing fast, analysts said. But most appeared to hold a belief that the Fed would raise short-term interest rates by a minimal amount to try to keep an economy that has been expanding too rapidly from generating faster inflation.
"We still expect the Fed to tighten policy by 25 basis points at the Sept. 24th Federal Open Market Committee meeting," Bruce Steinberg and Cheryl Katz of Merrill Lynch told clients today. "However, that is an extremely close call, and the P.P.I. report certainly supplies a rationale to hold policy steady."
Although the core finished-goods index eased just one-tenth of 1 percent, the consensus forecast had been for a slight rise. Moreover, prices of the goods at the intermediate and crude stages of production were also well behaved -- each up two-tenths of 1 percent over all and up one-tenth of 1 percent excluding the volatile food and energy components over which Federal Reserve influence, in any event, is scant.
"There is simply no inflation in the pipeline," declared analysts at Macroeconomic Advisers, a St. Louis consultant, pointing to actual deflation in the core intermediate and crude indexes since late last year.
On the other hand, while core finished-goods inflation was being halved, to 1.4 percent, over the latest 12 months, the finished goods index as a whole was rising nearly a point, to a 3 percent year-over-year rate in August.
"Unfortunately, the run-ups in food and energy prices coincided and will likely show up in broader measures of inflation about the same time the increase in the minimum wage does," Macroeconomic Advisers said. The Federal minimum rises 50 cents an hour, to $4.75, on Oct. 1.
Prices of finished foods advanced 1 percent in August, with pork prices leaping 8.7 percent. Fresh fruits and melons, eggs for fresh use and shortening and cooking oils also turned up after July declines. Fresh and dry vegetables, however, dropped 11.9 percent, and fish and young chickens also turned down.
Prices obtained by energy producers climbed seven-tenths of 1 percent after a modestly larger July decline, with gasoline a major contributor. Residential electric power and lubricants also moved up. Residential natural gas and heating oil rose less than in July.
Elsewhere, price increases for paper products, alcoholic beverages, tires, floor coverings, sporting goods and newspaper circulation were offset by declines for prescription drugs, passenger cars, books, apparel and light trucks, the department reported. Producers of capital equipment saw prices they receive edge down one-tenth of 1 percent.
Among intermediate goods, durable items like aluminum mill shapes used in manufacturing fell six-tenths of 1 percent following a nine-tenths of 1 percent decline in July. Nondurables like organic chemicals used in factories posted a three-tenths of 1 percent increase in August, reversing a larger July decline.
The index for all domestic manufacturing, including petroleum refining, advanced two-tenths of 1 percent after showing no change in July.
The department's report on jobless claims, which analysts viewed with more than the usual caution because of the difficulty of adjusting for the Labor Day holiday, found 338,000 workers applying for new benefits. This compared with an exceptionally low 317,000 for the week ended Aug. 31 and lifted the four-week moving average to 327,750, a rise of 4,250.

HEADLINE: Ernesto Geisel, 88, Is Dead; Eased Military Rule in Brazil

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Former President Ernesto Geisel, the Brazilian military dictator associated with the gradual reopening of Brazil to the outside world, died in a Rio clinic today. He was 88.
A stern figure whose father immigrated from Germany at the turn of the century, General Geisel was the fourth of five military leaders during the dictatorship that ran Brazil from 1964 to 1985. 
 Stirrings toward democracy were evident during his administration, which ran from 1974 to 1979, and he called his policy a "slow, gradual and sure relaxation" of military authority. But he made frequent recourse to the repressive powers vested in him as the head of a military state.
Two years after General Geisel took office, he shut down an already weak Congress after the opposition party blocked a bill he had presented on judicial reform. A few months later, Congress was back at work, but the pro-Government majority party passed a law restricting the speech of candidates in coming elections.
Walder de Goes, a Brasilia-based political consultant and author of "The Brazil of General Geisel," said the former leader's authoritarian bent was typified by his reaction when his Finance Minister, Mario Henrique Simonsen, told him he wanted to resign. General Geisel turned his minister away with the scalding admonition, "The day I don't need you anymore, I'll be the one to tell you."
"He was probably the President with the single greatest awareness of his own power," Mr. de Goes said.
General Geisel's administration was not notable for the widespread use of torture and the large number of unexplained killings that tarnished the tenure of his predecessor, Gen. Emilio Medici, largely because the dictatorship's perceived enemies had already been silenced or killed by the time he took office, Mr. de Goes said.
General Geisel, who had been president of the state petroleum company, Petrobras, took office as the so-called "Brazilian miracle" of economic growth was winding down. He faced the world petroleum crisis, increasing Brazil's foreign debt to pay for oil imports. He also increased the state's role in industry and production and concentrated the country's budget on developing communications, railroads, ports and shipping.
He also reduced the traditional trade dependence of Brazil on Europe and the United States, increasing its trade with Africa and Asia. He signed a $10 billion contract with Germany to build eight nuclear power plants to lessen the country's dependence on foreign energy sources, though the plan was severely criticized.
Even after he was succeeded by another general, Joao Figueiredo, who completed the transition to democracy, General Geisel remained a respected figure. President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who has been wrestling with military dissatisfaction as Brazil begins to recognize and compensate the victims of military repression during the dictatorship, made it a point to visit General Geisel in recent weeks.
In a statement today, Mr. Cardoso praised General Geisel, whose political presence, he said, "was marked by his efforts to end repression, and his determination to bring Brazil back to democracy in what seemed to him the most appropriate way."

HEADLINE: Deane Malott, 98, Educator Who Ran Two Universities

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Deane W. Malott, a business-minded educator who led the University of Kansas and Cornell University through periods of significant growth, died on Wednesday at his home at Cornell in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 98.
In 12 years as Chancellor at Kansas, from 1939 to 1951, and 12 years as president of Cornell, from 1951 to 1963, Mr. Malott raised so much money, built so many buildings and supervised such growth in the student bodies, faculties, research and other resources that it seems hardly surprising that his only prior experience as an educator had been at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration. 
 But for all his business acumen and ability as a fund raiser, Mr. Malott was not content to leave academics to the professors. At Kansas, he initiated major changes in the curriculum, emphasizing thought over memory, and substituting Harvard's famous case method of teaching for some lecture courses.
At Cornell, where he transformed the face of the campus with an extensive construction program, he put so much emphasis on liberal arts that he was remembered yesterday by the president of the university, Hunter Rawlings, primarily as the builder of its intellectual landscape.
Mr. Malott was born in Abilene, Kan., where his grandfather helped found the Citizens Bank in 1885. His father was known as the dean of Kansas bankers, and the Eisenhowers were family friends, Mr. Malott served as a Navy seaman in World War I, majored in economics at the University of Kansas and received his M.B.A. at Harvard in 1923.
As Mr. Malott later recalled it, he had wanted nothing more than to return to Kansas and run a country newspaper. But he had been so impressive as a student that when he was offered a dual position as an assistant dean and assistant professor, he stayed on. In the next few years, Mr. Malott, who was respected for his calm administrative ability and sense of humor, began friendships with scores of future business leaders, many of whom later wrote checks that helped the building programs at Kansas and Cornell.
Partly, perhaps, because he wanted first-hand business experience and partly because he had fallen in love with Hawaii along with the Hawaiian-born woman who became his wife in 1925, Mr. Malott left Harvard in 1929 to work as a vice president of the Hawaiian Pineapple Company and as a personal assistant to James D. Dole, the Harvard graduate who founded the company, which was later named for him.
Returning to Harvard in 1934, Mr. Malott wrote casebooks and business texts, advised a variety of businesses and became such a recognized expert on the economics of agriculture that when the University of Kansas needed a chancellor in 1939, the State Board of Regents picked him out of more than 100 candidates, making him the first Kansas native and alumnus to head the university.
By the time he moved to Cornell, Mr. Malott was a member of so many corporate boards and a friend of so many business executives that fund raising sometimes seemed a breeze. It was rarely more so than in 1956, when Mr. Malott presided over what amounted to a check-writing competition between two brothers whose father had helped build the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation. Two months after Spencer Olin pledged $2 million to build a civil engineering building, his brother John pledged $3 million toward the construction of a library.
Mr. Malott, whose wife died in 1994, is survived by a son, Robert, of Kenilworth, Ill.; two daughters, Janet Elliott of Ocala, Fla., and Edith LaBonte of Palo Alto, Calif.; nine grandchildren, and nine great-grandchildren.
