HEADLINE: Big Labor With a Smaller Agenda;
U.A.W. Is Just Trying to Hold Its Ground With Detroit

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 12

 BODY:
For decades after World War II, the Big Three auto makers' negotiations with the United Automobile Workers were the biggest show in labor relations. The highly ritualized spectacle was watched closely by executives and union leaders in other industries because the U.A.W. had a history of winning big concessions, like automatic cost-of-living adjustments and fully paid health care for retired workers, that soon spread to other businesses.
But with the auto makers' current labor contracts set to expire at midnight on Saturday, it is becoming increasingly clear that the U.A.W.'s glory days of big labor breakthroughs are over. Instead of wresting yet more goodies for their members, the union negotiators are fighting a rear-guard action to conserve what they have already gotten and to halt the erosion of the union's membership. 
 Even though the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation are all earning near-record profits and sitting on cash reserves totaling $37 billion, the union is not even pushing for a big pay increase. Rather, in its talks so far with Ford -- the company it chose this year to hammer out a contract to serve as a model for the entire industry -- the U.A.W. has been throwing all its energies into protecting its members' jobs.
"Job security is everything," said Stephen P. Yokich, the U.A.W.'s president, at the beginning of this summer's negotiations. The U.A.W. wants the auto makers to guarantee that their employment of union members will not drop any further and that tens of thousands of retiring workers over the next several years will actually be replaced.
And, because the negotiations no longer set the trend for wages and benefits across the rest of the country, the rest of the country is not paying as much notice as it once did. Wall Street is keeping an eye on them in case another ugly strike develops at G.M. like the one that shut down the nation's largest company last March. Executives in other industries say that they are following the talks but do not expect any repercussions on their own labor costs. "At arm's length, we all watch it, everybody in American business does, but in terms of it being a big factor for us, it's not," said Herbert J. Schmidt, the senior vice president of operations at Contract Freighters Inc., a large, nonunion trucking company based in Joplin, Mo.
Added Sean P. McAlinden, an economics professor at the University of Michigan, "I have never seen so little attention paid to them by other industries' industrial relations departments."
True, the U.A.W.'s sheer size, with 400,000 workers in the auto industry, gives the union the ability, unique in American industry today, to shut down almost overnight assembly plants that account for several percentage points of the nation's economic output. That has allowed the union to hold on to far higher wages and much more generous benefits than workers enjoy in most other sectors of the economy..
At the same time, though, the long-term decline in the union's membership to half its peak in the 1970's, largely as a result of rising worker productivity, the European and Japanese invasions of the American car market and the general decline of the American labor movement -- has weakened its position and made it more wary of taking on management. While G.M. has suffered eight local strikes in the last three years, some of which spread across the country, the last national strike took place at Ford in 1976.
As the U.A.W. has lost influence, it has watched with dismay as the Big Three have moved aggressively to get out of the parts-manufacturing business, thinning the union's ranks further. First Chrysler and Ford, and now G.M., have closed factories or sold them to buyers that quickly negotiated much stingier contracts. As a result, all three companies have been steadily buying more and more parts from outside suppliers, only a fifth of which are unionized and many of which pay their workers half or less of the $19 an hour that U.A.W. workers make.
The spectacle of so many workers outside the auto industry slipping down the economic ladder out of the middle class -- and in many cases the sight of their own sons and daughters entering the work force with better educations but worse job prospects than they had a generation ago -- has profoundly frightened the U.A.W.'s rank and file and made job preservation its No. 1 goal.
The auto makers contend they have no choice but to parcel out the parts business to low-cost suppliers if they are to compete with foreign rivals and still maintain high wages for the workers who remain in their assembly plants.
"We have added 13,000 U.A.W. jobs in the last couple of years, and that is because we have become more efficient at what we do and our market share is going up," Robert A. Lutz, Chrysler's president, told reporters last month. "And we can only do that if we can continually reduce our costs and focus on the things that we do best, which is design engineering, fabricating bodies, painting them, trimming them and doing transmissions and four-wheel drive transfer cases and some axles -- in other words, the core of the car."
But the design, engineering and manufacture of other parts, from seats to steering wheels to dashboards, is better left to outside suppliers, Mr. Lutz said.
Indeed, the the U.A.W.'s scrutiny of outside-supplier contracts shows how much the union's focus has shifted away from bread-and-butter economic issues like higher pay and better benefits and toward assuring its long-term survival.
The threat posed by the auto makers' shedding of parts factories produced a rift in the union leadership that is only now being resolved, according to people close to the U.A.W. At first, some senior officials wanted to work more closely with management, participating in parts-purchasing decisions. The U.A.W. actually controlled a seat on Chrysler's board from 1980 until 1992, when Owen Bieber, then the union's president, relinquished it under pressure from the company.
But the influence of those who advocated such cooperation has waned, as the younger leaders who succeeded Mr. Bieber and his aides showed themselves to be leery of getting too close to management and reluctant to expose themselves to blame for any future sales or closings of factories. The U.A.W. is not even seeking seats on the auto makers' boards this year.
Besides, being the only union representative on a board "is like being the lone chicken in a den of lions -- you can be screaming and ranting and raving but it doesn't matter," said Andrew C. Meyer, a Cleveland lawyer who represents nonunion suppliers.
The union is now trying instead to organize more of the outside suppliers. The goal is to raise the wages paid by the suppliers enough to reduce the incentive for the auto makers to use them.
To achieve that goal, the U.A.W. has rapidly increased its budget for unionization drives. But it also wants the Big Three to use their tremendous buying power to push the suppliers into dropping their staunch resistance to unions.
Some of the nation's largest auto-parts suppliers complain privately that Ford in particular is nudging them to let the union into their factories if they want to keep doing business with the world's No. 2 auto maker. "Some of them are saying that they don't think their customers should dictate what they should be doing," said Donna L. Parolini,, the president of IBD Corporation, a supplier-consulting firm in Troy, Mich.
Ford officials deny that they are putting any pressure on the suppliers. "All we're prepared to do is say to our suppliers that we want them to behave in the same kind of way to their employees as we do," said Alexander Trotman, Ford's chairman, chief executive and president. "We cannot, should not, must not bully or jawbone our suppliers into having unions, that's not our business."
Any overt move by Ford to force unions on its suppliers could subject the company to litigation, labor experts said, adding that Ford still might influence its suppliers by letting its friendly views toward the union be known.
With little chance of obtaining Big Three contracts that would require direct pressure on suppliers, the U.A.W. has instead been negotiating ways to persuade the auto makers to go back to manufacturing their own parts. One likely possibility is that the union may allow a lower wage for workers in any new auto-parts industry that the auto makers may enter. Wages would remain high in the auto makers' existing auto parts factories under this plan.
While the U.A.W. is widely expected to conclude deals quickly with Ford and Chrysler, the toughest bargaining may come at G.M. The giant auto maker's initial offer this week angered the union even with its preface, which warned of the rigors of international competition and the need to reduce costs. "It's condescending, it's insulting, it's global economics nursery school," complained one angry recipient of the document.
But a few people close to the negotiations say that the U.A.W. may quickly reach a loosely worded deal with G.M., then try to resolve tough issues like outside parts purchases through separate negotiations at each of G.M.'s more than 100 assembly and parts factories. If that happens, there could be rocky labor relations in the auto industry for many months to come.

HEADLINE: Jamestown Fort, 'Birthplace' Of America in 1607, Is Found

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

 BODY:
On May 13, 1607, the first successful English settlement in what is now the United States got off to an unsteady start at a swampy island in a broad tidal river. The 104 settlers of the Virginia Company named the place James Fort, later Jamestown, after the sovereign for whom more than half would die in a few wretched months.
This was the colony where Capt. John Smith made his name in history and Pocahontas, a young daughter of the powerful Indian chief Powhatan, became a legend befriending the beleaguered English and supposedly rescuing Captain Smith from death. Looking back from the 19th century, the orator Edward Everett spoke of the Jamestown fort in tidewater Virginia as the place "where the first germs of the mighty republic . . . were planted." 
 All traces of the original fort, however, had been lost for more than two centuries. The log fort burned a year after it was built. Buried remains of the wall, along with any weapons, ceramics and other artifacts, were thought to have been washed away by changing currents of the James River. Anything of the first structures at the first permanent English settlement in America seemed beyond recovery.
But archeologists announced yesterday that the lost had been found. In recent excavations, they uncovered stains of decayed wood where they said logs of the palisade wall had stood in the ground.
From this they established the three-sided fort's footprint, determining the outlines of a rounded bastion at one of the three corners and the angle at which the walls were joined. Archeologists said these observations conformed exactly with contemporary written descriptions of the original fort.
Archeologists also reported finding traces of two buildings within the fort, evidence of glass-making and copper-working industries there and thousands of other artifacts, including swords, armor, a smoking pipe, jewelry, ceramics and coins.
A grave at the site held the well-preserved skeleton of a white man in his early 20's who probably died of a gunshot wound, a fate raising intriguing questions about murder or mutiny or other tempests.
In making the official announcement at Jamestown Island, Gov. George Allen of Virginia declared, "We have discovered America's birthplace -- the original fort."
Dr. William Kelso, the director of archeology of the Association for the Preservation of Virginia Antiquities, which owns the site and supported the excavations, said in a telephone interview that the artifacts should afford historians a clearer view of "a very early Colonial society" in the time of Queen Elizabeth I and her successor, James I.
Among the most interesting finds, Dr. Kelso said, were dozens of sky-blue glass beads apparently manufactured by the colony for trade with the Indians. "John Smith got himself out of hot spots by trading these beads," he said.
The project, which is also supported by the National Geographic Society, is expected to excavate most of the site of the one-acre fort and surrounding town ruins by the 400th anniversary of Jamestown, in 2007.
"Any time we get early Colonial artifacts, it's important," said Dr. James Axtell, a historian at the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va., an expert on early encounters between Europeans and American Indians.
"There's also the symbolic significance here. Jamestown represents the founding of Virginia and of English America, even though other places are better examples of successful colonization."
Indeed, if John Rolfe, who married Pocahontas, had not developed a hybrid tobacco in 1613 that won a ready market in London and the first economic boost for the colony, historians say, Jamestown would have become just another Colonial failure.
An earlier English settlement, in 1584 at Roanoke Island, in present-day North Carolina, was a disastrous failure. In 1562, French Huguenots had no more luck with their Charlesfort, the site of which on the South Carolina coast was discovered earlier this year.
In 1565, the Spanish founded St. Augustine in what is now Florida and which is the oldest permanent European settlement in North America outside Mexico.
Jamestown's early tribulations were many. As Samuel Eliot Morison wrote in "The Oxford History of the American People," the colonists "made the usual mistake of first-comers in America by settling on a low, swampy island." They also put down among a mighty Indian confederacy, which made its first attack on the fort on May 26, 1607.
So because of malaria, starvation and death at the hands of Indians, only 38 of the original 104 settlers lived through the first year. High mortality and bad management led to rumblings of mutiny, which provoked harsh punishment. Supply ships from England were few and inadequate; one relief ship became wrecked on Bermuda, an event that inspired Shakespeare's "Tempest."
"It's incredible that the colony survived," said Dr. Axtell, the historian at William and Mary. "There was 80 percent mortality in the first 15 years. They had no way to make money in the first years. They were a poorly organized community and ill supplied. And their relations with the native people were probably the poorest of any place."
An account of the settlement written in 1610 described the original fort as triangular in shape with a 360-foot wall on the river side and the other two sides 300 feet long. Two sides of the fort form a 46.5-degree angle, identical to the number given in the written account.
The palisades were made of vertical planks and posts of oak and walnut. From the new excavations, it now appears that only 20 percent of the original fort may have been lost to the river. When the fort burned in 1608, it was replaced with a five-sided fort enclosing about four acres.
The excavators were surprised by the number of military artifacts at the site, said Dr. Kelso of the Antiquities Association. In a trash pile buried near one building, they found a helmet and metal breast plate of the type Captain Smith is depicted wearing in a contemporary engraving.
Archeologists also found a smoking pipe, marked with the letter S. "I'm not saying it's his," Dr. Kelso said, referring to Smith. "But who knows?"
The most recent discovery was of a young man's skeleton in a grave inside the fort. Forensic experts from the National Museum of Natural History in Washington examined the skeleton on Wednesday.
From the outline of wood decay and presence of nails, the scientists said, the man had been buried in a wooden coffin. The shape of the nose, teeth and cheek bones indicated that he was a European. Archeologists suspected that he was buried in the first two or three years of the colony.
Dr. Douglas W. Owsley, a forensic anthropologist at the Smithsonian Institution, said the man had definitely met a violent end. Both the tibia and fibula of the right lower leg were fractured, with a metal ball resting at the fracture site. There was a hole in one of the shoulder blades, which could be another gunshot wound.
Since the Indians did not have guns at that time, was this evidence of a murder among disgruntled settlers, an accident or an execution? That will be a problem for historians, who must comb through colony documents searching for references to men dying of gunshot wounds.
Dr. Owsley said there was an account of a man who had been killed as the result of a mutiny but also an account of an Indian who had seized a gun from a settler and shot him.
Anthropologists are more interested in studying the skeleton and any others found at the fort for insights into the nutrition, diseases and other physical conditions of early 17th-century people living in the harsh Colonial circumstances.
The fort site has so far yielded nothing to embellish the familiar story of Captain Smith and Pocahontas. Many historians suspect that elements of the story border on myth.
In an interview, Dr. Axtell of William and Mary said historical documents had failed to support the notion that Captain Smith and Pocahontas had a love affair. But she did go out of her way, often at great risk, to bring food to the English and warn them of impending attacks.
"I read her as a kind of traitor to her people, particularly to her father, Powhatan," the historian said.
Moreover, according to revisionist history, when Captain Smith was captured by Indians, he was held hostage and exchanged for goods, not freed by Pocahontas.
"The story that she saved him was added in much later editions of Smith's writings, as an afterthought," Dr. Kelso said.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE RACE FOR PRESIDENT -- THE SOUTH;
If Clinton Sees Votes in South, He's Not Just Whistling Dixie

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: NASHVILLE, Sept. 12

 BODY:
The most remarkable thing about Bob Dole's visit to Tennessee this week, his third in the last month, was that he had to come here at all.
Only two years ago this was the epicenter of a vast political shift in the South: Tennessee voters gave the Republicans a clean sweep of the state's two Senate seats and the governor's office, all of which had been held by Democrats. 
 Stunned by the hostility toward President Clinton, his advisers said at the time that their best hopes in the South for 1996 -- and they were not much more than hopes -- were that they could hang on to Tennessee, because Vice President Al Gore is a native son, and to Arkansas, because it is Mr. Clinton's home state.
But with eight weeks until Election Day, Republicans now find themselves trying to foil the Democrats' far more ambitious -- and suddenly not-so-farfetched -- designs on the region.
Although Mr. Dole assured supporters at a rally in nearby Murfreesboro on Tuesday that "we're going to carry the state of Tennessee," a poll of registered Tennessee voters, issued today by Mason-Dixon Political/Media Research, suggested that doing so would be a struggle. Among those likely to cast ballots, Mr. Clinton drew 48 percent, Mr. Dole 37 percent, and Ross Perot 2 percent.
Not only is the President leading Mr. Dole, or running neck and neck with him, in polls in Tennessee and the four other Southern or Border states Mr. Clinton won four years ago -- Arkansas, Georgia, Kentucky and Louisiana -- he is also competitive in Florida and North Carolina. No Democratic Presidential nominee has won either of those two states since Jimmy Carter in 1976, although Mr. Clinton himself came close in 1992. The President is even threatening Mr. Dole in Virginia, which no Democrat has captured since President Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964.
"It's scary from the Republican standpoint," A. Linwood Holton, a former Republican Governor of Virginia, said of Democratic prospects in his state. "The vote in statewide elections in Virginia turns on middle-of-the-road voters. And there are a lot of people who don't like the very, very heavy baggage that Dole carries from the Republican platform."
The President's ability to stay competitive in the South -- and so force Mr. Dole and Jack Kemp to campaign extensively there, depriving them of precious time in the showdown states of the Midwest -- demonstrates that after being vilified throughout the region early in his term for raising taxes and promising to end the military's ban on service by homosexuals, he has had some success in repositioning himself as a cultural conservative. It helps, of course, that the Southern economy is fairly healthy and that many voters do not sound especially enthusiastic about Mr. Dole.
While Mr. Dole also seems to have been hurt by his association with Speaker Newt Gingrich, who remains quite unpopular, Republican officials are far more optimistic about prospects that the party will pick up House seats in the region. Some express hope for a "reverse coattails" effect, in which the popularity of Republican candidates in Congressional races would lead voters to turn out for Mr. Dole as well.
But by and large Republicans are increasingly concerned. While Mr. Clinton could lose most of the Southern states and still retain the White House, the South is the foundation of Mr. Dole's electoral strategy, and the only Southern states where he appears to have a comfortable edge are the Republican strongholds of Alabama, Mississippi and South Carolina, although he is also ahead in polls in Texas, rich in electoral votes.
"If Dole has to fight for states like Florida, North Carolina and Virginia, he's fighting behind his own 40-yard line," said Robert Joffee, a vice president of Mason-Dixon, which polls extensively in the South. "These are states that Bush won in 1992, and one would think a competent Republican campaign would have sewn them up some time ago."
His weakness in the South also complicates Mr. Dole's issues strategy: to attract Southern voters, he needs to emphasize policy issues, as well as questions about Mr. Clinton's character, that may not find so welcome an audience elsewhere. Republicans are reminding voters in North Carolina and Kentucky, major tobacco-growing states, of Mr. Clinton's efforts to regulate cigarette makers, Mr. Dole's opposition to which has not played well nationally.
Still, Mr. Dole's best chance for a comeback is in the South, which remains the weakest region for the all-Southern Democratic ticket. Mr. Clinton's lead in the South as a whole is narrower than anywhere else -- a New York Times/CBS News Poll conducted last week showed that the margin was 16 points among registered voters around the country, as against 9 points among those in the South -- and surveys show that Southern voters express even greater disapproval of his character than do those elsewhere.
Republicans argue that Mr. Dole is just beginning to fight back after being the target of months of advertising that the Clinton campaign has showered on several Southern states.
"I wish the race were tighter; I wish we didn't have as much ground to make up," said Ted Welch, a major Republican fund-raiser in Nashville. "But I do believe the race is winnable."
One illustration of Mr. Clinton's change of fortunes is that Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, a Democrat who sparred with the President throughout the Administration's first two years -- and on one occasion did not show up at a Clinton appearance in Atlanta -- has signed on as co-chairman of the President's re-election effort in the state. "He agreed to, and is serving, and that's a statement," said Gordon Giffin, an Atlanta lawyer who for years was Mr. Nunn's chief fund-raiser.
Dole campaign officials say that they expect the race to tighten nationally and that the first states to move in the challenger's favor will be in the South. Seeking those inroads, the campaign is relentlessly emphasizing Mr. Dole's proposal for a 15 percent cut in personal income tax rates, and underscoring character as well. Introducing Mr. Dole at the Murfreesboro rally, Gov. Don Sundquist said: "He's a man of character, and character does count in public life. He offers mature judgment. And isn't it time we had an adult in the White House?"
But many Republicans are fearful that Mr. Dole's message is not sinking in, that he has not given voters a reason to back him. More than one supporter of his noted that the front-page article in The Tennessean about his visit here did not reflect what he would do to help voters in the state.
Whit Ayres, a Republican pollster in Atlanta, said Mr. Dole needed "to get some muscle behind his message." Once that happens, he said, Mr. Dole could pull ahead.
"These states are all close," Mr. Ayres said. "There are a lot of voters in the middle who have gone from moderately opposed to Clinton to moderately in favor of him. But they are hardly in his corner yet."
Several voters from Murfreesboro, interviewed at random in July 1994 and again this week, say that although they backed Republicans in the off-year elections two years ago and have little nice to say about Mr. Clinton, they are torn over how to vote this fall.
Michael Henderson, a 47-year-old teacher who backed President George Bush in 1992 and Republicans in 1994, said he was still deciding between Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton.
"I'm trying to keep an open mind," Mr. Henderson said. Struggling to explain his reservations about the 73-year-old Mr. Dole, he went on: "I don't know whether it's his age, or what. Or maybe it's some of his comments about teachers."
Jeff Sweatt, 29, a former shipping company supervisor who recently went back to college, also voted Republican in the last two elections. He too said he was trying to decide, between Mr. Dole and Ross Perot.
"I like Bob Dole -- he's an honest man," Mr. Sweatt said. "But I think he's got an uphill battle beating Clinton." Asked to explain why Mr. Dole was down in the polls, he replied, "I really don't understand the American public."

HEADLINE: Nation of Islam Guards Ordered to Leave Housing Project

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Sept. 12

 BODY:
The Pataki administration has ordered the managers of a state-financed housing project in Brooklyn to break a contract with a security group associated with the Nation of Islam, responding to complaints that the group has been passing out anti-Semitic literature.
But residents of the project, Ocean Towers in Coney Island, immediately expressed outrage at the order, saying that the group, X-Men Security, had greatly improved security in an area once plagued by drug deals, shootouts and other violence. They said the presence of the Nation of Islam guards had brought order back into daily life in the cavernous project. 
 The group was awarded the security contract, now worth $360,000 a year, by the company that runs the building, BSR Management, in the summer of 1993. The previous security agency had been dismissed because some of its guards had been found to be involved the drug trade in the project.
With the new sense of calm that the Nation of Islam guards, in their characteristic business suits and bow ties, brought to the area, vacancies at the 360-unit project dropped to 5 from 50, according to the management company.
"I really think this is a sad day," said Sheila Boyd, president of the Ocean Towers Tenants Association. "That group got rid of the drug dealers and criminals. People were begging to move in here because it was so safe. Now, all I can do is pray that things don't get worse again."
Still, pressure on Gov. George E. Pataki to remove the X-Men from the project had been strong; politicians and Jewish organizations repeatedly complained that the group had tried to recruit members during patrols, passed out racist pamphlets and hung posters of Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, in hallways and lobbies.
A spokeswoman for the Governor, Zenia Mucha, said today that the management company would end its contract with the X-Men as of Oct. 10 because officials at the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal had found flaws in it. Ms. Mucha said the Governor had directed the agency to review the contract because of the allegations made against the X-Men.
"We certainly have a problem with the fact that the leader of this organization is a person who practices anti-Semitism," she said, referring to Mr. Farrakhan.
Groups associated with the Nation of Islam have conducted similar patrols in public housing complexes around the country, including Baltimore, Washington and Pittsburgh, often ridding these places of drugs and crime. Those groups have also been accused of proselytizing and vigilantism.
The Ocean Towers complex is privately owned but was built with state money under an agreement that a certain percentage of apartment units be set aside for low-income families.
The first complaints about the X-Men date to 1993, when the group began sending guards to the projects. In testimony last year before a Congressional subcommittee looking into the Nation of Islam security details at public housing complexes, Jules Polinetsky, a Democratic Assemblyman from Brooklyn, said that the X-Men had been distributing issues of the Final Call, the Nation of Islam newspaper, at the Ocean Towers complex.
"In this paper," he testified, "white men are called wicked and filthy, Jews are called bloodsuckers, and the Pope is described as the leader of organized crime on this earth."
But attempts by the state to remove the group met with strong opposition from residents and building managers, who said it was doing a good job. Mr. Pataki himself, in a July 26 letter to Mr. Polinetsky, said vacancy rates had declined sharply since the X-Men's arrival.
Today, Mr. Polinetsky expressed satisfaction with the administration's decision but criticized the length of time it had taken. "The Nation of Islam did a good job at providing security but did a better job at proselytizing," he said. "Mussolini made the trains run on time, but that did not make Fascism an acceptable evil."
But residents of the complex expressed dismay, saying the X-Men had been criticized by people with a vendetta against the Nation of Islam.
"If they move, I'm moving," said Jeanie Booker, a resident. "These drug dealers are waiting for the X-Men to leave so they can come back. The X-Men are the only ones who have been able to get them to leave. I don't know why they are trying to get rid of them."

HEADLINE: Don't Start New York on School Vouchers Path;
Don't Siphon Gas Tax

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Gas Tax Could Help Our Cities," by Felix Rohatyn (Op-Ed, Sept. 11): Wrong. It would be wrong to use a Federal gas tax for school improvements or anything other than transportation maintenance. Federal gas-tax revenues should be dedicated only to the Highway Trust Fund. Breaking this trust in 1993 has already resulted in serious decay of roads and bridges. Economic development and jobs would suffer under Mr. Rohatyn's plan, as would the tax base that now pays for most school improvements. 
 Education is the responsibility of local and state governments. If unrealistic debt limits are the problem, they should be increased to allow for longer-term repayment. When it comes to educating the nation's young, who will pay off the debt as productive adults, the expense is well worth it.
 
ROSSJ. PEPE
Tarrytown, N.Y., Sept. 11, 1996
 
Pres., Construction Industry Council
of Westchester and Hudson Valley

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Follows Stocks and Bonds In Rise, Ignoring Weaker Data

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the German mark and Japanese yen yesterday, aided by rising stocks and bonds, even though weaker-than-expected economic data eased speculation that the Federal Reserve would push up interest rates.
The dollar again reached two-month highs against the yen and mark, its third time in recent sessions, after initially dropping on news of scant rises in consumer prices and retail sales for August. 
 Both statistics indicated inflation was in check, creating less need for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to avert inflation at its Sept. 24 meeting.
But the dollar shot up shortly after that, supported in part by spiking stock and bond prices. Foreign investors bought dollars to invest in American securities.
"Because the dollar was not significantly hurt by this morning's data, that only boosted the confidence of traders who were already dollar bullish," said Tom O'Malley, a senior foreign exchange analyst at Technical Data in Boston. "The dollar has built upside momentum over the past week," he said.
In late New York trading, the dollar traded at 1.5134 marks, up from 1.5125 Thursday. The dollar traded at 110.35 yen, up from 110.20 yen.
The British pound traded at $1.5535, down from $1.5545.
The dollar has risen 3 pfennigs, or nearly 0.05 percent, since Sept. 4, largely on speculation that the Fed will raise interest rates.
"The dollar in general was supported by what I think was good news from U.S. data today, which showed continued growth in the U.S. economy with moderate inflation pressure," said Lisa Finstrom, a senior currency analyst at Smith Barney Inc.
However, Lawrence B. Lindsey, a Fed governor, said yesterday that despite the weak data, the economy "still looks robust." Analysts said the comments supported their contentions that the Fed still might raise rates, but they came too late to influence the market.
Mr. Lindsey sits on the central bank's policy-making committee that will decide whether to raise rates.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday, were: 1.2434 Swiss francs, up from 1.2373; 5.1550 French francs, down from 5.1601; 1,521 Italian lire, unchanged, and 1.3695 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3714.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Opposition Grows in Brazil To High Domestic Air Fares

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 13

 BODY:
As Brazil moves slowly toward selling off state companies and trimming government's regulatory role, its airlines have become an anomaly: an industry forced to bear high costs and tight regulation while still charging high domestic fares that most Brazilians cannot afford.
But opposition is growing in a country where it is often cheaper to fly from Sao Paulo to Miami than to Manaus, despite the greater distance. A consumer group's campaign to deregulate domestic air fares has drawn unexpected support. 
 At just four airports over eight days last month, more than 20,000 travelers signed petitions complaining of the high cost of domestic air fares, said Danilo Santana, national president of the Brazilian Consumers Association, which ran the campaign. The number of signatures was all the more noteworthy since the airports, which are government run, limited the consumers group to two volunteers at each airport.
The instant support for the campaign among passengers has put the airlines, accustomed to protection in determining prices and to lax enforcement of consumer rights, on the defensive. As Brazil moves slowly toward privatization of state-run industries and dismantling of regulation, the campaign appears to have struck a chord at a politically opportune moment.
Before the petitioning campaign even closed, Francisco Dornelles, Minister of Industry and Commerce, gave the Government tourism board 30 days to come up with recommendations to reduce the cost of domestic tourism, particularly air travel.
"Tourism is a priority, and we're going to do everything to reduce its cost," Mr. Dornelles said, adding that the Government would move to reduce some of the heavy taxes, including a 33 percent tax on kerosene, that Brazilian airlines cite for the high cost of domestic travel.
"The move toward liberalization is unstoppable," said Robert C. Booth, president of Aviation Management Services, a Miami-based consulting firm to many Latin American airlines. "The country can't embrace the free market system and ignore things like this. Airline deregulation is one of the last things they're going to do, but they've got to do it."
Flying remains an elite form of transportation in Brazil, despite the country's size. Only 5 percent of all Brazilians have ever flown, and 80 percent of all air travel is for business, according to industry figures. In the United States, only 30 percent of the population had been on an airplane before prices were deregulated in 1978. With deregulation, prices dropped 50 percent and the share of people flying reached 70 percent, Mr. Booth said.
Domestic prices in Brazil are proposed by the airlines and approved by the Department of Commercial Aviation. In addition to controlling which airlines may serve which routes, the agency sets upper and lower bands for prices, limiting promotional fares to 30 to 50 percent of the full economy fare. The president of the department, Joao Felipe Lacerda Jr., declined to respond to written questions for this article.
The airlines say the cost of fuel in Brazil is 40 percent greater than in the United States. They also cite high interest rates and inefficient, Government-run airports as reasons for their heavy costs. They also dispute the contention that fares are higher here than in the United States, and note that Brazilian airlines began offering limited discounts in 1992.
"Right now, we have a flexibility that can be considered the beginning of deregulation," said Ramiro Tojal, president of the Brazilian Airline Association. "I don't think deregulation itself will solve anything."
In an attempt to defend itself against the mounting criticism, Transbrasil took out full-page newspaper ads contending that Brazilian prices were similar to those in the United States and Europe. The advertisement compared full economy fares in the United States and Brazil, a somewhat misleading demonstration, since unlike Brazil, 90 percent of all travelers in the United States fly using discounted tickets, Mr. Booth said. At Varig, Brazil's largest airline, only 28 percent of domestic tickets are sold at less than full economy fares, a spokesman said.
The ad also compared a $295 round-trip Rio-Sao Paulo shuttle ticket not with the similarly priced New York to Washington shuttle, for which steep weekend discounts are available, but with a $419 fare between Kennedy and Dulles airports. The Rio-Sao Paulo shuttle offers no discounts.
"We want to compete in quality, service, frequency, not only in price," Mr. Tojal said.
But it is prices that are on the minds of consumers here. "People are not complaining about what kind of food they get served on board," Mr. Santana said. "They're thinking about more basic things, like how their baggage is handled and how much they pay for a ticket."
Mr. Santana said the association had found that fares were related not so much to distance or frequency of flights or airport costs but to the degree of competition. "Where there's competition, the prices are lower; where there's no competition, it's much higher," he said. "When our companies have to compete with an American company on international flights, those are very low, competitive prices. But if it's a route where the airline has the authorization to cover that route and is protected from open competition, the rates get higher."

HEADLINE: Consumer Price Index Barely Rises, Easing Inflation Fears

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Consumer prices rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in August, the Labor Department disclosed today, a better performance than expected and one that economists regarded as solid confirmation that inflation remains in check.
Shoppers, meanwhile, spent at a subdued pace last month, sending retail sales up by a modest two-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department reported. 
 The two sets of figures, perhaps more important than any still to come before a crucial meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers on Sept. 24, seemed to further diminish -- but by no means rule out -- the chance that the central bank would decide to raise short-term interest rates to restrain an overheated economy.
"The numbers encourage the view that the Fed won't tighten at its September meeting," said Paul W. Boltz, chief economist at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore. "The urgency goes out of it when inflation looks this good."
Today's numbers followed the Government's report on Thursday that prices received by American producers climbed three-tenths of 1 percent last month, but that price index actually declined slightly when the erratic food and energy components were removed.
Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist for the Chase Regional Bank, said today that inflation posed little immediate threat. He noted that there was wide agreement that prices were rising even less than was being registered by the Consumer Price Index, and that Fed policy was already restrictive as gauged by the inflation-adjusted rate for Federal funds, the overnight lending rate among banks.
He played down the recent creeping up of wages, saying it was more a reflection of higher skills than of general wage acceleration.
"What business is doing, having cut costs as much as it could, is to invest in technology," Mr. Kellner said. More technicians, he added, mean larger numbers of people in higher-paid jobs.
But Paul L. Kasriel of the Northern Trust Company in Chicago contended today that it was time for the Fed to remove the "punch bowl" from the economic party, invoking the definition of a central banker's job used by William McChesney Martin Jr., the Fed chairman in the 1950's and 1960's.
"Human-capital capacity appears to be getting strained," Mr. Kasriel said, adding that an acceleration in wages is a natural result of efforts to attract new workers and retain current ones.
Securities markets rallied today on the twin reports, with interest rates sliding across the board and the Dow Jones industrial average soaring 66.58 points, or 1.15 percent, to a record of 5,838.52, surpassing the high of 5,778 set May 22.
Today's price report, which included a rise of one-tenth of 1 percent in so-called core items in August, showed that overall inflation was down to 2.9 percent for the latest 12 months and was at an annual rate of 1.8 percent over the latest three months.
Although analysts noted that the Consumer Price Index was a lagging rather than a predictive indicator, further reassurance came today from a poll of members of the National Federation of Independent Business.
The survey found that only 18 percent of 800 respondents raised prices this summer while 13 percent cut them, the most benign inflation results this year. And it said that only 20 percent of respondents planned to raise prices in coming months, with two-thirds of those planning increases of less than 5 percent. The survey also found that service industries were no more likely to raise prices than others were.
The price index last month was held down by a third consecutive easing in energy costs, which fell six-tenths of 1 percent; gasoline dropped 2 percent, more than offsetting a rise in household fuels. Food prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent, reflecting increases for meats, poultry, fish and dairy products.
Housing costs ebbed after a July surge related to out-of-town lodging; the August decline came despite a 2 percent jump in the cost of intrastate telephone calls. In transportation, automobile finance charges climbed 1.8 percent, but the price of used cars was unchanged after four consecutive declines.
Apparel prices, the report showed, dropped 1.4 percent, reflecting the slower introduction of higher-priced fall and winter wear coupled with large declines for spring and summer wear. The cost of college tuition and schoolbooks and supplies rose 1 percent and 1.2 percent, respectively.
The report on August retail sales showed a rise of three-tenths of 1 percent for durable goods -- those intended to last at least three years -- and an increase of one-tenth of 1 percent for nondurables.
Stores selling general merchandise posted a gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent, and apparel stores also did well. But merchants selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes had a decline of seven-tenths of 1 percent, and furniture sales were also down.
Food stores and bars and restaurants also had lower revenue. A drop at gasoline stations reflected lower prices, rather than less volume.

HEADLINE: Judge's Efforts Gain a Reprieve for Farberware Factory in the Bronx

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Under pressure from a state judge, the company that closed the Farberware plant in the Bronx eight days ago agreed yesterday to reopen it temporarily to give government officials more time to find someone to buy and operate it permanently.
At a hearing in which Justice Douglas E. McKeon of State Supreme Court in the Bronx stressed that his priority was to preserve jobs, U.S. Industries of Edison, N.J., agreed to reopen the plant for at least a week and possibly up to three months, and to rehire some of the 700 laid-off workers. 
 City and state officials had sought Justice McKeon's help in keeping the plant open because they said it would be far easier to find a buyer for an operating plant than a shuttered one. They asserted that U.S. Industries had breached a promise to operate the plant until 2006. In exchange for that promise, they said, U.S. Industries had been allowed to rent the state-owned building at below-market rates in 1981.
At a testy daylong hearing in Justice McKeon's chambers, company executives agreed to reopen the plant for one week starting Wednesday and to rehire 120 workers. By the end of the day, city and state officials expressed confidence that a deal could be reached to keep the plant going for three months, but U.S. Industries executives said any such agreement would depend on whether the company could obtain more raw materials for the plant.
The justice made his sympathies clear. "There are families with real problems and real concerns who are impacted by this," he said. "I am most interested in trying to restore hope to these people."
A government official involved in the negotiations called his strategy "judicial capitalism," and several other negotiators agreed that the efforts of the city, state and judge to twist the company's arm to reopen a plant were extraordinary.
U.S. Industries lawyers criticized what they saw as improper government meddling in the free-enterprise system, arguing that the city and state had no basis for asking a judge to keep the plant open. But Frank Mahoney, executive vice president of the Empire State Development Corporation, asserted that the company had violated its 1981 contract. "We're trying to show that when a company makes a promise to us, we're not just going to let them walk away from it," he said.
Charles Millard, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, said: "For 15 years, these people have had the benefits of the bargain. Now the Mayor wants the city to have its benefits of the bargain."
In April, U.S. Industries sold the Farberware name and the machinery from the factory -- the largest in the Bronx -- to the Syratech Corporation. Within weeks, word emerged of Syratech's licensing of the Farberware name to another cookware company. This convinced many workers that the factory's demise was imminent. They doubted that consumers would buy cookware lacking the renowned Farberware name.
Under the original arrangement between U.S. Industries and Syratech, the former operated the factory and the latter marketed the pots and pans. This explains why U.S. Industries remains involved in the factory's fate: It retains the lease and responsibility for the workers.
In Justice McKeon's hearings, U.S. Industries and Syratech sought to portray each other as villains. When U.S. Industries officials began by saying that they would not even discuss keeping the plant open for three months unless Syratech paid $4.5 million in bills, Syratech's lawyer lambasted U.S. Industries for putting debt collection above the good of 700 workers.
Then lawyers for U.S. Industries attacked Syratech for having doomed the plant by licensing away the Farberware name. U.S. Industries officials said Syratech had hidden an important piece of information in May when it was negotiating with the city, state and workers about turning Farberware into an employee-owned factory. During those talks, Syratech failed to inform city and state officials that it had already licensed away the Farberware name.
"The fact is both companies are villains," said Ben Camadeco, president of the Teamsters local representing Farberware's workers.
Syratech, which has repeatedly been attacked by Farberware's workers, recently sought to alleviate their anger by agreeing to work with the city and state to keep the plant open until Dec. 8. But U.S. Industries executives have stressed the difficulties of selling the cookware without the Farberware name.
U.S. Industries officials said that even with an agreement to extend the plant's life by three months, the factory would have to be closed for most of October because it could take 6 to 10 weeks to obtain needed raw materials. State and city officials vowed to press suppliers to deliver raw materials faster than that.
Outside Justice McKeon's chambers sat more than 40 laid-off Farberware workers, who awaited word of their fate. "A lot of us worked there for years, even decades," said Hamilton Fields, a mechanic. "Now it's all down the drain. It's very hard on the nerves."

HEADLINE: Flare-up of Gang Gunfire Vexes, Gary, Ind.

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: GARY, Ind., Sept. 13

 BODY:
This faded steel town, which has had stubbornly high crime statistics for years, had a quiet summer and a 34 percent drop in its murder rate for the year so far, primarily, city officials say, because of increased anti-gang efforts.
But the quiet ended on Wednesday with two drive-by shootings at local high schools, followed by several hours of gunfire and a gang-related shootout at a public housing development, where gang members in bulletproof vests armed with semiautomatic weapons darted between the buildings and the trees, firing at each other and the police. 
 Athough no one was killed, Mayor Scott L. King issued a citywide state of emergency, tightened the curfew and increased police patrols.
"We will not tolerate this ever happening again in this city," Mr. King said today in an interview.
"There were an incredible number of shots fired at the housing development, endangering hundreds of innocent people. It's a miracle no one was hurt."
With the two high schools holding football games against separate opponents tonight, there were fears of further violence. But at Roosevelt High School, which is next to the housing development, about 100 students and their parents gathered to watch game without incident. At the other game, at West Side High School, there were no reports of any violence, either.
"Everything looks fine," Mr. King said after visiting both games, each of which had their usual police contingent of about a half-dozen officers.
At a news conference on Thursday, a Gary police officer who was at the housing development during the shootout seemed on the verge of tears as he described the intensity of the gunfire that was finally quelled when police officials sent in the SWAT team. The streets have been quiet for the last two days as investigators try to piece together the motives behind the shootings and determine if they were related.
"Who knows right now," Mr. King said, throwing up his hands and then lighting his third cigarette in 10 minutes. "We're dealing with people who might draw and fire their guns over a disagreement over a baseball score."
But residents of the housing development, the Delaney Housing Complex, say they know the answer: the quick flash of drug cash.
"This is all about drugs," said Marietta Powell, a 41-year-old mother of five, who is afraid to allow her children out to play. "They have no jobs in this city for young people, so they're killing each other up over drugs."
Jobs have been hard to find in Gary for a long time, ever since the steel mills began to cut back a generation ago. In the 1960's the mills employed 30,000. Today, the number is closer to 5,000. Downtown Gary is one long strip of empty stores and burned out buildings, the American Dream in reverse.
But last June, two riverboat casinos, one of them owned by Donald Trump, opened on the city's edge and officials and residents were cautiously talking about a comeback on a wave of $20 million a year in revenue from the boats.
"We're going to devote a lot of those dollars to public safety," the Mayor said then.
Still, gangs have long haunted this city, which is just 30 minutes from Chicago and has some of the biggest gangs in the country. Last year, 50 Indiana State Troopers helped patrol Gary for several months and last spring, Mr. King said the gangs put a bounty on his head because he refused to allow them to use a city building to hold what they said were peace talks.
"It was a whopping $3,000," Mayor King said with a smirk. "My response was to crack down on them." Mr. King said the main reason Gary was relatively quiet this summer was because the Police Department's gang unit was able to keep the gangs separated.
But the resumption of school, where rival gang members are often under one roof during the day, may have set the stage for this week's outbreak of violence.
On Thursday, hours after the shootings, Mayor King started his day by addressing 100 of the city's top honor students.
"I spent 20 minutes with them and 12 hours worrying about a few goofballs," Mr. King said. "People have to remember that only a small minority of kids are involved in the gangs. You can't demonize young people over all."
The "day from hell," as one resident described it, began at 12:30 P.M. with a drive-by shooting at Lew-Wallace High School on the city's West Side.
A few hours later, as hundreds of students poured out of a high school at the end of the day on Gary's Far West Side, shots were again fired from a passing car.
Then as dusk fell over the city 116,000 residents, the police were called to the Delaney development to investigate reports of even more gunshots. When the first two officers arrived, they saw four armed men fleeing the scene but who were caught after a chase by one officer on foot.
"It's amazing, he wasn't killed," the Mayor said. As the crime technicians were inspecting the area, a resident told them that she had just seen four more men in bullet proofvests, carrying rifles. Then a barrage of gunfire lit up the night and the officer drove for cover. The SWAT was called in but the men had escaped.
Today, all was quiet outside Lew-Wallace as Doris Scott, 15, waited for her father, Elton, to pick up her. Mr. Scott, 38, a building contractor, said he had wanted his daughter to attend parochial school but "we didn't have the finances."
Now, after the shooting, he is more determined than ever to raise the money.
Doris said she was afraid.
"You might get shot for wearing the wrong gym shoes," she said, "or for wearing your cap the wrong way. When I see a group of boys together, I get scared."
A few miles away at the Delaney development, Ms. Powell, the mother of five, said she was also scared. She has lived in the development of one-story buildings, twisting streets, neat lawns and shade trees for two years. The beauty of the place hides the danger, she said, adding when she and her family first moved in her daughter saw a man get shot in the head.
"This has been going on for too long around here," she said. "I applaud the Mayor for doing something. But its hard to live here."
But what concerns her more than any noise in the night is what her 18-month-old son did after the shooting.
"He was going, 'Boom, Boom,' like he was shooting a gun," she said. "He had never done that before. This madness is affecting everybody."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow at a Record 5,838.52; Bonds and the Dollar Rally
The stock market surged to a record, keeping alive one of history's greatest bull markets and erasing a midsummer downturn that had many analysts predicting the end of good times on Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 1.2 percent, or 68.58, to 5,838.52, eclipsing its May 22 record of 5,778.
The bond market also rallied, as long-term interest rates fell below 7 percent, to 6.95. Behind the surge was economic news showing inflation in check, lessening fears that the Fed will push up interest rates. [Page 1.]
 
The dollar rose against the mark and yen, reaching two-month highs. It followed stocks and bonds upward, despite the weaker-than-expected economic data. Foreigners bought dollars in order to buy American securities. In New York the dollar edged up to 1.5134 marks. [34.]
 
Oil Futures Prices Tumble
Crude oil futures plunged with the contract for October delivery down 49 cents, to $24.51 a barrel, after tensions with Iraq eased. [34.]
 
F.A.A. Faulted on Airport Security
A newly issued Government report says that in inspecting airport security, F.A.A. agents sometimes overstated how well airports performed and made efforts to help airlines do well on the inspections. [1.]
 
In the Tobacco Economy: Alarm
Tobacco is the main cash crop in Kentucky and much of the South, and now a whiff of national politics has tobacco farmers in full alarm. Many local Democratic politicians find themselves opposing President Clinton. [1.]
 
Compuserve Backpedals on Profit
Compuserve retracted a prediction of profits made by one of its executives. Steven Stanbrook, Compuserve's president of international operations, had said in Munich that based on the strength of European operations, "for the year as a whole we will be making a strong profit." [32.]
 
Japanese Economy Shrinks 0.7%
Japan's economy contracted seven-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter. It was the first time economic output had declined since 1994's final quarter, but the Government said the nation's recovery was continuing. [32.]
 
A Mistrial in California Bankruptcy
A mistrial was declared in the first criminal trial related to the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif., that of the former budget director, Ronald S. Rubino. [44.]
 
Brazilian Air Travelers Restive
As Brazil moves slowly toward privatization of state-run industries and dismantling of regulation, a travelers' campaign opposing the high cost of domestic air fares appears to have struck a chord at an opportune moment. [32.]
 
Nestle Profits Advance 20%
Nestle, the world's largest food and beverage company, said its net profit rose 20 percent, to 1.35 billion Swiss francs ($1.1 billion) in the first half of 1996, but its stock price fell 10 Swiss francs to 1,413, as investors focused on stagnant trading results. Heineken, the Dutch brewer, reported a 6.1 percent profit rise. [32.]
 
The Hottest Shop in Moscow
Moscow's hottest store is suitably named Arrears. Bargain hunters rush to buy the latest booty seized by the Moscow tax police -- boxes of down coats going for the equivalent of $17, and even a 10-year-old Hungarian-made bus for $19,000. [4.]
 
Mexican Publisher Arrested
The owner of one of Mexico's biggest newspapers, El Universal, was arrested on charges of criminal tax fraud and evasion. Juan Francisco Ealy Ortiz, the owner and publisher, contended the Government was cracking down on dissent in the press. [5.]

HEADLINE: On Eve of Election in Bosnia, Peace Is a Last Resort

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: TRNOVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Sept. 13

 BODY:
With most of its villages in ruins, its forests and fields saturated with land mines, its infrastructure so devastated that an entire generation can expect little more than a life of drudgery and poverty, and its people plagued by memories of slaughter and loss, Bosnia can hardly be considered at peace.
But the warfare that raged in this land's hamlets and cities for nearly four years has sputtered out in exhaustion, with hate and fury often smothered by pain and mourning. And the main hope, as ethnic Croats, Muslims and Serbs vote on Saturday in the first elections in six years, is that the fighting never resume. 
 "We can live with anything now except war," said Sofija Jokic, 62, as she and her husband boiled pieces of pumpkin in a blackened pot over a wood fire here in a once idyllic mountain town that changed hands four times during the war and now is little more than a patch of ruins. "The rest does not interest us."
Bosnians are struggling to make a place for themselves in a land where, for many, a pane of glass is a coveted luxury and a small cabbage patch the only thing that stands between a family and hunger. Most simply want a job. And most watch in disgust as the few jobs available in the three ethnic regions go to supporters of the three dominant parties.
"Those of us who refuse to define ourselves as Serbs or Croats or Muslims no longer have a place in Bosnia," said Liljana Kljakic, a 28-year-old Serb from Sarajevo who joined the Muslim-led Bosnian Army during the war and whose father was killed in Sarajevo by a Serbian grenade. "It is as if we have no identity. I will leave soon for Australia."
It is left for the international architects of these elections to debate whether the Croats, Serbs and Muslims who will vote for a three-member presidency and joint parliament will create -- as Washington hopes -- common institutions that will unify the splintered country. Most Bosnians seem beyond caring about that abstract goal. Not a few see in the current de facto partition an end to the conflicts that caused so much misery and grief.
The deep antipathy to war is also accompanied, for many, by a demonization of opposing ethnic groups. Muslims, Croats and Serbs who insist they did not want the conflict blame their opponents for the carnage. Many Serbs and Croats say they would be happy to keep the country divided.
Muslims, especially their leaders and the hundreds of thousands who were expelled from their homes in the process of "ethnic cleansing," are more apt to want to reunify the country -- under a Muslim-led Government.
In the vision of the Dayton peace pact, Bosnia was by now supposed to be a place where refugees could go back to destroyed homes, where a Muslim or a Serb or a Croat could travel freely and where there was freedom to express divergent political views. That Bosnia has not emerged, but under pressure from the United States and European nations -- anxious to bring their military involvement to a quick end -- the elections are proceeding anyway.
The country remains divided in three ethnic enclaves.
The Bosnian Croats, despite the fiction of a federation with the Muslims, carry Croatian passports, use Croatian currency and continue to expel Muslims from the swath of territory they control in the southwest.
The Muslims have refused to allow tens of thousands of Serbs who fled Sarajevo during the war to return to their homes, saying the apartments now belong to the Muslim squatters who took them over.
And the Bosnian Serbs continue to beat and stone small groups of Muslims who try to come back to visit former homes and the graves of their relatives.
Trnovo saw as much of the war as any village in Bosnia: most buildings lack roofs, windows and four complete walls; the main street is pock-marked with huge craters left by artillery shells; its three small factories are blackened hulks. The town changed hands four times during the fighting, before being taken in 1993 by the Bosnian Serbs.
Most of the 1,800 people who still live here are elderly; all of them are Serbs, and many were driven out of Muslim towns.
Trnovo lies inside the demilitarized zone of separation that cuts across Bosnia. This small stretch of the border, known as the inter-ethnic boundary line, is patrolled by 140 French soldiers who are part of the 53,000-member NATO-led peacekeeping force.
Seated in the soldier's mess hall, in the scarred remains of a small tourist hotel on the edge of town, the company commander, Capt. Jean-Philippe Leroux, poured himself a glass of red wine from a bottle adorned with the emblem of his battalion.
He has sent his soldiers to clean up the fetid piles of garbage in the center of town and to help fix a few lathes at the local textile factory, which went bankrupt before the war, and to repair a few street lights. A German charity repaired the kindergarten and a Japanese group gave some supplies to the clinic, but otherwise Trnovo remains as desolate as when he arrived last spring.
"Trnovo's fate depends on what happens in Bosnia," he said. "It will either be a key crossing point for Bosnian Muslims and Serbs who work together, or a wasteland located on the edge of a hostile border."
At the edge of town is a stretch of a three-mile-wide corridor that is being built by NATO troops to link Sarajevo to the Muslim enclave of Gorazde. Trnovo county, between the border and the corridor, is sliced into a crazy patchwork of Serb and Muslim territory. Fields are cut down the middle, with neither side willing, yet, to cultivate land held by an opposing ethnic group.
French soldiers, wearing flak jackets and carrying heavy assault rifles, are at each crossing, stationed behind sand bags and protected by armored personnel carriers.
Tension remains high.
On Sept. 6 a car with four Serbs from Trnovo drove too far down the road, crossing into Muslim-held territory. The vehicle was sprayed with automatic fire by men on the Muslim side in civilian clothes. An elderly woman and young girl, wounded and left behind on the blood-soaked seats, are still in the hospital. The two men traveling with them, also shot, have disappeared.
The ambush took place 100 feet from a French checkpoint. But as with so much that happens here, no one seems to be able to say who carried out the attack, why it took place or what happened to the missing men.
"Can war ever really end in a country where every man has an AK-47 assault rifle and a thousand rounds of ammunition?" Captain Leroux asked. "Our presence has prevented a lot of bloodshed."
Many Bosnians, like Palestinians in the Gaza Strip, thought the peace agreement would be accompanied by large injections of international aid to rebuild the country and jump-start the economy. But while the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and private relief groups still hand out flour and cooking oil, the country's factories lie broken and idle. Bridges remain down, and electricity and sewage often does not function especially outside the cities. And foreign investors like Volkswagen, which once had a large plant in Sarajevo, have come, taken a look and left.
On the edge of Trnovo, 15 men gather each morning in a gear-box factory where they have spent their own money and labor to patch up the holes in the roof and walls. The men, once part of a work force of 150, laboriously scrape the rust off parts of old gear boxes that have lain for four years in a warehouse. They sell the reconditioned parts locally.
"The government in Pale owns the factory now," one frustrated worker said, referring to the capital of the Bosnian Serb republic, "and it is only interested in trying to sell off the machines or the building for some cash."
"We used to make parts for Mercedes-Benz before the war, and we contacted the company in Germany, but they said investment in Bosnia in this political climate was out of the question," the worker said. "We are not very optimistic."
Although unity would mean the possibility of economic cooperation, it is hard to find many Bosnians ready to accept the return of neighbors who fought against them. Many know the names of those who killed their family members.
Milena Vitkovic, a 39-year-old mother of four, lived in the mountain hamlet of Ledici, seven miles west of Trnovo, at the start of the war. The village had only Serbs. The surrounding villages had only Muslims. This was the usual pattern in the Bosnian countryside, and only in the large urban centers like Sarajevo, Mostar and Banja Luka did the ethnic groups mix.
Shortly after the war started, on June 9, 1992, Muslims from the surrounding villages attacked Ledici, Serbs here say. The 83 Serbs in the hamlet fled into the pine forests on the slopes of the mountains above the town. In the woods 10 people from Mrs. Vitkovic's family, including her mother, her two brothers and nephews as young as one, were shot down, according to a 12-year-old nephew who was wounded and survived.
Mrs. Vitkovic pulled worn black-and-white photos from a plastic bag and dabbed her eyes as she haltingly introduced her dead relatives. Her 6-year-old son sat in a corner of the small apartment watching his mother and repeatedly pulling the trigger on the handle of a white plastic toy pistol.
"I want no one, not even a Muslim, to feel what I feel," she said, "but I never want to see Muslims again, even in my dreams. I want to go back one last time to find the remains of my family and give them a proper burial, that is all I ask from the Muslims now."
Ledici is a ruin, a forlorn collection of roofless houses taken over by high grass, saplings, rusting kitchen appliances and trash.
But in the neighboring Muslim village of Dujmovici, just two miles away, men were using plastic tarpaulins and crude planks to rebuild destroyed houses.
When the men in Dujmovici were read the names of Mrs. Vitkovic's family, they acknowledged that they knew them, that for years they had traded cheese and eggs with them, drunk homemade brandy with them, counted them as friends. They also said those on the list had disappeared, but they insisted they did not know where they had gone.
"They did not die in Ledici," said a 45-year-old man in black rubber boots who was rebuilding a home burned by the Serbs during the war. He would not give his name.
"Maybe they died in the hills," he said. "A lot of people died in the hills. But this is over. Muslims and Serbs will not live again together again. There are things outsiders should never know."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;
By Fits and Starts, Dole Explains His Tax Cut

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Sept. 13

 BODY:
Bob Dole tried three times today to give a new and simpler explanation of his economic plan, but it did not prove to be easy.
The first time, at a small manufacturing plant in Ohio, Mr. Dole, the Republican Presidential nominee, gave a rambling explanation that mixed up some numbers. That led his spokesman, Nelson Warfield, to tell reporters that Mr. Dole would give a "more concise" version of the plan at the next stop, in Michigan. 
 But at that stop, he was speaking in a huge airport hangar with lousy acoustics, and it was so hard to hear what he was saying that the boisterous audience of about 2,000 people was easily distracted. Even Gov. John Engler of Michigan and Jack Kemp, Mr. Dole's running mate, who were seated on stage with the nominee, chatted with each other throughout the speech. Mr. Dole was virtually shouting to be heard, then skipped three paragraphs of the explanation that was in his prepared text.
Here in Illinois, he offered it up a third time, Mr. Warfield said, "because he didn't get all the way through it last time." This time, standing on a platform with bales of hay in the middle of a soybean field, he stuck to the script.
Mr. Dole was trying to illustrate how the Federal Government could cut taxes and still balance the budget by shaving just five cents from every dollar the government spends.
So at each event, he depended on a new prop -- the lowly nickel -- to show how small his cuts in the Federal budget would be. As if to show how puny an amount he was talking about, he would ask someone in the crowd to part with a nickel, to help him make his point..
Earlier this week, Mr. Dole said it would only be six cents out of every dollar that would need to be trimmed. In Ohio and Michigan, it was five cents. By the time he reached Illinois, it was down to "less than five cents."
The Dole campaign is encouraged by a new survey showing that voters rank taxes as the number-one issue in the Presidential campaign. In that survey, by the Pew Research Center in Washington, taxes edged out health care, welfare reform, crime and drugs.
Still, other surveys show that most voters are skeptical that Mr. Dole can actually do what he promises: cut taxes over six years and balance the budget without cutting Medicare or Social Security.
Mr. Dole is banking on his economic plan to help him close President Clinton's huge lead in national polls. As part of that effort, Mr. Dole, the former Senate majority leader, has been repeating the plan everywhere.
Today, his first explanation came in response to a woman in Wauseon, Ohio, who asked him how he could cut taxes, balance the budget and not touch entitlement programs like Medicare and Social Security.
First he told her, "You're right, sooner or later, you've got to put entitlements on the table." But in his plan, he said, they would be "off the table." He said he preferred appointing a commission to consider the issue to take it "out of politics." Later, at the airport hangar in Saginaw, Mich., he brought in an element he had neglected to mention in Ohio that is central to the plan. "We just have to slow the rate of increase in Federal spending," he said.
He added: "We need only $576 billion in spending control. Two-thirds of it, or $393 billion, is in the budget resolution already passed by Congress."
But that resolution was never enacted because many of its proposed cuts and curtailments in spending were politically unpalatable.
Beyond that, Mr. Dole assumes that there will be no recession, and he is counting on the economy to grow at a rate that many economists believe to be extraordinarily high.
The Dole campaign has specified few cuts that would be necessary, above and beyond the sort of severe proposals suggested last year by the Republican-controlled Congress. Robert D. Reischauer, the former director of the Congressional Budget Office and now an analyst at the Brookings Institution, said by telephone from Washington that most voters were not asking how the billions of dollars would be shifted around. They want to know whether it is plausible "to be handing out a tax cut that is one and a half times larger than the one offered in the Contract With America, which the Republicans themselves decided was unaffordable," Mr. Reischauer said.
