HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REFORM PARTY;
Relgious Right Delivers Perot Cool Response At Convention

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 13

 BODY:
Ross Perot stepped into an unfamiliar pulpit today at the Christian Coalition's convention here and found himself preaching to the unconverted, many of whom did not like his sermon.
The opening line of one of Mr. Perot's favorite 1992 anecdotes -- "In this audience, I am sure there are many people who honestly believe that I elected Bill Clinton in 1992" -- backfired when hundreds of delegates signaled their agreement with that nugget of conventional wisdom by jeering, whistling and giving Mr. Perot his most sustained and vigorous round of applause. 
 When the clapping in hotel ballroom of the Washington Hilton subsided, Mr. Perot, the Reform Party Presidential candidate, tried to recover his rhetorical footing, saying, "That's why I brought it up: to get that reaction."
He then forged ahead with his standard anecdote. He said surveys of voters leaving polling places in 1992 showed that his Presidential bid that year had drawn equally from Mr. Clinton and President George Bush. Mr. Perot then made his main point: Had Americans voted their conscience in 1992, he would have won 40 percent of the vote, with Mr. Clinton receiving 31 percent and President Bush 27 percent.
The delegates' initial reaction to Mr. Perot's opening line foreshadowed how many delegates assessed his overall speech. As members of an influential Republican Party lobby that opposes abortion and favors school prayer, they generally gave it low marks at their annual gathering.
"He wasn't well received," said Armstrong Williams, a conservative radio talk-show host in Washington. "We were psyched, but he didn't give us anything."
Mr. Williams said Mr. Perot had erred in not presenting his views on abortion, school prayer and same-sex marriage. "He kept saying 'Just Listen,' " Mr. Williams said, trying to wag his finger Perot-style. "People don't know his core beliefs."
Yet throughout his speech, they tried to find out, periodically shouting, "What about abortion?" Mr. Perot declined to explain his position.
In the past, Mr. Perot has said abortion should be "a moral, personal issue between a woman and God." But he has insisted that such divisive social issues, while important, should not distract the nation from first solving major fiscal and economic challenges posed by the Federal debt and stagnant wages.
In addition to sketching out his other standard positions -- like raising the ethical and moral climate in Washington, improving schools and ending poll-driven political campaigns -- Mr. Perot delivered his version of a family values speech.
Bemoaning the effects of crime on America's schools and neighborhoods, he said: "Our moral, ethical base is eroding. We should admit it and stop sleepwalking."
Signaling his support for the traditional family, Mr. Perot said: "The most efficient unit of government the world has ever known is one we forgot, never even gets brought up. You'd think they'd be looking for it with the problems we have. Watch my lips. It's the strong family unit, the most efficient unit of government in the world."
Mr. Perot, whose standing in many polls has been hovering at 5 percent to 8 percent, devoted much of his speech to child development, including his summary of a baby's brain development and the link between nurturing parents and an infant's intellectual development and ability to learn in school.
The topic, which Mr. Perot uses to demonstrate his commitment to improving public schools, especially for poor children, seemed to annoy some delegates, prompting several to call out and urge him to spell out his stand on abortion.
Laura Erpelding, a delegate from Michigan, said she liked Mr. Perot's emphasis on improving secondary education but was skeptical about his commitment to family values.
"I have a problem when he talks about family values because he and his wife were involved with Planned Parenthood in Texas," Mrs. Erpel ding said after the speech. "Planned Parenthood to me equals abortion, which doesn't equal family values."
Mrs. Erpelding attributed what she termed Mr. Perot's "cool" reception at the convention to the abortion issue. "This is a pro-life audience," she said. "He can't expect adulation from this crowd."
Larry Dubbs Jr., a council member from Pine Grove, Pa., said he admired Mr. Perot's grasp of financial issues and statistics.
"He knows a lot about financial issues," Mr. Dubbs said. "But the general consensus of the coalition seemed to disagree with his ideas, because we believe our problems are more moral than financial."
Turning to the November elections, Ralph Reed, the executive director of the Christian Coalition, said his organization would carry out a national drive to try to register one million religious conservatives as new voters.
Mr. Reed announced the plan in a speech to the convention after strongly criticizing a lawsuit filed against the organization by the Federal Election Commission. The commission has argued that the organization violated its nonpartisan, tax-exempt status by supporting individual candidates in its voter guides.
"We will not be harassed, we will not be intimidated and we will not be silenced," Mr. Reed said.

HEADLINE: RESURGENT STOCKS HIT RECORD HIGHS ON LOW INFLATION

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The stock market surged to record highs yesterday, continuing one of the greatest bull markets in history and erasing a midsummer downturn that only recently had many analysts predicting the end of good times on Wall Street.
The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 1.2 percent, to 5,838.52 points, eclipsing its record close of 5,778 of May 22. The broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks climbed 1.4 percent, to 680.54, breaking the record of 678.51 on May 24. The bond market also rallied, as long-term interest rates fell below 7 percent to 6.95. 
 The spark for the rally -- as has been the case for most big market moves this year -- was economic news that caught investors by surprise and changed their short-term outlook.
Yesterday's triggers were reports that last month's retail sales were weak, which suggested that the economy might be slowing more than thought, and that consumer prices rose only slightly, indicating that inflation was still in check. [Page 31.]
Just days ago, many analysts were predicting confidently that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates later this month to help brake an economy that appeared to be racing over its speed limit. But the new information indicated that the Federal Reserve might wait before making a move, which allowed interest rates to fall and the market to rally, led by technology stocks like I.B.M., Microsoftand Intel.
For individual investors who have been pouring billions of dollars into stock mutual funds, the outlook may not be as certain as yesterday's rally. Views of the likelihood of an interest rate increase engineered by the Federal Reserve have shifted at least three times in just the last two weeks. Indeed, while the consensus now leans toward the belief that the Federal Reserve will leave short-term rates where they are, there is still a chance that it will raise rates at its next policy-setting meeting on Sept. 24, or perhaps later this year when the Presidential election is out of the way.
Moreover, even as the Dow hit a record high, long-term interest rates -- which have had a major impact on the stock market recently -- do not appear to be headed sharply lower. They are well above where they were at the beginning of the year and could move up again on stronger economic news.
Even more remarkable yesterday than the stock market records was the sight of economists, market analysts, traders, speculators and investors scrambling as the outlook for both stocks and bonds turned in a new direction yet again.
The day was toughest on the bears, those equity strategists who have been saying that the high-flying stock market had to be headed for a fall. "It's not very comfortable," said Michael Metz, chief investment strategist at Oppenheimer & Company. "It's a humbling business and occasionally humiliating."
Byron R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company, has predicted a 1,000-point decline in the Dow. Yesterday he lamented, "I haven't changed my position but this has not turned out as I thought."
Economic forecasters were also caught off guard. John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, was fielding questions from London. "We got this one wrong," he said. For Mr. Lipsky, the most important news in the report was not just that retail sales were weak last month, but that the Government also revised downward its earlier estimates of monthly sales of everything but automobiles for both June and July. He now may lower his forecast for growth in the third quarter.
"It is possible we could end up with 2 percent or less," he said, adding that this was a pace that "could remove the near-term incentive for the Fed to raise interest rates."
What is causing all the recent wild swings in stocks and bonds, analysts said, is the difficulty of figuring out whether each new economic report indicates that the economy is slowing enough to persuade the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates steady. "Today's data, with the backward revision in retail sales, raise the issue of whether this slowdown has happened already." Mr. Lipsky said. But he said he did not believe the question was decided yet.
Just as the uncertainty over whether the economy is growing at just the right pace is expected to continue, so will the dispute between those with a cautious outlook and the real bulls. And it does not appear yet that the new stock records have changed many minds.
Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Smith Barney, called the record-breaking performance a "high-quality breakout that suggests there should be some follow-on."
But he cautioned that earnings, one of the most important underpinnings for stocks, might disappoint investors, weakening the case for a continuing rally. Earnings gains have already slowed from a 20 percent pace to 10 percent or less this year.
"We are moving into a period where you have to show me more top-line growth in earnings," he said, "and that is going to be hard to do."
But a bull like Alfred Goldman, director of market analysis at A. G. Edwards Inc. in St. Louis, had no patience for such uncertainties. "The bears say, 'It is as good as it can get, so where do we go from here?' " he said. "I say it is as good as it can get and I think it can get better."
The 66.58-point rise in the Dow and the 9.41-point climb in the S.& P. 500 index were helped by rallies in technology stocks, which were among those hardest hit during the summer.
"The animal spirits in the market are linked to the technology stocks," said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist and an equity portfolio manager at the Dreyfus Corporation.
I.B.M. jumped 4 7/8, to 122 1/8, as it was upgraded by Merrill Lynch & Company, and Microsoft rose 2 3/8, to 131, its second new high of the week. The Nasdaq index, which includes many technology stocks, outperformed the Dow yesterday, jumping just under 2 percent. And the Pacific Stock Exchange technology index climbed 2.7 percent.
Big institutional buyers also returned to the market, providing an additional shot in the arm.
Laszlo Birinyi of Birinyi Associates in Greenwich, Conn., said that his calculations for trades on the New York Stock Exchange showed that the net purchases of shares in block trades of at least 10,000 shares -- the hallmark of institutions -- totaled $1.1 billion yesterday. That was more than the institutions put into the market during the period from Aug. 1 through Thursday.
"The public has been buying all along," he said, "and today, with the economic news, instititutions could no longer not participate."
The price of the 30-year bond jumped 117/32 , to 9717/32 , as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, dropped to 6.95 percent, from 7.07 percent on Thursday.
Shorter-term interest rates also fell. That reflected a belief that even if the Federal Reserve increased rates, the rise would be at best only a modest quarter percentage point.
Despite his view that a rate increase was not needed, Jack Ablin, director of fixed income and senior fund manager at the Private Bank of the Bank of Boston, said he suspected that the central bankers probably would do so anyway because of the split in opinion among Fed officials over just how strong the economy currently is.
"I think the Fed is concerned," he said, "about the looming minimum- wage hike and its implied impact on future inflation pressures."

HEADLINE: City Prohibits Borrowing By Improvement Districts

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration restricted the power of the city's business improvement districts yesterday for the first time, announcing that it would prohibit them from borrowing money to pay for big projects.
The administration moved after concluding that it did not have enough control over the finances of the districts, said senior aides to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. They said they believed that if one of the districts defaulted on its debt, the city might be held responsible. 
 Under the new policy, the districts would not be able to borrow money by selling bonds or even by getting a loan from a bank, said Rudy Washington, the Deputy Mayor for Community Development and Business Services.
Since they were authorized in the early 1980's, more than 30 business improvement districts have been set up in the city. Their influence has increased in recent years as they have taken over some services, like sanitation and security, from a municipal government that has been facing serious fiscal problems.
The districts levy special taxes on property owners and use the proceeds for a variety of activities, from picking up garbage to promoting the local sights. Yet as they have grown, some critics have said they have become too independent and are not accountable to the public.
Until yesterday, the districts were able to borrow money after receiving approval from the city. Two of the most prominent districts, the Grand Central Partnership and the 34th Street Partnership in Manhattan, have sold a total of $56.5 million in bonds in recent years to finance a range of improvements in their neighborhoods, including new benches, lights and signs.
As part of the new policy, the city yesterday denied the Grand Central Partnership's request to sell $10.7 million in bonds to help the Metropolitan Transportation Authority renovate Grand Central Terminal.
Daniel A. Biederman, president of the Grand Central and the 34th Street districts, did not respond to messages seeking comment.
Another district, the Alliance for Downtown New York, which is in lower Manhattan, had been planning to ask the city for approval to sell $20 million in bonds for projects. Its president, Carl Weisbrod, said he was disappointed by the administration's decision.
"However, in view of the importance to the entire city of the type of public improvements contemplated for downtown, we look forward to working with the administration to develop other ways to get the job done quickly," Mr. Weisbrod said.
City officials had said last week that the Mayor was considering limiting or ending the districts' power to sell bonds. Mr. Washington and Deputy Mayor Fran Reiter, who oversees economic development, said yesterday that the administration agreed on the new policy after concluding that the districts were getting involved in financial dealings that were best left to government.
"The purpose of BID's was not to act like government and then start running up debt," Mr. Washington said. "That is completely getting away from the core mission of what a business improvement district is."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
HAYES MICROCOMPUTER TO CLOSE A CALIFORNIA PLANT

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Hayes Microcomputer Products Inc., a closely held modem maker that recently emerged from a Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization, said yesterday that it would close its manufacturing plant in Thousand Oaks, Calif. The move will put 350 to 375 people out of work. The company said it was consolidating its domestic production operations at its headquarters in Norcross, Ga., a suburb of Atlanta. An engineering group and multimedia products unit will remain at Thousand Oaks. Hayes will take a one-time charge in the fourth quarter of $6.5 million to pay for the plant closing.

HEADLINE: ON LANGUAGE;
As We Know It

BYLINE: By William Safire 

 BODY:
"ENDING THE I.R.S. as we know it" was a centerpiece of Bob Dole's economic plan, later driven home in his acceptance address with "You will have a President who will end the I.R.S. as we know it."
This was, of course, a play on Bill Clinton's pledge, made in his 1992 acceptance speech and carried out as his re-election campaign began in 1996, to "end welfare as we know it,"and repeated mockingly by Republicans in Congress as he vetoed their first two efforts to pass welfare-reform legislation. 
 "Many people heard only the first two words: end welfare," wrote Jason DeParle in The New York Times Magazine about that '92 promise, "but Mr. Clinton was mindful of the as-we-know-it qualifier. He was talking about new training programs, expanded child care, universal health care."
The earliest use I can find applying the qualifier as we know it (AWKI) specifically to welfare was by David Stockman, before his term as the frequently woodshedded Reagan budget chief, in 1978: "Welfare as we know it should be abolished," he asserted in an article for an economics journal, "for all but the nonworking -- the aged, blind and disabled -- whose eligibility can be ascertained by reference to physical characteristics."
We have come to know as we know it all too well. In "Independence Day" (the movie blowing up the White House, not the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel about a real-estate salesman's rites of passage), a computer expert persuaded a fictional U.S. President not to employ nuclear missiles against the Martian spaceships hovering over Earth, warning that it would mean "the end of life as we now know it." The rock group R.E.M. (the initials stand for "rapid eye movements" that take place in sleep) recorded a song in 1987 titled "It's the End of the World As We Know It (And I Feel Fine)."
AWKI originally meant "as it is understood today," then was used as an intensifier, then (in Mr. Clinton's case) as a qualifier and often -- as it gained cliche status -- as a self-mocking dramatizer.
What was it before we knew it? In tracking back the source, before welfare, life and the world came civilization. Elizabeth Knowles of Oxford University Press cites Orson Welles, in his 1941 "Citizen Kane," proclaiming: "I've talked with the responsible leaders of the Great Powers. . . . They're too intelligent to embark on a project which would mean the end of civilization as we now know it."
The screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz popularized, if he did not coin, that use of the phrase. More than half a century later, it is used with a tongue-in-cheek connotation: reviewing a $24-dreadful thriller, "Triangle of Death," by Michael Levine and Laura Kavanau, in a recent New York Times Book Review, Colin Harrison refers to a fictional genetically engineered drug that simulates a 20-minute orgasm and wryly notes, "Such a drug would no doubt imperil morally upright civilization as we know it."
The hawkshaws of the Phrasedick Brigade led me to an early etymological source.
When I queried the American Dialect Society's bulletin board on the Internet (send queries to adsl@uga.cc.uga.edu, and subscription inquiries to listserv@uga.cc.uga.edu), a writer on gardening, Duane Campbell, dug up and sent back a citation from Oscar Wilde's essay "The Decay of Lying," in his 1891 book, "Intentions," in which a character says, "The 19th century, as we know it, is largely an invention of Balzac." (You didn't think this laid-back language maven was hip enough to use this resource? You thought I was computer-illiterate? Better not nuke them Martians, Mr. President.)
Pretty soon the cliche will wear out, phrase makers will turn to fresher material and that happy day will spell the end of as we know it as we know it.
 
Arklatex Nugget

 The Whitewater case is producing locutions as well as prosecutions. Joe Pinder of Washington sends along an article from The Washington Times, filed from Little Rock, Ark., by Hugh Aynesworth. In it, the assistant independent counsel, Jackie M. Bennett, asked an investment partner of Jim Guy Tucker, then Governor of Arkansas, "Would it be fair to say that Governor Tucker kind of rolled your pant leg up on that one, didn't he?" The witness, R. D. Randolph, glumly replied, "I came out on the short end of the stick."
The short end of the stick, which first appeared in print in the mid-1800's, refers to the old custom of fighting with sticks or staffs; whoever holds the short end is at a disadvantage. Less familiar is rolled up your pant leg, which, according to Aynesworth, means "saw what you had, looked at your hand -- it's Arklatexan, colloquial for this area, meaning 'took advantage of.' "
He referred me to Guy Bailey, a native of Oklahoma, now dean of liberal arts at the University of Nevada at Las Vegas, familiar with idioms of Oklahoma and the Arklatex region (southwestern Arkansas, northwestern Louisiana and northeastern Texas). Dean Bailey directed me to the song "Deep Elm Blues" (the elm is pronounced ELL-um), recorded by the Shelton Brothers, from northern Louisiana, in the early 1930's.
"When Dallas was becoming the first urban community of the Southwest in the late 20's," says Dean Bailey, "folks were drawn there to have a good time. The song alerted them to the evils of the big city and advised them to protect themselves while there. It warned them of what could happen to careless country people."
The telltale lyric: "Now when you go down in Deep Elm, put your money in your socks/Or the women in Deep Elm, well, they'll put you on the rocks."
And how do you get the money out of the poor innocent's socks? First you roll up his pant leg.
Delicious dialectical discovery. Who says Whitewater is a waste of taxpayers' money?

SECTION: Section 5; Page 6; Column 1; Travel Desk 

LENGTH: 2550 words

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
The Oregon Trail, by Rail

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO 

 BODY:
IF you're looking for train memorabilia, however arcane, you can find it at Grandpa's Depot Store, on the second floor of the Oxford Hotel annex in Denver, across Wynkoop Street from Union Station. There, amid antique railroad lanterns, Union Pacific martini sets and matchbooks from the old Rio Grande line, you can also find Grandpa John White, who's spent a lifetime watching trains come and go. When I met him on a hot afternoon in late July and told him of my plan to ride Amtrak's Pioneer train all the way from Denver to Portland, Ore., he said, in perfect deadpan, "The Government runs it, you know. They don't have a timetable anymore. They just post the day the train's expected."
I had a timetable, though -- along with an itinerary sent to me by Amtrak's Great American Vacations, a book on the Lewis and Clark Expedition ("Undaunted Courage" by Stephen Ambrose) and expectations for the trip almost as high as those of Meriwether Lewis when he paddled into the Missouri River on May 21, 1804. The train's route touches that of Lewis and Clark along the Columbia River, and follows portions of the Oregon Trail, as well -- you could call it Manifest Destiny on wheels. In Wyoming it passes south of pioneer landmarks like Devil's Gate and Independence Rock to join up with the wagon trains around Boise, Idaho; it follows and then leaves the Snake River behind where the settlers did, at Farewell Bend in eastern Oregon, provides bracing views of Mount Hood and the gorge of the Columbia River (the pioneers' two last great hurdles), and finally glides into the promised land of the Willamette Valley. 
 Riding the train west also struck me as a decidedly good deal. I bought an air and rail package for $416, which included coach-class train fare with three stopovers en route, trip protection insurance allowing me to make last-minute itinerary changes, and a plane ticket on United from Portland back to Denver; this month, the price for the same package has dropped to $332. If I had taken the train from Denver to Portland with no stops and no return airline ticket, the one-way fare would have been $194 in coach; if I had booked an economy bedroom (with two seats and sleeping bunks, a shower down the corridor, and three meals a day) the air-rail package would have cost $574.
The journey required intense planning, chiefly because the Pioneer doesn't run daily but only three times a week, stopping in a number of cities at ungodly hours, such as Boise at 4:24 A.M. Also, I wanted to find places to stay in my stopover cities as close as possible to the depots and downtowns, since the idea of renting a car when I got off the train seemed anachronistic. I planned one night in Denver, two nights in Laramie, an overnight on the train from Laramie to Boise, a week in the Sawtooth Mountains of Idaho, followed by three nights in Boise and a two-night visit to Baker City, Ore. The last leg of the trip would take me to Portland, where I would stay for two nights before flying back to Denver.
In Denver I had booked a $95 room with no view at the Oxford Hotel, built in 1891 largely for train staff and passengers; that is much more than I normally pay for a room, but the Oxford is in LoDo, my favorite section of Denver, half a block east of Union Station, where a red neon sign exhorts passers-by to "Travel by Train." My room on the fourth floor was all deep blue Art Deco, with fancy toiletries, a plump double bed and a full range of cable channels -- although I never bothered to watch because the Rockies were playing my hometown team, the Mets, that night at Coors Field, which opened last year, just four blocks north of the hotel.
It seemed ironic that Coors Field should be surrounded by microbreweries like Breckenridge on Blake Street, where I had an Avalanche Ale for $3.25 a pint before lining up for a $4 seat out in home run heaven beyond center field. This would have been a nice economizing measure were it not for the high price of dinner at the ballpark, consisting of a hot dog, peanuts and a beer for $9.25. On top of that, the Rockies homered three times in the first inning, going on to beat the Mets 11-10.
The next morning the lofty neo-classical main waiting room of Union Station, built in 1914, was busy enough to recall the days when the depot saw as many as 80 departures a day. I checked two bags, and sat on one of the station's high-backed wooden benches as the bilevel Superliner that had just arrived from Chicago was divided into two parts. One, the California Zephyr, headed to Oakland via the Great Salt Lake (taking the window-encased sightseeing lounge with it, alas). The other, the Pioneer, carried mail in the front cars, followed by first-class sleepers, the dining car, several coach cars (with toilets on the lower level that were relatively clean, at first), and a cafe-lounge where seniors played Yahtzee, European backpackers consulted travel guides, and teen-agers mixed.
The attendant gave me a pillow and I bought an Amtrak blanket for $7 (in preparation for my overnight onboard); my seat was roomy, next to that of a nice dad who had spent just $800 to take his family of five on the train from Portland to Chicago and back. As the Pioneer crossed the rolling plains of northern Colorado I spotted antelope and a herd of buffalo out the window.
I lunched on a Cheyenne Burger and hot tea in the dining car for $7 (which tasted better than the cafe lunch of juice, pretzels, and a tuna sandwich that I bought later in the trip for the same amount). The decor reminded me of a slightly upscale coffee shop and the food was palatable enough, but the atmosphere was rushed (I eventually discovered that you can stay as long as you like if you reserve a place at the last seating). Afterward, my tablemates, a mother and daughter from Seattle, showed me their economy bedroom, a tiny compartment with two knee-to-knee seats that could be made into a bunk, and another bunk that pulled out from the wall above, in which they claim to have slept soundly through the night. Down the hall I peeked into bigger, deluxe sleepers with convertible sofas, armchairs and private baths just before the train pulled into Laramie, about four hours after we left Denver (making it 45 minutes late).
The little wooden Laramie depot, built in 1923, lay in the middle of a narrow park and was managed by a good-natured stationmaster who kept one of my bags behind the counter during my stay in town and could sometimes be seen riding a skateboard in the waiting room. Wide Third Street led from there through the tidy Victorian storefronts of the business district six blocks north to the Downtown Motel, distinguished by a huge satellite dish; my $53 room on the first floor of the back wing had a king-sized bed, a parking lot view, and enough floor space to easily accommodate the bicycle I rented from Use It Again Sports on South Second Street ($30 for two days).
Low-slung Laramie occupies the broad, flat corridor between the Snowy and Laramie Mountains. It grew up when the Union Pacific railroad came through in 1868, but owes its long-term well-being to the University of Wyoming, with a student body of 12,000, which constitutes a third of the population. When I was there, the town had settled in for a long midsummer nap, but I still found entertainment, like an excellent exhibition called "The Buffalo in Art and Culture" at the university's art museum ($3.50); rummaging through dinosaur bones at the university's wonderful, old-fashioned Geology Museum (free); visiting the Wyoming Territorial Prison ($6), where the walls bear unnerving, enlarged mug shots of the outlaws who did time there between 1875 and 1903; dining on stir-fried chicken and vegetables for $4.95 at a convivial restaurant downtown called Jeffrey's, and sampling a glass of Fat Tire beer ($1.25) at the Buckhorn Bar, where the walls groan with moth-eaten, taxidermically preserved beasts.
Two days later, the Pioneer came through town an hour and a half late, carrying 23 Boy Scouts with water pistols, two screaming babies, a couple of astonishingly loud snorers even my earplugs couldn't drown out, and a visibly weary staff -- when I asked a passing attendant where we were at one point during the night, she said, "Don't ask me. I just got up."I learned from an assistant conductor that rides on the Pioneer are far more pacific in September, after the kids go back to school. For now, I was thankful that Amtrak had banned smoking on the train, and happy to vegetate as the sagebrush desert of southern Wyoming rolled by. But I hardly slept, so when the Pioneer reached Boise's beautiful Spanish colonial depot at about 5:30 A.M., I felt like a piece of lost baggage.
My condition improved markedly after a week in the Sawtooths and three nights in Boise at a comfortable bed and breakfast called the Idaho Heritage Inn, built in 1904. There my room in the rear had an antique double bed and a small private bath and access to a veranda, ($60 a night, including a delicious hot breakfast). I saw "Twelfth Night" at the Idaho Shakespeare Festival ($15) and learned about the lives of Basque immigrants who came to the city in the late 19th century, at the Basque Museum ($3) before sampling Basque croquetas and potato and chorizo soup (about $7 with a drink) at the Bar Gernika next door. After strolling along the beautiful green belt that lines the Boise River, I toured the Old Idaho Pennitentiary off Warm Springs Avenue ($3), where I learned how to turn a spoon into a shank. Finally, at 4:24 A.M. I caught the train to Baker City, which arrived right on time.
A FTER a two-and-a-half-hour-hour ride, we arrived in Baker City, a little southeastern Oregon town in a high valley between the Blue and Wallowa Mountains that looks like a set for "The Music Man." When pioneers saw Baker City during the Great Migration (which took a half million settlers west on the Oregon Trail between 1840 and 1870), they felt they were at long last getting somewhere. I went there to see the Oregon Trail Interpretive Center (free), on Flagstaff Hill about five miles east of town, with daily re-enactments from settlers' journals, exhibits and life-sized dioramas on prairie schooner life so detailed they include a fly in an ox's eye. A rutted section of the trail itself is about a mile down the hill.
A free shuttle from the Best Western Sunridge Inn took me to the Interpretive Center, and to and from the depot, as well. The shuttle was why I had chosen the motel at the edge of town, with big, two-bedded doubles, a hot tub, and a pool, for $53 a night. On my last night I celebrated with a New York steak and two glasses of merlot for about $25 at the Phone Company Restaurant, in an historic building downtown.
The next morning, the Pioneer was two and a half hours late (and only got later as it chugged along the Columbia River to Portland, because the temperature was over 100 degrees, preventing the train from going more than 50 miles an hour).Waiting at Baker City, I got to talking with a conductor who explained some of the other reasons for the Pioneer's habitual tardiness, including the fact that it often has to wait for passing freight trains. And then, almost as an afterthought, he told me that Amtrak had just announced the cancellation of the Pioneer as of Nov. 10, apparently owing to a sharp drop in riders (especially in winter), and to anemic financing from Congress. Two other Western lines -- the Texas Eagle from St. Louis to San Antonio and the Desert Wind from Salt Lake City to Los Angeles -- had been terminated as well.
I was stunned, and not even the beautiful scenery along the Columbia River could break my mood, which lingered during two busy days in Portland. I stayed in a well-equipped $65 basement room at General Hooker's Bed and Breakfast on the southwest side of town and visited the sprawling Powell's City of Books and an exhibit of Chinese Imperial artifacts at the Portland Art Museum ($13). But all the while I kept thinking about the Pioneer.
Certainly, most people choose to travel by air because they don't have time, or patience, to take the train. But on the Pioneer, which was packed every time I boarded it, I had met fellow passengers with a whole host of reasons for preferring the train, including fear of flying, the relatively low cost of tickets and the desire to see the countryside close-up. Despite the inconveniences and delays , I would like to travel by long-distance train again myself, because the tracks take me back to some of the most stirring moments in America's past. Maybe I'll try the Empire Builder, which follows a northern route from Chicago to Seattle, or the Southwest Chief from Los Angeles to Chicago via Santa Fe. But I won't be taking the Pioneer again. That line is history now.
 
 The bottom line on a rail trip
Transport

But for details on air-rail and other special packages, call Amtrak Great American Vacations, (800) 321-8684. My package cost $416; in late August I was quoted a price of $332 for the same package, in late September. I spent 11 days on my train trip, and an average of $91 daily, with $56 of that going toward accommodations.

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 17; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 946 words

HEADLINE: Bedford Seeks Retailers to Speed Growth

BYLINE: By ANNE C. FULLAM 

DATELINE: BEDFORD

 BODY:
BEING just another pretty-faced hamlet is not enough for Bedford. Her merchants want her to go out and earn. But has her time passed?
With a petite apron of a Village Green and a bib of white clapboard buildings, Bedford was last a commercial hub during the War of 1812. Clattering hooves and squeaking coaches resounded on Old Post Road, then the main thoroughfare between New York City and Albany. 
 The tiny, wavy-glassed shops grew dim once automobiles started to speed consumers away to newly opened malls. Bedford continued to sell her wares with some zest in the 1950's. But long before strip malls and megastores, cars left behind dusty dispirited stores.
Recently, Bedford got a face-lifting. Sidewalks were repaired, buildings painted and trees watered. Signs were aligned. Cosmetically, Bedford looks great. Now, the merchants want to feel a retail pulse.
"The charm of a hamlet is how it looks, but there's a need for economic viability," said John Dinin, Supervisor of the town of Bedford, which includes Bedford village, Bedford Hills and Katonah.
"They want to attract people who live in the area to shop in area hardware stores and other commercial stores for baked goods, clothing, things like that," Mr. Dinin said. "They want to promote a sense of a small community, not another strip mall."
Perhaps the most community-spirited establishment in the village is Stewart's Market, a friendly blend of grocery and delicatessen. Customers often sit outside, reading, eating or daydreaming.
"The village will die and become a museum unless something is done," said Jim Crookston, who opened Stewart's nearly 12 years ago. Mr. Crookston is president of the Bedford Village Business Association.
"Stores have moved out in the last 10 years because there's no parking," Mr. Crookston said. "People jump in their cars and go to the malls. Bedford won't stay such a pretty little village if everybody shops out of town."
Prodded by Mr. Crookston's business association, the Bedford Village Historic District Review Commission conducted a yearlong study of how to improve business profits. The commission's recommendations, besides additional parking, included relocating the nearly dozen real estate agencies on the main street from shopfronts to the second floor. Retailers, presumably, would move in.
All the real estate agents interviewed declined to talk about the review commission's recommendation on relocation.
Mark Boyland, a salesman at the Prudential-Ragette Realtors, whose comments were representative of other real estate agents, said, "I think any added business to the town is great."
Bedford's real estate offices are thriving, from estates sold to celebrities like Ralph Lauren and Mariah Carey to two-acre and four-acre subdivision houses sold to professionals. Property seems to be the hamlet's most valuable commodity.
"Get a drugstore in the town," said John P. Renwick Sr., a former president of the Bedford Historical Society and a local real-estate agent. "That's what we really need."
While Mr. Renwick talked nostalgicly about the soda fountain era, others yearned for small-town department stores, restaurants and hardware stores. Current regulations for the location of many kinds of businesses require more water, sewage, parking and other services than the village needed in the past.
Too busy with today to think about yesterday, Velda Greenan at Velda Design took a break from cutting cloth to dress patterns to offer her opinion of the plan.
"Rents are becoming so high that it's very hard for the small retailer," said Mrs. Greenan, who opened her business in 1984. Others agreed.
"The people who own the buildings are asking exorbitant amounts," Mr. Renwick said.
Despite its visual impact as a historic place, there are no efforts to commercialize the village's tourist appeal. The idea of making money out of history seems not to have been explored here. For example, there are no walking tours of the nearly two dozen historic buildings surrounding the village green. While dates are posted, no signs explain the historic significance of the buildings.
In 1973, the village was listed on the National Register of Historic Places and the state register. Bedford's three square miles were bought in 1680 by 22 men from Stamford, who paid Chief Katonah in blankets, cloth and wampum.
The village's triangular green was a hop ground, and the town seal honors that use with a wreath of hops. Bordered on one side by the old burying ground, the green's north side is a solid line of late 18th- and early 19th-century buildings. The southern edge is the 1928 granite St. Patrick Roman Catholic Church.
Originally part of the colony of Connecticut, Bedford became part of New York in 1700. Patriotic during the Revolutionary War, when most of Westchester was neutral, Bedford was burned by the British in 1779. Until 1870, Bedford was one of two county seats for Westchester. The other, less populous then, was White Plains.
Perhaps the most stirring event to occur in the village was a gathering in 1781 of Rochambeau's infantry and cavalry before they joined Washington's forces on the way to Yorktown.
"We need to extol the virtues of the village," said Dick Farrell, a representative of the town historian to the review commission. "We have a treasure of history, and it's not being packaged in an educational manner that would benefit not just outsiders but local adults and schoolchildren."
Mr. Farrell continued: "The problems of Bedford are endemic to the entire United States. Wonderful old towns everywhere are facing the same problems. The Walmarts and the Krogers are taking over."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 15; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2258 words

HEADLINE: FILM;
A Timely Tale, With Endings Unforewarned

BYLINE: By WILLIAM McDONALD 

 BODY:
TO THE MOVIEGOING PUBLIC he was just beginning to reach, Russ Hexter was an unknown. But he did not come out of nowhere. Here, then, are some salient facts about him.
He was a child of affluence from Westchester County's thickly bowered back country, where wealth is displayed tastefully and discreetly behind stately old hardwoods and ivy-covered brick walls. He was inventive as a boy, always making up stories, creating his own comic book heroes, playing long hours alone at his computer in his manorlike home. His quiet way might have been mistaken for shyness, but his mother understood him differently. To her he was simply observant, so much so that he developed a remarkable talent for mimicry that left his family and friends in stitches and that would one day lead to a short stint supplying characters with voices on the MTV animated series "The Head." 
 In high school he discovered the perfect instrument through which he could channel his restless enthusiasms: the movie camera. Before long, a teen-ager's fascination became a passion, and it carried him to New York University's film school, where he made short, funny features about the foibles of ordinary people in the kind of working-class small towns his own upbringing had largely insulated him from.
In the spring of 1994, he shot his first full-length movie about the collision of a fading factory town with the global computer economy. His home-grown film company was mostly made up of pals from N.Y.U., the financing gathered mostly from trust funds, relatives and family friends. After weeks of whittling 27 hours of film down to 90 minutes, the movie was shown at film festivals in Boston and Vancouver, British Columbia, and got admiring reviews in the local papers. Last January it climbed another rung on the ladder, earning a showing at the Sundance festival in Utah, where -- and Mr. Hexter marveled at this -- audiences applauded heartily.
The film's warm reception persuaded the powerful William Morris Agency to represent him. He began flying out to Los Angeles to meet with important people in the film industry. Diane Keaton talked to him about making movies with her production company. Discussions were also held with two major independent companies, Lumiere and Fine Line. On April 28 he was in sunny Los Angeles again for more talks. The horizon indeed looked bright.
The next morning he was back in New York, in his Greenwich Village apartment, chatting with a friend who had stopped by. Suddenly he clutched at his chest and fell to the floor, unconscious. About 24 hours later, at St. Vincent's Hospital, Russell Anthony Hexter died. The cause was an aortic aneurysm, a cardiac malfunction that in his case resulted from Marfan syndrome, a disorder that he had been born with and that commonly results in unusual height and long limbs. Mr. Hexter, at 6 feet 4 inches, had both of those characteristics. He was 27 years old.
By uncanny happenstance, his death echoed by a matter of months that of another promising young talent, Jonathan Larson, the 35-year-old composer and author who died hours after the final dress rehearsal for his hit musical "Rent." Both men had grown up in suburban Westchester, both collapsed in their downtown Manhattan apartments, both were stricken by aortic aneurysms, and both died as the curtains were about to rise on promising careers. Mr. Hexter's movie, "Dadetown," with a national distributor lined up, will open on Wednesday at Film Forum in Manhattan, a theater only blocks from where he lived.
"INCREDIBLY TRAGIC" IS HOW Jim Carden, the producer of "Dadetown," describes Mr. Hexter's death. They had been close friends since their student days at N.Y.U. "Through film school everyone knew this was a guy who was going to succeed," Mr. Carden says, "that his was a career worth watching."
Together the two had started their own independent company, Big Ol' Productions, formed largely around a core of striving young former classmates. "He was the cornerstone of the company," says Mr. Carden, who is 28. "Now, without him, we're nothing."
"Dadetown" was to be their first hurrah. In 90 minutes the film spins out a parable for our times, observing in a quiet corner of small-town America the sort of wrenching transition, from machines to microchips, that much of the country is going through at the end of the 20th century. On the wane is the security and prosperity that bare hands fashioned on assembly lines during a mid-century heyday, when workers labored in the belief that loyalty to an employer would be returned in kind. On the horizon is an uncertain, "downsized" future, where the workplace will be a web site and only the computer-literate will need apply.
The movie's Dadetown is a peaceful patch of central New York State where everyone knows everyone down at the Runway Coffee Shop and every third person works at the town's biggest employer, Gorman Metal Bending. In its glory days, 50 years ago, as Gorman Aircraft, the plant -- and thus the town -- had done its patriotic part during the war by manufacturing wing and fuselage assemblies for American fighter planes. Now, in humbler times, it produces paper clips and staples.
Out on the edge of town, a big software company called American Peripheral Imaging, or A.P.I., has set up a regional headquarters, bringing with it a wave of corporate immigrants from the cities. No one in Dadetown quite understands what the company does or what its initials stand for ("Alien Persons Invade?" one local woman guesses derisively). But the townspeople are smart enough to see that these educated, middle-management newcomers in tailored suits and foreign cars are not just adding to the tax base but trying to remake Dadetown in their own image, putting up handsome new homes that the factory workers could never afford, building a fancy playground (for themselves, really) and, as a harbinger of a tonier future, ushering in a cappuccino shop.
Tensions between the two camps smolder until Gorman Metal Bending, squeezed by the cheap labor in third world countries, announces that it must "downsize" and begins laying off workers, the first step toward a plant closing. Now resentments flare, a strike is called, and A.P.I. families become the targets in a guerrilla campaign of harassment. There is violence. But there is no changing the new order of things.
HOW MR. HEXTER filmed this story is a story in itself. The style is documentary: events are recorded as they happened and dozens of people are interviewed, sometimes after a camera crew collars them, just as Michael Moore did in another blue-collar film, "Roger and Me." But there is a secret behind this movie that isn't owned up to until the credits roll at the end -- a surprise that illuminates the achievement of the film (or a manipulative hand at work, depending on one's point of view) and that must be divulged here if the achievement isn't to be ignored.
For the truth about "Dadetown" is that it's fiction. There is no Dadetown, N.Y. The film was shot mostly in Hammondsport (pop. 929), a village nestled in the Finger Lakes region, and the 82 people who were given lines to speak are actors, most of them amateurs -- ordinary citizens from Hammondsport and elsewhere upstate who answered casting calls to play people very much like themselves and who perform so convincingly that film festival audiences, and even a movie critic or two who didn't stick around for the credits, have been completely fooled.
People involved in the film say the faux-documentary style was chosen as the best way to fulfill Mr. Hexter's ambition to create, often with droll humor, a portrait of a town as a mosaic of voices. "We had wanted the town itself to be the protagonist, not a particular character," says John Housley, another N.Y.U. classmate who wrote the script with Mr. Hexter. "And it was Russ's solution to film it as a documentary. He saw the documentary style as really freeing for him."
He also delighted in not revealing his method until the end. "He loved the idea that it could fool people," says his mother, Maren Hexter.
Not every festival filmgoer welcomed the surprise; some felt that they had been had. Mr. Carden recalls one tense moment during a question-and-answer session after a screening in Vancouver in which a woman rose from the audience and said to Mr. Hexter, "I think you're going to do great in Hollywood because you're a liar and a cheat." The audience gasped, Mr. Carden says, but then someone rose to defend the director, drawing a round of applause.
Mr. Hexter addressed his unconventional approach in a "director's statement" that accompanied the movie to film festivals. "I've always believed that 'Dadetown' could not have been made in any other way without doing damage to the story I wanted to tell," he wrote. "I'll admit that the film was somewhat of an experiment to see just how far I could go with the nonfiction style."
WITH A SLIM BUDGET of $300,000 and months of research behind him, Mr. Hexter began shooting the film in the spring of 1994. A few professional actors were signed up, but for the most part the cast was an unlikely assemblage mustered from everyday walks of life: a town councilman, a disabled Vietnam veteran, a homemaker. Some were given monologues, others a few lines, and after many rehearsals and much gentle coaching they were put in front of the camera. What often happened next was something akin to improvisational theater. Mr. Hexter himself, in the role of an off-screen interviewer, would ask the actors questions about Dadetown's plight and encourage them to depart from the script and use their own words, drawing on their own real-life experience.
"These people could become the characters and talk about Dadetown and know exactly what was going on there, as if from firsthand knowledge," Mr. Carden says. One novice, Bill Garrison, a 74-year-old former town supervisor who plays Dadetown's leading councilman and grandfatherly sage, often put more trust in his own ear for upstate speech patterns than in the film makers'. "I had a little problem with their lines; sometimes one didn't seem to follow another," recalls Mr. Garrison, who came down from fixing his farmhouse roof to talk about the movie over the phone. "So Russ let me put it in my words, and it went smoother then."
Another amateur, Terry Nardone, saw himself as "a natural" for his role. "The part they were looking at was a disgruntled factory employee," he says. Mr. Nardone, who is 43 and lives in Hammondsport, says he has gone through 18 jobs since 1982, a work history that he attributes to delayed onset combat fatigue stemming from his naval service in Vietnam.
Through the months of production, his associates say, Mr. Hexter's dedication to the project deepened as he got to know the cast members better and, through them, came to understand the characters even more. "Russ loved every character in this movie," Mr. Carden says. "He didn't try to make the townspeople look like idiots. He didn't try to make the A.P.I. people look like idiots. He just wanted to state a case, without judging either side."
Mr. Housley, the script writer, says: "He had a real loyalty to the people there. He almost felt it really was a documentary, that he was really telling their story."
It might seem an unlikely affinity, that of an investment banker's son from moneyed Armonk, the home of I.B.M., with an obscure middle-American town. Yet Mr. Hexter believed, as expressed in a kind of epilogue to the film, that "the story of America starts and ends right here, with our myths, in the small town."
"Somehow he was fascinated by small towns," his mother says, "and although Armonk is a small town, that was not his idea of one. This is kind of an upscale place, where you meet people running around in fancy labels and Mercedeses. I think Russell felt that he lived a rather privileged life, that it wasn't real life, in a way."
Mrs. Hexter, a composed, gracious woman of 58 who is tall and slender like her son, is sitting in the comfortable den of her Norman-style brick home in the hushed stillness of a drizzly August afternoon. Later, she escorts a visitor on a tour of the house, past an indoor squash court and a large circular office overlooking four parklike acres and up a spiral staircase to a landing where, on a table, there is a framed photo of her son, a young man with sandy, unruly hair, an aquiline nose, sleepy eyes and a placid countenance. "A very funny, generous, sweet nature," his mother says. The two had lived in the house alone after her husband, Richard, died in a scuba diving accident in the Netherlands Antilles in 1981. Russ was 12 at the time.
Her only child's death came without warning, Mrs. Hexter says. "Knowing he had Marfan syndrome, we knew he had to be careful about certain things, and that when he was older, when he was in his 30's or 40's, he might have had to have heart surgery done," she says. "But the fact that this happened when he was 27 was quite unexpected."
His death was mourned in Hammondsport; Mr. Hexter had become something of an adopted son there. And he had returned the town's affection. In a gesture of gratitude toward the people who had served as both backdrop and cast of his film, Mr. Hexter chose to hold the premiere of "Dadetown" in Hammondsport last October, followed by a party over at Jim Gifford's winery. There were three showings of the movie at the Main Street School auditorium, and just about everybody in town came out to see it.

HEADLINE: CD-ROM's;
Disaster Is Imminent, So Plan Ahead

BYLINE: By Thomas Hine; Thomas Hine, the author of "The Total Package" and "Populuxe," is working on a history of American teen-agers. He is multimedia editor of the CD-ROM of "Bartlett's Familiar Quotations."

 BODY:

OUR SECRET CENTURY
Archival Films From the Darker Side of the American Dream.
By Rick Prelinger.
Six CD-ROM's
(Windows and Macintosh).
New York: Voyager Company.
$29.95 per two-disk set.
Strange things happen in "Our Secret Century." An evil clock makes a suburban housewife accident-prone. A professional football player travels coast to coast by bus, encounters what may be the ghost of the Unknown Soldier and marries Angie Dickinson at journey's end. A newlywed, ecstatic over her new Corvair, sips a "teeny weeny polka dot martini." A state trooper is so zealous in pursuit of young people with poor driving habits that he chases them to grisly deaths. And everywhere there are authoritative voices -- some identified as judges or clergymen, while others seem to be the voice of the superego, of concerned bureaucracy, of God, John Forsythe or General Motors. Who can tell the difference? 
 "Pleasant unemotional conversation helps digestion," youngsters are advised. While a teen-age girl weeps in her upstairs bedroom, a female voice taunts, "It's a little late for tears, isn't it, Barbara?" Her sin seems to have been poor management of her dry cleaning, which is somehow associated with an uncultivated mind.
And while an industrial army of everyone from miners to goatherds massages the continent to "harvest" a Chevrolet, a grandiloquent orator apostrophizes: "A gripping springing live thing, resiliently spry and untiringly useful." He's talking about tires.
The voice-overs we hear on so many of the corporate and educational films presented and annotated in "Our Secret Century" rarely try to sell or convince. That would imply doubt. Rather, their message is that this is the way life is. The high-school dropout will lose his girlfriend and his self-respect, and a girl who takes a ride from a stranger risks having something happen that's quite unspeakable. The automobile workers in Flint, Mich., in 1937 are not the vanguard of the labor movement, but "a legion of craftsmen . . . joined to supply transportation to a nation of individuals." And if you get into an accident, it's not because of external dangers but because of your own thoughtlessness.
These three two-disk sets constitute the first half of a projected 12-disk series based on the collection of the New York film archivist Rick Prelinger. Made between the 1930's and the 60's, these corporate and educational films are documents both of an overlooked sector of the film industry and of the values that were winning sponsorship at midcentury.
The films were shown in schools and church basements, and on television at odd hours. People over 40, even if they haven't seen these particular films, are likely to find something familiar about their guilt-inducing narratives, their often awkwardly pantomimed acting and their plodding pace, which is occasionally relieved by flashes of redeeming trashiness. Everyone, regardless of age, will find them odd.
In the lingo of CD-ROM publishing, imagery and sounds are known as "assets." There is tremendous logistical and economic incentive to limit the number of permissions you need to obtain. CD-ROM's are more likely to be generated by the availability of particular material from one museum, movie studio or archive than by an idea. "Our Secret Century" follows that pattern, but Mr. Prelinger has more than assets. He has a sensibility. He sees these films as overlooked documents of social history and, often, as artful works in themselves. He goes out of his way to point out the facts and ideas that are missing from these films, but he is also sensitive to the virtues that are there.
It's possible to speak of Mr. Prelinger's sensibility, because there is quite a lot of him on each disk. Each of the three to seven films on each disk comes with several screens full of written commentary. There are also supporting visual and written documents and interviews that relate to each film and to the disk as a whole, supplemented with excellent bibliographies. And each CD-ROM is introduced by a moving Quicktime image of Mr. Prelinger himself. With his clunky shoes, flap-pocketed shirt and reedy voice, he presents himself as a student and enthusiast. His informal, inquisitive stance on the surface of the screen contrasts strongly with the omniscient off-screen voices of authority found in so many of the films on view.
In this marginal cinematic realm, Mr. Prelinger has even unearthed a couple of auteurs. One is Sid Davis, whose films on youth set in working-class southern California, especially "Age 13" (1955), show a lost time and place and pack a good deal of emotional power. The other is the Detroit-based Jam Handy, who was addicted to aerial camera work and run-on sentences. His was an epic of salesmanship. The earth and all mankind labor and bring forth . . . a Chevrolet!
The disks are packaged in unmatched pairs. Volume 1, "The Rainbow Is Yours," which deals with consumption and design during the 50's, seems logically to belong with Volume 6, "The Uncharted Landscape," whose centerpiece is a remarkable marketing film about 50's suburban life. Instead, it is paired with Volume 2, "Capitalist Realism," containing 30's industrial films.
Volume 3, "The Behavior Offensive," films exhorting teen-agers to plan ahead, refrain from necking and pretend to enjoy their parents' company, seems a natural pair for Volume 5, "Teenage Transgressions," about delinquency. Instead, it's mated with Volume 4, "Menace and Jeopardy," films about safety in which disaster is always imminent.
Nearly all the films, which range from a few minutes to more than half an hour, are shown in their entirety, with about 80 minutes' worth on each disk. Viewers have their choice of seeing the films in a small window, where the images are more or less distinct, or in a larger window, where they aren't, especially if you use only a 256-color display. While the CD-ROM format allows Mr. Prelinger his authorial presence, I'd much rather be watching these on a videocassette recorder, with the comments and supporting documents in a book.
You may start out laughing at these films but they have an odd way of eating into your mind. Just yesterday, I found myself wondering whether my life would be better today if I'd taken command of my closet as a teen-ager. I'd never learned Barbara's lesson, and it's too late for tears now. I really knew I'd had enough when I was watching "Frigidaire Finale," a maniacal 1957 dance to the joy of major appliances, found on Volume 1. A tail-coated gent flung open the freezer and dumped ice cubes all over the floor, and I, brainwashed by Volume 4, found myself worrying that someone might fall and get hurt.
"Our Secret Century" is, perhaps, best taken in smaller doses. (A little Jam Handy goes a long, long way.) But Mr. Prelinger has done a great service by opening a window to such evocative documents of our recent past and presenting them so thoughtfully.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 19; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 651 words

HEADLINE: Madam President

BYLINE: By Linda Robinson; Linda Robinson, the Latin America correspondent for U.S. News & World Report, is the author of "Intervention or Neglect: The United States and Central America Beyond the 1980's."

 BODY:

DREAMS OF THE HEART
The Autobiography of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of Nicaragua.
By Violeta Barrios de Chamorro with Sonia Cruz de Baltodano and Guido Fernandez.
Illustrated. 352 pp. New York:
Simon & Schuster. $25.
The national obsession with Nicaragua throughout the 1980's, when the United States waged a proxy war against the Sandinista revolution, seems like ancient history. The bloodshed ended in 1990, after the Sandinistas agreed to elections, which they then lost. The winner, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, was a symbolic candidate chosen to unite the fractious opposition, and she inherited a country wrecked by war and revolution. 
 "Dreams of the Heart" is the story of how Mrs. Chamorro passed from spectator to leader during Nicaragua's tumultuous journey from dictatorship through revolution to democracy. Political memoirs can be tedious, self-aggrandizing affairs, but this one is a modest and engagingly personal portrait. The first half is a charming account of the author's idyllic girlhood, and of her marriage to Pedro Joaquin Chamorro Cardenal, an impassioned journalist who exposed the corruption and atrocities of the dictator Anastasio Somoza Debayle in the family newspaper. Mrs. Chamorro, a housewife and mother of four, was drawn inexorably into her husband's fight.
The signal event of her life was Pedro Chamorro's assassination in 1978, which detonated an insurrection that brought down Somoza. Nicaraguans rallied to the side of the Sandinistas, who had been waging a hit-and-run war from the hills since the early 1960's. Mrs. Chamorro recounts the first momentous decision she had to make on her own, whether to join the Sandinista-dominated junta that replaced Somoza. In describing her first meeting with the top Sandinista comandantes, she says, "They gave me the chills."
Wary of collaborating with Communists, who wanted her as window dressing to make the new Government palatable to Washington, Mrs. Chamorro recalls lying awake at night: "I ask Pedro . . . to give me a sign if he thinks I can be of use to my country." Ultimately, she joined the junta, but defending this decision now is an awkward task. Her rationale is that she and others in the middle class "still thought of the Sandinistas as sons and daughters of our friends, children we could influence or order around."
Mrs. Chamorro's life poignantly mirrors her country's trauma. Her own children are divided: two are prominent Sandinistas and one became a leader of the United States-backed contra rebels. Yet they were all welcome at her dinner table, even though she criticized the contras and eventually broke with the Sandinistas.
Mrs. Chamorro is still miffed that many foreign reporters derided her neophyte candidacy. But her simple message hit home with Nicaraguans who, she says, saw in her an escape from United States hostility, Sandinista arrogance and a disastrous experiment in Marxist economics.
As president, Mrs. Chamorro infuriated her coalition by opting for a policy of national reconciliation, allowing the Sandinistas to keep control of the armed forces. She contends that it was the only way to shrink that gargantuan machine without sparking another war. The results, she claims, vindicate her: the Sandinista army now has only 12,000 enlisted troops, and the economy is finally reviving. Yet Ms. Chamorro did commit herself to the coalition's platform, which pledged to uproot Sandinista control, and disregarding electoral promises sets a poor example in a place where democracy has more often than not been subverted by back-room deals.
Mrs. Chamorro's successor, to be elected in October, will face the same choice between partisan rule and the politics of compromise. But whatever the outcome, the fact remains that this homemaker steered the Nicaraguan family through a perilous transition more ably than anyone could have imagined.

HEADLINE: What Was in It for Them?

BYLINE: By James Sheehan; James Sheehan is a professor of history at Stanford University. His most recent book is "German History: 1770-1866."

 BODY:

THE LOGIC OF EVIL
The Social Origins of the Nazi Party, 1925-1933.
By William Brustein.
235 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press. $27.50.
Like a recurring nightmare, Nazism haunts our historical imagination. In part this is because of the enormity of Nazism's crimes, in part because they occurred in a well-educated, economically developed modern society not so different from our own. To those who want to believe that evil is an ailment that can be cured by education, therapy and reform, the experience of Nazism remains an unyielding challenge. 
 Some of the most popular explanations of Nazism try to weaken its connections to modernity by emphasizing its atavistic character. The Nazis were successful, these explanations suggest, only because Germany was not an authentically modern nation; Germans were not really like the rest of us because they had approached modernity along a "special path," a path that eventually ended with Hitler and Auschwitz. Daniel Jonah Goldhagen's much-discussed recent book, "Hitler's Willing Executioners," presented one version of this argument: Nazism, Mr. Goldhagen maintains, was the latest and most murderous expression of a historical anti-Semitism that had survived in Germany long after it had withered in the rest of Europe.
In "The Logic of Evil," William Brustein suggests a very different explanation of Nazism's origins. Mr. Brustein, a professor of sociology at the University of Minnesota, believes that political behavior is based on people's rational calculation of their economic self-interest. Because German voters were, like those everywhere, "voting their pocketbooks," the Nazis' successes came from their "superlative success at fashioning economic programs that addressed the material needs of millions of Germans." People supported Hitler not because of "irrational leitmotifs such as anti-Semitism, hypernationalism and xenophobia," but because he offered the "best prospects for a better life."
To demonstrate this proposition Mr. Brustein uses data from the enormous collection of party membership records now in the Berlin Document Center. With the help of a team of research assistants, he randomly selected the files of 42,000 individuals who joined the Nazis from 1925, when the party was reorganized, until January 1933, when Hitler became the Weimar Republic's last chancellor. Through a sophisticated set of classifications and statistical analyses, Mr. Brustein concludes that Nazism was overrepresented among those occupational groups to which its economic program most actively appealed: small-business men and farmers, married male white-collar employees, industrial workers in import-oriented enterprises and skilled blue-collar workers.
Mr. Brustein is neither naive nor ill informed. He recognizes that no single factor can explain Nazism's appeal, and he carefully restricts his remarks to what happened before Hitler came to power. Especially in his chapter on the incentives and disincentives for joining the party, he offers qualifications that seem to undermine the basic structure of his argument. But, in fact, his argument is only interesting in its extreme formulation: no one, after all, has ever denied that people's economic self-interest played some role in Nazism's origins. Yet was it, as Mr. Brustein claims, the most significant source of their support?
It is possible, I think, to raise serious questions about Mr. Brustein's methods. I am skeptical that some of his social categories have much analytical value. Furthermore, Nazism's economic program appears here to be a good deal more coherent, consistent and transparent than it actually was. But the most serious weakness in Mr. Brustein's approach is the concept of rational self-interest itself.
How, for example, does this idea explain the relative brevity and apparent instability of Nazism's success before 1933? In 1928, the Nazis were a marginal party with less than 3 percent of the total vote. Between September 1930 and July 1932, their share of the vote grew dramatically, from 18 to 37 percent, and then, in November, two months before taking power, they lost two million voters and declined to 33 percent. Party membership was even more unstable: although it also grew rapidly after 1930, as many as 40 percent of those who joined between 1925 and 1933 eventually left the party. Mr. Brustein cites these figures as an argument against those who explain Nazism through "irrational" appeals like anti-Semitism; it seems to me that they are equally hard to combine with his conception of economic calculation. What these figures do suggest is the fear, frustration and disorientation produced among German voters by the economic and political crisis that gripped Germany after 1929.
Economic rationality also fails to explain the manifest unevenness of the Nazis' success. Although every German party was affected by the Depression and its aftermath, some were far better at retaining their supporters than others. The liberal parties, for example, had virtually disappeared by 1932, whereas the Center Party (the party of political Roman Catholicism), and to a lesser extent the Social Democrats, managed to hold on to their voters. Many Social Democratic and, particularly, Center voters had economic interests quite like the groups overrepresented in Mr. Brustein's sample. It seems clear that people's previous political affiliations, not their occupations, remained the most powerful element in determining German voting behavior.
The most disturbing part of "The Logic of Evil" is the author's conclusion that because they acted "rationally," Hitler's supporters were not fully responsible for the grim consequences of their choice. Mr. Brustein is probably right (and Mr. Goldhagen wrong) that before 1933 anti-Semitism was not particularly important for many Nazi voters and even for some party members. But while the Nazi leaders did not emphasize their anti-Semitism before coming to power, they made no effort to conceal their conviction that Jews should be removed from German society. Nor did they attempt to conceal their willingness to use violence against their opponents at home and abroad. In the summer of 1932, for example, Hitler expressed his solidarity with a group of his followers who were convicted of dragging a suspected Communist from his bed and beating him to death in front of his mother. Any satisfactory account of Nazism's success must explain why so many "ordinary and rational" Germans chose to endorse, justify or simply ignore these aspects of the movement they helped bring to power.
