HEADLINE: Black-Owned Bank To Open a Center In Mount Vernon

BYLINE: By F. ROMALL SMALLS 

DATELINE: MOUNT VERNON

 BODY:
CARVER Federal Savings Bank, the largest black-owned financial institution in the country, is coming to Westchester.
Carver Federal, based in Harlem, will open a mortgage and loan center in downtown Mount Vernon next month. Local officials and bank administrators say they hope it will be the beginning of a long relationship. 
 The Mount Vernon lending center will be Carver's second loan center to open this year, and outgrowth of what is considered the once fiscally conservative bank's new, more aggressive approach. Much of Carver's new direction is attributed to the appointment of a new president and chief executive officer, the veteran banking executive Thomas L. Clark Jr. of Greenburgh.
Mr. Clark took the helm of of the $363 million institution in February 1995, about the time that Ernest E. Davis was sworn in as Mayor of Mount Vernon. "We were both friends, and the way fate would have it, he was elected president of the bank and I was elected Mayor," Mr. Davis said. "He promised me that if I was elected that he would work with me in bringing Carver to Mount Vernon."
Carver Federal Savings and Loan Association opened in a storefront on 125th Street in Harlem on Jan. 5, 1949. It was founded by a coalition of community advocates, church leaders and small business owners, who established Carver in an area that was being overlooked by other banks.
Today Carver, named for the black scientist and educator George Washington Carver, has two locations in Manhattan, three in Brooklyn, two in Queens and one in Roosevelt, L.I.
Bank and city officials here are looking for a site for the mortgage and loan center. "We think Mount Vernon fits our profile of where we want to be and what we want to be," Mr. Clark said when asked why Carver Federal was moving into the suburban market north of New York City. "It's a middle- to upper-class, African-American community -- predominantly. We feel that we're going to give them an opportunity to deal with a bank that is steeped in working for communities and helping people to attain their goals."
Like Carver's Chelsea District location in Manhattan, the Mount Vernon center will have a small staff and will focus exclusively on originating mortgages, small business loans and loan and debt refinancing. "The target market is lower Westchester and the North Bronx," said Howard Dabney, Carver Federal vice president and chief lending officer. "It will be a central location for all in the area." Mr. Dabney said bank representatives would have laptop computers with modems and will arrange meetings at clients' homes or businesses if necessary. Mr. Dabney said the computers would speed up processing time. "The laptop allows them to evaluate things on the spot. The modem allows communication back to the central office and to credit bureaus," he said.
Mount Vernon's importance to Carver lies not only in its convenient location but also in its sizable black middle-class base. Carver has gained a reputation for opening branches in neighborhoods that are largely populated by members of minority groups or where major commercial banks have closed offices.
"I would like to see Carver, at a minimum, as a $500-million asset institution by December of '97, and by the turn of the century I would like to see us, at a minimum, as a billion-dollar institution," said Mr. Clark, who has lived in Westchester for more than 20 years. "To obtain that growth, we've got to be where the markets are. So following where our people are, those that want an urban-development community bank is important."
Mr. Clark said he felt that Mount Vernon would become Carver's northern corporate headquarters. "Everything we launch in Westchester County will be from our base in Mount Vernon," he said. "So at some point we would like to see a full-service bank operating in Mount Vernon." Mayor Davis said this would require nearly $25 million in bank deposits.
Community leaders and members of a church here have formed a committee to gain support for a full-service branch of Carver Federal Savings. Two innovative products that Mr. Clark said should attract residents are Carver's reverse mortgage, which will allow older residents to use the equity in their home, and a 100 percent-financed first-time home mortgage, which should appeal to young prospective home buyers.
Philippe Francois, a contractor, said he was eager to see the bank come to his hometown. "I would be happy to support a black-owned bank here in Mount Vernon," he said, adding with a broad smile: "I'm sure they will help me. I'm thinking about expanding now and buying more equipment. This could be a good push for me." City officials are also optimistic about Carver's arrival. "This is a dream come true," said Ruth Hassell-Thompson, president of the Mount Vernon City Council. "It speaks to an economic stability that sends very positive signals. They see the growth and development that we are planning."
Community leaders said that the added competition should force other banks to be more aggressive in offering loans to small businesses and those not currently being targeted for loans. "If you look at the record of many banks in Mount Vernon, you will see that the record is poor. We are looking to Carver, who are very much on the forefront of community reinvestment," Councilwoman Hassell-Thompson said.
Mr. Dabney said Carver is different from commercial banks because "we spend the time to get the answer to the problem that in normal circumstances would disqualify a candidate. We look for reasons in how we can make the loan, not reject a loan."
Throughout much of the 47-year history of Carver, it had a conservative lending policy, but in recent years the association has gone through significant changes. Two years ago, Carver started trading publicly on Nasdaq. And Mr. Clark, former Deputy Superintendent and Secretary to the State Banking Department for nearly 20 years, was elected to lead the bank into the 21st century with a new mission of "urban community redevelopment," he said. The bank also recently became a certified Small Business Administration lender.
So far this year, Carver has issued nearly $19 million in family mortgages and small business loans. The seven bank members in the Westchester Regional Small Business Loan Program have themselves provided $4.5 million in small business loans this year.
"We think it's a terrific thing for Westchester," said Harold E. Vogt, president of the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce.
Before the establishment of black-owned banks like Carver Federal, which was chartered in 1948, many blacks were denied access to basic financial services. Even now recent studies show that there are still large disparities in the lending patterns between blacks and whites nationwide. Carver Federal is the only black-owned bank in New York State, and is one of only two of its kind traded on Nasdaq.
For many, Carver's arrival in Westchester is considered a milestone. "It is another building block in my city that will last for decades," Mayor Davis said.

HEADLINE: Adapting to Downsizing

BYLINE: By ANN COSTELLO 

DATELINE: PURCHASE

 BODY:
IT was a 10th anniversary get-together for the group, held on a perfect morning in an opulent room in the Gothic-style castle at Manhattanville College. But it was no frivolous party.
The group of 50 career counselors who attended were there to observe the birthday of the founding of the Westchester Career Counselors' Network, an educational and networking group of 125 counselors, the only one of its kind in the county and, possibly, the country. They also heard two speakers discuss "Are You Change Agile or Change Fragile?" They wanted to be better able to help Westchester's job seekers, displaced homemakers and foundering college graduates. It was part of the effort to hear about ways to adapt to change, gain new insights and update and improve career-counseling skills. 
 One speaker, Dr. Herbert Nieburg, a therapist, author, lecturer, trainer, college professor and director of Behavioral Medicine/Psycho-Oncology at Four Winds Hospital in Katonah, used a humorous style to explain how job seekers who were stuck in a self-defeating way of thinking could learn to become unstuck. The other speaker, Kate Wendleton, a career coach and author based in Manhattan, used a saleswoman's pitching skills to explain how her business, the Five O'Clock Clubs, which she founded in 1978, help job hunters work out similar problems, using job-search strategy groups.
Faye Woocher, the founder of Westchester Career Counselors' Network and a career-development counselor for 16 years, lives in Ardsley-on-Hudson and is president of the Career Resource Center in Tarrytown. She recalled starting the group 10 years ago because of the loneliness of the profession. "It was a professional exchange that I started and kept going on my own from 1986 to 1991," she said. "Then I got busy with a job in Manhattan and needed to have a steering committee to keep it going." In the early days, there might be 5 or 6 or as many as 14 around her conference table. They now meet four times a year.
Ms. Woocher, who says she knows of no other group like it, said that the nonprofit Westchester Career Counselors' Network "provides education for these nationally certified career counselors and career-development specialists so that their skills and information can be on the leading edge."
She said that, as the economy has changed and downsizing and outplacement have become common, the career-counseling profession has grown. The group also outgrew Ms. Woocher's office. It began meeting in college or corporate settings like Manhattanville College's centerpiece, the Castle, this year.
When Ms. Woocher opened the meeting, she acknowledged the three career counselors who, with her, formed the steering committee in 1991: Elaine Sozzi of Mount Kisco, Claire Watsky of Mamaroneck and Gloria Goldstein of Larchmont.
Ms. Sozzi runs what used to be the Westchester Educational Brokering Service but is now the WEBS Career and Educational Counseling Service program operated through the Westchester Library System, providing free career counseling. Ms. Watsky runs job-search workshops for people 50 and older at a nominal fee for the American Association of Retired Persons. Ms. Goldstein heads Directions Career Counseling in Larchmont.
In her practice, Ms. Woocher said, she handles placement for the Ciba Corporation of Hawthorne and the Pure Food Company of Mamaroneck, after the food company was bought by Durkee French Company. She said she also works with "relocating spouses from Big Six accounting firms who move to the Westchester area."
Dr. Nieburg said of the group: "This is an extremely professional and highly ethical group, and when the issue of career counseling comes up, which is really outside of my scope, I often refer to them and they might refer to me. It's very reciprocal."
Karen Ganz, director of the Office of Career Services at Manhattanville College and a member of the Network, praised the group's ability to network.
In explaining the makeup of the group, Ms. Goldstein said: "The diversity is great. Most of us have a master's degree in counseling. We have a couple of psychologists, and a number of us are nationally certified counselors, which means we've taken a four-hour exam and have earned 125 clock hours of re-education to be certified. This could include these meetings, where you can qualify for C.E.U.'s."
Recalling that 10 years ago, "there were just a few of us," Ms. Goldstein summarized the group's appeal by saying: "Now we have 125. We were just friends, and somehow this started to grow and turned into an enormous thing. It's run on a volunteer basis. But it's done for the love of it."

HEADLINE: The Poetry Crowd Goes Wild

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
COMPARED with music, art exhibitions, novels and movies, even obscure ones, poetry has few followers and fewer practitioners. It is widely regarded as uncomfortably highbrow and not much fun.
True, the last few years have brought a boom in poetry readings and book sales. Poems have shown up in unorthodox places like New York City buses and Amtrak's New York-to-Washington trains. 
 It's safe to assume that most adults in search of entertainment would choose poetry over a zoning board meeting, or a lecture on the impact of Nepalese immigration on the economy of Bhutan. But most other diversions -- "Seinfeld," a dinner out, lying on the couch talking on the phone -- would probably win out over poems. And few strangers to poetry would understand why people get worked up about it: arguing about it, being moved to tears over it, generally investing passion in it.
This is why the Geraldine R. Dodge Poetry Festival, taking place from Thursday through next Sunday at Waterloo Village in Stanhope, is so different from poetry as outsiders would view it. The Dodge festival, held every two years since 1986, contradicts the usual assumptions of what poetry is and who cares about it.
First, the festival is not a select, rarefied gathering. It is, in fact, huge -- bigger than many major rock concerts, the biggest gathering of poets in the country, the continent, maybe the world. Some 10,000 people from all over the United States have attended past festivals and are expected at this one. They include hundreds of English teachers, thousands of high school students, and thousands of others who work at a variety of jobs, from park superintendents to high school coaches to homemakers, business people and the occasional heavy-equipment operator.
Few of the teachers teach at universities; most teach at middle schools and high schools. The teen-agers will not necessarily be the ones who shine in school with high grades and S.A.T. scores.
The Dodge festival was founded and is run by the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation of Morristown, which gives money to causes including education, public policy, animal rights and the arts, especially in schools. Its fame has increased since "The Language of Life," a Bill Moyers documentary series seen by millions on public television, focused on the 1994 festival.
People who have attended past festivals say they anticipate them as eagerly as others do vacations in Cancun. What these participants love -- with an intensity some reserve for the beach or the World Series -- is the onslaught of words, billions of them, words booming simultaneously from nine different stages. At the Dodge festival, people can wander from terse free verse in the gazebo to rich, rolling images in the weaving barn, from heart-stabbing descriptions of private pain at one end of the meadow to wryly witty recitations at the other.
Festivalgoers can listen all day, and they do. Scattered throughout the reconstructed Colonial village's 365 acres from 8 A.M. to nearly midnight, are readings and readings and readings. There are intimate readings, and there are readings to audiences of 300 or 400. There are readings that are booming and dramatic, quiet and intimate, sung to music. In the air are poems that are rhythmical or structured or free or spontaneous; poems that are blunt and plain, intricate and mellifluous, as subtle as a glance or as abrupt as cardiac arrest.
In between all these readings, all these poetic groupings of words, the participants may talk to strangers or muster the courage to recite their own work. They may mingle with the featured poets, indulging in hero worship, or engage in displays of fraternal-sororal affection between bites of funnel cake and leaden cafeteria-style food.
There's a lot of weeping and laughing and touching because of the joy of being around others who love what is ordinarily a lonely pursuit, and because of the abrupt intimacy created by poems expressing profound emotions and personal experiences.
"People are always embracing, hugging each other," said Edwin Romond, a poet who teaches at Warren Hills High School in Washington, Warren County. Mr. Romond, who has attended other Dodge festivals, ranks them among his life's high points. "It's a very beautiful experience.
"It's the Woodstock of poetry: Allen Ginsberg in one tent, Lucille Clifton in another," he continued, describing the 1994 festival. "It was overpowering. Poetry requires such concentration. I had to get in my car and go down to the diner for a cup of coffee -- get unpumped before I would go back."
Many poets would agree. "I don't know why it's magical," said Robert Hass, the nation's poet laureate, who said he was planning to attend the festival. "It's very festive, very lively. It's like some plant growing the dark, hugely and gorgeously blooming. Poetry gets practiced in private a lot. Suddenly there's thousands of people there interested in it."

A Safe Harbor, Or Just Too Darn Nice?
Thousands of people -- teachers, students, people who secretly write poems they would not even show their spouses, and many professional poets -- love the Dodge festival. Many think it is unparalleled in introducing poetry to a much wider audience.
Not all poets are so complimentary.
Certainly none object to the cause of poetry's being championed, which, if nothing else, could lead to bigger book sales.
But there are those who are not fond of the festival's all-inclusive, populist style. And since they are poets, artists whose medium is language, their arguments about what the festival and its poets lack tend to be lengthy, impassioned and nuanced.
Briefly, some poets -- individuals and groups -- think the Dodge festival tends to simplify and sentimentalize an art that should be complex, multi-layered with meaning and nuances of language, and best savored privately, on the page. Another objection is that in trying to be palatable to many, the festival's poets avoid gritty, jarring, experimental and scathing works. Much of the poetry read at Waterloo is autobiographical, revealing very personal feelings and occurrences. Some deride this genre as confessional; some even say it is little more than elegant Oprah.
Some poets and critics say that vast, populist poetry readings are too undiscriminating, too inclusive of mediocre works.
"A feel-good, fun kind of thing doesn't go very far," said Marjorie Perloff, a critic of contemporary poetry who has not attended a Dodge festival but knows the work of its poets. "That's nice, but who needs it?"
Another influential poetry critic, Helen Vendler of Harvard University, has accused the festival of placing too much emphasis on politically correct, multicultural poetry, of carefully including poets of different races and ethnic backgrounds but not putting enough emphasis on the complexity and sophistication of the art form.
"Pernicious polarization," said Bill Wadsworth, executive director of the Academy of American Poets, a 62-year-old organization that gives out prizes and grants to poets of its choice. A lot of these so-called controversies "would be quieted if poetry were run like a decent record store -- there's sections for classical, pop, rock, blues, jazz," he said, adding: "You pick what you like. No one's saying there shouldn't be pop or jazz."
Ms. Perloff said she admired some of the festival's featured poets, including Robert Creeley and Geraldine Brooks, but she compared the writing of others to Hallmark verse. "If it's not going to be better than greeting cards, why not see something on TV?" she said.
Some poets see the Dodge festival as a fine forum for exploring oral poetry, a way of introducing newcomers and deepening the connection and knowledge of others to a wide spectrum of poets. But at the Dodge festival, all poetry is recited or sung.
"Poetry on a page in a book is the very best, highest form of the art," said Bill Wadsworth, executive director of the Academy of American Poets, a national association that gives awards and fellowships. "I love going to poetry readings. But for me a deep love of poetry leads one to read books." At its best, "poetry is the attempt to put something into language that's absolutely permanent," he said. "It does involve composition on the page."
Yet Dodge's multitudinous readings, "done so magnificently," he said, "make poetry living for high school students."
"Nothing could be more important for the future of the art than that," he said.
Even an admirer like Mr. Hass conceded that startling poetic innovations or intricate many-layered verses do not emerge from the Dodge festival.
"It's not a gathering of new writing on the edge," he said. "It's not a place for austerity and difficult abstractions. It's not for poets who have a loathing for easy images, a distrust of autobiography or big, emotional resolutions. Nor is it an academy of American poetry, a gathering of the most eminent poets teaching at the Ivy League. Its sensibility is both populist and democratic. It's got good poets and not so good. The atmosphere is very nice."
That is precisely what Robert Creeley, the groundbreakingly innovative, venerable, old-dog poet of upstate New York, is hoping will not be too apparent. At this, his first Dodge festival, he's delighted with the company; "the poets are terrific," he said. He savors the idea of being surrounded by dozens of loud and frequently musical recitations, of off-the-cuff creations, of experiments that work and that don't. But the prospect of being in the middle of thousands of people who are decorous, who skirt edgy danger, who are, in a word, nice -- well, he doesn't look forward to that.
"Poetry can be mean, vicious," he said. "It's utterly human, an utterly human agency. I just hope this isn't too nice. I hope it doesn't turn out to be a conference of nice people."

Buds Among Weeds, And Other Lessons
In the four days of the Dodge Festival, 50 poets will read 3,000 or more poems to audiences ranging in number from 5 or 10 to 300 or 400. Fifty other poets will conduct 80 workshops; dozens of participants will read their work or recite spontaneous poems.
Among the poets will be the eminent -- Ms. Brooks, Mr. Ginsberg and Mr. Creeley, among others -- and the aged, the eldest being Stanley Kunitz, 91, a Pulitzer Prize winner who also holds the distinction of being the oldest living poet writing in English to have a new book published ("Passing Through," W. W. Norton). The youngest will be 23 winners of the 1996 New Jersey High School Poetry Contest, sponsored by Rutgers University.
The audience will consist of 1,500 high school teachers and 3,500 students from New Jersey and New York as well as 5,000 individuals, who will arrive from around the country. For $15 a day they will be able to select from a bewildering number of events: Mr. Hass's 8 A.M. reading at the old church; poets reading from the works of Langston Hughes and Federico Garcia Lorca; Mr. Ginsberg singing poems he'll create on the spot; poets at numerous formal and open readings. In the evenings, poets will read and sing to the music of the Paul Winter Consort. Participants can select among workshops on poetry and women, and poetry and history, and jobs, and teaching, and living with another poet, and living with oneself as a poet, and the Spirit and the all-purpose "Search for Truth."
Clearly, with workshops called "The Search for Truth," the organizers of the Dodge Festival are not embarrassed at sounding earnest. This is precisely the way Jim Haba, poetry director of the Dodge Foundation, wants it. As much as possible, he has put together a gentle, unsarcastic, uncritical gathering, a place where new or shy poets can stutter through their first readings without having to face boos or groans or low scores waved in their faces.
"You have to be willing to write your bad poems, to be embarrassingly, shamefully corny," Mr. Haba said. Good poems, he said, grow among weeds. At Waterloo, this willingness means a decorous willingness to listen -- without grimacing, even to oneself -- to weeds along with better work.
"Poets -- who can be vicious -- come together there around a protected space," Mr. Haba said. "It's a place where the truth is not something to deny."
This is an approach thousands of New Jersey teachers have taken from the festival into the classroom. Teachers who have attended the festival, especially the two weekdays set aside for students and teachers, tend to experiment with personal poetry that lets students express themselves while becoming adept with language.
"It taps the poetry already in them," said Patrick Trujillo, who teaches English at Lincoln Middle School in Passaic. "They get turned off by conventional writing, but they're turned on by this."
Laura Czekaj, who teaches creative writing at Hasbrouck Heights High School, said: "When I teach standard poetry, I get groans. But when they write poetry this way, they get excited. I'm surprised how enthused they are with standard poetry. They wonder: 'What's the relevance to my life? Why do we have to do this?' But when they write poems about themselves and listen to what the others have written, their attention is riveted. They don't have to be told this is important. They know."
 
Festival Highlights
 The sixth Geraldine R. Dodge Poetry Festival opens Thursday at Waterloo Village, exit 25 off Interstate 80, Stanhope. Admission: all-day tickets for Thursday, Friday or Saturday, $15 ($12 for students and the elderly); evening tickets for Thursday, Friday or Saturday, $9 ($7); Sunday, $10 ($8). Workshops cost an additional $20 or $40. Information: (201) 540-8443, extension 129; bus information: (201) 366-0600.

LENGTH: 1445 words

HEADLINE: The Voice of Women in Politics

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
SHE was considered a trailblazer, one of a tough new breed of women breaking ground in politics. She edged into the old boys' network, cut deals in smoked-filled rooms and promoted the economic and social causes affecting women. Recently, though, Cecile D. Singer, 66, looked back at the generation of female politicians coming up in the ranks and said that, contrary to what she had hoped for, there was no thundering herd following in her footsteps.
"My generation navigated a difficult political system: we opened up a lot of doors," said Ms. Singer, a former Republican State Assemblywoman from Yonkers and one of a field of possible candidates for County Executive next year. "The problem is that if there aren't more like us, women won't continue to be heard." 
 Indeed, statistics show that women are markedly underrepresented in government. In Congress and in most state legislatures, only 10 percent of the lawmakers are women; in the New York State Legislature, that number is about 18 percent.
Experts in the field say that even though politics appears on the surface to be an alluring field, it continues to be a difficult one for women to enter for several reasons.
In recent interviews, female politicians in Westchester described the difficulty of balancing families with careers that often take them away from home for long periods of time -- the result being that many women wait until their families are grown.
Some women spoke of the problems they encounter in raising money for campaigns, which have become more and more expensive.
Others lamented the persistence of the old boys' network, which sometimes spurns them and other times fails to take them seriously.
"With all of these variables," Ms. Singer said, "it's no wonder that it sometimes takes us a long time to get out of the gate."
Ms. Singer described herself as part of "a bridge generation that sandwiched politics in between the children and the chicken soup."
For black women in politics today, entering the field is especially daunting. In interviews, they complained about what the Yonkers City Councilwoman Symra D. Brandon, a Democrat, called "a double whammy -- the racial as well as gender stereotypes we have to battle."
Overall, the most difficult issue for the women, regardless of race, was deciding when to enter politics, and many said they waited to run for state or national office until they were older.
Like Representative Nita Lowey, a Democrat from Harrison, many of the women came up through the ranks from a background of public service, which centered on parent-teacher organizations and community affairs.
"I never had a long-term plan," said Mrs. Lowey, who raised her children first and then ran for Congress eight years ago when she turned 50. "I got there circuitously. Yet looking back, I can see that each step I took set me up for the next."
Several of the women, like Sandra R. Galef, 56, a Democratic State Assemblywoman from Ossining, said they had entered politics while their children were young but ran only for local office. Mrs. Galef was a County Legislator from 1980 to 1993, and although her schedule involved many late-night meetings, she said she managed with "a lot of Kentucky Fried Chicken" to come home each night for her family.
Amy R. Paulin, 40, of Scarsdale, a Village Trustee, an advocate of many county issues and the mother of three children under 12, said she was debating whether to seek higher office. "If there was an opening to go to Albany, would I even want to?" she said. "On the one hand, I would miss out on these important years with my children, but then do I want to wait 10 or 15 years to make a difference politically?"
The interviews also revealed that the female politicians -- regardless of age, race or their paths to elected office -- shared a common characteristic, what many of them described as an intense desire to have an impact on issues.
"What it comes down to is a passion," said the county's District Attorney, Jeanine Pirro, 45. "It's in our blood.".
Or as Ms. Singer described it, "We burn with all these fevers, this need to be present on the issues."
For the most part, those passions are directed at issues directly affecting women and their families -- what Dr. Ester Fuchs, a professor of political science at Columbia University, called "the kinder and gentler issues."
For District Attorney Pirro, those issues have included domestic violence and child abuse. For Representative Lowey, who was co-chairwoman of the Congressional Caucus on Women's Issues, it has been financial support for fighting breast cancer. Councilwoman Brandon of Yonkers has focused on the needs of children and health care for the mostly poor and minority constituents in her district. And Lois T. Bronz, a Democratic County Legislator from Greenburgh, said she has similarly focused on the housing concerns and human services needed by her minority constituents in a middle- and low-income district of Westchester's largest town.
"These are quality-of-life issues," Mrs. Lowey said. "Men share those concerns, but they focus more on jobs and the economy. By contrast, women bring a lifetime of personal passions to politics."
Or as Ms. Paulin said: "It's not that men are unsympathetic. They're just not as aware of these issues as women. Somehow, life has divided us."
Ms. Singer, however, said, "I'd like to see more women get up and talk about Bosnia and economics."
Eager though they were to contribute to the political process, the women said their efforts were not always welcome.
"I have a coffee cup that keeps reminding me of how difficult politics can be for us," said Vincenza A. Restiano, 48, a Republican, who is President of the Yonkers City Council. "It says that the ladder to success is harder to climb in high heels. This is true.
"So how do I crack the old boys' network? By showing them I can get the vote. I get the satisfaction when I go to the polls."
When Mrs. Galef first became a County Legislator and worked late into the evening, she said a fellow politician once told her to go home and cook for her husband.
"Another time a group of women Legislators were working around a table when one of the male Legislators came in and said, 'Oh, look, the housewives are doing the County budget,' " she said.
"We told him thank you, we were doing a very good job."
Mrs. Bronz, who is 69, said she experienced the most opposition from black men. "Not only did I have have to prove that I knew what I was doing and where I was going, but I had to learn to build a partnership with them," she said. "At first, they were extremely critical. Nothing that I was doing was right."
On the other hand, Mrs. Lowey, a member of the House Appropriations Committee, said she never experienced any resistance from her male counterparts, although Washington, when she first arrived there, was clearly male dominated.
"There were only three gynecologists on the staff of the National Institutes of Health," she said. "Even the lab rats were all males. That has since changed."
Expressing another difficulty for them, many of the women said that campaign contributions were harder to come by for female politicians, although they conceded that they were less adept than men at raising money.
Emily's List, a national political-action committee, which backs Democratic candidates who favor abortion rights, has made available more than $50,000 in campaign donations from across the country. Emily is an acronym for Early Money Is Like Yeast.
The goal of Eleanor's List, another political action committee, is to get more Democratic women who favor abortion rights into the New York State Legislature.
Professor Fuchs at Columbia University said that the women's difficulties in raising campaign funds kept their numbers in politics low.
She also said that it was not unusual for female officeholders, like Representative Susan Molinari of New York and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, to come from political families.
"Not only do the women have a harder time raising money but it is difficult sometimes for them to break into politics," she said. "It is not an accident that Susan Molinari or Christine Todd Whitman are successful. They had someone showing them the ropes."
But Steven A. Galef, Mrs. Galef's husband, observed that women can often afford to go into low-paying political jobs -- for example, in the County Legislature -- when men cannot. Mr. Galef, a lawyer and a Democratic County Legislator from 1976 to 1980, said he chose not to continue because he could not afford to give up his law practice and devote full time to county business.

HEADLINE: WORK

The author has the temerity to tell those of us who do work how we have to function in order to get the unproductive members of society out of their beds and off their duffs. Then, to top it off, we have to bring the jobs to them. 
 It is an insult to everyone in the United States who goes to work every day for Wilson to use Western European democracies with homogeneous populations as a yardstick. Those countries allow almost no immigration; their societies share the same cultural values, attributes and language. Their children attain the same basic educational levels.

HEADLINE: WORK

 BODY:
Wilson informs us that work "constitutes a framework for daily behavior because it imposes discipline." But is someone really employable before he learns discipline, and when is that instilled? I suspect very early in life. We do have data indicating that inner-city black youths who grow up attending church or mosque and/or live in two-parent families do much better statistically in school, are much less likely to commit crimes or use drugs and usually end up gainfully employed. Where do they find jobs? They commute on public transportation to jobs in other sections of the city. How many Americans, even urban dwellers, white or black, have the luxury of walking to work?
 
STUART CREIGHTON MILLER
Truro, Mass.

HEADLINE: WORK

 BODY:
As one who reached maturity in the Great Depression, I remember well the accomplishments of the W.P.A. and feel strongly that something of that nature is what we need today.
 As a young newspaper reporter, I can recall asking a W.P.A. administrator about the "wastefulness" of some of its projects. (For example, dozens of men with snow shovels laboring -- or, as some critics complained, merely leaning on their shovels -- to complete a job that could have been accomplished by one man with power equipment in about the same time.) His answer was: "We're not trying to do the most efficient job. We're trying to create jobs where none now exist." Rather than collecting "welfare" checks, workers had the satisfaction of feeling that they had earned the income they received. 
 And it was not only manual laborers who found work under this program. The W.P.A. recognized that artists and writers, actors and playwrights also had to buy groceries.
Less widely known were the activities of the Civilian Conservation Corps. Its work was largely in forestry, national parks etc. With the importance of conservation today, this program, too, might be revived.
 
RICHARD M. HEMENWAY
Block Island, R.I.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Fate of a Derelict Mill Clouds Patchogue's Future

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: PATCHOGUE

 BODY:
THE first thing that visitors from the west see as they enter this South Shore village is a complex of dilapidated red-brick factory buildings, which many say is a prime cause of the community's deteriorating fortunes.
The sprawling former lace mill, its windows boarded up and extensive fire damage visible from the street, occupies a 12.5-acre site between West Main Street and Waverly Avenue. 
 The complex consists of six interconnected buildings with more than 200,000 square feet of space, towered over by a giant smokestack and a clock tower.
Proposals ranging from boutiques to condominiums have fallen by the wayside as the mill deteriorated over the years. New investment has been deterred, a third of the stores lining Main Street are vacant and residential values have been dragged down.
Nevertheless, a proposal by Roizman Development of Norristown, Pa., a developer of rental housing, to turn the 19th-century structures into a $22 million housing project for people over the age of 55 was rejected by the village's Board of Trustees Sept. 3.
The developers need a special permit to build housing on the industrially zoned site and its purchase from the owner, 225 West Main Street Corporation of Patchogue, is contingent on getting that approval.
The denial of the permit may face a court challenge by the developers.
"We didn't anticipate opposition to senior housing and we've invested between $400,000 to $500,000 in this project in engineering studies, architectural fees and cleaning up the location," said Robert J. Joy, the vice president of Roizman Development. "Right now we are exploring several options, and leaning toward litigation."
Mayor Stephen E. Keegan defended his board's decision, saying, "Since this is the last piece of industrially zoned land on Main Street, we felt that the highest and best use would not be housing."
Patchogue was most successful when the lace mill provided jobs, the Mayor noted, adding that now the best thing to do would be to demolish the existing buildings and use the site for commercial development.
Back taxes of almost $200,000 are owed to the village and an additional $700,000 is owed to Suffolk County, he said, adding that the village intended to foreclose on the owners.
"My vision for that property is to see a 21st century lace mill, whether it would be a bank back office or a credit card or an insurance company, but something that would bring jobs to the community," he said.
Preservationists say that if the lace mill buildings were demolished, Patchogue would lose a historic identity that sets it apart from other communities.
"Patchogue will be a much less interesting place because of their decision," said John Auwaerter, program analyst for the New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation.
THE state agency had urged village officials to approve the development proposal to insure "the preservation and continued use of Patchogue's most prominent complex of historic buildings."
"These buildings, with this great high looming smokestack that was the hallmark of industry, jut up like the cathedrals of their landscape, dominating everything," said George E. Thomas, historic consultant to Roizman Development and a lecturer on historic preservation at the University of Pennsylvania.
"As you turn into Patchogue you see this cluster of brick buildings with wonderful arched heads over the windows and with the scale and majesty that at least in America only industry could provide in our villages."
The complex was built in phases between 1880 and 1920, using the water power of the Patchogue River originally to produce cotton twine that could be used in weaving rugs and, later, to produce crinolines and laces. As the mill prospered and expanded, it provided employment for up to 800 people and built a thriving local economy.
"The story of the community was written around the lace mill," Dr. Thomas said. "We all too often lose the touchstone buildings that tell our story and that would be the big loss here."
Roizman had originally proposed 250 apartments, using five of six existing buildings and adding some new construction. Income limits would have been applied because the developers expected to use Federal tax credits available for the production of housing affordable to households making 60 percent or less of the area's median income.
But that raised fears in the community that a low-income housing project was being proposed.
Those fears persist even though the plan was subsequently scaled back to 140 units, all of them within the existing structures. Occupancy was to be limited to older people, with one family member at least 55 old and children under 19 not allowed. A single person could have had an annual income of up to $27,960 and a two-person household up to $31,920. Proposed rent ranges were $584 monthly for a 845-square-foot, one-bedroom, $842 for a 1,000-square-foot, two-bedroom and $967 for a 1,200-square-foot three-bedroom.
An economic impact analysis prepared for the developers by Lee E. Koppelman, executive director of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, and by Thomas Conoscenti, an economist, found that not only was housing for the aging greatly needed, but the proposed project would have yielded $200,000 annually in net taxes and generated more than $3 million annually for the region's economy.
"It would have put shoppers on Main Street, which it sorely needs, and it would have cleared up a blight that is like an anchor weighing everything else down," said David A. Sloane, a Hauppauge lawyer who represents Roizman.
The developers expected to apply for tax credits available to projects that meet strict state and Federal criteria for historic preservation.
ALTHOUGH the interiors would have been gutted, the facades would all have been retained, along with the smokestack and clock tower. The building shapes, the large window openings, and the high ceilings would have permitted apartments with spacious layouts and lots of light, said Richard J. Kline, vice president of GGK Architects of Philadelphia, the project's designer. A four-acre parcel at the west end of the site would have been donated to the village.
Opponents of the project found its sponsors' arguments unconvincing.
"The question is, 'Why add rentals if the village's existing 2,000 rental units that have been there for years haven't produced any economic activity?' " said Martin R. Cantor, a former Suffolk County Commissioner of Economic Development.
He had also been a consultant to the village for its ongoing plan to develop the community as a tourist destination with a maritime center and other attractions.
Instead of shopping locally, he said, "people go to malls and outlet centers to spend their money."
A group of investors has proposed building a minor-league baseball stadium on the property, with a 5,000- to 6,000-seat capacity. Forty-five home games a year would bring in 3,000 to 4,000 visitors each time, said Michael Barsanti, a member of the group called Patchogue Professional Baseball. Parking behind stores would provide some of the off-site spaces that would be needed and that would help Main Street merchants, he said.
Ronald Bush, a local real estate broker who was involved in putting together the Roizman deal, called the stadium plan "ridiculous," because of parking problems, because it was seasonal and because of the danger that the team could founder, "leaving Patchogue with a big, empty stadium."
Mr. Bush said anyone purchasing the property would have to spend $1 million demolishing the buildings and another $1 million to pay back taxes.
"For the past 30 years I did three comprehensive plans for the site, " said Dr. Koppelman of the Regional Planning Board. "This was not the only project proposed, but this developer was going to put in the investment needed to revitalize this site."
"My hope was that this project might act as a catalyst for improving the whole situation, but my arguments fell on deaf ears," he said. "The end result is that the village could sit with that derelict mess for another 30 years."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Jersey City's Waterfront Showing Signs of an Upturn

BYLINE: By By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
A ROLLER-COASTER office market took the commercial revitalization of the Hudson River waterfront here from the heights of the mid-80's to the depths of the early 90's, when construction ground to a halt. But in the years since, the riverfront has slowly rebounded, rekindling interest in building at the water's edge.
At the northern end of the riverfront, the Lefrak Organization of Rego Park, Queens, is gearing up to build the 17-story, 750,000-square-foot Newport Office Centre III at its 400-acre Newport Center mixed-used project. About a mile south, on Colgate-Palmolive's 20-acre Colgate Center site, once occupied by a toothpaste factory, plans are advancing for a 12-story 435,000-square-foot building. 
 Both projects have their approvals in place and will move forward once tenants are found to sign preconstruction leases, which are needed to obtain construction financing. The Lefrak Organization said it would build after 30 percent of its building was preleased. Colgate said it would go ahead when it had a tenant for half the space.
Many commercial brokers say the plans reflect the strengthening of the office market along the Hudson County portion of the waterfront in general and of Jersey City's in particular. In turn, they said, the next round of office construction is not far behind.
"The waterfront has been a major growth corridor for North Jersey since 1984 and since then Jersey City has given companies a lot of justification to move there," said Robert P. Antonicello, president of the ACI Group, a local real estate services concern. "It is no longer a frontier. "
In that time some 8.6 million square feet of offices were built, initially for a flow of financial services companies from Manhattan seeking larger and less expensive space. A 1.2-million-square-foot regional mall was also constructed, as were thousands of residences within the waterfront redevelopment district, which stretches for 1.7 miles along the riverfront and roughly eight blocks inland.
But then the 1987 stock market crash, followed by the real estate recession, stemmed the flow of tenants, leaving the riverfront with blocks of empty space and a vacancy rate that as recent as 1992 was as high as 36 percent. Under current zoning, at least 13.4 million more square feet of offices can be built on the remaining land in the district.
Steady leasing activity over the last three years has chipped away much of that available inventory. "Tenants looking for 100,000 square feet of prime space have no place to go," said Edwin H. Cohen, executive director at the East Rutherford office of the Cushman & Wakefield brokerage, which is marketing Newport Centre III.
AS of the first half of the year, Jersey City's waterfront had a vacancy rate of 8.9 percent, down from 12 percent a year ago; the rate for class A space fell to 7.2 percent from 10.6 percent a year ago, according to Cushman & Wakefield. As a result, average asking rents rose to $25.58 from $24.29 for all space and to $28.09 from $26.89 for prime space, among the highest in the 11-county northern New Jersey market.
Steven M. Frank, a first vice president at the Teaneck office of the CB Commercial brokerage, added that many tenants nearing the end of leases had not only renewed but expanded in Jersey City.
Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the Manhattan-based investment firm, for example, just expanded by 73,200 square feet to just under 400,000 square feet at the 600,000-square-foot Cali Financial Tower on the Jersey City riverfront. And M.H. Meyerson, another securities firm, recently moved from Montgomery Street in Jersey City to the nearby Newport Office Tower along the water's edge, doubling its space to 30,000 square feet.
"Everyone expected that after companies initially jumped over the river they would migrate westward," Mr. Frank said. But that has not happened, creating a need for new space from within the market as well, he added.
Space along the rest of the Hudson County portion of the riverfront is also being absorbed. Even the long-vacant 300,000-square-foot building on Boulevard East in Weehawken has contracts signed but not yet closed with two tenants for half the building, said Seena Stein, president of Newmark Partners, the Mountainside-based brokerage that is marketing the building. "The waterfront is ripe for new construction," she said.
Yet while financing for new construction has become more available, it is still dependent on finding a tenant. Brokers said there were big users known to be shopping for space, including Federated Department Stores. The unknown is whether they will land in Jersey City.
Despite New York City's resolve to improve its downtown and retain companies, many brokers and owners believe Jersey City's waterfront will continue to draw tenants, and not only those tied to the financial sector.
In recent years a few telecommunications companies, including USA Networks and Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, have located there.
Among the city's other advantages, Mr. Antonicello said, are its mass transportation links, including three PATH stations near the water's edge, the ferry service to Manhattan as well as the planned light rail line through the riverfront. There is no corporate occupancy tax and the area is a state-designated urban enterprise zone, where most corporate tenants pay no sales tax.
In addition, companies relocating to or expanding anywhere in New Jersey can take advantage of financial incentives offered through a state program begun in May. Up to 80 percent of the personal income tax revenue generated by each new employee brought on the tax rolls can be returned to the companies for up to 10 years.
THE more than 3,000 waterfront residences built or under way bolster the office sector by providing housing to employees and bringing life to the area after the offices close.
Mindful that more offices are in the works, Robert Cotter, Jersey City's planning director, said the waterfront master plan was being reviewed to encourage more of that mix along the first two blocks inland from the river's edge.
The developers of the planned office buildings said that those factors, along with technologically up-to-date buildings, would help them snag anchor tenants. Marketing for both began this summer.
Newport Centre III will join two office buildings now at the mixed-use site. One, with 450,000 square feet, is occupied by Recruit U.S.A, a Tokyo-based computer services company.
The other, the million-square-foot Newport Tower, is nearly fully leased with tenants including First Chicago Trust and USA Networks. The complex is also home to the 1.2-million-foot mall and 2,300 residences.
Richard S. LeFrak, president of the Lefrak Organization, said the new building was "very efficient, ready to go," and in a 24-hour, seven-day-a-week, walk-to-work environment. "People tend to bring in more people," he said.
Mr. Cohen of Cushman & Wakefield said, "a lot of tenants are looking hard and heavy for space, not just kicking tires."
At the Colgate Center, the new building, 90 Hudson Street, is to be one-third the size of its sister building, 101 Hudson Street. Now over 90 percent leased, that 1.2-million-square-foot building was built to specification for Merrill Lynch, which has half the space.
Peter Gilpatric, project executive for the Colgate site, said that with 90 Hudson Street "we have created a building we believe will give tenants what they want." He said the new building was smaller because financing would be easier to obtain.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Sites of planned 17-story, 750,000-square-foot Newport Office Centre III, left, and 12-story, 435,000-square-foot 90 Hudson Street at Colgate Center. (Photographs by Mitsu Yasukawa for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Six Flags Wants to March Into Tourist Territory

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
WITH six of the state's seven top tourist attractions already in place, one about to open and another on its way, southeastern Connecticut may get still more destinations and millions of visitors if proposals for two entertainment complexes are realized.
Six Flags Theme Parks Inc. has proposed a $200 million amusement park on 200 acres off Interstate 95 in North Stonington, which it estimates would attract as many as four million people a year, about four times the number of people that now visit the region each year. 
 A Six Flags spokeswoman, Lauren Hurvitz, said the park would employ 2,000 to 3,000 people on a seasonal basis, and 200 to 300 year-round.
The site, midway between Boston and New York, would tap into a huge new market, said Ms. Hurvitz, noting that it was one of the nation's few metropolitan markets that is not within a five-hour drive of a theme park.
A few miles south on I-95 in Groton, Fun-Plex Inc. has proposed a $20 million development on 115 acres that would include educational and recreational computer simulations.
"This region is already the destination of eight out of 10 tourists who come to Connecticut, so it makes sense that they would want to be here," said the Groton Town Manager, Ronald P. LeBlanc. "It's clear that tourism is going to continue to grow, and will be a stable part of our economy in the future."
But not everyone is in favor of the new proposals. A new regional organization called Not a Done Deal, which is still mustering a membership, has sprung up to oppose the Six Flags project because of concerns that it will add to already heavy traffic generated by the Foxwoods Resort Casino a few miles up Route 2.
Members are also concerned about Six Flags attracting increased commercial development to the region, and other impacts on rural North Stonington, said Douglas J. Carocari, a fourth-generation North Stonington resident and founder of the town's Citizens Land Alliance who is also working for Not a Done Deal.
Nevertheless, both municipal officials and business leaders expect approvals of both Six Flags and Fun-Plex within a year, with construction taking about two years.
George T. Donnelly of Connecticut's Mystic & More, a local tourism promotion bureau, said studies that his agency commissioned showed the percentage of tourists spending two nights or more in the region had increased from 28 to 73 percent from 1994 to 1995. Spending increased from an average of $313.59 per tourist, to $457.09, during the same period.
Those statistics show Six Flags and Fun-Plex are following the tourists to southeastern Connecticut, rather than drawing them, Mr. Donnelly said.
"But if it were not for new ventures, tourism would not only flatten out, it would die off," Mr. Donnelly said. "If you want to keep people coming back to a region, you have to offer them something new."
Tourism has long been a part of the region's economy. Key attractions are Mystic Seaport, Mystic Aquarium, the Nautilus Submarine Memorial in Groton, the Coast Guard Academy and Ocean Beach Park in New London and Foxwoods Resort Casino in Ledyard. State tourism officials say the region already draws more than a million visitors a year.
Two additional major attractions are in prospect -- OceanQuest, a marine sciences educational camp in New London, and the Mohegan Sun Casino in Montville. Site clearing has begun on the former and the casino is scheduled to open Oct. 12.
Ms. Hurvitz of Six Flags, which operates 12 theme parks around the country, said her company looked forward to "cross-marketing opportunities."
"We think there's a real potential to get people to stay in the area long enough to see everything," she said.
Ms. Hurvitz said the park would pay $2 million in property taxes each year, in addition to $10 million in state sales and amusement taxes. And tourists would spend an estimated $3 in the local economy for every $1 spent at the park, she added.
WHILE the Six Flags park will not be able to operate year-round because of the harsh New England winters, Ms. Hurvitz noted that the park park in Gurnee, Ill., outside Chicago, was a financial success even though the seasons there are similar to those in the Northeast.
Ms. Hurvitz said the company was sensitive to some opposition over the fact that the proposed site sits atop one of the state's largest aquifers and other environmental considerations. But she noted that its park in San Antonio had been built over an aquifer as well, with ample safeguards to protect the groundwater.
Arthur V. Pintauro, chairman of the North Stonington Planning and Zoning Commission, noted that a Legoland theme park had been proposed for the same industrially zoned site three years ago. But its Danish sponsor decided to build in Carlsbad, Calif., instead.
"They kind of made us ask the question, 'What if a theme park comes in?' " Mr. Pintauro said. "So for the last few years we've been trying to figure out how to measure the impact of something like a Six Flags, how to stack up all the pluses, and all the minuses."
On the plus side, he said, there are the new jobs and taxes; on the minus, the potential impact on schools, roads, city services, and so forth.
"We haven't put our arms around this yet, we don't know what to expect," Mr. Pintauro said. "Things are changing and we still have to come to grips with it."
While fewer specifics are available on the Fun-Plex proposal, Mr. LeBlanc, the Groton Town Manager, said his conversations with the company's executives had been encouraging.
"It's the family-type recreation we're looking for, in an area of town that we want to encourage development and it doesn't pose any significant environmental hazard," Mr. LeBlanc said.
Planners are urging caution because of the magnitude of the proposed operations. Richard B. Erickson, director of the Southeastern Connecticut Council of Governments, said traffic was a major consideration.
"Most of the local highways are not near the point of gridlock," said Mr. Erickson. It's more a question of at what point does the congestion reach a point where it's no longer acceptable, For some people, I think we're well past that point already."
But many are anxious to work out solutions. William D. Moore, executive director of the Southeastern Connecticut Chamber of Commerce, said a study last year commissioned by the nonprofit Corporation for Regional Economic Development, based in New London, had concluded that tourism was a segment of the economy that should be promoted. It specified the region should try to attract a theme park.
The proposals for the two entertainment complexes "will force the State Department of Transportation to make some decisions, particularly with regard to Route 11," Mr. Moore said. Route 11 was once planned as a limited access connector between Hartford and I-95 in Waterford. But it fell 10 miles short of its southern goal when the state ran out of money.
Mr. Moore said the proposals could create some spinoff development. The region's 6,400 hotel rooms already operate at near capacity for most of the summer, he said, and Foxwoods is building 1,000 more.
"You're going to see even more hotels built," Mr. Moore predicted. "And once the tourists come in the summer and see what we have to offer, you're going to start filling them up in the shoulder seasons, March to May and September to November."
BUT Mr. Carocari of Citizens Land Alliance remains firmly opposed to the new tourism proposals. "I don't want to live in a resort community," he said.
Promoters have touted the jobs and tax revenues the parks would bring, he said. But the development would also bring increased costs entailing the probable establishment of full-time police and fire departments, hiring building inspectors and beefing up its road improvement budget.
"If it ends up lowering my taxes even $50 a year, I would be surprised, and is that worth giving up our quality of life?" Mr. Carocari asked. "I don't think the town will become a more affordable place to live, but it will become a less desirable place to live.
"And as far as the jobs go, you're going to bring in a lot of seasonal positions that are low skill, low pay, not the kind of jobs that allow people to move into a town and raise families," Mr. Carocari said. "Basically, you'd have 4,000 kids partying all summer long -- and that's not the community where I want to raise my family."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Arthur V. Pintauro, chairman of the North Stonington Planning and Zoning Commission, at possible Six Flags amusement park site. (George Ruhe for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Incentives Are Luring Buyers to Bucks County

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE 

 BODY:
DEVELOPERS in a fast-growing, competitive market for single-family homes have started using time-tested car dealer tactics like financial incentives and short-term promotions to lure move-up buyers to Bucks County, a 40-minute drive northwest from downtown Philadelphia.
Prices for detached homes have declined in the last year to an average of $248,000 in the popular hilly rural area, which draws many people who commute to work 90 minutes by rail to New York City. 
 Despite the strongest market for single-family homes in this year's first half since 1992, the Orleans Corporation has revived a seasonal offer of cash rebates on home purchases, and Realen Homes, recently advertising 36 houses, invited buyers to "make us an offer."
The technique is employed by large developers trying to maintain the momentum of construction and a steady revenue stream. Such companies can afford to shave a few thousand dollars off sales prices of certain homes or are able to provide below-market mortgages to motivate buyers.
In some cases, these developers bought property from smaller, cash-strapped concerns during the downturn of the early 1990's, and there is now a rivalry for a market share. Bucks County has been a center of suburban home development for 20 years, and some towns, like Warwick and Newtown, have seen their population more than double since the early 80's.
According to a survey conducted in May by the the National Association of Home Builders, only about 6 percent of builders nationwide said they offered interest rates below market rates earlier this year; of those, most took a percentage point off a buyer's mortgage rate.
Since August of last year, Orleans has offered buyers a credit at closing of 6 percent of their old home's price, 4 percent of the new home price or the commission for selling the old house, whichever is lowest. Buyers may also opt to delay construction of their new home while locking in the price. If the old house has not yet sold, the amount of the credit is made contingent upon the price eventually obtained. With the credit offer in hand, buyers feel free to use more of their cash resources in their purchase.
Most purchases under its Trade Up program cost Orleans slightly less than 4 percent of the new purchase price, said John P. White, the company's vice president for sales administration. Its homes typically sell for $200,000 to $400,000. The company has also developed an appraisal service and list of suggested realtors to help buyers sell existing homes.
"The most it would cost us is 4 percent of the new home," Mr. White said. "But there has to be an appraisal on the old property; we specify a list of agents it can be listed with to insure a fair market value and that it's going to be marketed aggressively. I think it makes the difference in whether buyers can buy or not."
THE program has been offered twice by Orleans, the region's second-largest home builder. Based in Bensalem, Pa., it sold 497 homes in this area in 1995, ranking it behind the publicly traded Toll Brothers, according to the Legg Mason Realty Group. About 75 sales used the Trade Up program, said Gary Schaal, executive vice president for sales and marketing at Orleans.
"The main effect it's having is bringing people to our home sites," he said. "We see a lot of families who are first-time move-up buyers. We thought we'd see a lot of people with zero equity. Home equity is a disappearing commodity and we felt equity was a big reason why people weren't moving up."
The program enabled Thomas and Marcy Liberta to delay construction at the Deer Run development, near Doylestown, Pa., in Bucks County, until they sold a town house in Collegeville, about 40 minutes away. Making the move was a nightmare, they said. It took nearly a year to sell the town house and the couple and their daughter had to live with relatives for four months until their new home was ready, Mr. Liberta said.
"The move was driven by a new company I was working for and it took a while to actually pick up and move," Mr. Liberta said. "It was about a year from the time I changed jobs. We were willing to sit it out and weren't going to give our house away just to get out."
A building boom in Collegeville made older town houses such as the Libertas's difficult to sell, he said. He had to give concessions to his buyer, offer some appliances and agree to an earlier closing date than he preferred. The Libertas moved into their new home on April 15 after selling the old house for $115,000. The new four-bedroom, two-and-a-half bathroom house cost $200,000.
What led him to buy was the location and affordability of the new house, Mr. Liberta said, but the incentives clinched the deal. "If it had been a free fireplace or something like that, another element with cash value attached to it, it would have had less impact on us," he said. "If the incentive was worth $6,000 on a mortgage over 30 years, that doesn't mean a whole lot."
Other area developers have selectively offered incentives such as contingency sales (the lot is held for construction, which begins after the old house is sold) and "free" amenities like fireplaces or cathedral ceilings, which might otherwise increase the home's price. Other incentives include special mortgage rates or reduced premium charges on choice lots.
Gopal Ahluwalia, director of research at the National Association of Home Builders, said incentive programs reached their peak during soft housing markets like the recession of the early 1990's. The May survey by the trade group found few builders offering financial benefits, but those doing so were large-volume builders in Northeast and Western states, he added.
"This seems to be a program of large-volume builders," Mr. Ahluwalia said. "Only 2 percent of the small-volume builders were doing this. But 20 percent of large-volume builders were buying mortgage rates, and some were buying some of the points. It's the large-volume builder who has the greatest number of homes to sell, to generate cash flow and build their profit."
Such incentives are an open secret, available to buyers who ask but rarely offered in advertisements, said Adriane Jones, market manager at Legg Mason Realty Group. Large builders offer benefits to spur business while others simply wait out the slow periods.
"It's become a sensitive topic," she said. "More and more people are using them, but they don't want to discuss them. Most builders seem to be willing to work with buyers so they'll do everything they can to satisfy the buyer. A lot of builders wait and see what buyers are interested in. If the buyer isn't interested in a fireplace, then offering one won't make a difference."
HOME buyers who capitalize on incentive programs might not otherwise move into new homes. For John Kent and Juliann Rostelli-Kent, a $7,000 bonus from Orleans cut their mortgage to $175,000 and enabled a contingency sale. Both Mr. Kent and his wife had to sell properties before purchasing their new four-bedroom house. The wait was nerve-racking, they said, and both also spent time living with parents until the new house was finished.
"The important thing is I got out," Mr. Kent said. "If we hadn't sold, we would have had to give up that lot. But we looked at a lot of places and we decided that was the one we wanted."

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
3 More Months to Answer A 20-Year-Old Riddle

BYLINE: By Jennifer Preston; Jennifer Preston is Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
The State Supreme Court cut the Legislature some slack last week when the justices granted lawmakers a three-month extension to come up with a new school-financing plan.
It had become increasingly clear in recent weeks that the Legislature would never meet this month's court-imposed deadline. Neither the Assembly nor the Senate, both controlled by Republicans, is expected back into session until October. And legislative leaders are not even close to reaching agreement with the Whitman administration on a proposal that would end the two-decade court battle over school-aid formulas without jeopardizing their political careers. 
 Over the summer, it became evident to many Republican lawmakers, who represent the more affluent suburban communities, that some of their constituents were unhappy with Governor Whitman's proposal. A growing number of suburban parents notified their lawmakers that they did not support any plan that threatened the level of spending in their school districts. They sent thousands of letters to the Governor's office saying the plan could jeopardize the high quality of public education they have come to expect.
Under the Whitman plan, new statewide curriculum standards would be imposed and school boards would be required by the state to cover only the cost of implementing those standards -- a one-size-fits-all program at the same price. Thus, school spending is equalized in rich and poor districts. But more than half of the state's school districts, particularly wealthy suburban districts in the northern part of the state, spend much more than what the Whitman administration says is necessary and offer more programs, like advanced-placement courses, that many parents do not want to give up.
The plan would allow cities and towns to approve any increases above what the Governor has deemed "constitutionally required." But many parents and educators worry that overburdened property-tax payers might be persuaded to reject any spending that is described as unnecessary to meet what Mrs. Whitman describes as "world class" curriculum standards.
And now suburban parents have formed an alliance with parents and advocates from urban parents who never supported the Governor's proposal because it does not provide enough money to close the existing spending gap between the richest and poorest districts.
"When this whole thing started, they were just trying to pit the urban against the suburban school districts," said Molly R. Emiliani, a parent with five children in Livingston's public schools who has become the parent coordinator for the Garden State Coalition, a group that represents suburban districts.
"That is not the case at all," Ms Emiliani said. "The urban and suburban districts have joined hands and said that this does not help any of the districts. We are not going to stop until we close the gap and it is equal for all the kids."
Until the suburban parents began showing their political might, Democrats, who represent mostly urban districts and who wield little power in the Legislature, stood no chance of seeing their Republican colleagues make any major changes to the Governor's plan. But now, this issue has become a tricky problem for Republicans.
In the Assembly, Republican leaders are pushing for a provision that would maintain current spending levels in the wealthy districts. The Senate version would allow districts to put just a portion of their budgets above what is "constitutionally required" up for a local vote. Some districts fear that they could lose as much as 20 percent of their budget in one year if voters reject spending above what is needed to meet the new statewide standards.
But last week the Governor raised concerns about whether the court would accept language protecting the spending levels of the wealthier districts. Those concerns are well founded: by letting the affluent districts to continue to offer more than what the children in the poorer districts can get, the amendment would destroy the entire premise of the Whitman plan.
The late Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz had set the September deadline and had reserved the right to impose a court-ordered financing plan if the Legislature failed to act this month. He had also wanted to resolve the issue before his retirement, which had been scheduled for next February. He died of cancer in July.
In granting the Legislature a reprieve from the September deadline, the Supreme Court last week concluded that lawmakers and the administration were making progress. The court said it lifted the deadline because "the Legislature is actively considering legislation to address its obligations."
Yet anyone familiar with the inner workings of the Legislature knows that this is one body in need of a strict deadline -- and heavy sanctions, if it's not met.
Take charity care, for example. The source of state financing to help hospitals cover the cost of providing treatment to the uninsured expired last December. As the Legislature dickered over finding a new solution, hospitals delayed payments to vendors, and in some cases laid off staff. Six months later, lawmakers agreed on a new financing plan that turned out to look very much like the old one, depending heavily on the state's unemployment compensation trust fund to foot the bill.
But all during that time, the Legislature was "actively considering legislation to address its obligations."
