HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
Debating The Merits Of Wetlands And Stores

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD

 BODY:
The proposed Meadowlands Mills mall in Carlstadt promises to be BIG. It would cover 2.4 million square feet, making it the largest shopping center in New Jersey. There would be 2.2 million square feet of office space, 50,000 square feet of restaurants, 1,000 hotel rooms, 150,000 square feet of light industrial space. Not to mention 9,000 new jobs, 17,000 parking spaces and a new exit ramp off the New Jersey Turnpike just so people can get to the mall site, which, at 594 acres, would be almost three quarters of the size of Central Park.
But big suggests big trouble to some people concerned about the implications of the project proposed by the Mills Corporation of Arlington, Va., and Empire Ltd. of Wood-Ridge. They are dismayed that the project would require 206 acres of wetlands to be filled with dredged material. They are wary of more traffic. And they wonder whether northern New Jersey really needs so many new places to shop. 
 For now, the $1 billion project is only in the preliminary stages; the Army Corps of Engineers is considering whether to issue a permit allowing the wetlands to be filled.
But what is sure to be a passionate, protracted debate has already started. Just listen to the comments made Wednesday, when more than 300 people attended hearings at Henry P. Becton Regional High School here, sponsored by the Army Corps of Engineers:
Bill Sheehan, the river tender for the Hackensack Estuary and River Tender Corporation, likened the project to "domestic violence" on the environment. To which the next speaker, Craig S. Wask, representing Local 825 of the International Union of Operating Engineers, retorted, "We're more important than any fish, any bird, any plant in the Meadowlands."
When Meadowlands Mills was originally proposed several years ago, the project included 5,700 residential units. Carlstadt officials, objecting to the prospect of tripling the town's population of 5,500, filed suit against the Mills Corporation and the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission, the state agency that acts as a supergovernment for the parts of 14 towns that make up the Meadowlands district. A settlement was reached in April, dropping the housing.
The revised plan features a two-level structure with 18 to 20 anchor stores, 200 specialty stores and a 30-screen movie complex.
If the Army Corps of Engineers approves, ground could be broken next summer, and the mall could be open in the spring of 1999.
To the Mills Corporation, which specializes in megamalls offering brand-name merchandise at discount prices at stores like TJ Maxx, Bed Bath and Beyond, and Nordstrom Rack, the Meadowlands site makes sense because of the demographics: 15.5 million people with an annual household income of $62,000 living within 40 miles.
"We are more than just a shopping experience; we are a destination," said Edward B. Vinson, Mills's development director, adding that the average shopper at Mills projects spends four hours per visit -- more than three times longer than a customer at a regional mall.
Mr. Vinson also said the mall would produce sizable economic benefits. Construction work alone would generate 2,500 jobs, which speakers at Wednesday's hearing said were desperately needed.
The state could get $15 million annually in sales tax receipts. In Carlstadt, property taxes could be reduced by up to 40 percent, said Mayor William Roseman. And other municipalities in the Hackensack Meadowlands district would split up to 10 percent of the estimated $3 million that the Mills project would pay in property taxes, he said.
Some residents remain unconvinced by these fiscal calculations. "How can people be so naive to think there will be tax relief?" Elizabeth Moser of Hasbrouck Heights said at the hearing. "They will need larger police departments and larger fire departments, and on top of it, the courts will be clogged with more and more cases, which are expensive."
Some businesses wonder how badly the project would hurt already struggling downtowns and other area malls. The nearby Garden State Plaza just expanded to 2 million square feet, and a 3.99 million-square-foot project, which would be the country's second biggest mall, has been proposed in West Nyack, N.Y., 45 minutes away.
For local residents, the biggest concern may well be traffic. Janine Bauer, executive director of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, estimated that the mall would generate at least 100,000 more car trips in the area daily.
To alleviate that crush, the Mills Corporation has proposed building a new road parallel to the New Jersey Turnpike, a new exit ramp off the turnpike and a mass transit center for possible links to light rail.
This has not satisfied everybody.
"If you think people are going to spend money on the New Jersey Turnpike to get into this thing, you're out of your mind," said Erwin Fedhenheuer, chairman of Carlstadt's planning board. "They're going to take the cheapest way; that's what I would do."
Environmentalists are alarmed that the project could be approved without a Federal environmental impact study because of the special nature of the government of the Meadowlands district, even though the wetlands have already dwindled from 20,000 acres to about 6,000.
"This is the single largest destruction of wetlands since 1972, and it's being proposed in the most densely populated county in the most densely populated state in the nation," said an exasperated William J. Cahill, an attorney with the Rutgers Environmental Law Clinic. "Where do you break the back of the system? Which acre is it going to be?"

HEADLINE: CUTTINGS;
Young Man's Obsession: The American Chestnut

BYLINE: By Anne Raver 

 BODY:
Timothy Van Vliet is one of those intense 17-year-olds who's madly in love. But it's the American chestnut that captured his heart.
"I read about it in 'The Complete Trees of America' when I was 12," said Tim, now a senior at Somerville (N.J.) High School. "I'm kind of a naturalist anyway, and I kept wondering what the whole Northeast looked like before people came here. When millions of passenger pigeons nested in the branches." 
 If anything is an archetype for the lost wilderness, it's the American chestnut. It used to soar 80 to 125 feet into the sky, its deeply furrowed trunk 8 to 10 feet across, earning it the name Eastern Redwood.
In the late 1800's, according to the American Chestnut Foundation, a squirrel could have traveled from Maine to Georgia without ever leaving the branches of a chestnut tree.
This vision of the virgin forest has captured the imagination of a young man who has grown up in a little white ranch house, set on a typical green lawn, with an above-ground pool and a toolshed out back that looks like a red toy barn.
"One in every four trees in the Appalachian forest was a chestnut," said Tim, standing near one of the 10 American chestnut trees he planted from nuts three years ago in his backyard in Branchburg, N.J. (His pride and joy is 10 feet tall; the others are scraggly 4-footers.)
"At one time, squirrels ate more chestnuts than acorns," he said. "That's why chestnuts have those burs -- as a squirrel prevention," developed in centuries of evolution.
Passenger pigeons loved them too. So did wild turkeys, and people, who made chestnut flour and fattened their hogs in the forest on the fallen nuts. They used the wood for sturdy fencing, houses and furniture.
"It's known for its soft, straight grain," he said. "It was as strong as oak, but it wouldn't dull the saw." Abraham Lincoln's log cabin was made of chestnut and oak. The tannin from its bark was used to tan leather.
Then, in 1904, an orange fungus, Cryphonectria parasitica, was found on the American chestnut trees that graced the avenues of the Bronx Zoo. The fungus, which was girdling the trees and cutting off nutrients and water, had apparently been brought in on chestnut trees imported from Asia. Within 50 years, the blight had traveled up to Maine and down to Georgia and across the country to the western edge of Michigan, killing several billion mature trees -- and the economy that went with them.
By 1913, plant explorers found the fungus in China and Japan -- on Asian chestnuts resistant to the disease. Thus began a breeding program, crossing the Asian species with the American, to develop a blight-resistant tree. By the 1930's, trees were planted at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station, and research has been continuing there and in other places ever since.
In 1983, a group of prominent scientists, including Dr. Norman Borlaug, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1970 for crop breeding, and Dr. Peter Raven, the director of the Missouri Botanic Garden, started the American Chestnut Foundation. It now has 2,200 members, and 7,000 chestnut trees growing on its two research farms in Meadowview, Va.
"We're trying to introduce the blight resistance of the Chinese chestnut into the American, but otherwise retain the traits of the American tree," said Dr. Fred Hebard, the superintendent of the research farms. The Asian species is more of an orchard-type tree, rather than the regal American that once marched up and down the Appalachians.
"We expect to be releasing seed by 2005 or 2007," Dr. Hebard said.
The foundation wants to put the American chestnut trees back in the hardwood forest. It sells seed kits to members like Tim, who want to grow the trees in their backyards. When they're old enough, these trees can eventually be pollinated with pollen from the blight-resistant trees being developed in Virginia.
It costs $40 to join the American Chestnut Foundation (P.O. Box 4044, Bennington, Vt. 05201; 802-447-0110). A seed kit is $50.
"And we already have a fair number of people in Pennsylvania, Kentucky, Ohio and Vermont who have taken some of our pollen and pollinated existing American chestnut trees to increase biodiversity and avoid inbreeding," Dr. Hebard said.
As well as growing chestnut trees, Tim scouts the countryside every chance he gets for chestnut trees that might, by some chance, have developed resistance in the wild. But almost every time he finds an old chestnut tree stump -- with sprouts valiantly trying to turn into new trees -- he returns to find a house lot springing up in its place.
"It's not so much the development that gets me; it's the concept of extinction," Tim said. "It's irreversible. For the passenger pigeon, that's it. But maybe the American chestnut can be brought back."
Tim has charted the progress of his trees -- from the height of their trunks to the size and color of their leaves -- in yearly letters to the foundation, which are peppered with his observations of the decline of the natural world around him.
"If gray wolves were reintroduced, perhaps I would not have to keep cages around the trees to keep them safe from squirrels, rabbits and groundhogs," he wrote in July 1994.
Three years ago, Tim went looking for an American chestnut listed by the New Jersey Department of Environmental Conservation on its 1991 registry of largest trees. It was supposed to be on the corner of Five Points Road and Asbury Avenue in Freehold. There was a housing development there instead.
"I investigated the fragmented remnants of forest on land marked Lot 16, adjacent to the piles of bulldozed soil, new roads, holes in the ground for foundations, and recently planted hedgerows of our state tree, the telephone pole," he wrote. In a couple of small groves untouched by the bulldozer, he found a few 30-foot chestnut trees with furrowed bark, apparently holding their own.
"They may have evolved to resist the blight," he said. "But when I came back a year later, they were entirely obliterated. Except for one stump with some shoots."
Still, when you're 17, you're an optimist. "Wouldn't it be nice if people took a survey to see if any wild chestnuts were growing in their woods," he said. Even if they aren't blight-resistant, their nuts can be used to increase the genetic pool of this beleaguered tree.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tim Van Vliet in his backyard with his prize 10-foot American chestnut tree, which he grew from a nut. (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE;
Future Vision: Planners Head in Different Directions

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
It has been discussed for a decade, undergone several incarnations and been led by three different people. Now, leaders of a committee creating a plan for future development along the waterfront in Williamsburg and Greenpoint say they will release a draft plan later this month. "It will be a blueprint for redevelopment of the Greenpoint-Williamsburg waterfront," said Ronald Webster, who heads the 197-A Waterfront Committee. "When developers come out, they can say this is what the neighborhood wants."
But such a plan would be a remarkable achievement in this sprawling, Balkanized swath of northern Brooklyn where each neighborhood has its own vision. 
 In two and a half years of negotiations under Mr. Webster, the committee -- with representatives from Greenpoint, the artists' colony of Williamsburg's Northside, the largely Hispanic Southside and the Hasidim from below Division Street -- have found consensus on a few things. The committee objects to future waste transfer stations on the water, though it has not yet decided what to do with existing ones. Everyone agrees on opening up the waterfront -- now mostly in private hands -- for public access. And in principle, at least, the committee agrees on rezoning some heavy industrial stretches near the water for housing.
But much is still contested. Greenpoint, for instance, wants to get rid of waste transfer stations and objects to subsidized housing.
Southside leaders insist on affordable housing and worry that waterfront gentrification will drive out Williamsburg's working-class Hispanic and black residents. Southside leaders also want more jobs from Williamsburg's industrial base. "What good is housing if the people in that housing are just warehoused, with no possibility for real growth and development?" charged Luis Garden Acosta, director of El Puente, a Southside community group.
The Hasidim, who favor unsubsidized housing, want to convert former factories like the old Schaefer brewery in the Southside into apartments. "Market-rate housing will only strengthen the neighborhood," contended Rabbi David Niederman, who heads the United Jewish Organizations of Williamsburg.
And factory owners do not want the industrial areas reduced. "We would like to retain as much as possible the existing industry and even expand it," said Henry Ludmer, director of the Metropolitan Industrial Development Corporation, which represents waterfront businesses.
But Mr. Webster asserted that although specific developments would have to be fought over from block to block, his committee would find the common ground needed to draft a 197-A plan. "When push comes to shove, people will lock arms and do the right thing," he said.
For their part, city planning officials are looking at part of the Southside and weighing whether to convert the heavy industrial zones near the water -- much of the area is now unused -- into mixed-use and commercial zones.
Near the entrance to the Williamsburg Bridge, for instance, a possible area for rezoning, one-fourth of the buildings are vacant; nearly half are used for manufacturing and fewer than 20 percent for housing, according to a department study.
Rabbi Niederman said the Hasidim favored the conversion. Others, like Mr. Garden Acosta, called for a cautious approach to rezoning to insure "that the housing will be affordable for the very families who are doubled up." SOMINI SENGUPTA

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Clinton or Dole? You Might Check Your Portfolio

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
IF history is any guide, small stocks have a better chance of shining if Bill Clinton wins a second term than if Bob Dole unseats him, according to a study by the Liberty Financial Companies, a financial services concern in Boston.
Big stocks, however, are more likely to do better under a Dole Presidency, the study showed. 
 That is consistent with a general belief that big business fares best with a Republican as President. But the study's findings on small stocks run counter to the common notion that policies of Democratic Presidents can hurt business and put a damper on the stock market.
The study analyzed the gains of small stocks during Republican and Democratic administrations beginning in 1929. It used as a proxy the Ibbotson Small Stock Index, comprising the bottom fifth of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange plus stocks of the same size on Nasdaq and the American Stock Exchange. Market capitalizations of these stocks range from $86 million to $171 million.
Since the start of the Hoover Administration in 1929, small stocks have risen 22.8 percent a year, on average, during the nine terms of Democratic Presidents and just 1.9 percent during the eight Republican terms. The trend continues even when the Depression years are eliminated. Since 1937, small stocks have risen 17.2 percent a year, on average, under Democratic Presidents, compared with 10.2 percent annually under Republican Presidents.
More recently, small stocks have gained 19.9 percent a year during the Clinton Presidency, through June 30, the study found. That compared with 11.8 percent a year during the most recent Republican Presidency, under George Bush, or 13.3 percent if the results under Ronald Reagan are also included.
By contrast, large stocks have performed better during Republican administrations than during Democratic ones. After the Depression, the S.& P. 500 posted an average annual return of 11.9 percent, through June, under Republican Presidents, compared with 10.2 percent under Democrats in the White House.
"While it is generally accepted that Republican administrations are often good for big business, the Democratic focus on reducing unemployment tends to help small business," said Kenneth R. Leibler, Liberty's president and chief executive.

New Managers
David Ellison, manager of Fidelity Select Home Finance, has left Fidelity Investments; Bill Rubin, who continues to manage Select Defense and Aerospace, will take his place.
Andy Kaplan, an equity analyst, has picked up Fidelity Select Electronics from Marc Kaufman, who left the firm to join Vinik Asset Management, which was set up by Jeffrey N. Vinik after he left Fidelity Magellan in May. Katherine Collins, manager of Fidelity Select Leisure, took over Select Consumer Industries, formerly Select Consumer Products, from Mary English, who continues as an equity analyst.
Margery C. Parker, who runs Keystone Mid-Cap Growth, has picked up Keystone Global Opportunities, and Donald C. Dates, director of equity research, has picked up Keystone Small Company Growth II, both on an interim basis from Christopher Ely, who left the firm to join Loomis Sayles.
Dong Zhang, an equity analyst with Benham Equity Growth, has taken over the fund from Steven Colton, who continues to manage Benham Income and Growth.
Mary E. Canning, a co-manager of Phoenix Total Return, assumes full responsibility for the fund; her former co-manager, C. Edwin Riley Jr., will devote his energies solely to running Phoenix Balanced.

On-Line Update
T. Rowe Price Associates has started an on-line service that provides retail fund shareholders access to their account information and lets them conduct transactions on home computers. Shareholders can review account balances; buy, sell and exchange shares; check share prices, yields and total return; get real-time stock quotes; send E-mail, and connect to a World Wide Web site. On the Internet, account transactions will be available after security issues are resolved. The software costs $15, plus $2.95 for shipping and handling, and includes Netscape Navigator 2.01. To order, call (800) 541-3036.

In Brief
John Hancock Global Income was renamed John Hancock World Bond.
The trustees of John Hancock Special Equities have voted to close the fund to new investors when its assets reach $2.5 billion. It has $1.82 billion.
Calvert World Values Global Equity has been renamed Calvert World Values International Equity, and the amount that can be invested in the United States was reduced to 5 percent.
Four Thornburg bond funds, Limited Term Municipal Fund National, Limited Term United States Government, Limited Term Income and Intermediate Municipal, have added institutional shares with no sales charges, redemption or exchange fees. The minimum investment is $2.5 million, or $1 million for retirement and employee benefit plans.
Franklin Premier Return has been renamed Franklin Asset Allocation and its investment objective changed from "high current return" to "total return."
The Vanguard Group has a 36-page booklet covering mutual fund basics available free to investors who call (800) 276-7235. The company has also started a personal trust business for people who have trust assets of more than $500,000.
The Investor's Guide to Low-Cost Mutual Funds, a directory of more than 900 no- and low-cost funds, is available for $15 from the Mutual Fund Education Alliance, a trade association, at Department 0148, Box 419263, Kansas City, Mo. 64193-0148.
Fidelity High Yield Tax-Free has been renamed Fidelity Municipal Income. The fund can now invest up to 5 percent of its holdings in below-investment-grade securities and up to 100 percent in issues subject to the alternative minimum tax.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
How the Gold Group Is Keeping Its Luster

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
GOLD mutual funds seem to have a magical touch in 1996. For the year so far, they hold the lead among all equity funds that have at least $30 million in assets, and the precious-metals group has gained 17.4 percent, on average, nearly twice the 9 percent for the equity funds through Thursday, according to Morningstar Inc. in Chicago.
The meteoric rise of gold funds has not escaped the notice of market commentators, who have offered a variety of reasons for the surge. Earlier in the year, nervousness over the United States budget impasse, with the possibility of default, was named as a cause. Another was skittishness about the markets, which led investors to hedge their portfolios against possible declines in stocks and bonds. 
 At midyear, the run-up was attributed to a speculative bubble in gold stocks that could burst any time. The funds did experience a correction in June, losing more than 13 percent for the month, on average, but the bigger, more established gold-mining companies were hit hardest.
Confounding the situation, the price of gold itself has been treading water. After hitting a high of $415 an ounce in February, gold prices fell markedly and have held in the $380's since early June, closing at $385.80 a troy ounce on Thursday. Clearly, the recent returns on gold funds are not linked to the metal's price.
The basic reason, it seems, is much simpler: an imbalance in the supply and demand for gold that is prompting small exploration companies to accelerate operations.
As prices reached the low $300's at the start of the 1990's, it became less profitable to look for new gold sources, said Abhay Deshpande, a Morningstar analyst. But South African mines began drying up, he said, and demand started rising over the last three or four years as markets in China, India and Southeast Asia began growing strongly.
ONCE the stage was set, the trick was finding the companies most likely to succeed.
"It comes down to stock picking," said Daniel B. Leonard, who runs the $381 million Invesco Strategic Gold Portfolio. That fund led the equity fund group through Thursday this year, with a gain of 54.4 percent.
Mr. Leonard says he follows a "growth-gold" philosophy. "We're looking for middle-size and small companies that are looking for new gold mines around the world," he said. "Over the past few years, there's been a reasonable degree of success with that strategy, if you pick the right stocks."
He owns Bre-X Minerals, a Canadian company that recently discovered a large gold mine in Busang, Indonesia. Mr. Leonard said he paid $3.85 a share in January; the stock closed Friday at $18.875.
Another winner was Arequipa Resources, a Canadian gold-mining company on the Toronto Exchange. The company made a major discovery in Peru in June, prompting Barrick Gold to acquire it in early September for $22 a share, an impressive jump from the $1.50 a share Mr. Leonard said he paid last year.
A third company, also Canadian, is Golden Star, with a portfolio of prospective properties in South America and Africa. The stock price took off this spring when the company discovered diamonds as well as gold on its properties in South America. Mr. Leonard said he bought the stock at $5.50 a share in late 1995; it closed on Friday at $17.
Have prices gotten ahead of themselves? "There are some mistakes out there, but there are also a number of stocks with good geologic reserves," said Richard H. Warden, who manages the $115 million IDS Precious Metals fund, up 45.6 percent this year and right behind Invesco. "People are buying because gold is being found," he said, and the major producers need more gold.
Besides Bre-X and Arequipa, several stocks have contributed to Mr. Warden's return: Dayton, now in gold production in Chile, and Stillwater Mining, which found platinum and palladium in Montana.
Mr. Warden concedes that 1996 has been a "very unusual year," given all the major discoveries. But he said he owned a number of other companies "that have a good chance of finding gold." He cited Greenstone Resources and Romarco Minerals, both on the Toronto Exchange.
Douglas D. Donald, who runs the $215 million Scudder Gold fund -- up 40.8 percent since December -- uses a similar "growth-gold" approach. A geologist by training, Mr. Donald tends to avoid mining stocks in South Africa, which he says is too unstable. And he said he looked for low-cost producers, "so they don't need runaway gold prices to succeed."
While rising gold prices play only a small part in these funds' returns, they add some kick. Where do managers see gold prices going? Given today's supply and demand, Mr. Leonard said they should continue to move up slowly. Mr. Warden agreed, forecasting prices in the low $400's.
But Mr. Deshpande, of Morningstar, said the run-up in small exploration companies "seems excessive, so it seems like a correction might be in order, but it shouldn't be more than that." He advised investors to wait for a selloff of 10 percent to 15 percent in the more speculative gold funds before buying.
This year aside, gold funds have been unimpressive. As a group, the funds had annual returns of just 7.4 percent for the 10 years ended in August, versus 11.5 percent for all equity funds, Morningstar said.
Even so, Mr. Leonard sees gold as a good long-term investment. "In 1914, it was said that you could buy a good suit of clothes for an ounce of gold, which then cost $20," he said."Now, with gold almost $400, that's still true. If you had kept paper money, that wouldn't do it."

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
When It's Time to Do Your Math

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
AS your child struggles with her application for admission to a well-known boarding school, you get to apply for financial aid. What can you expect?
All boarding schools use a complex formula to determine need, developed by the School and Student Service for Financial Aid in Princeton, N.J. The service looks at a family's size, income, assets, expenses, the cost of living in its geographic area and other factors. 
 Be prepared to share all sorts of financial intimacies with the service, including not only the market value of your house and your children's college nest eggs but also what you spent on camp last summer and the number of cars and boats you own. All the schools will want a couple of years' worth of 1040 forms, too, although they won't demand a list of your jewelry and paintings.
"It was intrusive, and a lot of work," said Gwen Haley, whose younger son received financial aid to attend Choate Rosemary Hall. "It meant we got our taxes done a lot earlier than usual."
Among its rules of thumb, the service deems child support and uninsured medical costs as essential expenses that could not be rerouted toward tuition. But the interest on the loan for the backyard pool is seen as nonessential, and could be.
Divorce -- 27 percent of all financial-aid applicants come from divorced families -- further complicates the process. Schools, as well as the service, want to know about the finances of both parents, and remarried parents need to detail the finances of their new spouses as well, said Constance L. White, program director for the service. "We tell the schools to take a look at the information and do a variety of scenarios," she said. Most schools will make case-by-case decisions.
The financial resources of an applicant's grandparents are not counted, since extra-generational subsidizing is not assumed. You may, however, want to look to grandparents for help, said Meade B. Thayer, director of financial aid services at the National Association of Independent Schools, based in Washington. "Grandparents can reduce their estates by passing on $10,000 a year each to grandchildren," he said. The gift is tax-free to the recipients and cuts the tax liability of a grandparent's estate if it exceeds $600,000.
Parents can help their cause, too. Assets are considered as of the day you complete the form, and your income is based on the year in which you apply. So a big bonus might be deferred until the new year.
But beware. "We do ask about next year's income, and if you anticipate the income, you should report it," Ms. White said. "If you don't, the school might be quite angry."
For basic information, Mr. Thayer's association offers two free booklets on financial aid to parents who write to it at 1620 L Street N.W., Washington 20036-5605.
After all the math, the Princeton service -- known as the S.S.S. -- ends up with an amount called discretionary income. That is the figure it uses in recommending how much your family can pay.
Many schools revise the service's recommendation, and not always in your favor. For example, depreciation losses on second homes and hobby businesses are not recognized. (Bad!) But at Deerfield, accommodations are made for home-equity inflation based on real-estate vicissitudes. (Good!)
Being turned down for aid, or receiving less than you had hoped, shouldn't be cause to turn sadly back toward the local high school. Start a dialogue.
"Rarely do those families call us and say another $1,000 would make a big difference," said Jay Doolittle, director of admissions and financial aid at St. George's School in Newport, R.I. "If we don't interpret the data correctly, I want to know about it." Appeals make particular sense if your circumstances have changed -- if you are now supporting an elderly parent, for example.
But do not expect the aid to flow freely. "We recognize that it's not a piece of cake to pay tuitions," Mr. Thayer said. "At the same time, we don't want families to think they shouldn't also be planning for this."
Indeed, when school officials sit down to discuss their aid decisions, they are not shy about suggesting where you could be more cost-wise.
"We might figure they could unload one of their cars, or do with a lesser car," Mr. Doolittle said. "We don't order families around. But we do say, here's the rationale for our decision -- that extra Subaru was not really necessary."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
Choate on the Cheap: Prep Schools Woo the Middle Class

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
GWEN HALEY teaches at a public high school in Stratford, Conn. Her husband, Ted, is a drug rehabilitation counselor. Together they make a decent income, but not enough to simply say yes when their younger son, Ben, announced he wanted to go to Choate Rosemary Hall, a boarding school with a blue-chip reputation and a price tag of more than $22,000 a year.
So they applied for financial aid, and received an award that covered half of Ben's costs for his freshman year. The following years, his aid was increased to meet three-fourths of the cost because by then Ben's older brother had entered a private college. 
 "I would say to anybody who wants to go to a school like that, just go for it," said Mrs. Haley, whose son graduated last year and now attends Amherst College.
During the last few years, sending your child to boarding school -- that fabled realm of quaint buildings around a picturesque green; steam tables loaded with mysterious, clotted entrees, and well-weathered teachers wielding big academic sticks -- has become surprisingly attainable for people like the Haleys. Dismayed by the paucity of middle-income students on their campuses, the nation's boarding schools are widening the array of financial-aid options for people who know they are not rich enough to pay outright and have long presumed they were too rich to receive help.
The eligibility rules vary from school to school, but many families with substantial salaries are receiving help. At Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N.H., for example, middle income now refers to people earning between $60,000 and $120,000 a year. This year, 70 of the 331 financial-aid awards went to students whose families fell into that category. The Emma Willard School in Troy, N.Y., gave aid to 46.7 percent of its 270 students. Nearly all the families who received that aid reported incomes of more than $75,000.
At Concord Academy, a coeducational school in Concord, Mass., 23 students whose parents earned $60,000 or more received awards that averaged $12,000 apiece. At St. George's School in Newport, R.I., someone whose parents earned $145,000 still got a break on the cost this year.
"There's no income cutoff because there are so many variables," said Jay Doolittle, director of admissions and financial aid at St. George's. "If you make $100,000 and you have three or four children at tuition-paying schools, you could easily qualify for aid."
High fees, now as high as those at many colleges, and attributed to unavoidables like salaries, heating bills, technology and deferred maintenance, are one reason that boarding schools are offering a more generous helping hand. The median annual cost, including tuition, room and board, has risen from $10,195 in the 1985-86 school year to $19,850 in the 1995-96 year, according to the National Association of Independent Schools in Washington. That is a 94.7 percent increase in dollars, and a 37.1 percent increase after inflation is taken into account.
Particularly in the 1990's, these numbers can unnerve a group that admissions directors call "the emotional middle class."
These people earn far more than the Government's definition of middle income. Children in families earning $35,000 a year would receive automatic free rides at a typical boarding school. But while many middle-class families could and did send their children to boarding school through the 1970's, these days many more of them balk. They worry about an insecure job market, another four years of tuition at college and the specter of a penny-pinching retirement as traditional pensions vanish.
Boarding schools are worried, too -- about losing their socioeconomic diversity. In some institutions, enrollments have started to resemble barbells, with the wealthy clustered at one end and the woefully deprived at the other. Over the last decade, the same concern has propelled many colleges to award merit scholarships to even out their enrollments.
At Choate Rosemary Hall, "we definitely want to avoid having just the haves and the have-nots," said Charlotte Murphy, the school's communications director. "It's an issue that all the schools are hearing and are concerned about."
At Exeter, trustees were hearing complaints at alumni cocktail parties that tuition had spiraled beyond many people's means. A comparison of middle-class enrollment in the 1950's and in the 1990's found a definite discrepancy, said Rick Mahoney, the director of financial aid at the school. "We still had a spread, but we felt the middle-income group was less well represented here than they were 40 years ago."
Thomas Hassan, Exeter's admissions director, said: "It's part of our charter that this place shall ever be open to youth from every quarter. We want to get all kinds of kids. It's just healthier."
THE schools, eager for the best students, know they face tough competition. "Our biggest competitors are the public high schools, for which the price tag is zero," said Trudy Hanmer, Emma Willard's director of admissions and associate head of school. Moreover, "it is not an expectation that middle-income families are going to pay for high school," she said, and when they do they "typically pay for education out of discretionary income, not out of trust funds."
For all these reasons, boarding schools have set aside more money in the last few years for the middle class. In 1994, for instance, Exeter began offering more aid to families with incomes of $60,000 to $120,000, Mr. Hassan said.
Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., with a $6.7 million aid budget, recently increased its middle-class support too. In the 1992-93 school year, 52 families with incomes greater than $80,000 received aid from the school; this fall, 140 such families will.
The schools, which generate their financial-aid money from endowment earnings or annual campaigns, can often be generous with both the size and number of awards. After all, they are making them for just three or four years, not 14 as with schools that run from prekindergarten through grade 12. Choate, for example, gave an average award of $14,000 to middle-class students this year, while at St. George's the average was $11,900. (But never say "scholarship" in talking about the new largess. The somewhat cumbersome "need-based financial aid" is preferred.)
One beneficiary is Amanda Cohen, an Exeter senior from Sacramento, Calif. The school covers about three-quarters of the $20,000 tuition. "Let's put it this way," said her father, Ned, a deputy counsel for the California Legislature. "I don't make enough to send Amanda to Exeter. But we made the decision that we would afford it, and that she would go."
His daughter, he added, has flourished. "They work them to death," he said, approvingly. "I think she's gone through four years of sleep deprivation."
Besides outright grants like Amanda's, monthly payment plans are offered by most schools to help those without ready chunks of cash. For a $70 annual fee, Concord Academy will deduct a monthly payment directly from parents' checking accounts, said Rachel Countryman, the school's director of financial aid.
Schools can also steer families to low-interest loans. Knight College Resource Group, which administers many monthly payment plans, offers through many schools a low-interest, variable-rate loan pegged to the 13-week Treasury-bill rate.
For many families, aid ends up being a combination of grants, loans and payment plans. "In general, we will meet about 80 percent of a family's need," said James F. Ventre, financial aid director of Phillips Academy. "And then we will help them come up with the other 20 percent."
Nevertheless, many middle-class parents are too embarrassed to acknowledge that they cannot afford boarding school. Many also believe that to check the box next to the question "Are you applying for financial aid?" is to deal a death blow to their child's chances for admission.
Charles Pittman, an advertising manager from Charlotte, N.C., battled those anxieties when he applied for aid to send his son, Tony, to Andover in 1989. "I thought at this stage of my life I should have been better prepared," he said. "But I don't think you can prepare for this unless you make tons of money."
Since then, he has sent his two daughters there, too. His youngest, Mauresa, is a senior who manages the football team. She said that once she enrolled, she felt no different from anyone else on campus. "Nobody asked, and nobody brought it up," she said.
PARENTS might be surprised at how many boarding-school students receive aid. At Deerfield Academy in Deerfield, Mass., for instance, only about two-thirds of the families pay full tuition and "most of them were born into it," said Bill Cumming, the admissions director. The remainder receive financial aid or use monthly payment plans.
Parents need to squelch their reluctance and check the box when they apply, Mr. Cumming said. After all, what is more painful: a little honesty now or a huge humiliation later?
"I don't want to get blindsided in the middle of someone's junior year by a phone call from the father, saying 'I've tapped everything I have, I can't come up with the money, and he won't be coming back,' " Mr. Cumming said. "It's not the best thing for the child."
Some schools have revised the aid process to help eliminate embarrassment and worry. At Concord, all parents receive information about financing options along with the application packet.
Concord also handles all aid requests on a sheet of paper apart from the rest of the application. "We've started not to have a box per se," Ms. Countryman said. "We were concerned about keeping the two processes separate." At many schools, just who is getting help is a closely held secret as well. Gone are the days when scholarship students had to help out in the dining hall.
Despite all this concern and generosity, however, there is no guarantee that asking means you will receive. Only a handful of schools -- Deerfield is one -- call their admissions need-blind, and even they acknowledge that their resources are not so bottomless that they never turn down someone who needs help with tuition.
"There are a lot of families who may well qualify for financial aid but won't get it because the school doesn't have a big enough financial-aid budget," said Meade B. Thayer, director of financial aid services for the National Association of Independent Schools. The approach may differ: a Concord applicant may be accepted and not receive aid, while Deerfield tries not to accept someone who needs aid unless the money is available. But the point is that there is not enough cash to go around.
Parents should not conceal assets, however, because while the schools may be more supportive, they are often vigilant in checking the truth of applications.
"Some people think it's a hiding game, but these days it's real easy for us to find out about other information," said Mr. Ventre, of Phillips Academy. "They do have to provide tax returns, and we have C.P.A.'s here who are trained to look things over."
While aid is clearly welcome, it hardly means easy street for the middle class.
"We haven't been on a real vacation in a long time," Mrs. Haley said, "and we drive old cars."
Mr. Pittman said, "It's the sacrifice we've opted to make, to give our children the best education possible." With financial aid, he added, the boarding-school experience becomes manageable.
"It stretches you," he said, "but at the same time, it doesn't bankrupt you."

HEADLINE: An Asian Billionaire Tries to Fly by the New Rules

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: MANILA

 BODY:
EARLIER this summer, the largest tax evasion case on the planet landed in the lap of the Supreme Court of the Philippines. Lucio Tan, one of the country's richest men, stood accused of evading more than $1 billion in taxes.
The Government, many economists and a large segment of the business community argued that losing the case against Mr. Tan would risk the very integrity of the Philippine state. But a sharply divided Supreme Court faulted the Government for failing to give Mr. Tan adequate notice in pursuit of its case, and dismissed the case. 
 Score another one for Mr. Tan, a 62-year-old Chinese immigrant who has become a billionaire legendary for his brazen business ways and his seeming invincibility. Using street-smart strategies, Mr. Tan has built an empire that spans banking and brewing, tobacco and trading as well as real estate development. But he also benefited from political cronyism reaching back to Ferdinand Marcos and Government-granted monopolies. For years Mr. Tan has refused to disclose financial data on his companies to the Government. In the beer and cigarette business, he was given open-ended tax breaks that allow him a big competitive advantage. And with the Philippine Congress debating a major tax overhaul, he is peddling a plan to give his breweries an even greater edge over his leading competitor.
In the process, he has faced accusations of not only tax evasion but also corruption, receiving political favors, and ruthlessness. Mr. Tan and his lieutenants steadfastly maintain that no legal case has ever been proved against them.
But now, as the Philippines follows other Asian nations in trying to open its economy and become another Asian tiger, the rules are changing. And Mr. Tan intends to prove he can win at this game, too. To do so, he is taking on a challenge that even his own advisers consider folly: to fix Philippine Airlines, the money-losing national carrier known as P.A.L. or, among its critics, "Planes Always Late."
This time, there is no Ferdinand Marcos to help him with tax favors; indeed, Mr. Tan is out of favor with the current President. And this time he has no ready-made monopoly; the airline faces competition from a spate of domestic start-ups and sleek, efficient Asian carriers.
Just as the economy here is in transition, Mr. Tan himself is trying to transform his image from Marcos crony with sweetheart deals to respected businessman who put the airline on course for sustained profits and ended its years on the public dole.
Mr. Tan declined to be interviewed for this article. But from his rare public comments, it seems that his obsession with Philippine Airlines stems from a determination to achieve what many think impossible as well as from a chance to demonstrate a public commitment to his adopted country. As Teresita Ang See, who runs a research center on the Chinese in the Philippines, points out, there is still tension between ethnic Filipinos and ethnic Chinese, fueled in part by the sense among many ethnic Filipinos that the Chinese have prospered at their expense and hold a disproportionate sway over the Filipino economy.
Because of this, some people here believe that Mr. Tan's takeover of the national airline is a way of asserting his Philippine identity. For Mr. Tan, who speaks poor English and Tagalog when he cannot converse in his native Fujian dialect, this is not unimportant.
Last March, at the airline's 55th anniversary dinner, Mr. Tan confessed that the airline takeover was really an "emotional" decision. "This is 100 percent emotion," he told employees. "This is my contribution."
Emotion alone will not salvage the floundering airline. For years, Philippine Airlines has piled on losses and staff. Since 1983, the carrier has lost at least $408 million. According to Airline Business magazine, the carrier had a net loss last year of $66.1 million on revenue of about $1.1 billion.
The airline, which ranked 56th worldwide in revenue last year, between Aeroflot and Aerolineas Argentinas, has wallowed around Asia with aging planes, bad service and approved but unused routes. For years it had been run by political cronies who looted its assets and neglected its modernization. It was a basket case in the fiercely competitive Asian market, which is bustling with crisp, efficient and profitable carriers like Singapore Airlines and Thai Airways.
It is no accident that Cathay Pacific's flights to Manila are solidly booked in all classes while seats always seem to be available on Philippine Airline flights.
Yet, the allure of controlling a national airline, even one as bedeviled as this one, proved irresistible.
"Mr. Tan started investing in the airline in 1992, when the airline was privatized by Mrs. Aquino's administration," Jaime J. Bautista, a long-time executive with Mr. Tan's companies and now the chief financial officer of Philippine Airlines, said of Corazon C. Aquino, who had succeeded Mr. Marcos as President. "Being a taipan in the Philippines, it is a challenge to him to take over a very challenging business."
In 1992, a group of Philippine investors agreed to commit about 10 billion pesos, roughly $400 million, into a consortium called PR Holdings to buy two-thirds of the airline. When one of the leading investors failed to come up with his half of the capital, he secretly turned to Mr. Tan for help. "He agreed to invest about 5 billion pesos as a silent investor," Mr. Bautista recalled of Mr. Tan. "There was an agreement that he would not come into the open, but he wanted to be consulted."
Mr. Tan scrupulously hid his participation in the takeover because of an aggressive series of moves by the Government of President Aquino against Mr. Tan and his companies. Mr. Tan, whose close ties to Mr. Marcos included preferential tax status, had faced a series of investigations into accusations of corruption and tax evasion. At one point, the Government failed in a legal attempt to seize his companies.
Even as a business matter, Mr. Tan's lust for the national carrier seemed risky to his senior aides.
"I was involved in the cigarette and beer business," Mr. Bautista said, referring to the Fortune Tobacco Company and Asia Brewery Inc., two of Mr. Tan's flagships. "There was a consensus among the senior executives that it was very difficult investing in an airline. We don't know the business. We knew the airline was beset by problems. We knew P.A.L.'s people were known to be involved in graft and corruption. But he wanted to make it his personal challenge."
Mr. Tan's involvement in the airline, and his momentum toward complete control, came to light only after a series of management wars at the airline. Philippine President Fidel V. Ramos was so enraged at Mr. Tan's subterfuge that he authorized the licensing of a second national airline, Grand International Airways, to compete against Philippine Airlines.
For Mr. Ramos, Mr. Tan's attack on the airline presented a quandary. On the one hand, the Government was desperate to privatize a failing state enterprise. On the other, Mr. Tan was anathema to post-Marcos Governments. In the end, Mr. Ramos decided, on the advice of many of his advisers, to let the takeover go through. Last week, the airline's shareholders approved it.
It remains unclear whether Mr. Tan can turn the airline around. His executives profess that the carrier may show a profit this year, although it will be so slim that it will fit into a billfold. Like Mr. Tan, his competitors here, including John Gokongwei, another leading Filipino-Chinese businessman, who runs Grand Airways, declined to be interviewed.
LUCIO TAN was born in the Chinese coastal province of Fujian and little is publicly known about his rise to fortune. When he was still a young boy, his parents fled the chaos of China and moved him and his six brothers and sisters to sleepy Cebu in the middle of the Philippines archipelago. Arriving with virtually nothing, he struggled like many other immigrants to the Philippines; for a time he worked as a janitor, later as a dock worker. Various stories surround his emergence into the ranks of powerful businessmen here and into one of the world's richest men. According to Forbes magazine, his holdings are roughly valued at $2.2 billion but no one outside the Tan clan seems to know for sure. What is known is that his ties to President Marcos did much to fuel his success.
Within the tight Chinese social and business network, opportunities for credit abounded and business practices were less hindered by tradition and convention than for the landed aristocracy and Spanish business houses of the country. More, the Chinese showed extraordinary flexibility in dealing with a series of political regimes. And none were as adept in their footwork as Mr. Tan.
Indeed, the success of Chinese family empires throughout southeast Asia can be attributed in no small part to an indifference toward the nature of the political regime of the moment. And in many cases, exemplified here by Mr. Tan and in Indonesia by several dominant Chinese tycoons, substantial support in the early days of regimes has been rewarded with lavish contracts, licenses and monopolies.
MR. TAN'S first major venture was in the cigarette business and the founding of Fortune Tobacco in 1966. With tax breaks and near-monopoly licenses, he quickly captured the dominant share of the Philippine cigarette market with his Champion brand smokes. "It was," a Manila banker put it, "a license to print money." Today, Fortune commands 67 percent of the cigarette market.
In 1977, as the Philippines labored under the rigors of martial law, Mr. Tan and a group of Filipino-Chinese businessmen banded together and acquired a small, floundering bank, General Banking and Trust. Mr. Tan changed the bank's name to the Allied Banking Corporation.
Today, from its headquarters on Makati Avenue in Manila's thriving business district, Allied is the country's eighth-largest bank, according to Moody's. On the bank's worn second-floor executive headquarters, the language that drifts from offices and down the central hallway is Mr. Tan's native Fujian dialect.
Three years after Mr. Tan's foray into banking, President Marcos gave him a license to open Asia Brewery Inc. to compete against the San Miguel Corporation, the old Spanish brewer that had a monopoly in the Philippines and was the country's only real multinational. Wiseacres at the time suggested that the new beer would be called Lucifer, a contraction of the first names of Lucio Tan and Ferdinand Marcos. Mr. Tan reciprocated Mr. Marcos's favors with substantial contributions to the President's election campaigns; Mr. Tan's critics denounced the donations as bribes.
Despite the favoritism shown by Mr. Marcos, Mr. Tan also displayed a ferocious desire for his companies to succeed on their own merits. A former Government adviser on privatization and a management expert here contend Mr. Tan has thrived in the sharply shifting political winds by being a smart entrepreneur.
"He's very good at taking care of his people," said the former adviser, who maintained that he could be more candid by speaking anonymously. "He believes in single proprietorship; he has no listed companies. He believes in getting the most modern equipment."
Still, this former adviser said: "Lucio Tan is very secretive. Many Filipino Chinese wield a lot of influence here, but Lucio Tan maybe wields the most. He has the most political connections of everyone. He's funded almost every Congressman."
It is in Congress where Mr. Tan has waged one of his biggest battles. Under stiff demands from the International Monetary Fund, which is a major lender to the Philippines, the Philippine Government is attempting to rewrite its tax laws. A major element of the revision entails changing the formula used for calculating the excise tax on cigarettes and beer, revisions that would sharply increase the taxes paid by Mr. Tan's companies.
Because Mr. Tan releases no financial data on any of his companies -- despite requirements by the country's Securities and Exchange Commission that all companies, public or private, do so -- it is impossible to determine the profitability of his cigarette and beer operations. As for revenues, discussions with financial analysts and competitors suggest that Fortune Tobacco's were about $670 million last year, and that Asia Brewery's were in the neighborhood of $215 million, about 20 percent of the beer market.
The Philippine Department of Finance contends that not only do Mr. Tan's companies underpay taxes, but also that he employs a variety of schemes to evade accurate assessments of his existing tax liability. Based on its findings, the department devised a simplified excise tax code that would make such cheating difficult or impossible and would eliminate the favorable, open-ended low tax brackets Mr. Tan had obtained for his products. The department submitted the proposal in legislative form to Congress as part of the overall tax overhaul package.
"There was very strong opposition from him, and it was translated into opposition from members of Congress," said Milwida M. Guevara, the Undersecretary of Finance. "We say everybody should pay the same amount on each bottle, on each pack of cigarettes. We say companies should compete on quality and brand name, not on special tax preferences."
After a blizzard of lobbying by Mr. Tan's companies, an alternative tax proposal was put forward by some members of Congress. "They have come up with a compromise that is worse than this current system," Ms. Guevara said.
Mr. Tan's only competitor in the beer market, San Miguel, reacted with fury to the new bill. "It seemed specifically designed to put us at a marketing disadvantage," said a senior executive at San Miguel, who preferred that his name not be used. "He wants to carve out a larger market share through this tax bill."
AT the same time, Mr. Tan has remained embroiled in a tax evasion case of cosmic dimensions. For years, the Government has pushed a case through the court system charging Mr. Tan with evading 25.6 billion pesos in taxes, about $1 billion. In June, in a 3-to-2 decision, the Supreme Court dismissed the case against Mr. Tan, a move that was greeted with a public uproar and accusations of payoffs to the justices. So deafening was the criticism of the court that it felt compelled to take the bizarre step of issuing a letter denying that it had been bribed.
But President Ramos left no doubt where he stood on the court's decision. "The decision of the Supreme Court First Division is certainly a setback," Mr. Ramos declared. "It has a grave implication on the Government's effort to proceed against those who violate our tax laws."
The dean of newspaper columnists in Manila, Amanda Doronila, who writes for The Philippine Daily Inquirer, put the matter bluntly. "The Court just delivered another blow to further weaken the state on the capacity to raise revenue," he wrote.
"No business entrepreneur in the history of this country has been more successful in gaining his objectives in the strategic economic, political and judicial arenas in so short a time than Lucio Tan," he wrote. "Lucio Tan appears unstoppable."
Estelito P. Mendoza, Mr. Tan's chief lawyer and the solicitor general for part of Mr. Marcos's regime, noted that Mr. Tan's victory in the Supreme Court did not mean that the Government had given up or that Mr. Tan was home free. "Now that we have won does not mean that Fortune Tobacco does not owe the Government," he said.
Still, despite the implications of his tax case and the problematic fate of the Government's tax package, many business people believe not only that Mr. Tan will continue to thrive, but also that he is a needed force in the economic revival of the country.
"Yes, he's having real problems with the executive" branch of the Government, said Gregorio U. Kilayko, the president of ING Barings Securities (Philippines) Inc. "But the Government realized that the only way to save Philippines Airlines was to let him run it. He had real trouble getting financing from local banks for the airline because of worries about liabilities from his tax cases. But he got it."
Mr. Tan is moving aggressively on a range of fronts, from Philippine Airlines to property interests abroad -- and even in beer. Although he is now clunking around in the low-priced end of the beer market with Beer na Beer (translated roughly as Really Beer), Mr. Tan's Asia Brewery just won rights from Anheuser-Busch International to produce Budweiser beer in the Philippines.
In Hong Kong, Mr. Tan's development group, Eton Properties, run by his brother Frank Chan, has grown to become one of the top 15 developers in the territory. With as much as $500 million invested in commercial and residential property in Hong Kong, Mr. Tan has used the territory as a base to expand into China. Already, Mr. Tan has property investments, of unknown size, in Shanghai, Beijing and Xiamen.
With a bit of arm-twisting from President Ramos, Mr. Tan has teamed up with six other Filipino-Chinese tycoons to form an infrastructure group, the Asia's Emerging Dragon Corporation . Each of the tycoons anted up 100 million pesos, about $3.8 million, to get the consortium off the ground. Its first project is building a new passenger terminal at the decrepit international airport in Manila, a project already under court challenge from other developers who want a piece of the action.
BUT it is with Philippine Airlines that Mr. Tan faces the most formidable and immediate challenge. As part of the country's economic liberalization, a spate of new airlines -- eight at last count -- have sprung up, all competing with Philippine Airlines' most lucrative domestic routes. And all offer cheaper seats, up to 40 percent cheaper, than P.A.L.'s.
"Mr. Tan concluded that P.A.L. can recover from losses and its bad image by four strategic initiatives," said Mr. Bautista, the airline executive. "First we have to develop new and profitable routes. Second, we have to improve on-time performance. Third, we have to maximize the use of our resources. And fourth, we have to get optimum efficiency from our employees."
Although P.A.L. has nearly 14,000 employees -- comparable carriers like China Airlines of Taiwan have about 4,000 -- Mr. Bautista said that dismissals were unlikely. "What Mr. Tan wants to do is make all these 14,000 people productive," Mr. Bautista said. In addition, the airline needs more than 30 new airplanes, equipment that will cost billions of dollars. Financing, he said, will come from Mr. Tan and from borrowing. He declined to be more specific.
"No one can do what Mr. Tan is doing," said Mr. Mendoza, the lawyer for Mr. Tan. Indeed, the lingering belief that Mr. Tan has only succeeded because of favoritism continues to rankle, an irritation that Mr. Mendoza joked about.
"No one has the guts to do what he is doing," he added. "He was saying that after he turns Philippine Airlines around, it will show that he can actually succeed, and then retire. Of course the retort is that if you don't succeed, you'll have to retire anyway because you'll be bankrupt."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Like the Philippines, Lucio Tan, right, wants to improve his image. To do it, he will try to turn around Philippine Airlines, a persistent money loser whose shareholders voted him in last week. (M. Photo/Hong Kong; Asia Week)
