HEADLINE: The Rise and Fall of El Feo

BYLINE: By BRIAN McDONALD 

 BODY:
THE night of the shooting was supposed to be a celebration. Just that afternoon, Jose Reyes had gone downtown to F.A.O. Schwarz and purchased the perfect gift, a three-foot tiger, for the guest of honor -- the 1-year-old child of an associate.
It was a fine night and the powerfully built 22-year-old was in a fine mood. Times were good; money was rolling in. The party stretched on. At midnight, Mr. Reyes decided to make a private call. He and his right-hand man, Raul Vargas, walked down the block to the Amsterdam Deli Grocery, around the corner at 2172 Amsterdam Avenue at 167th Street. The street lights glowed a dull yellow. The streets were filled with teen-agers and as he passed, they undoubtedly nodded at him with respect. 
 This was his street. The place where he got his start, where, as a 15-year-old lookout, his whistle warning of passing police cars became a familiar sound. Now it was his headquarters.
The shooting happened quickly. As Mr. Reyes walked into the bodega, a man stepped out of a double-parked maroon sedan, pointed a revolver into the open doorway and fired twice. The first shot hit Mr. Reyes in the abdomen. The second shattered his spine.
Mr. Reyes couldn't feel his legs.
" 'I don't want my mother to see me like this,' " Raul Vargas remembers him saying. " 'Take me to the hospital.' "
This was July 12, 1992, and Jose Reyes would never walk again. But he would keep playing the chess game of the streets from a wheelchair in a van and from suites in suburban hotels. It was like that in the Washington Heights drug trade. You went for the money. You took your chances. You killed before you were killed.
When the history is written of the drug gangs of New York in the 1980's and mid-1990's, the kind that wrecked a city's nerves, helped create record-high murder rates and made gunfire a common sound in many neighborhoods, the author might want to spend a chapter on Jose Reyes, or, as he was known, El Feo.
Calm, charismatic and predatory, Jose Reyes rose to become both dealer and supplier, building an empire that even the most ruinous drug organization of the era -- like the Wild Cowboys, a South Bronx gang -- paid respect to. He called the Wild Cowboys "my sons."
Court testimony from Mr. Vargas, a Reyes hit man, and a major dealer, combined with interviews with a close friend, a business associate, detectives and prosecutors, offers a glimpse into the brutal inner circle of the El Feo organization and explains some of the dynamics behind the out-of-control violence of the era -- the street-by-street turf battles, the pressures that made guns a necessity, the jealousies among the hit men.
Operating in a neighborhood doused in drug money, Mr. Reyes was a general in an army of dozens of teen-agers and twentysomethings. Like those around him, he smiled easily, wore jeans and T-shirts, played pickup basketball, ate Chinese takeout, watched crime movies on the VCR. He also devoured books on the Mafia. He read Machiavelli and argued Gibran's philosophy. And he killed, managing a hit team that left a trail of rivals dead in Manhattan and the Bronx. He was eventually indicted for 17 murders.
He was so well insulated that it took law-enforcement authorities several years to hear of his existence. When they did, they were often amazed at his reach. "There were six major dealers in Washington Heights and Mr. Reyes was one of them," said Detective Gary Dugan, who did surveillance on Mr. Reyes. "I would rate him at the very top."
Two months ago, Mr. Reyes was convicted of running a drug organization and of killing seven men. At his trial, he often sat in a courtroom empty of spectators. Paralyzed, he was already in his own private prison. He wore a urine catheter (he could not even make a bowel movement without being positioned by a nurse or attendant). Every five minutes or so his torso would shake uncontrollably and he would cling hard to his wheelchair to keep himself steady.
When a visitor entered the courtroom, he would swing his head slightly to catch a glimpse. In a flash, his eyes could go from a frightening, piercing stare -- an intense sizing up -- and collapse into a warm welcoming -- summing up in less than a moment the two sides of Jose Reyes, extreme violence and personal charisma.
The charm part almost worked on some of the jurors. Some said they felt themselves almost taken in.
"To be honest, a bond developed," one juror said.
 
 
FROM FEOLITO TO EL FEO
 Partly by accident of geography, Washington Heights became a symbol of the drug crisis in the 1980's. Access to the highways gave parts of the neighborhood almost the feel of a tourist economy. It is at the nexus of the Cross Bronx Expressway, the Harlem River Drive, the Henry Hudson Parkway and the George Washington Bridge.
If you lived in northern New Jersey or Westchester and were looking for a high, it was easy to get into -- and out of -- very quickly.
The locals learned the basics of the quick sale, employing pitchers and even making sure translators were on hand to bridge language gaps with the newest Spanish-speaking arrivals. The blocks of 166th and 167th Streets, between Audubon and Amsterdam Avenues, were among the earliest crack spots; word got around that they had a reliable product. Those blocks also lay in the reasonably well-kept neighborhood around Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital, with its street traffic of doctors and nurses, probably making it less threatening to suburbanites.
Jose Reyes came to the neighborhood around 1975, at the age of 5. He was born in Puerto Rico. His father abandoned the family in Puerto Rico. He moved to 501 West 167th Street with his mother, older brother and sister. The family declined to be interviewed for this article. Though he grew up in a neighborhood dominated by Dominicans, he quickly gained acceptance.
"Everybody on the block liked him," said Tino Grana, whose father owned the Amsterdam Deli Grocery back then. One day, Mr. Grana called Jose Reyes, "Feolito," the little ugly one, and the name stuck.
"I said it as sort of a pet name," Mr. Grana said. "It wasn't meant to be derogatory, and Jose didn't take it that way. Nothing ever bothered the kid."
Jimmy Lucca, a lifelong friend, said of Mr. Reyes: "He was a little toughie. He was a little rough kid. He was bad, always. He wasn't a bully, but he was tough; he could handle himself."
Eventually, in the mid-1980's, Mr. Reyes grew close to the man who ran the crack business on 166th and 167th Streets -- Rogelio Perez Almadovar, or Chocolate. Fifteen years older than Mr. Reyes, Chocolate became a father figure to Feolito. At the age of 15, Mr. Reyes dropped out of Automotive High School in Brooklyn when Chocolate offered him an entry-level job as a lookout. Mr. Reyes moved up the ranks quickly. He began working "the table," an apartment where heroin was cut, packaged and stamped. He became a messenger, carrying drugs and money.
These were days of relative quiet on 166th and 167th Streets. No other gangs had tried to move in. But in 1987, Chocolate was arrested in a drug deal and sent to prison for several years. Chocolate handed Jose Reyes the reins. Feolito became El Feo.
Even Mr. Reyes's defense lawyer concedes that his client took over most of the drug spot, describing Chocolate's move as a way to avoid warfare within his gang by not giving any of the usual factions total control. Mr. Reyes was to be a caretaker -- tough but balanced, completely loyal to Chocolate while he was in prison but inoffensive to the factions.
The operation was fairly large. Mr. Reyes controlled all of 167th Street and half of 166th Street -- the other half of 166th was bequeathed to a Dominican in Chocolate's gang, Victor (Pielo) Battista. The business was even diversified. As the drug trade of Washington Heights, dominated in the early and mid-80's by crack, began to return more to heroin, Chocolate had expanded his operation to include "American," the street name for heroin. Customers from New Jersey were willing to pay Mr. Reyes's rate of $13 for a bag of heroin; the going street rate in less convenient locales was $10.
For the first time, Mr. Reyes saw how much money came with the turf. "These were carefree and exciting times," said his lawyer, Don Buchwald, whose defense in the trial was that Mr. Reyes was a drug dealer but not a murderous one.
Mr. Reyes also came into contact with the larger players. And then he made the same decision other dealers in the city made in the frenetic, brutal atmosphere of money in the late 1980's. He expanded. Testimony from his trial told of an operation that changed from a relatively small, tightknit, self-contained crew of fewer than a dozen to an organization both fueling, and adapting to, the imperialism of the streets. In some ways, the drug trade reflected the go-go high finance of the times: mergers, acquisitions, takeovers.
Under Mr. Reyes, the crew began supplying in bulk both cocaine and heroin to other dealers. He moved kilos of heroin to a drug organization on St. Ann's Avenue in the South Bronx. He bought a drug spot on 167th Street in the Bronx for $15,000 to $20,000. He opened a major crack and heroin location at 1770 Andrews Avenue in the Bronx and he began supplying the Wild Cowboys. By the time Chocolate returned in 1990, Mr. Reyes had turned his crew into an organization. Prosecutors said he was making as $1 million a week.
And he honored his mentor, his father figure, by allowing him to retire. The financial terms are not known. But it is believed that Chocolate became a drug boss emeritus in his mid-30's. Chocolate was shot to death in his native Dominican Republic in 1993.
But Mr. Reyes continued Chocolate's philosophy: take care of the block. And he had added a new proviso: the hell with everyone else.
 
ENCHANTED BY THE MOB
 Jimmy Lucca, Mr. Reyes's boyhood friend, is a neighborhood kid, home-grown on 167th Street, a mutt -- as he describes himself -- half-Dominican and half-Puerto Rican. Mr. Lucca, now 26, chose a different road. He now he works two jobs -- as a barber and a groundskeeper at Columbia-Presbyterian.
"I'm just a garbageman at the hospital," he says.
Mr. Lucca and Mr. Reyes were close, even after his rise. Mr. Reyes used to go to Mr. Lucca's home. They were crime buffs; they would watch tapes of crime movies while Mr. Reyes gulfed down his favorite Chinese takeout -- lemon chicken and watercress.
Mr. Lucca often taped movies for Mr. Reyes's crew. In fact he once edited out the commercials out of a season of the television series "Wiseguy" and sold the tape to a crew member.
The crew member had a reputation for being cheap, but forked over $100 for the shows. When Mr. Reyes found out, he was astounded. "You're kidding me right?" he asked Mr. Lucca.
Mr. Lucca and others close to Mr. Reyes say he played down his intelligence on the street. But they say he was a voracious reader and hungry to talk about what he read, fascinated by the lessons about tactics and the dynamics of betrayal. Some of his reading was history and political power.
He loved books on crime and the Mafia, studying them very closely. And some say he even imagined himself as a Sicilian. During one hit, he ordered that a .38 be used, instead of a 9-millimeter, because that's what "the Mafia dudes" use. Once, trying to get the owner of a drug spot to clean up his act, he gave the man a Mafia book to read for educational purposes but he was so insistent that the book not be dogeared or marred in any way that the owner was too intimidated to take it.
Mr. Lucca said that he had no illusions about what Mr. Reyes did but that they never talked about it. The topic would sometimes reach the borderline of discussion. Mr. Reyes would play mind games with Mr. Lucca. They would be in a car and another car would pull alongside at a light. Mr. Reyes would say: "Oh, that car looks suspicious. I think those guys are after me." Mr. Lucca would try not to look nervous but he couldn't help himself.
But conversations drifting too close to Mr. Reyes's real life would end quickly. Mr. Reyes would say, "You're better off not knowing," or "Someday I'll explain it all to you."
If Mr. Lucca had known the details, he would have known his friend had taken on the heavy responsibilities that came with expansion. Opening new spots and supplying "work" -- drugs -- meant creating alliances and managing an entire new layer of middlemen, security people and auxiliary personnel, finding the best product sought by the drug spots.
"In the early 80's crack dealers were mostly freelancers," says Richard Curtis, a professor at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice. "By the late 80's these were replaced by corporate-style organizations. Typical of these organizations were levels of ownership, management and labor. Tensions between management and labor frequently occurred. Workers were untrustworthy. This was one source of violence."
Expansion meant Mr. Reyes had to expose himself to new threats, new competition. And that required a determination to use violence.
"My God is great," Mr. Reyes would often say. "I will kill anyone who tries to do me in."
 
THE GOOD WARRIOR

Mr. Lucca says one of Jose Reyes's favorite books was "The Sicilian" by Mario Puzo. They had long conversations about many aspects of the book.
He said Mr. Reyes identified in particular with the character Guiliano. In the tale Guiliano steals a piece of cheese for his sister's wedding and is shot at by a policeman. Guiliano shoots back and becomes a fugitive.
According to Mr. Lucca, Mr. Reyes once said: "Guiliano found himself in a situation and had to live with it. He was a good warrior, had good tactics. He tried to make the most of his situation, and do some good for people that needed it."
Mr. Reyes became a good warrior, which meant reveal no weakness, protect your turf and strike first. He became a killer.
It was a highly tense, paranoid time in many neighborhooods. Sometimes two or three gangs would fight for dominance of one street. Drug dealers would check one another's spot for movement. Those who did not feel capable of defending themselves brought in others to help out.
Mr. Reyes's basic needs were to keep his drug spots supplied with desirable cocaine and heroin, to back up his allies in northern Manhattan and the Bronx with violence or the threat of it and to watch his back on his own turf in the upper 160's, an increasingly sticky situation because Pielo, the man to whom Chocolate bequeathed half of 166th Street, was undercutting Mr. Reyes's $13 price for a bag of heroin by 30 percent, a clear sign of disrespect in Mr. Reyes's own backyard.
These dynamics came out strongly in the testimony of Edwin Ortiz, the boss of a heroin crew supplied by Mr. Reyes, and of Raul Vargas, the right-hand man who pleaded guilty to taking part in all 17 murders for which Mr. Reyes was indicted.
Mr. Vargas's testimony, in particular, has a Leopold Bloom feel, depicting his wandering through the Washington Heights drug world from the age of 14. It also shows the ebb and flow of life inside the El Feo hierarchy in the early 1990's -- a mix of everyday management problems, mass production, checking for signs of betrayal and fierce defense of turf.
Violence was routine. Mr. Vargas gave an account in his testimony of one night when Mr. Reyes and his crew were hanging out in front of the Amsterdam Deli, drinking rum. A worker from his 166th Street crew got into an argument with a man in a neighborhood restaurant. Hearing about it, Mr. Reyes led his crew in a rush to find the man. They jumped him, kicked him, beat him and repeatedly stabbing him until he collapsed at a gasoline station.
There were threats. Soon after, Mr. Vargas had Mr. Reyes sent him to a drug spot he had opened on 184th Street and Audubon Avenue. Mr. Vargas went to help out another crew member. Dealers on 182d Street warned Mr. Vargas and another crew member to get out.
"They said they weren't going to approach us talking next time," he said.
Mr. Reyes said he would take care of it. That night Mr. Reyes and several others pulled out machine guns, jumped in a car and headed to the spot. Mr. Vargas, who wasn't in the car, didn't offer details but said he had heard they settled the dispute.
You had to keep watch far from home. In his burst of expansion, Mr. Reyes bought a drug spot on 167th Street in the Bronx for somewhere between $15,000 to $20,000. "It's like buying a store," Mr. Vargas said. "You buy a store, it's just change the owner."
But then Mr. Reyes started hearing that the sellers had taken the customers, too, around the corner. So Mr. Reyes hired an "old-timer" -- a veteran street warrior -- and with several other crew members carrying guns visited the spot and settled the matter. At least for the time being.
Mr. Reyes had a host of business principles: always carry a gun; keep your guns, drugs and bookkeeping records in separate stashes and never use your own car for a hit. He also test-marketed his product. That meant finding a hard-core but trusted addict with a high tolerance for heroin who would rate the intensity from 1 to 10. The testing usually took place in a shooting gallery on 166th Street. Samples were sent down from the gang's heroin factory tables at an apartment up on Dyckman Street. Anything over 8 1/2 was a smoker.
The gang kept a stash of guns up in the Bronx, in an apartment of an associate. Mr. Vargas visited the place at least once, to prepare for a bloodbath that was later canceled. He saw a closet packed with boxes and duffel bags filled with bullets and dozens of handguns and machine guns.
An apparatus of murder developed. Mr. Vargas testified that the gang had kept special cars for hits in garages in the Bronx -- Mark VII's, Celebrities and even ex-police cars. These cars had specially designed stashes, hidden compartments you opened by simultaneously hitting the windshield wipers, the defrost, and the nickel slot of the coin-holder. Guns would pop out.
In the back, they would have strobe lights to deflect the eyes of any accidental witnesses from the license plates, which would roll up.
There were more mundane details. The owner of a drug spot in the Bronx wanted more "Fruity," a hard-to-get brand of heroin that had sold well. The head manager of the 167th Street spot was skimming money and had to be fired.
Mr. Reyes needed a driver. Occasionally, Mr. Vargas drove Mr. Reyes on shopping trips. One day in 1990 they were driving in tight traffic on the F.D.R. Drive. Mr. Reyes was so impressed with how Mr. Vargas cut in and out between the slow-moving cars, sometimes at speeds of 80 miles per hour, that he offered him a job as a driver.
" 'Yeah, you know I always knew you was a driver,' " Mr. Vargas said Mr. Reyes told him.
RECRUITING THE TALENT
Drug gangs need hit men -- ready-made or trainable -- and Mr. Reyes clearly had his eye out for talent and opportunities to train.
One day, a young man named Francisco Medina showed up at 167th Street. He was what they all called "new new" -- recently arrived from the Dominican Republic. He had heard about Mr. Reyes's reputation and said he wanted to kill for him.
"I'm going to show you I'm a smoker -- I ain't no joke." Mr. Medina told Mr. Reyes during his interview, according to Mr. Vargas.
Another crew member, Hippolito Polanco, told Mr. Reyes that he didn't like Mr. Medina. But Mr. Reyes soon gave him a test, and he arranged for a gun. Mr. Medina took the job with relish, Vargas said.
When Mr. Medina returned, Mr. Vargas said, he recounted the shooting this way:
" 'Oh you should have seen, you know, you should have seen the way I shot him. I went up to the door, and I told him who, Smoky, Smoky, and then the guy said, yes, come on in, come on in, and the guy turns around and I forget he said turned around or I just know that he said, and I started to shoot him, and I left him stooped over the stove there, and he said the damn door got locked on me, it didn't have any handle and I was trying to get out I couldn't get out and I left by the window."
The body was discovered several days later when people began complaining about a foul smell coming from the apartment. "I think Freddy was like laughing about it, a dead body up there," Mr. Vargas said.
Mr. Reyes paid Mr. Medina $3,000 for the hit, Mr. Vargas said, and Mr. Medina became part of the inner circle.
Then one day, a man named Willie Jones came by. Mr. Jones was an old friend of Mr. Reyes. Mr. Jones ran a crack operation on Allerton Avenue in the Bronx and Mr. Reyes supplied the cocaine. Mr. Jones was desperate. The dealer who once ran the spot had returned from prison and was putting pressure on Mr. Jones and his workers.
"No problem," Mr. Reyes said, according to Mr. Vargas.
He sent Mr. Medina and Mr. Vargas to the Bronx. They found the former dealer, Ronnie Gedders, in a park just as school was let out. There were children in the park. "Freddy wanted to do it," Mr. Vargas testified, 'but I said no, no, no, there is a lot of kids coming out of school."
A couple of days later, Mr. Reyes, Mr. Vargas and Mr. Medina all went after Mr. Gedders. They found him on the street and Mr. Medina took out his 9-millimeter and started out the door of their car.
But Mr. Reyes told Mr. Vargas to do the hit. Mr. Vargas testified that he said: "Damn I never shot nobody. You know, I never shot anybody."
Mr. Reyes said, "Yeah, you got to -- that's how you start training yourself." He said Mr. Vargas needed to polish his skills.
Mr. Gedders was knocking on the door in front of a building.
Mr. Vargas, laid back through much of testimony, rose in the courtroom to describe what he says is his first hit:
"I got out on the driver's side, and I put my hand back like that, like I was going in my pocket, and the guy looked at me, and he's knocking on the door. And he turned away. When he turned away, then I just started shooting.
"You know I shot at the guy so I just started shooting. I was jumping when I was shooting him . . . I just held my hands like that and started shooting and when I started shooting I was jumping like that."
The Beretta he used held 15 bullets. He "emptied out" -- shot all of them.
He ran back to the car.
"Yo yo yo," Mr. Reyes said. "Slow down. Slow down. You never run from the scene because then people know that it was you."
He said Mr. Medina and Mr. Reyes started laughing at him. Mr. Medina said he was surprised it was Mr. Vargas's first hit.
"I thought you were a big-time hit man," Mr. Medina said, according to Mr. Vargas.

DOM PERIGNON AND SUN TZU
There were the good times, too. Mr. Reyes liked to party. He threw Gotti-like Fourth of July parties on 167th, for the block. He took his gang out to dinners and clubs. He drank Dominican rum, Dom Perignon and Guinness. Mr. Vargas testified that Mr. Reyes said he didn't use drugs.
He spread his money around. He became close to Michael Dean, a barber he played basketball with on 167th Street. Mr. Dean had a company, Sure Shot Entertainment, which promoted parties in clubs like Private Eyes, Bentley's and the Palladium that Mr. Reyes attended. Mr. Dean testified that Mr. Reyes invested $3,000 in a party thrown after the 1991 National Basketball Association draft, and that it was attended by several pro players.
They also had long talks about books. Mr. Dean says they discussed "The Prophet," Kahlil Gibran's poetic account of a spiritual quest.
"Jose believed, we both believed, that we were put here to master the earth, master all possibilities," Mr. Dean said. "Jose would say, 'You work with the liabilities or assets you have."
"We walked about poverty -- that it's like living without food or water and how it produces a savage state. But it doesn't mean you don't strive for knowledge. And it doesn't mean you don't worry that you'll be an old man worrying where the rent was coming from."
He said Mr. Reyes was also attracted to Sun Tzu's "Art of War" "Jose liked that it taught you that the best way to fight is to never fight. That everything in life is war. Everything always clashes. Everything is always chaotic."
But avoiding a fight was impossible around his own turf. Still he did try -- at least once, according to Mr. Vargas, who otherwise painted Mr. Reyes as very quick on the trigger.
The issue on 166th Street had to be dealt with. Mr. Reyes felt he could no longer allow Pielo and his brother, Morenito Battista, to undersell him on heroin.
He knew the two brothers well. They once all played basketball together on the 167th Street court. Jimmy Lucca says Pielo had an extremely wild temper. You could not call a foul on him; he would throw the ball over the fence in anger.
One day, Mr. Reyes walked to 166th with Mr. Vargas to persuade Mr. Battista to up his price. Mr. Battista spit at Mr. Reyes's feet and challenged him to a fistfight.
Mr. Battista put on a big show, Mr. Vargas said, and "embarrassed Jose in front of everybody." But Mr. Reyes wouldn't fight.
As they walked away, Mr. Reyes told Mr. Vargas, "I will get mine."

HIT FOLLOWS HIT
Drug violence often occurs in clusters. Here is how prosecutors presented events over the next year or so around 166th Street and 167th Street.
In March 1991, Mr. Battista and his brother send a hit man to kill Mr. Reyes in front of the Amsterdam Deli Grocery. Mr. Reyes is shot in the leg and survives. Mr. Medina is shot in the shoulder, but kills the hit man. He later cuts the bullet out with a knife.
In response, Mr. Reyes orders the shooting of the two brothers. Morenito is shot but survives. On March 3, 1992, his brother, Pielo, is killed by Mr. Medina, who uses an assault rifle.
A few months later, on the night of the birthday party for the 1-year-old, Mr. Reyes is shot and paralyzed for life.
Morenito thus had his revenge, prosecutors say.

EPILOGUE
Mr. Reyes loved the book "The Westies," by T. J. English, the story of the Irish gang in Hell's Kitchen. Like "The Sicilian," it has a major theme of betrayal. In the end, gang members turn on each other. Discussng the book with Mr. Reyes, Mr. Lucca said he could not understand how this could happen.
But Mr. Reyes told him: "Anybody would do it. Anybody put in that position would do it."
After the shooting, Mr. Reyes kept power but not for long. From his hospital bed at Columbia-Presbyterian, he continued to direct operations at his headquarters just a few blocks away. People who visited him said he took his circumstances in good humor. There were sad moments, though, like when he told his girlfriend to find another man.
After being released, he customized a van and used it to prowl his empire, says Detective Dugan, whose surveillance provided prosecutors with important evidence. Detective Dugan says Mr. Reyes searched desperately for a cure: "He had one of those computerized organizers. He had the world at his fingertips. He called Canada, Cuba, everywhere."
Mr. Reyes offered to pay a Cuban doctor a million dollars to cure him. But it couldn't be arranged.
He started to stay in suburban hotels, with Mr. Vargas sleeping at the foot of his bed. He gave out $30 tips at breakfast, Detective Dugan says.
The organization got shoddy. Edwin Ortiz testified that heroin distributed to him in the Bronx was brown and hard, like paint chips. The Bureau of Alcohol Tobacco and Firearms raided Mr. Reyes's prime spot, 1770 Andrews Avenue. That set off a domino effect that landed Mr. Ortiz and Mr. Vargas in prison.
Facing life imprisonment, Mr. Ortiz gave up Mr. Reyes and he was arrested in Miami. At some point, Mr. Reyes met Mr. Vargas in prison. "He said, you know, you could really hurt me," Mr. Vargas recalled.
He said Mr. Reyes at first threatened him, then told him they could escape to the Dominican Republic. Then he said Mr. Reyes tried a different tactic: implicate Mr. Medina instead, Mr. Reyes urged, thus trying to throw to the dogs the man who killed for him and took a bullet in his body for him.
Later, at his trial, Mr. Reyes's face showed no expression as he sat in his wheelchair watching Mr. Vargas testify for two weeks against him. Perhaps, as his interpretation of "The Westies" and "The Sicilian" suggests, he understood.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1243 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By HUBERT B. HERRING 

 BODY:

WELFARE PROTEST
Goodbye, Mr. Clinton
 
The welfare bill that the President signed a few weeks ago hasn't been too popular at the Department of Health and Human Services. But reactions have varied. Donna E. Shalala, the department's Secretary, has joined those who seem to be saying that Bill Clinton needs to be re-elected to undo the welfare damage done by Bill Clinton. "This bill will be changed," she vowed, "until we get it right." Others at the agency, though, are not buying this Mobius-strip logic. Last week two top welfare officials -- Mary Jo Bane and Peter B. Edelman -- resigned in protest. For Mr. Clinton, the departure of Mr. Edelman had to sting. He and his wife, Marian Wright Edelman of the Children's Defense Fund, had started as staunch members of the Friends-of-Bill club, but as Mr. Clinton was washed to the right by the conservative tide, the Edelmans receded in the liberal distance. Last week Mr. Edelman was simply waving goodbye.
 
WALL STREET
What Goes Up Must Go Up
 
In July the party seemed to be over on Wall Street, as the Dow industrials took some scary drops. But the resounding message last week was: Never mind. The Dow piled gain on top of gain, soaring to a new record of tktktktk. Does it make any sense? Not really. After that summer scare, money is flowing back into mutual funds -- the market's lifeblood -- but it isn't the flood it was earlier in the year. And higher interest rates -- the market's mortal enemy -- seem highly possible when the Federal Reserve next tinkers with them in a week or so. The explanation seems to be that investors have it fixed in their minds that this is a bull market that won't die. By that logic, a market dip means "buy." Period.
 
TERRORISM
Can Air Travel Be Perfect?
 
If everyone at an airport, whether traveler or employee, faced the scrutiny accorded, say, a Supreme Court nominee, you can bet there would be no terrorism. But perhaps three or four people would fly a day, having each spent a week at the airport. So what's needed is the right balance between reward (everyone flies) and risk (getting blown up). Some would say that balance had been found, considering how vastly safer it is to fly than to drive or do a lot of other things. But the bottomless mystery of the T.W.A. crash created a vacuum that demanded to be filled by action (especially -- dare one say it? -- in an election year). Last week, sure enough, President Clinton proposed sweeping changes, from criminal background checks on workers to searching the luggage of "suspicious" passengers (is that you, Big Brother?). Airlines and airport operators, though, raising the specter of three-hour airport check-ins, quickly questioned whether such steps were practical.
 
IMAGE INSURANCE
Bad News, Spin Away
 
It doesn't matter what you do, Henry Higgins said, as long as you pronounce it properly. What a sadly outdated notion. For one thing, E-mail means never having to pronounce anything. Now it doesn't matter what you do; it's how it looks. Image is all. Say a corporation gets bad news, be it a defective product or a defecting executive. Given the speed of communications today, that news will hit the streets in no time. You need spin control, fast. Miss a beat and the egg gets imbedded on your face. Enter National Union Fire Insurance, the first insurer to cover the hiring, if the need arises, of a public-relations firm for "crisis management." Spin the bad news fast enough, the theory goes, and it will just fly away.
 
SECOND THOUGHTS
Tax-Cut Memories
 
It was 1981. Ronald Reagan was smiling, taxes were falling, all was Republican with the world. To Bob Dole, it was the good old days, and now he wants to revive that tax-cut crusade. A survivor of those good old days, though, has distinct second thoughts. Murray Weidenbaum, who as Mr. Reagan's chief economic adviser applauded the 1981 cuts, warned last week against copying them. It is easy to cut taxes, he said at a gathering of business economists, but far harder to cut spending -- a lesson he "learned the hard way." Simply cutting taxes, he said, is like pumping air into a flat tire without patching up the holes first. Easy for him to say. He isn't running for office.
 
TAKEOVERS
Smiling at Duracell
 
It was hard to tell whether it was a lovefest or a merger announcement. Analysts and executives fell all over themselves in applauding Gillette's deal last week to buy Duracell for $7 billion in stock. A perfect fit, they all cried. Few acquisitions "could be better for Gillette." "Duracell absolutely fits their core competencies." But as often happens, the big winner is not Duracell or Gillette, but a deal maker in the wings. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts -- sound familiar in these billion-dollar windfalls? -- put up just $350 million to buy Duracell in 1988, and now stands to make billions on its controlling stake. But do those billions emerge from thin air, or come out of someone's pocket? An enduring capitalist mystery.
 
HEALTH INSURANCE
The Mighty A.A.R.P.
 
If the A.A.R.P. speaks, the elderly listen. So it's clearly a big deal when the group bestows its seal of approval on a health insurer -- roughly a $4 billion deal. That's the amount of business Prudential will lose yearly after the A.A.R.P. switched its blessing last week to United Healthcare. There is not much of a profit margin in this business as it stands, of course -- the lure for United Healthcare will be the shot it will get at persuading elderly policyholders to switch to H.M.O.'s. That's where it can make some money. And though 3,500 jobs will be lost at Prudential, United Healthcare has committed itself to hiring many of them.
 
SOCIAL POLICY
Depressed? Build a Prison
 
Whenever America has a bad day, it seems, it cheers itself up by building a few prisons. Keep locking people up, we say, and our problems will evaporate. The trouble is, it costs such vast sums to build and run prisons that there is less left for society's other needs. Usually that trade-off is hard to see up close, obscured in the shifting billions in Government checkbooks. But in Los Angeles last week the choice was stark: whether to take $19 million away from poverty relief so a new high-tech prison could open. An advocate for the homeless estimated that it would cost the same to support 10 people on relief as to support one prisoner. And another predicted that crime would rise by a third if relief was cut. This time, Los Angeles stuck with poverty relief. But the prison industry keeps booming.
 
TRADE POLITICS
Too Many Best Friends
 
Imagine calling everyone you know, wife-beater and model citizen alike, your dearest friend. Sounds silly, doesn't it? Yet the United States has done exactly that, using the gushy phrase "most-favored nation" for, well, any country we trade with. This relic of some long-forgotten tariff wars is not just linguistic nonsense, though, that can be easily ignored. Every time the topic of, say, China comes up, indignation erupts. How can we give special treatment to such a nation? Take heart. An elegant solution is at hand: Since we obviously can't change China, we'll just change the words. The Senate voted last week to scrap "most-favored" and make it "normal" trade relations. "It's a victory for clarity," said Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a co-sponsor of the bill. True, China still won't be a model world citizen -- but is anyone really?

HEADLINE: The Nation;
What Welfare Research?

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN trying to remake the nation's welfare system, members of Congress and President Clinton rarely cite any data or research to support their arguments. And for good reason.
The data are skimpy, and on many important questions, the research results are ambiguous, contradictory, confusing or nonexistent. 
 In a survey of the available research, Robert A. Moffitt, an economist at Johns Hopkins University, said that studies of people moving on and off welfare "appear to suffer from a lack of theoretical content and from a failure adequately to construct testable hypotheses."
More than 4.5 million adults receive monthly cash payments through the main welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children. But it is difficult to determine from Government data how many of them work while on welfare or how long they stay on the rolls.
Many members of Congress want to change the behavior of welfare recipients, to increase work effort and reduce out-of-wedlock childbearing. But Mr. Moffitt said that lawmakers had "ignored even the small amount of research" that has been done on the effects of various incentives.

Little Demand
By contrast, a student of health insurance or pension policy can find dozens of studies by Government agencies, business organizations, labor unions, Wall Street analysts and actuaries describing who gets what benefits. For such research, there is a large market.
Christine Seltz, a spokeswoman for Hewitt Associates, an employee benefits consulting firm based in Lincolnshire, Ill., said, "When a company considers offering a new benefit, it wants to know whether such benefits are prevalent in its industry, in its region and nationwide."
But there is less demand for data on welfare benefits.
For social insurance programs like Social Security, the Government keeps detailed data on a person's work history and lifetime earnings to compute benefits. But there is no need for such data in determining who gets A.F.D.C. All that matters is a person's income and assets.
It is relatively easy for the Federal Government to collect data on Social Security, Medicare and food stamps because Congress sets uniform national eligibility criteria and the Federal Treasury pays the entire cost of benefits. By contrast, welfare varies from state to state. So the task of compiling data is more formidable.
Social Security is able to provide an abundance of data to defend its programs. For example, it says, "12 percent of the aged are poor, and 42 percent are kept out of poverty by their Social Security benefits," so more than half of the elderly would be below the official poverty line without Social Security.
But welfare has proved harder to track and thus harder to defend. The number of people in a household, the number of workers and the amount of income change frequently. Few welfare recipients have regular work habits. Some work in the underground economy.
Barbara Boyle Torrey, executive director of the Commission on Behavioral and Social Sciences and Education at the National Academy of Sciences, said: "Poverty is a very dynamic concept. Because people continually go in and out of poverty, you need to be able to follow the same person over time. That is difficult."

No Complaints
What's more, in recent years, it seems, poor people have been less outspoken, less well organized and less likely to report the effects of changes in Government programs. While a small cut in the cost-of-living adjustment for Social Security would generate a torrent of mail to Congress and studies from the American Association of Retired Persons, welfare recipients register few protests when the purchasing power of their benefits erodes.
Studies of welfare are often confounded by other factors as well. Changes in the economy at large, like a recession or strong economic growth, can obscure the effects of changes in welfare policy. Moreover, there are complex interactions between welfare and other benefit programs like food stamps and Medicaid, which are often changed by Congress at the same time. Thus, researchers have found it difficult to separate and measure the effects of each change.
Of course, there have been many attempts to study the effects of welfare, and Democrats cited some of those studies in defending parts of the current system. But Republicans in Congress tended to view data on the old welfare system as irrelevant to the new world they were creating.
So what about the future? Evelyn Ganzglass, director of employment and social services policy at the National Governors' Association, said, "We're entering largely uncharted territory," with time limits on benefits and no one entitled to any specific amount of cash assistance.
Under the new law, states can go off in 50 different directions. Each state is supposed to collect data on each family receiving Federal aid, and in theory these reports will provide a treasure-trove for researchers.
But Peter T. Gottschalk, a visiting scholar at the Russell Sage Foundation in New York, is doubtful. "States will have every incentive to make it look as if their programs are successful," he said. "Unless you have impartial data, it will be impossible to determine whether these reforms succeed or fail."

HEADLINE: Political Briefing;
The Congress and the Issues

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

 BODY:

The West
'War' Refrain Is Given the Boot
Bolo ties and cowboy boots come out of the closet at this time of year in the West, as candidates in costume try to appear like ol' Clem at the electoral corral. What worked for Republicans in 1994 was an accusation that the Clinton Administration's restrictions on logging, grazing and mining were a "War on the West" against average folk. 
 But what played in Casper and Durango in 1994 looked like anti-environment oratory once it got to Congress and was given broad exposure. So this year, Speaker Newt Gingrich has told his troops out West to curb the war talk and show up at tree-planting photo-ops instead.
It may be too late. While Republicans believe their candidates will ultimately prevail, Democrats say they could pick up 10 or more Congressional seats in the West, and at least 1 gain in the Senate -- in part because suburban swing voters disagree with recent Republican positions on public lands, forests and endangered species. Republicans say the West will return to the party fold, albeit by a narrow margin.
When Bob Dole showed up in Utah last month with the War on the West refrain -- his campaign has yet to get the word that Mr. Gingrich has sent out -- he was blasted by the Salt Lake Tribune for embracing "the Whine of the West."
Senator Larry E. Craig of Idaho, considered perhaps the best friend of the mining and ranching industries in Congress, has recently appeared in advertisements where he is seen rafting down a wild stream.
In the race for the open Senate seat in Colorado, Tom Strickland, a Democrat, has been criticizing Representative Wayne Allard, a Republican, for his vote in favor of a measure to sell some Federal lands. Recent polls give Mr. Strickland, a lawyer, a seven-point lead in the race to replace Senator Hank Brown, a Republican who is stepping down.
Some of the bloodletting has come from within the party. In Arizona, Robin Silver, an emergency room physician, mounted a Republican primary challenge against Representative John Shadegg based entirely on environmental issues. Mr. Silver said his party "basically created the most anti-environment Congress in history."
Mr. Shadegg, who won the primary by a comfortable margin, said his own polling showed people "all want clean air and and clean water, but they don't want extreme approaches on the issue, like throwing people off Federal lands."
In Wyoming, another hotly contested Senate race in a ranching stronghold has steered clear of War on the West sloganeering.
"That whole issue has abated," said Kathy Karpan, the Democrat who is facing Mike Enzi, a Republican, for the seat being vacated by Senator Alan K. Simpson, also a Republican.
Another sign that times have changed: Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt has yet to be hung in effigy this year. Two years ago, the mock lynching of Mr. Babbitt was a regular feature of property rights rallies in the West.

Tobacco Ads
Racing Fans Likely To Feel the Squeeze
It is no secret that the Clinton Administration's attack on cigarette advertising has hurt the President among the farmers and others on tobacco road. But the proposed restrictions on smoking advertisements may cost the President another constituency: the fans of stock car racing.
Big tobacco companies are the main sponsors of the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing, or Nascar. The sport drew 5.3 million people to tracks across the country last year. At places like the Charlotte Motor Speedway in North Carolina, the Winston label is ubiquitous at trackside. It adorns buildings, carpets and patches worn by drivers like Jimmy Spencer, whose "Smoking Joe" Ford is sponsored by Camel.
All that could change under the President's proposed regulations restricting cigarette advertising from sporting events.
"I don't think it's right what Clinton is doing to Nascar," said Ron Burts, a racing fan. "Who knows what could happen to the Winston Cup?"
Another fan, Bruce Buske of Dallas, said: "It's more government censorship of my freedom to choose. And I look at all the good things the Winston Cup does for the family unit."
Of course, there are racing fans who despise the restrictions but still plan to vote for Mr. Clinton.
"It just ain't racing if it don't have Winston on it," said Joe Armstrong, a retired mechanic, who plans to vote for the President.
Recent polls indicate that among cigarette smokers, Mr. Clinton leads Mr. Dole by a ratio of almost 2-to-1.

Nebraska
Agriculture Issues Still Top the Menu
Red meat, corn and hay -- these are still the staples of Nebraska's agricultural economy, and they hold the political food chain together as well. Big Government generally does not come in for a lot of praise, unless it is used to sell Nebraska foodstuffs overseas.
In the contest for the Nebraska Senate seat being vacated by J. James Exon, a Democrat, a big issue has developed over how much the Federal Government should continue to help sell the home-grown products of the state.
The Democratic candidate, Gov. Ben Nelson, wants more Government help. He would like to see more effort made to promote specialty products, like pasta and ethanol.
The Republican nominee, Chuck Hagel, an investment banker, supports the changes in a recent Congressional bill, which gradually reduces Government agricultural subsidies. Republicans far outnumber Democrats in Nebraska, but recent polls give the Democrat, Mr. Nelson, a 20-point lead, perhaps proving the old saw about knowing on which side your bread is buttered.

Louisiana
This Is the Song That Never Ends
Conspiracy alert: Harry Connick, the New Orleans area district attorney who defeated James Garrison in 1970, looks to be in trouble this fall, facing Morris Reed, a lawyer. Mr. Garrison, of course, said he had figured out the key to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, bringing charges that were quickly dismissed by a jury. He alleged a conspiracy between the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency. Mr. Connick is the father of Harry Connick Jr., the singer often compared to Frank Sinatra. Mr. Sinatra was a close associate of Mr. Kennedy. Mmmmmm. TIMOTHY EGAN

HEADLINE: POLITICS;
Christian Coalition Offers Dole Both Cheers and Sharp Prodding

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Bob Dole made a brief and unscheduled appearance at a Christian Coalition conference today, bringing cheers from the rank and file of the politically powerful religious conservatives but barbs from some of their most outspoken leaders.
Pat Robertson, the founder of the Christian Coalition, told the nearly 5,000 delegates that it would take "a miracle from Almighty God" for Mr. Dole to win the Presidency and that Mr. Dole would win only if he made moral issues the core of his campaign. 
 "It's not the economy, stupid -- it's morality, stupid, and that's where the issue's going to be decided in this campaign," Mr. Robertson said.
But in Mr. Dole's brief comments to the Christian Coalition today, he focused mainly on the issues that have become the standard in his stump speech: his economic plan, school choice and the war on drugs.
Only in the last moments of his speech did he touch on one of the issues dear to religious conservatives, -- the legislation President Clinton vetoed that would have outlawed a type of late-term abortions that opponents call "partial birth" abortions. An override vote is scheduled next week in the Republican-controlled Congress.
"When I get the partial-birth abortion bill, I won't veto it, I'll sign it," Mr. Dole said, drawing his most thunderous applause. "I still believe, if you continue to work, you may yet persuade enough Senators so we can override this terrible veto."
The Republican Presidential candidate made the "surprise" visit during the final session of the Christian Coalition's two-day "Road to Victory '96" conference to introduce his running mate, Jack Kemp, who was the featured speaker. Mr. Dole had turned down an invitation to speak at the conference but decided to appear after he came under a barrage of criticism from Christian Coalition followers and after a personal appeal from the group's leader, Ralph Reed Jr.
"If you want to retain control of the House and Senate," Mr. Reed told his members at the opening session on Friday, "and you want to have any chance at all of gaining the White House, you had better not retreat from the pro-life and pro-family stands that made you a majority party in the first place."
Campaign aides said Mr. Dole had turned down the first request to speak to the group because the conference conflicted with campaign events. But, in some circles, Mr. Dole appeared to be distancing himself from the Religious Right in order to appeal more centrist voters. In his place, the campaign sent Mr. Kemp, who is very popular with religious conservatives.
The Christian Coalition is the largest and most prominent organization among politically active religious conservatives. Evangelical Protestants, the core group of the coalition, are credited with helping Republicans take control of both chambers of Congress two years ago. At the urging of Mr. Reed, the coalition threw its support behind Mr. Dole early in this year's Republican Presidential primary races.
But Mr. Dole was not welcomed by the crowd with the same enthusiasm that greeted him at last year's gathering, when he was one of the keynote speakers.
Before Mr. Dole took the stage, Mr. Robertson reminded the audience that evangelical conservatives had provided the margin of victory for George Bush in the 1988 Presidential election and that Mr. Dole needed similar help in 1996.
"I want to say this as clearly as I can," he said. "This campaign for the Presidency is far behind. Twenty-three points is about as insurmountable an obstacle as I can think of.
"In my personal opinion," he continued, "there's got to be a miracle from Almighty God to pull it out, and it could happen."
The Christian Coalition joined other conservative forces at the Republican National Convention to make sure that the party platform retained a strong anti-abortion stance, a move that alienated some moderates.
Initially, Mr. Dole sided with the moderates who attempted to weaken the anti-abortion language in the platform, fearing that such language could drive away some women voters and moderate voters. But the candidate backed down after a strong push by party conservatives.
Shortly after the convention, Mr. Dole riled party conservatives when he said that he had not read the platform. On the stump, neither Mr. Dole nor Mr. Kemp have made abortion an issue.
But Mr. Kemp used the platform today to deliver the strongest anti-abortion message of the Republican campaign.
"It is impossible to speak credibly about compassion for the weak while allowing the tragedy of partial-birth abortion," he said.
"These children, just moments away from their first breath, must be allowed to live," he added. "Our nation must be humane enough and inclusive enough to welcome them into life. And let me say that as President, Bob Dole would never veto any attempt to save these precious lives."

HEADLINE: ELECTION IN BOSNIA: THE SCENE;
Traveling to the Polls Is Difficult for Many

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER

DATELINE: ALISICI, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Sept. 14

 BODY:
Wearing a suit, black cardigan and white shirt and tie, Hivzo Burazezovic and his wife, Nusreta, in a patterned dress, walked with dignity into a war-damaged house in this rural village at 9 A.M. today to cast their votes in the Bosnian election.
The Burazezovics are Muslims, and they were the first to vote in this Serb-controlled village. Behind them another 100 or so Muslims waited, some somber, some in tears. They included a man from Canada and a woman from Stuttgart, Germany, who had journeyed here to vote. 
 They were escorted here by the police and international monitors, with NATO armored personnel carriers omnipresent, from the Muslim-controlled town of Sanski Most across the boundary line that divides the Serb-controlled part of Bosnia from the federation of Muslims and Croats.
"I voted for the parties that want to have a unitary Bosnia," said Mr. Burazezovic, 59, an economist who once managed the Hotel Prijedor and now lives as a refugee.
His wife, an elementary school teacher in Prijedor before Serbs dismissed her when they took control of the town and expelled the Muslims, said, "We would like to have voted in Prijedor." Around Prijedor were some of the most notorious Serbian concentration camps.
Prijedor is only 10 miles north of here, on a road past cornfields and along the Sana River, which is pushing over its banks these days.
Other Muslim voters, many wiping back tears, were even closer to their former homes.
"My house is just over there," said Nurka Alisic, 54, pointing to the hills and choking with tears. It was the first time she had been back since 1992, but this was as close to her former house as she would get today.
But in getting even this far, the Muslims who voted here had made a journey that Bosnian Serb leaders had denied to their ownpeople wanting to go the other way.
The election day odysseys of Muslim and Serbian refugees along the 18 miles of road between Sanski Most and Prijedor illustrated the different approaches to the elections by the Muslim leaders on one side and those leading the Bosnian Serb republic on the other.
And they provided more evidence of the utter failure to realize two fundamental principles of the Bosnia peace accord negotiated in Dayton, Ohio. Nearly a year after the agreement was signed, there is little freedom of travel in the country and refugees have been unable to return home.
"These are not elections," said an irate election official at the Prijedor office of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which is overseeing the elections. "It is not free and fair. And it began with the registration process."
Registration irregularities were minor in the Muslim-Croat Federation but were extensive in the Bosnian Serb republic, he said.
Under the peace agreement, refugees had the right to vote in the places where they used to live, either by absentee ballot or by going in person today. But in furtherance of their desire for an ethnically "pure" Bosnian Serb state, Serbian officials used intimidation and coercion to force Serbian refugees from federation areas to vote in the Serbian towns and villages where they are now living as refugees.
And today there were no buses and no polling places for Serbs who wanted to go back to their homes and vote.
In the northwestern part of Bosnia, only four buses with Serbs crossed into federation territory, said Alum Roberts, the spokesman in Banja Luka for the United Nations International Police Task Force.
It was one year ago this very day that Savo Strivicevic, a Serb, was forced to flee his village near Kljuc, where he had worked in a furniture factory.
He now lives as a refugee in Ljubija, a mountain village that has towering trees but is rundown physically. Today, he was sure he would be able to make the 40-mile journey home. To vote, yes, but more important, he wanted to see his 76-year-old mother, who is ill and could not flee when he did.
"I do not know if she is still alive," he said. Mr. Strivicevic had appealed to local Serb leaders to help him get home, but they told him they were not providing any transportation, that he would have to get there on his own. But it is not safe for Serbs to go alone back to the federation.
"I'd like to vote for a united Bosnia, so I can live where I used to live," Mr. Strivicevic said when asked whom he was going to vote for.
But when he went to vote today, he discovered that the municipal officials had filled out his registration form improperly. Mr. Strivicevic went to the European security organization's office for help, but the election officials there said there was nothing they could do for him.
It was before the morning fog lifted -- bringing crisp but clear voting day weather -- that Lazar and Milica Baic were on a walk of several miles to the polling place in Prijedor. They had wanted to vote in Drvar, their former home, two hours by car southwest of Prijedor, but there was no transportation.
With no freedom of travel, the only way for refugees from one part of Bosnia to vote in their former towns and villages was along 19 special routes agreed on at the last minute by the federation and the Bosnian Serbs. Only buses were permitted on the routes.
Neither the European organization nor NATO troops provided transportation. The federation provided buses to take its people across the ethnic boundary line. The Bosnian Serb republic did nothing. It did not ask for polling places to be set up for Serbs on the other side of the boundary, similar to the one here on this side for Muslim voters.
Officials thought that 7,000 people would cross from the federation to vote at this rural polling place. Altogether only 13 buses crossed, bringing just over 400 voters, said Mr. Roberts, the United Nations spokesman. He praised the Bosnian Serb police, who were stationed every 400 yards up and down the road here, for their professionalism.
One reason for the low turnout appeared to be the postponement of municipal elections because of registration irregularities.
"Local elections are what count," said Refik Hodzic, 25, who used to live in Prijedor but is now a refugee in Lusic Palanka, where he works for a new radio station, Free Radio Prijedor.
"This is absurd," he said, as he waited to vote in the damaged house here. "This is democracy? But it's a step we have to take."
A big enough step so that people traveled long distances.
"I could have voted by post," said Ahmed Alisic, who emigrated to Canada 40 years ago. Six years ago he returned to build a retirement home in the hills here.
"There are chestnut trees, mushrooms, places to walk," he said. "And the River Sana, for swimming," he said, the rapidly flowing river within sight of the polling place. "I wanted to bring my grandchildren."
He had almost completed the house in 1992 -- having spent $35,000 -- when the war broke out.
"You don't see it, but it's in that direction, just behind that hill," he said pointing.
Waiting in line, he still was unsure whom he would vote for. "I'm a Muslim, but not very religious," he said, adding that therefore he probably would not vote for the ruling Muslim party, the Party of Democratic Action. "I want a united Bosnia, to see all my friends."

HEADLINE: AIDS Patients Slipping Through Safety Net

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
William Krantz, a 29-year-old chef who lives in Indianapolis, has AIDS and no health insurance. Early this year, as his medical bills began to mount, he applied for a program that was supposed to help people like him get medications. He is still waiting.
The program, the AIDS Drug Assistance Program, or A.D.A.P., was established by Congress in 1990 to provide money to states to assist people with AIDS who fall through the cracks of the American health care system. They are not poor enough for Medicaid, the medical insurance program that pays for the drugs and other health care of low-income people. And they either have no insurance or insufficient insurance to buy drugs for themselves. 
 The problem is that more and more people are applying for the AIDS drug program, encouraged by the discoveries of drug combinations that seem to keep H.I.V., the AIDS virus, at bay. At the same time, the price of AIDS therapy has soared, with more and more drugs added to the arsenal. As a consequence, many states, and many people with AIDS, are having to make tough choices.
In a recent survey, the National Alliance of State and Territorial AIDS Directors found that some states had set up waiting lists for people who want to join the AIDS drug program. Others have closed their enrollments or limited how much they will pay for each patient. And nearly half of all states were limiting or expecting to limit access to a new class of drugs called protease inhibitors. These drugs, used in combination with older drugs, can knock the AIDS virus down to nearly undetectable levels in many patients and have restored the health of many who were severely debilitated, but they cost $10,000 to $20,000 a year.
The group found that the programs in New York and Connecticut paid for protease inhibitors and that New Jersey's program would start paying for them next month. None of the three states' programs had a waiting list.
The A.D.A.P. Working Group, a Washington group that lobbies for AIDS patients who need help paying for drugs, calculates that the $190 million that Congress and the states have appropriated for AIDS Drug Assistance Programs in the 1996 fiscal year is less than half the amount needed. In 1995, the programs served 70,030 people, a 20 percent increase from the previous year.
Mr. Krantz is one who fell victim to the cutbacks. "Right now I can't get any of the drugs I need unless I pay out of pocket," he said. "I had to get samples from my doctor for six drugs." He added that he could not afford the prescriptions. He started trying in Janauary to get into the AIDS Drug Assistance Program in Indiana. But he said, "I don't think I'm any closer to being accepted now than I was then." And protease inhibitors, he added, are out of the question because of their cost.
Paul Chase, at the Indiana Community AIDS Action Network, said that 400 people were in Indiana's AIDS drug program and that 75 were on the waiting list.
Mr. Krantz's roommate, Ray Ford, has taken another tack, impoverishing himself so he qualified for Medicaid, which meant that all his drugs, including protease inhibitors, would be paid for. To qualify for Medicaid, he said, his income cannot exceed $482 a month. Mr. Krantz said he was not ruling out this solution, but, for now, he wants to work.
Dr. Uwe Reinhardt, a Princeton University health economist, said that tales like Mr. Krantz's were nothing new in American medicine. The very poor are covered by Medicaid, which pays for prescription drugs and medical care, he said. Many other Americans have health insurance plans supplemented by their salaries or savings. But, he said, that leaves "the lower middle class, the gas station attendant, the taxi driver, the waiter." And these people, "the silent sufferers of America," Dr. Reinhardt said, "take all the abuse."
Some people with some diseases, however, are provided for. The Federal Government pays the medical bills for all people whose kidneys have failed. The State of California pays for clotting factor, a $100,000-a-year drug, for all hemophiliacs.
"You've heard of the natural lottery?" asks Dr. Norman Daniels, a philosophy professor at Tufts University who specializes in health care. "You have to be lucky in the disease you get.
"When you have a system that doesn't have a fundamental commitment to helping people, what you have is politicians and lobbyists and activists who are trying to make headway. You end up with irrationalities. A favorite disease gets selected."
All too often, the silent AIDS suffers are indeed silent, advocates say. Unwilling to go public, reticent about saying they have AIDS, many will speak only anonymously and make do as best they can.
A woman who lives in a Washington suburb, for example, who spoke only on the condition that her name not be used, explained that some people in her church did not know she had AIDS. Her insurance policy has a $3,000 annual cap for prescription drugs, which she quickly exceeded. She has begun taking protease inhibitors, which cost $900 a month, she said, and she cannot bear to give them up. "I can actually feel the difference in my body," she said. "I generally feel good."
So with her insurance exhausted, the woman started charging her drugs on her credit cards and applied to the AIDS Drug Assistance Program. But the program would not pay for her prescriptions for protease inhibitors, she said. And she has reached the limit on her credit cards.
"I haven't exhausted all my resources yet, but it's really rough," the woman said. "It's rough and it's sad."
Even affluent and outspoken AIDS patients can have a hard time. Jeff Bloom, a volunteer lobbyist at the AIDS Action Council, a Washington group that represents 1,400 AIDS service organizations, said he was so ill from AIDS in 1994 that he retired from his job as chief executive and chief financial officer at an audiovisual corporation. He paid his own insurance premiums after he retired, but he, too, had a $3,000 annual cap on his prescriptions. That, he said, covered only two months' worth of the drugs he needed. He said he had got drugs by asking his friends to persuade their doctors to prescribe more drugs than they needed so they could give him the surplus.
Dr. Wayne Greaves, an AIDS expert at Howard University in Washington, said he knew that many patients did what Mr. Bloom did. There are dangers with such an approach, he said, because the drugs must be taken regularly, on a rigid schedule, so it is risky to allow supplies to depend on the generosity of friends and their doctors.
Drug companies have plans that provide drugs for the destitute, but many patients do not qualify. Even when a patient does qualify, the doctor must spend hours on telephone calls and paper work to get the patient enrolled in the program.
Dwight A. Knuckles, a social worker at Blacks Assisting Blacks Against AIDS, a St. Louis organization, said he had found himself "with my hand out, begging" for drugs for his clients or for doctors willing to enroll his clients in drug company programs for the destitute. Even so, he said, he can "only help about 5 percent" of his 65 clients.
Advocates for people with AIDS say that at the very least, the Federal Government and most states must chip in more for the drug assistance programs.
"We're at a turning point, and I honestly don't know how we're going to resolve this one," said Gary Rose, the research and treatment coordinator at the AIDS Action Council. "For the first time, we have this therapy, you're seeing your friends get out of bed, people you did not expect ever to get out of bed. But you can't have these people out in the world talking about their experience and then look at someone who's less fortunate than you and say, 'You can't have it.' "
