HEADLINE: ELECTION IN BOSNIA: THE OVERVIEW;
BOSNIA HOLDS VOTE WITH FEW REPORTS OF REAL VIOLENCE

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Sept. 14

 BODY:
With only minor incidents of violence, hundreds of thousands of Bosnians voted today in elections that the United States and its allies hope are a major step toward democracy and ethnic integration in a country bitterly divided by war.
Turnout was heavy, with European monitors reporting that 60 to 70 percent of Bosnia's 2.9 million eligible voters had cast ballots for a three-person presidency, a national parliament, regional parliaments and presidents for the Muslim, Serbian and Croatian enclaves and provincial councils. 
 These institutions are to begin functioning within two weeks, international officials in Sarajevo said, and they will clearly be the last instrument left to overcome the stark division of the Bosnian state into three enclaves that have so far evidenced neither the tolerance nor the cooperation envisioned in the peace accord signed last year.
"These elections were necessary as the first, concrete step on the long, long road that will take generations for peace and reconciliation," said Flavio Cotti, the Swiss Foreign Minister and chairman of the European organization that ran the vote.
"If opposition parties can place in the different parliaments even a few members, then perhaps this will open a pluralist dialogue," he said. "What four years of war created cannot be eliminated in a few months or by elections. You need generations now for the fear to disappear from the souls of the people."
Tensions and divisions were evident today. Relatively few voters crossed the old confrontation lines to vote in areas where they once lived but that are now held by a different ethnic group. Many Bosnian Serbs and Croats appeared intent on electing leaders who will push for continued partition and independence from the central Government in Sarajevo.
And this evening the party of President Alija Izetbegovic, who leads the Muslim-dominated Bosnian Government, said that because of "voting irregularities" in Serb-held areas, it would consider the vote there "invalid" and would contest the results.
European monitors acknowledged problems in all parts of Bosnia, with voters being dropped from registration lists or the wrong lists turning up at polling stations.
But Robert H. Frowick, the head of the European mission monitoring the vote, said he considered the election to be "almost entirely free of abuse." And he answered Mr. Izetbegovic's charges by saying that the Muslim-led Party of Democratic Action had no authority to decide if the elections in Serb-held areas were valid or invalid.
Muslims, Serbs and Croats went to the polls today with vastly different expectations.
Many Muslims hoped the vote, a crucial part of the peace plan, would be the first step to reunifying a country they believe they have a right to control.
But the Bosnian Serbs see in the vote the final legitimization of their own state. Bosnian Serb leaders openly call for union with Serbia and campaigned on a promise that they would secure a permanent partition of Bosnia.
Such a partition, many here fear, could lead to a war started by a resurgent Muslim leadership intent on taking control of a state the international community insists is one entity. Or it could see NATO forces bogged down here for years in an effort to keep the factions from renewing the war.
The Bosnian Croat leadership, although formally linked with the Muslims in a federation, is already so closely allied with neighboring Croatia that it is hard to tell where Croatia ends and the Croat-controlled part of Bosnia begins.
Nationalist leaders who governed during the war are expected to receive most of the votes, and many opposition parties, in all three enclaves, complained of harassment and intimidation.
Municipal elections that were also to have taken place today were postponed because of manipulation of voter lists, fraud and harassment of local candidates.
But today the focus was less on the outcome of the vote, which will not be known for three or four days, than on the often confusing voting procedures set up by the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which is overseeing the vote.
Casting ballots took as long as 10 minutes per person, with each voter required to fill out four pieces of paper. Voters at times had trouble locating polling stations, many polling stations received the wrong ballots or registration lists, and some had to be closed for a few hours until the correct papers were delivered.
In Tuzla and other parts of northeastern Bosnia, European monitors said at least several thousand voters did not appear on registration lists at their local polling stations. Polling hours were extended in some places in Tuzla to give monitors and the voters time to search for names on master lists. But some voters, lacking transportation and fearing having to go to check lists in areas controlled by another ethnic group, simply gave up.
In Miljevina, a hamlet outside Sarajevo, a red and white bus, lumbered into town and disgorged 21 jittery Muslim voters at a polling station surrounded by French soldiers and Bosnian Serb police.
The few Serb onlookers watched their former neighbors step out, and only after the Muslims returned the gaze of several Serbs did the two groups exchange brief greetings. One Muslim, Jakup Varajic, extended his hand to a childhood friend, who told him softly: "We were not responsible for this. We did not want the war."
Then, once again, the two groups fell silent as the Muslims filed slowly into the small town hall to vote, climbed back into the bus and left under armed escort. "This was the first time I have seen my home in five years," said Mr. Varajic, 46, "and the way things are going it may be a long time before I see it again."
Voters, especially in urban areas, often waited outside polling centers for hours. And angry crowds in Sarajevo had to be dispersed by NATO troops after they kicked in doors and smashed windows in polling stations in the Novi Grad neighborhood because of the delays.
In several overcrowded polling stations, like the Butmir School in Ilidza, a Sarajevo suburb, distraught European monitors told voters, who pushed and shoved to get through the door, that they would extend the voting hours beyond 7 P.M.
Voting rules allowed those displaced from their homes by the war to vote in either their old villages or their current residences.
The election organizers requisitioned more than 700 buses to take some 100,000 Muslim and Croat refugees into Serb territory along 19 designated routes secured by NATO peacekeeping troops. But most of the buses had only a handful of people as they crossed the old confrontation lines and many never departed because passengers failed to show up.
For instance, a fleet of buses were prepared to take up to 8,000 Muslims to Serb-held Srebrenica, but fewer than a dozen people appeared this morning at the departure point in Kladanj. During the war several thousand Muslim prisoners were executed in the area around Srebrenica, which had been designated a "safe haven" by the United Nations, after the town fell to the Bosnian Serb army in July 1995.
Muslims also failed to cross in large numbers to vote in Serb-held Doboj, in the north, and in the disputed town of Brcko.
Most Serbs, likewise, did not venture into Muslim or Croatian sectors in Bosnia, although 55 buses were available to transport any who wanted to go back. Serbs voters, under the guidance of the ruling Serb Democratic Party, chose to vote in areas now held by the Serbs.
Mr. Frowick, the head of the European monitoring group, estimated that about 20,000 Muslims and Croats crossed into Serb-held Bosnia to vote, and about 4,000 Serbs entered the Muslim-Croat Federation.
He said that Muslim voters, who would have been unable to cast a ballot in Serb-held Bosnia for one of the main Muslim candidates for the three-person presidency, may have preferred to vote where they could elect their own candidate.
There were a few of reports of trouble, although no reports of injuries. Election officials said they were investigating what might have been a hand grenade attack on the home of a local election commission chairman in the Croat-held town of Bugojna. And Bosnian radio said Serbs had fired at a polling station in Felatici, northeast of Sarajevo.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Muslim refugees waited to vote yesterday in the Serb-held town of Doboj, Bosnia, as NATO tanks loomed. (Reuters) (pg. 1); Bosnian Serbs lined up to cast their ballots in Trnovo yesterday. Many Serbs seemed intent on electing leaders who will push for continued partition. (Reuters) (pg. 14)
; Chart: "A CLOSER LOOK: Voting for a Stake in Bosnia"
 Yesterday's election was a centerpiece of the American-brokered peace accord, which took effect last December, halting four years of war that followed the splintering of Yugoslavia.
Under the Dayton accord, Bosnia continues as a single country with power split between a national government and two substates: a Bosnian-Croat Federation and a Bosnian Serb republic. The vote is to fill the newly created national and regional positions. Municipal elections were postponed because of abuses in voter registration.
 
THE ISSUES
 
The Offices
The Muslim, Croat and Serbian communities will each elect one member of a shared national presidency. Voters will also elect representatives to a two-chamber legislature, an upper house with 15 members divided equally among Muslims, Croats and Serbs and a 42-member lower house, with one-third of the seats reserved for members from the Serb region. The Federation and the Serb republic will also elect their own presidents and 140-seat legislatures. Province-level assemblies will be elected in the federation only
 
The Problems
The Dayton accord called for free and fair elections, with free movement of people and a free press. Western officials acknowledge that these conditions were not met but still hope the elections will be a step toward healing.
The parties have clashing basic goals. The Muslim-dominated government is anxious to reassert the control it once had over the entire ethnically mixed country, and many Muslims displaced by the war hope to regain homes now in Serbian hands. The government fears that, instead, they may only legitimize Serbian "ethnic cleansing" and lead toward the country's permanent division.
Serbian leaders want to use the election to consolidate control over their half of the country, with a nearly pure Serbian population.
 
Who Votes Where
The many voters who were displaced by the war, or became refugees abroad, had a choice of voting either in the place they lived before the fighting began -- which often meant crossing ethnic lines -- or voting where they now reside or plan to live. In either case they could vote in person or by absentee ballot.
 
THE CANDIDATES
 
Muslim
Thirteen major parties and many smaller ones are fielding candidates. Here are the major candidates for the national presidency.
 ALIJA IZETBEGOVIC -- President of Bosnia and head of the Muslim-dominated Party of Democratic Action that governs the country. Widely expected to win and is esteemed as the father of the Bosnian state. Has close ties to the Islamic world, but says he favors a multi-ethnic state.
SEAD AVDIC -- Head of the Joint List of United Social Democrats of Bosnia and Herzegovic, a coalition of five parties from Tuzla that have shown a strong commitment to a multi-ethnic state. Has large following and may turn out to head the biggest opposition party.
HARIS SILAJDZIC -- Former Prime Minister, heads the Party for Bosnia and Herzegovina, a liberal, western-oriented party. Widely respected, Mr. Silajdzic is critical of the ruling party's Islamic coloring; expected to get the second or third largest number of votes.
FIKRET ABDIC -- Renegade Muslim leader who ran against Mr. Izetbegovic in 1990, won but handed over the Presidency in a political deal. When war broke out he raised a private militia, carved out an independent enclave in northern Bosnia that was backed by the Croats and the Serbs until it was overrun by the Muslims last year. Deemed a war criminal by Sarajevo, he heads the Democratic Peoples' Association from exile in Croatia, but he has a following in the Bihac area.
 
Croat
KRESIMIR ZUBAK -- President of the troubled Croat-Muslim federation, has long backed a separate Croat state. Heads the Croatian Democratic Union and has strong ties with Zagreb. Expected to win the Croat seat and keep his region's close links with Croatia.
IVO KOMSIC -- Head of the coalition, Joint List, as well as the Croatian Peasant Party. The Joint List is fielding both Muslim and Croat candidates for the Presidency. Has a loyal following among liberal Bosnians who want a multi-ethnic state and is attacked by the ruling Croatian party as selling out to the Muslims. Not expected to fare well.
 
Bosnian Serb
MOMCILO KRAJISNIK -- Hard-line speaker of the current Bosnian Serb parliament and right-hand man of Radovan Karadzic, who cannot run because he is indicted for war crimes. Running on behalf of Mr. Karadzic's Serb Democratic Party, which says it will work with the Dayton agreement but has advocated secession from Bosnia and union with Serbia. Expected to win.
MLADEN IVANIC
University economist who heads the Peace and Progress coalition as well as his own party, backed by Belgrade, the Democratic Patriotic Front. Takes a less hard line toward the Dayton plan, accepting that Bosnian Serbs may no secede for many years at least. Expected to poll second. (pg. 14)

LENGTH: 1665 words

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE MIDWEST;
Crucial Midwest States Lean Toward Clinton

SERIES: The Race For President: Midwest

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 13

 BODY:
The more Presidential politics changes, the more it stays the same.
Techniques evolve. Issues come and go. Candidates vary. Population has shifted from the North and East to the South and West. Yet the balance of power in the 1996 election remains where it has been in most elections since the Civil War -- in the six or seven states of the industrialized Middle West. 
 This year, the Middle West is tipping markedly, if not yet decisively, in President Clinton's direction. In states where Democratic Presidential nominees usually win without much difficulty, like Minnesota, Mr. Clinton seems unbeatable. In the battleground states, like Missouri and Ohio, he is running strongly. Even in Indiana, historically the Republicans' most reliable regional redoubt, a recent poll showed the President with a narrow advantage.
"Ohio is still in play," said Prof. Alfred Tuchfarber of the University of Cincinnati, "but Clinton looks formidable. Bob Dole can still win, but he can no longer do it by himself. He has to have some help from Clinton or the Whitewater prosecutor or Saddam Hussein or Ross Perot -- somebody, anybody."
Another political scientist, David Rohde of Michigan State University, said his state and the Midwest as a whole were simply mirroring the nation. Mr. Rohde said that of the Presidential elections involving incumbents since the 1950's -- when reliable polling was developed -- four had approval ratings of more than 50 percent the summer before the campaign got under way: Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1956; Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964; Richard M. Nixon in 1972, and Ronald Reagan in 1984. All four won. Incumbents who had approval ratings under 50 percent lost.
"Clinton is in the first category," he said, "and nothing suggests to me that Dole can change the pattern."
A few voices -- surprisingly few -- urge caution. Former Gov. Richard F. Celeste of Ohio warned during the Democratic convention in Chicago, "No election is ever a gimme."
Robert J. Keefe, a veteran Democratic operative in Indiana, expressed skepticism about his party's chances there.
In Wisconsin, Representative Scott L. Klug, a Republican, said it seemed to him "like an incumbents' year, without the anger at people in power we've seen, which means Clinton will probably win, but not by a lot, and not with a lot of gains on Capitol Hill."
If the President wins here in the nation's sixth largest state, which casts 21 electoral votes, he will be well on his way to re-election. Which is why he took a train through Republican strongholds in western Ohio on his way to the convention, and why Mr. Dole keeps returning.
On Thursday, the Republican was in Montpelier, Ohio, where his ancestors stopped on their way to Kansas, and he devoted Friday to stumping in Ohio, Michigan and Illinois.
Four Democratic Presidential candidates have managed, often narrowly, to carry Ohio since World War II. Three were Southerners -- Johnson in 1964, Jimmy Carter in 1976, Mr. Clinton in 1992 -- and the fourth, Harry S. Truman, came from the Southern-influenced part of Missouri. All were elected.
Although Presidential contests have a smaller influence on races for the Senate and House of Representatives in this day of widespread ticket-splitting, they do have some. Politicians of both parties in this region believe Mr. Clinton will help the Democrats hold two of the three Senate seats that they are defending this year: those of Carl Levin in Michigan, who is seeking re-election, and Paul Simon of Illinois, who is retiring. Representative Richard J. Durbin is trying to hold the Illinois seat for the Democrats.
It is only in Minnesota, probably Mr. Clinton's strongest Midwestern state, where the Democratic senatorial hopeful is in trouble, and he faces a struggle because he refused to abandon liberal orthodoxy. Senator Paul Wellstone, running against former Senator Rudy Boschwitz, held a lead in the polls until he, alone among Democrats seeking re-election, voted against the Republican-backed welfare reform bill. Now polls show the race even.
Mr. Clinton's strength in the region should guarantee that the Democrats hold on to most if not all the House seats they won by less than 55 percent in the Republican sweep of 1994 -- two in Ohio, three in Michigan, and three in Minnesota, for example. It should give them a good shot at ousting several vulnerable Republicans in the region, including Representatives Dick Chrysler in Michigan and Frank A. Cremeans, whose district stretches across most of southern Ohio.
Other Republicans would be in trouble no matter how Mr. Clinton was faring. Among those on that list are Representative Martin R. Hoke, in a Democratic-leaning district in the Cleveland suburbs, now threatened by Dennis Kucinich, a former Mayor of Cleveland who seems to have lived down his reputation as the bad boy of Ohio politics, and Representative Michael Patrick Flanagan, who in 1994 captured a Democratic stronghold in northwest Chicago because the incumbent, Dan Rostenkowski, got into legal trouble.
But only if Mr. Clinton can keep his lead in the high double digits in the Midwest, which most political experts doubt, does he seem likely to set off a landslide that would bury large numbers of House Republicans hereabouts.
Here is a quick look at the seven states in the region (Missouri, traditionally described as a border state, is included because its political behavior in the last three decades has tended to resemble that of the Middle West), with electoral vote in parenthesis:
ILLINOIS (22) Illinois has strong links to Mr. Clinton; his wife grew up in the Chicago suburbs, many Chicago blacks migrated from Arkansas on the Illinois Central Railroad, and some key early staff members came from this state. The successful Democratic convention only strengthened those bonds, and the President now leads by more than 20 percentage points in the polls.
William Daley, the brother and chief political adviser of Chicago's Mayor, Richard M. Daley, said, "Short of his world blowing up, the convention put the state away for him." Republicans contest that, but not very vigorously.
OHIO (21) The unorthodox but unfailingly reliable mail poll of The Columbus Dispatch shows Mr. Clinton ahead, 52 percent to 43 percent, with Mr. Perot at 4 percent. Robert Bennett, the longtime Republican state chairman, conceded that Mr. Dole faced an uphill battle, with Mr. Clinton much stronger now than at this stage in 1992.
But he argued, "It's doable for us, if he can shoot down the idea that he can't balance the budget and cut taxes at the same time, because Clinton's support is shallow and no one feels animosity towards Dole."
Prof. John Green, who heads the Ray C. Bliss Center of Applied Politics at Akron University, said Mr. Dole had failed to find any means of exciting swing voters in Ohio, "so they're leaning to Clinton, though they're not 100 percent sure why they like him, beyond his rediscovered sense of moderation."
MICHIGAN (18) William Ballenger, editor of Inside Michigan Politics, a newsletter, sounded categorical: "It's unbelievable. Dole did what people said he had to -- good convention, good running mate and a good issue in the tax cut -- and absolutely nothing works for him. He's already out of it in Michigan, and now, just to nail it down, Saddam has given Clinton his own gulf war."
Ed Sarpolus, a Lansing pollster, sounded a bit less sure. His surveys show Mr. Clinton ahead, 47 percent to 29 percent, but he said a large undecided vote (20 percent) and the President's failure to break the 50 percent mark gave Mr. Dole a chance. But Mr. Dole's weak campaign so far, he contended, has already cost the Republicans their chance to knock off Representatives Dale E. Kildee, Sander M. Levin and Lynn Rivers, all narrow victors in 1994.
INDIANA (12) A new Indianapolis Star poll shows Mr. Clinton leading, 38 percent to 32 percent, and Frank O'Bannon, a Democrat, leading Mayor Stephen Goldsmith of Indianapolis, in the governor's race.
Representative Mark E. Souder, a Republican freshman, commented: "What's got everybody nervous is that we're in toss-up races when we should be ahead. Something isn't jelling."
But Mr. Keefe, like many other Democrats, said he was pinching himself, "because the polls sound like 1964, and we're not there yet." President Johnson carried Indiana that year, like most other states, against Barry Goldwater.
WISCONSIN (11) Mr. Clinton won here in 1992, and he leads in the polls this time. Senator Russell Feingold, a Democrat, said, "If it was the economy, stupid, in 1992, it's probably still the economy, stupid, in 1996." But Jill Hanson of Beloit, a senior Dole aide, calls Wisconsin a toss-up.
Republican Presidential nominees have carried Wisconsin in five of the last nine elections.
The closest House race appears to be the contest for the LaCrosse-area seat of Representative Steve Gunderson, a Republican who is retiring.
MISSOURI (11) Suburban St. Louis County, often the key to close Missouri elections, is proving as troublesome for Mr. Dole as suburbs elsewhere. Ken Warren, a pollster at St. Louis University, said that his latest survey showed Mr. Dole with less than 40 percent of the vote there; Republicans usually need 55 percent to carry the state.
For reasons that baffle the locals, Mr. Dole has not been buying television spots in Missouri, which has voted with the winner in every Presidential contest since the New Deal except 1956, when it backed Adlai E. Stevenson from neighboring Illinois.
MINNESOTA (10) In a Minnesota poll completed on Sept. 8, President Clinton held a commanding lead, 59 percent to 31 percent. If he wins by anything approaching that, politicians say, the marginal seats of Representatives David Minge, Bill Luther and Collin C. Peterson, all Democrats, are expected to be safe, and Gil Gutknecht, a Republican freshman from Rochester who won by a 55-to-45 margin in 1994, might run into trouble.

HEADLINE: U.S. Companies Can Live With Trade Sanctions

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Regarding "Who's Punishing Whom?" (Business Day, Sept. 11), I found comments by Donald V. Fites, the Caterpillar chairman, quoted from his unpublished opinion article, to assume gullibility on the part of the reader. 
 Mr. Fites says of unlilateral trade sanctions that the real pressure is on United States companies that must cede American jobs to foreign companies. While pandering to nationalistic instincts, such proclamations disguise the truth.
A public company's main ambition is to increase net worth. As American corporations have sent jobs overseas by the thousands and their respective stocks have risen, executives have almost without exception spoken not of retraining displaced employees but of the need to compete in the international marketplace.
Of course, this cheap labor reduces costs and propels shareholder value upward.
In truth, then, Mr. Fites should have stated simply that these unilateral trade sanctions just might inhibit raising next quarter's dividends.
 
MARK A. HUNT
Atlanta, Sept. 11, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 1596 words

HEADLINE: The New World of (Skilled) Factory Jobs

BYLINE: By JULIE MILLER 

 BODY:
THE myth is that manufacturing in Connecticut is dead. The fact is that while large military contractors and older, heavy industries have lost thousands of jobs, small and medium-sized manufacturing companies are growing. In fact, their growth is being held back by a shortage of skilled workers, according to the Connecticut Skilled Trades Coalition, which represents small and medium-sized manufacturers.
"It's the best-kept secret in the state," said James Jackson, chairman of the coalition and president of Jackson Associates, a consulting firm. 
 Small and medium-sized manufacturers -- those with an average of 60 employees each -- number nearly 6,000 in Connecticut. A survey of 115 businesses conducted last year by the coalition found an average of 19 skilled trades positions per company. There were 351 openings in jobs like precision machining, tool and die making, plastics and precision sheet metal manufacturing and general machining. Business owners indicated they expected about 2,500 job openings in skilled trades during the next decade, which represents about 22 per company. The numbers may not be large, but machinery is moved into storage and sales staffs cut, because manufacturers are unable to find skilled workers, according to the coalition. They say training for this kind of work no longer exists in Connecticut.
Business owners also say that manufacturing jobs are no longer dull, dirty and dangerous. The noisy, dingy factory has given way to clean, well-lighted, air-conditioned shops. Employees who clock in, work like robots on an assembly line and clock out at the end of the day are gone, they say. In their place are people who are expected to solve problems, make decisions, adapt quickly to new technologies and processes and work in teams. A job in one of the skilled trades pays about $30,000 at the start and $45,000 to $50,000 for 40 hours a week after several years of experience. Pay can increase to as much as $70,000 a year with overtime, said Murray Gerber, president of Prototype and Plastic Mold Company in Middletown. Jobs are available immediately after high school, and most companies offer some tuition assistance.
The 81 employees at Prototype and Plastic Mold make plastic molded parts for a variety of manufacturers, including the aircraft and aerospace industries. Computers control the plant's milling and injection molding machines and optical inspection systems. Yet, most high school graduates who apply for jobs at the plant lack the math and science skills they need, said Mr. Gerber. Furthermore, they have no work ethic, he said: "They don't understand about coming to work on time. They think that in three months, they'll be vice presidents and a year later, company presidents. The state's education system has many flaws and is far from producing the educated people needed in an industrialized society."
Students who are not interested in college are not given as much attention and encouragement as those in college preparatory courses. Parents assume that a college education is the key to their children's career success, and going to college is seen as a measure of achievement, noted Larry McHugh, president of the Middlesex County Chamber of Commerce. "That has to change," he added. "We have to start getting kids ready for jobs immediately after high school."
The Connecticut Business and Industry Association promotes collaboration between schools and businesses in order to prepare students for work. Brian Beaudin, senior vice president of the association, said: "Word must get out that manufacturing is the only industry where you can support a family out of high school with no college degree. It's tough to support a family on a bank teller's wages."
Members of the Middlesex County Chamber of commerce who responded to a survey ranked attendance and dependability highest among the traits essential for employees. Ability to work as a member of a team came next, followed by skill in reading, writing, general math, blueprint reading and problem solving. The chamber of commerce, which runs job training programs, plans to start another training course to meet the needs of its members.
As the number of workers in manufacturing has declined, apprentice programs have dwindled and failed to keep pace with technology, said Mr. Gerber. Companies that set up apprentice programs, he said, should receive tax incentives, and advanced courses should be offered in locations across the state so employees do not have to travel long distances to attend classes after work.
The state's vocational-technical schools trained many students in manufacturing technologies until large companies started downsizing. Then the apprentice system, the traditional feeder for skilled workers, died out, and enrollment in the schools dropped. Last spring, only about 400 students out of 9,500 were enrolled in manufacturing courses, said Dominic Spera, assistant superintendent of the vocational-technical schools. Mr. Spera said he blames the students' lack of interest in manufacturing on continuous publicity about downsizing.
Mr. Spera added that vocational-technical schools need to become more involved with businesses, and he is asking teachers to meet at least twice a year with business people and to follow up on recommendations made at the meetings. "We need a lot of outreach," he said. "We can't sit back any longer and wait for people to hire our students."
There are some success stories, however. At E. C. Goodwin Regional Vocational-Technical School in New Britain, enrollment in manufacturing technologies has increased to four times the number of students there four years ago, according to the instructor, Bryan Sierpinski. Mr. Sierpinski's approach to teaching has attracted attention, and local businesses are enthusiastic about hiring the school's graduates.
Through his contacts in manufacturing, Mr. Sierpinski was among the first to learn that manufacturing was indeed alive and well, he said. "Even though the attitude in the general public was that manufacturing was dying out, we knew differently. We started telling everybody four years ago that this wasn't the case."
But breaking down stereotypes and convincing students of the opportunities in manufacturing wasn't easy, Mr. Sierpinski said, and he knew he had to infuse his message with excitement. He teaches production concepts by having students make flashlights and brass whistles. He deliberately chooses objects that demand activity and produce energy. "You can't give kids economic facts and expect to teach them," he said. "You have to excite them about careers by giving them tangible examples of things they can do."
Mr. Sierpinski also teaches what he calls "workplace readiness." In fact, he concentrates more on the importance of making a high-quality product and working as a team than he does on the actual technical skills, he said. "If I can make a kid a more conscientious worker, he'll be able to survive long enough in a company to be profitable for them," he said.
At Prototype and Plastic Mold, Mr. Gerber spends $20,000 a year training an employee in a four-year apprentice program, he said. "Before I'll invest $80,000 of my money in someone, I look for a person who has a couple of years of college, state technical college, or some kind of demonstration of willingness to learn. I like people who are married, who have a car or boat to make payments on, because they have accepted responsibility and have to produce and perform."
Employees at Prototype and Plastic Mold are trained in each other's jobs to allow flexibility in the plant's operation. Currently, five employees whose jobs require knowledge of computers are selecting a new computer system for the company, Mr. Gerber said. "These are not just rote operations. We want employees to be thinking about how to make things better, improve quality and reduce production time."
David Calabrese, president of Cole Screw Machine Products Inc. in Naugatuck, said he has to turn down orders because he is unable to find qualified workers to form a second shift. "If I see an opportunity to take a new order, I need additional equipment. Then I need guys to maintain those machines. If I don't have people to maintain them, I can't keep the machines running."
With help from the Waterbury Adult Education Department, Mr. Calabrese set up a training course in math, blueprint reading, measuring instruments, quality control systems and machine operation. He recently hired two graduates and is planning to hire more. "If I have a pool of people, and they prove themselves, I'll take that extra order," he said.
At least half a dozen of the 30 employees at Cole Screw Machine Products, none of whom are college graduates, earn between $35,000 and $40,000 a year, Mr. Calabrese said. "They have to have manual dexterity and ingenuity to use these machines. They have to be able to look at a part, see it's out of tolerance, know why it happened and fix it in 10 minutes, not 10 hours. They have to be smart people. It's a very sophisticated industry."
Employees in the new type of manufacturing plant also have to keep their training up to date, Mr. Gerber said, because they can no longer expect to spend their entire working lives with one company. And unlike factory workers of the past, who were trained in only one job, manufacturing employees today perform many different tasks. "Everybody does a hundred things a day," said Mr. Calabrese. "That's the way it is in a small company. That's how we survive."

HEADLINE: At UConn, $1 Billion Plan and a New Chief

BYLINE: By JACKIE FITZPATRICK 

 BODY:
Philip E. Austin was quite content doing what he had been doing the last seven years as Chancellor of the University of Alabama, overseeing three different campuses, 43,000 students and a budget of $1.1 billion.
He'd steered the university through tough times: A stagnant budget and later a 7 percent reduction in state spending for colleges and universities in Alabama and he even took a leadership role in tax reform in the state. He liked Alabama; despite fiscal constraints, the university was strong. 
 So Dr. Austin wasn't looking for a new job when he was first approached about an opening -- the position of president of the University of Connecticut. But as members of the search committee told him about the school, about the recent passage of UConn 2000, the $1 billion 10-year plan to rebuild the university's campuses and about UConn's strategic plan, he became intrigued. "We went to seek him, he didn't seek us," said the UConn board chairman, Lewis Rome, who believes Dr. Austin is "one of the top five sitting college presidents in the country." Dr. Austin visited the university, talked with faculty members, students, administrators and with political leaders in the state and liked what he saw, he said, especially the state legislature's backing of UConn 2000.
"I think UConn is at a point of a real potential transformation from an awfully good university to a stellar university," he said, adding that he feels UConn is one of few public universities in the country on the verge of such change.
Dr. Austin has been named UConn's 13th president, succeeding Harry Hartley, a popular president who is retiring after six years in the job.
Dr. Austin will become president by late September or early October, after completing his work at Alabama University and helping his wife, Susan, orchestrate their move North.
Mr. Rome said the school was looking for a heavy hitter, and he feels they have found one in Dr. Austin. "He gives us an unprecedented opportunity to become an extraordinary public university," Mr. Rome said.
Mr. Rome said the university would also greatly miss Dr. Hartley, calling him UConn's foremost promoter. He said that three years ago when the university was faced with the prospects of laying off professors, Dr. Hartley's efforts led to legislators restoring $18.5 million to the budget. Dr. Hartley will be no stranger to UConn, returning to the faculty of the School of Education -- no doubt still in his trademark Husky blue.
Dr. Austin said overseeing the revitalization of the campus would be one of his biggest challenges as would providing "high quality modestly priced education to any citizens who are able to compete intellectually."
Dr. Hartley has said one of his concerns for the future of UConn is that, with increasing tuition costs, the university could become unaffordable.
"That's a concern nationally," Dr. Austin said. He said he wants to keep "a downward pressure on tuition" but at the same time if the university is to have "the best faculty available" in a period of dwindling or level state spending, the money has to come from some place, he said. He wants the university to grow in excellence so that it is the first choice for the state's top high school students and to that end the faculty is key.
Dr. Austin also wants UConn's branch campuses to "grow and flourish."
"I want to get out and better represent Hartford, Stamford, all of the UConn branches. If one expects broad-based legislative support, people have to have an answer to the implied question 'What have you done for us lately?' All citizens have the right of access to the intellectual repositories."
His strengths as an academic administrator are many, say those who work with him in Alabama. Dr. Austin was able to juggle the delicate balance of overseeing and keeping communication lines open among three Alabama campuses. He also worked well with legislators and the business community, said Frank Franz, president of the University of Alabama campus in Huntsville. He said that while Dr. Austin is known as a man who can get along with everyone, he doesn't shrink from difficult tasks.
"The thing that impressed me was his willingness to take on a leadership role in the state," Dr. Franz said. "A couple years ago he and some others tried to bring about tax reform in Alabama. He took that on in a forceful and persuasive way."
While the tax reform was not successful, Dr. Austin had many successes while at Alabama. He strengthened the university's ties to the business community, attracted a record number of government research grants and improved coordination among the three university campuses, Dr. Franz said. "There is absolutely nothing good in the move for Alabama but everything good for Connecticut," he said.
Dr. Austin has already met with Gov. John G. Rowland and expects to have a strong working relationship with state and national legislators. The Governor's press secretary, Dean Pagani, said the Governor looks forward to working with Dr. Austin and particularly likes his emphasis on academics.
Mana Zarinejad, a senior at UConn and the editor of the daily campus newspaper, noted that from the initial press conference, Dr. Austin dug in and started talking with legislators about the budgetary needs of UConn. "I was very impressed to see that as soon as he was voted in he was already campaigning for our operating budget," she said.
Ms. Zarinejad said the new president also seems to know just where UConn's problems lie and he plans to meet them head-on. She and other students say they will miss Dr. Hartley's accessibility and his warm demeanor and that "Dr. Austin will be a change for us. He also seems like a nice guy and we have to get to know him," she said.
Among the first people Dr. Austin wants to meet are the student leaders. "I want to get there and get a feel for everything. I want to meet with student representatives and find out what their concerns are," he said. "Students are the reason we exist."
Students and faculty are interested to see what role athletics will play on campus, in light of complaints by some faculty members that too much emphasis has been placed on sports at UConn in recent years.
Dr. Austin said the mission of a research university is "the transmission of knowledge that occurs in the classroom, the laboratory and the library." But he said athletics can create excitement on campus, get the alumni revved up and are important for an all-round university. If the N.C.A.A. rules are followed, he said, "I'm the best cheerleader there is."
Dr. Austin said the success of the UConn women's and men's basketball teams and other sports has brought positive attention to the school, allowing people from across the country to discover UConn; after they find out about its sports they can also find out about its academic programs. The challenge, he said, is to be certain academics always remain the first focus of the university.
Challenges are something Dr. Austin has always liked taking on. A North Dakota native, Dr. Austin earned a Ph.D. from Michigan State University. He served in the Army from 1969 to 1971 as an economist and at U.S. military headquarters in Saigon.
After serving in Vietnam, he was a senior economist for the Federal Office of Management and Budget and later worked as an economist and then Deputy Assistant Secretary for Education in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare. His first taste of college administration, he said, was as director of a doctoral program at George Washington University in Washington, D.C.
From the start, he found university-level education to be just what he wanted to pursue. "I think high-quality education is the great equalizer in society," he said.
Dr. Austin spent six years as provost and vice president for academic affairs at Baruch College of the City University of New York. During that time he had a weekend home in New Fairfield. Dr. Austin then become president of Colorado State University. After five years he was named chancellor at the University of Alabama.
Dr. Austin, who is the father of two young sons, 10 and 8, says he looks forward to settling into the president's mansion with his wife and sons, and to diving right into his new job. "To say that I'm honored is a great understatement," he said.

HEADLINE: The Changing Voice of Local Radio

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
LONGTIME listeners to the Norwalk radio station WNLK got a rude awakening of sorts when they tuned in to the David Smith morning show on July 30. Not only did they not hear Mr. Smith; they also did not, in a sense, hear WNLK.
What they heard instead was the morning news team of Stamford radio station WSTC, Michele Donofrio and Bill Shepard, doing a four-and-a-half-hour news program interspersed with traffic, weather reports and sports reports, both on WSTC and WNLK. 
 Welcome to simulcast broadcasting: in this instance WSTC and WNLK, now under joint ownership, are carrying essentially the same programming, even though they are practically alongside each other on the AM radio band at 1400 and 1350, respectively. Local newspapers had reported the impending change but to many Norwalkers it still came as a surprise, if, indeed, not a shock, since Mr. Smith, as WNLK's "morning man," had established a large and loyal following over the last 21 years.
For many in Norwalk the shock has still not worn off. True, Mr. Smith is still on the air -- not only on WNLK but also on WSTC and WINE-AM in Danbury, which is now also included in the simulcast broadcasting -- but during a radically different time slot, from 3 to 6 P.M. Monday through Friday. Only now, rather than reporting school closings, school lunch menus and, in general, helping prepare his listeners for the day ahead, Mr. Smith now accompanies them home from work.
If WNLK in Norwalk seems to have lost its identity in the new simulcast venture, Stamford (where all of the broadcasting now emanates from) may be on the verge of physically losing a radio station that has been broadcasting from the city for 55 years. Although Scott J. Bacherman, the president of the Northeast region of the station's new owner, Commodore Media Inc., says no decision has been made, there have been reports -- not denied by Mr. Bacherman -- that WSTC will move its operations to Norwalk, either later this year or in early 1997.
"That would be worse than deplorable," said Don Russell, for many years the morning man on WSTC who is now the general manager of Public Television and Radio/Fairfield County in Stamford and who also writes a column for The Advocate in Stamford. "It would be a terrible shirking of local responsibility."
Such a move, if it happens, is almost bound to antagonize many Stamford area residents, many of whom were upset when, during the ownership change in May, about 30 of the station's 55 employees were let go. Among them were Len Gambino, a popular sportscaster who had been with the station for 27 years, and the locally-produced afternoon program featuring Mary Anne DeLuca-Melillo and Rick McDonald. Their dismissals spurred telephone calls to the station and letters to the editor of The Advocate, all of which protested the layoffs.
In Mr. Gambino's case, fans obtained more than 500 signatures on a petition that was sent to Mr. Bacherman calling for the sportscaster's reinstatement and threatening a boycott of WSTC and its advertisers if he was not rehired. "We never even got a response and a lot of us have stopped listening to WSTC," said Barbara Burke of Stamford, one of the organizers of the petition drive. "Lenny was tremendously popular, and did a great job of covering local sports, and also coached a lot of our kids in Babe Ruth baseball," Mrs. Burke said. "What they did to him was outrageous." Mr. Bacherman said he was unaware of the petition. "I never saw it," he said in an interview.
Although Mr. Bacherman says the new network will cover more news than ever in the Stamford, Norwalk and Danbury areas, the result to date seems to be far less on-scene coverage and more telephone interviews than in the past.
And many listeners have noted that much of what is being broadcast simultaneously in the morning on WSTC and WNLK bears a striking similarity to what they have already read in The Advocate. But Ms. Donofrio, the news director, denies that she and her news staff have been culling stories from The Advocate. "It's true that we're doing mostly phone interviews, but we're being more creative," she said. "And most of what we broadcast in the way of news comes from us or from the wire" -- The Associated Press -- "and from releases, faxes and phone tips. And we already know most of what's in The Advocate on any given day."
Ms. Donofrio said that the new news radio operation would continue to include important municipal board meetings. But she conceded that, at least for now, such coverage would be limited. "Our last news anchor, Jim Bleikamp, goes off at 8 P.M. so when he covers a meeting he can only stay for a while," she said.
In the past, as a former WSTC news director, John Roman, recalled, the station would cover Board of Representative meetings "from gavel to gavel." That, as Mr. Roman added, often meant covering, and broadcasting, meetings until well past midnight. "Sometimes, the meetings would last all night, and we'd broadcast them to the end," said Mr. Roman who worked at WSTC from 1965 to 1995.
Those were also the days when the news staff consisted almost entirely of native Stamfordites like Mr. Roman, Mr. Gambino and Mr. Russell, who, on and off from 1941, when the station first went on the air as WSRR, until 1994, became the station's best-known personality.
"Local news was the most important part of the station," said Mr. Russell, who in the late 1940's and during the 1950's was a pioneer television newscaster and network announcer for shows such as "The Cavalcade of Stars" starring Jackie Gleason. "And we had as many as 10 news reporters covering the city. And there was tremendous dedication. John Roman, for example, would come in at 5 A.M. and, when I was program director in the 1960's, I'd still find him in the newsroom at 6 o'clock at night, and I'd say to him, 'John, won't you please go home.' "
That was during an era when WSTC was owned by the Gillespie family of Stamford, which had founded both The Advocate in the early 1880's and the radio station in 1941. Local ownership continued until 1986 when Chase Broadcasting bought WSTC and then sold it to Odyssey Communications in 1993.
Both WSTC and WNLK have offered an eclectic array of programming in recent years, ranging from rock music on WSTC to big band music and vocalists from the 40's, 50's and 60's on WNLK.
But in recent years both stations have tended to emphasize news during morning drive time and a talk format the rest of the day. Under the current format, Ms. Donofrio and Mr. Sherpard jointly anchor a news and information segment from 5:30 to 10 A.M. and then return for a "Midday Report," which is sandwiched around a Paul Harvey broadcast, between 11:30 A.M. and noon. Thereafter, apart from Mr. Smith's show, the rest of the day's programming on WSTC, WNLK and WINE includes syndicated radio talk shows. However, Mr. Bacherman said that the three stations will begin to carry a one-hour news program interspersed with traffic reports between 6 and 7 P.M. Monday through Friday, starting in October.
Mr. Bacherman, who lives in Westport, said that both the cutback in staff and the simulcast programming were because of economic conditions. "We were losing a ton of money at both stations," said Mr. Bacherman whose company owns nine other radio stations in the Northeast and a total of 33 on the East Coast, including WKHL-FM in Stamford, WEFX-FM in Norwalk and WRKI-FM in Danbury, all of which he said draw more listeners than their AM counterparts.
"What we've done is take three little stations and combined them so that the sum is bigger than the three parts. Simulcast broadcasting is currently a trend in the United States and most people involved have to wear more than one hat."
Despite its current bare-bones news operation -- three fulltime anchor-reporters, including Ms. Donofrio, and one parttime newscaster-reporter, for its simulcast operation -- Mr. Bacherman said that in the long run news coverage of Stamford, Norwalk and Danbury and their surrounding towns would be more comprehensive than ever. "We're not going to skimp on the news," he said. "And we're going to go real heavy on Fairfield County news since we'll be simulcasting into a broader area. And there'll a lot of on-the-scene coverage. Eventually, we'll be hiring more people and using a large corps of stringers in the county."
He also said that advertisers would benefit from the new arrangement, since they could advertise on all three AM stations simultaneously at a considerable saving. "Yet small advertisers could still pick and choose the stations they want to use," Mr. Bacherman said.
The abbreviated news radio format, which Mr. Bacherman says is patterned after that of WCBS Radio in New York, is employed only on weekdays, although some of the promotional messages that are broadcast imply that it is in effect around the clock. Weekend programming primarily includes syndicated talk shows, along with locally-produced programs offering advice on gardening and a "Shop and Save" program during which various products are sold on the air.
Despite the simulcast broadcasting, Mr. Bacherman said the three stations would retain their local identities. "For example, we'll broadcast high school football games involving local teams on WSTC and the same on WNLK," he said. "And the stations will be able to break away to do other local programming. In Danbury, they'll also have "windows" where they can leave the simulcast and do Danbury area news. We're also looking into some other program changes including a sports talk show."
"We're trying to run a profitable operation here and be as economically sensible as we can," said Mr. Bacherman, a 42-year-old native of Boston who has been involved in broadcasting since his graduation from college. "We were faced with a mandate when we took over and we've had to make some painful moves. And some, like the layoffs, were more painful than others."
Commodore Media Inc. was able to purchase the Stamford, Norwalk and Danbury stations because of Federal deregulation that now enables companies own more than one station in a specific market. The company is in the process of merging with Capstar, a firm that specializes in the acquisition of radio stations.
The Stamford Mayor, Dannel P. Malloy, said he telephoned Mr. Bacherman when he heard a report that WSTC would vacate its studios on Prospect Street, near downtown Stamford, and move to Norwalk. "I told him we'd like to be host to a combined operation," Mr. Malloy said, adding that "it would be most unfortunate" if WSTC left the city.
Mr. Bacherman conceded that such a move was under consideration. "But if we do combine both stations in Norwalk, we would maintain a news office in Stamford," he said, while asserting that such a move, if it occurs, would not come until next year.
As for David Smith, he's enjoying the luxury of sleeping late, or at least trying to, after arising at 3:50 in the morning for 21 years to do his longtime morning show on WNLK. "Unfortunately, while my alarm clock no longer goes off at 3:50 A.M., my internal alarm does," said Mr. Smith who is also the longtime co-host of The Fairfield Exchange interview program on Connecticut Cablevision.
Mr. Smith said said that switching from morning man to mid and late afternoon interviewer represented "a new and different challenge." As a longtime Norwalk broadcaster, he now finds himself in the position of having to learn more about the Stamford and Danbury areas.
"People come up to me and say, 'I just can't get going in the morning without you there'," Mr. Smith said. "I tell them I hope they'll join me now during afternoon drive time. And I hope a lot of my other former morning listeners do, too."

HEADLINE: Things Are Looking Up -- And Going Up

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
FINALLY. After several years of spotty performance, replete with optimistic predictions and disappointed hopes, builders, brokers and industry advisers agree that the commercial real estate market in the New York area seems on a path of steady, if slow, improvement.
At long last, there are new projects. The Durst Organization has begun demolition in preparation for building a 48-story office tower in Times Square at the northeast corner of 42d Street and Broadway. 
 In Brooklyn, after 13 years of wrangling, Muss Development Company is at work on a $320 million, 32-story complex called Renaissance Plaza that will include offices and a 384-room Marriott hotel.
In New Jersey, Bellemead Development Corporation, a subsidiary of the Chubb Corporation, put up a 5-story, 205,727-square-foot speculative office building at the Somerset Hills Corporate Center in Warren Township and leased the entire structure to Hoechst Celanese Corporation almost a year before its scheduled completion.
But even though the market is in recovery, real estate industry veterans caution that the late 1990's will be very different from the go-go years of the 1980's. "There will be no speculative buildings in New York in the 1990's because the lenders will not finance a project without a commitment from tenants," said James A. Austrian of Austrian Shapiro & Partners, a consulting company.
"If I had to describe it in a word, I would say the 1980's were rampant while the 1990's will be measured," he said. Another inhibitor to new projects is that current rents do not cover the costs of land assemblage, he added.
"We clearly are in a recovery, but it is a slow recovery," said Bernard H. Mendik, chairman of the Mendik Company, one of the family-owned firms that have dominated the real estate market in the city for much of this century. He said that tenants are starting to expand, rather than contract the amount of space needed, and that rents are creeping upward, but that concessions by landlords are still needed to complete deals.
"We have a new phenomenon, the mobile tenant," he said. In search of a bargain, Mr. Mendik said, tenants long based on the east side of Manhattan will go as far west as Eighth Avenue or to Midtown South, locations they would have not considered in the past.
Like Mr. Austrian, Mr. Mendik predicted there would be little new construction in the near term.
"Banks and institutions were hurt badly by the last cycle, so there will be few sources of financing for new buildings," he said. In addition, he said, projects in New York are so large that they overwhelm the capacity of most lenders.
"In New York a building will have a $100 million mortgage at a time when most institutions do not want to place more than $30 or $40 million," he said. "So it gets tough to refinance projects."
While construction and leases continue to be the basics of shoptalk in the real estate world, two of the most discussed transactions this year involved real estate companies themselves.
The biggest surprise was the sale of the city's largest commercial real estate company, the Edward S. Gordon Company, to Insignia Financial Group of Greenville, S.C. The Gordon concern, which manages 27 million square feet of office space in the New York region, had been privately owned. The price was $74 million.
And the long-running drama involving Rockefeller Center has finally been settled by splitting the old company. The buildings to the east of the Avenue of the Americas are now controlled by an investment group including David Rockefeller, Goldman, Sachs and Tishman Speyer.
The four buildings to the west of the avenue are now a separate entity managed by Rockefeller Center Management Corporation, which is 80 percent owned by Mitsubishi Estate Company Ltd. Among its other holdings are the big brokerage firm Cushman & Wakefield, a retail, commercial and industrial complex in Mount Olive, N.J., and a building site on Seventh Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets. "That project is approved and we have a permit to build," said Jonathan D. Green, the president of Rockefeller Center Management. "We're just waiting for the right tenant."
OFFICE leasing in midtown Manhattan and Midtown South has begun to pick up, and effective rentals are up slightly, although no one is dancing in the streets. "There has been a lot of movement, but most of it has been lateral," said James Meiskin, the president of Plymouth Partners, a real estate brokerage and consulting firm in New York. "It's been like musical chairs, with companies moving and leasing 10 to 20 percent less space per employee."
"I have a sense that we are in a recovery in midtown and Midtown South, but the statistics do not really show it yet," said Mary Ann Tighe, an executive managing director of Gordon. "We are just on the cusp of feeling price pressure, with prices up about $1 a square foot from last year."
But others note that the recovery comes after a precipitous fall and that rental rates do not approach the levels of the late 1980's. "We had a virtual collapse of rents from 1989 to 1993, with declines of 25 to 30 percent," said Douglas Durst, president of the Durst Organization, which owns four large office buildings on Avenue of the Americas and four more on Third Avenue. "Since 1993 we have recovered 50 to 75 percent of the decline, but we are still not at the level of the 1980's," he said.
The building that the Dursts are constructing in Times Square is the first major office tower started in Manhattan in the 1990's and is an indication of how the area, once seedy and ridden with pornography, is reviving. Conde Nast, the company that publishes Vanity Fair, Vogue and other magazines, is the anchor tenant in the building, with an agreement to lease 583,000 of the building's 1.5 million square feet.
Because the city has an interest in redevelopment of the area, the project has the assistance of $10.75 million in tax abatements. Otherwise, real estate executives say, rentals have not yet risen to a level where new construction can be economically justified in Manhattan.
The average asking rate for Class A office buildings in midtown, which generally means recently built, well-equipped office towers, is $38.63 a square foot annually, according to RE/Locate, a statistical services company. Most executives say that will have to rise at least into the mid-40's before developers will be tempted to build.
When they do, they are going to find lenders more cautious than in the go-go days of the 1980's. "The difference between then and now is that you are going to see 75 percent financing, not 90 percent or 100 percent," said Peter Hauspurg, chairman of Eastern Consolidated Properties, a commercial brokerage. "The lenders are going to require a significant equity cushion."
But if rental rates are only creeping up, some kinds of space -- particularly large blocks in prime buildings -- may be growing scarce. RE/Locate reports that the amount of Class A space available in midtown has fallen out of double digits, to 9.3 percent in August compared to 11.1 percent in August 1993.
Indeed, some brokers say the market appears to be approaching a state of equilibrium, with power almost evenly divided between landlords and prospective tenants. "During the 1980's it was a landlord's market, then during the early 90's it was a tenant's market," said Mitchell S. Steir, executive vice president of Julien J. Studley. "Now it is what I would call a fair-play market."
Mr. Steir said such a market was one in which landlords can make a living while tenants can get a good economic deal. He said that both sides had learned from the ups and downs of the last decade and that landlords were once again putting a premium on retaining existing tenants with good credit to avoid the $100 a square foot cost of finding and installing new tenants.
Thus far 1996 has been a year of improvement after a disappointing 1995. Here is how some specific sectors performed so far this year, and the outlook for the near future.
Building Sales
With the market on an upswing and capital flowing in from abroad, sales picked up last year and are expected to be up sharply again when the books are closed on 1996.
"We are having back-to-back banner years," said Scott R. Latham, managing director of CB Commercial Real Estate Group's industrial properties division. He said the company keeps track of notable transactions, those involving major buildings in Manhattan. In 1994 there were 39 such sales for a total value of $1.2 billion. Last year there were 54 such sales, totaling $1.8 billion, with $1 billion of that from foreign sources. Based on deals done so far and those expected to close before the end of the year, Mr. Latham said 1996 should be $1 billion over last year.
One reason for the influx of foreign capital is that New York still looks cheap, despite the nascent recovery. "Foreign investors think that buying property at $120 to $125 a square foot is low when they remember that it was $330 to $340 a foot from 1985 to 1988," said Mr. Hauspurg of Eastern Consolidated. The weakness of the dollar in relation to major European currencies increases the attractiveness of property in this country as well.
Although sales prices are up from the lows of $105 to $110 at the bottom of the market from 1991 through 1994, the bounce has been too small to scare off foreign investors.
The Retail Market
Kmart is invading Manhattan, with stores on 34th Street west of Seventh Avenue and at Astor Place in NoHo. The city is trying to encourage other "big box" retailers to come into the city by rezoning manufacturing areas to permit stores as large as 200,000 square feet.
"New York is welcoming the big-box stores," said Faith H. Consolo, senior managing director at Garrick-Aug Associates, a firm specializing in retail leasing. "Home Depot wants to be here, Wal-Mart wants to be here." Both are said to be looking at sites on the west side of Manhattan.
As the 34th Street Kmart demonstrates, models developed for suburban locations need to be modified for a city location. Instead of providing parking for hundreds of car, the multilevel store will open onto the platform for the Long Island Rail Road.
In theory, at least, this should encourage commuters to zip through the store, buy what they need and run for the train with hardly a break in stride.
In spite of the difficulties involved in operating in the city, major national retailers are seeking stores in New York "because there are more people in three or four blocks than there are in some cities," said Alan Victor, executive vice president of the Lansco Corporation.
"Entertainment/retail is what is happening now," he added. He said the Disney and Warner's stores that trade on movie characters, and the All Star Sports Cafe at 45th Street and Seventh Avenue in the Times Square area, which uses sports stars to encourage consumers to spend money on food, drink and trinkets, are examples of this approach.
Noting that Chanel and Louis Vuitton co-exist on 57th Street with Warner, Nike shoes and Levi's jeans, retail specialists say exclusive shopping districts of the past will stay in the past. "These stores have different use groups," said Ms. Consolo. "Some customers want to shop Chanel, others want a sneaker."
Just about everyone agrees that Times Square, particularly 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, is quickly becoming an attractive location for retailers. "Times Square is hot," said Edward A. Friedman, executive managing director of Newmark & Company Real Estate.
Within the next few years the once seedy strip will feature a 25-screen film complex, a Disney Store, Madame Tussaud's wax museum, an HMV music store and many smaller stores and shops. Some retailers in the area are already doing quite well. The Virgin music store in the street and lower floors of the Bertelsmann Building at 45th Street and Seventh Avenue is widely reported to be selling $1 million worth of merchandise a week this summer.
The Hotel Industry
"Occupancy rates have been at or above record levels all year," said John A. Fox, a senior vice president of PKF Consulting. "Through July, the occupancy rate was 77.9 percent, compared 73.8 percent in 1995. We are projecting record rates through the rest of the year and an increase next year."
As a result of the demand, he said, room rates have gone up about 11 percent over last year. Prices for the properties involved are presumably moving up as well since the higher rates are expected to be sustained, although no sales are known to be imminent.
One sale that did take place was the Four Seasons Hotel which sold for about $190 million.
Although this was an eye-popping $515,000 a room, it was less than half the original $440 million cost to build. The hotel was sold to Lai Sun Group of Hong Kong and Singapore by a group of lenders led by the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan.
Hospitality industry executives said an improved domestic economy had increased business travel and domestic tourism. And the low value of the dollar promoted an increase in visitors from Europe, whose stronger currencies allowed them to purchase more dollars to spend here.
There also seems to be a sense among visitors that New York is a safe and acceptable destination again.
"The crime statistics are down, and that sort of information is transmitted all around the world," said Joseph E. Spinnato, the president of the Hotel Association of New York. "We are also still getting a positive impact from the repeal of the state room tax," he said.
The 5 percent surcharge, enacted in 1990, pushed tax on a room costing more than $100 a night to 21.25 percent. The repeal in 1994 and a lowering of a city tax has reduced the charge to 15 percent, which makes the city more competitive with other destinations, Mr. Spinnato said.
Despite the high occupancy rate, very few hotel projects are under way.
The SoHo Grand, which has 367 rooms and is owned by Hartz Mountain Industries, opened on West Broadway last month, and Donald Trump is converting some of the old Gulf & Western tower on Columbus Circle into hotel rooms, but the only completely new construction underway is the building that will house the Marriott in Brooklyn, and Lincoln Square West at 66th Street and Broadway, which will have some floors operated as a hotel.
Downtown
Part of the focus downtown is on converting old office buildings, many of which cannot compete with up-to-date, high-tech structures, into residences. As many as 20 buildings have been purchased for conversion or are the subject of negotiations.
The city has offered a system of tax breaks for the area that has attracted the attention of developers.
That program was instrumental last week as three New York State agencies agreed to lease 450,000 square feet of space on the lower 10 floors of 60 Broad Street. Concord Properties, manager of the building, said both the tax abatement and lower-cost energy provisions of the incentive program were invoked and will be passed on to the tenants, the state's Office of Court Administration, Department of Insurance and Division of Housing and Community Renewal. The upper floors are to be developed as residential condominiums.
Speaking of the move to convert downtown buildings to residential use, Carl Weisbrod, president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, said: "What has been happening exceeds our expectations and the city's. We originally thought we would get 3,000 apartment units over seven years, but now we are running at 1,000 units a year for a total of 7,000. We are going to double the population of lower Manhattan."
Mr. Weisbrod said that while an increase in resident population would undoubtedly attract more stores, shops and restaurants to the area, it is already a major tourist destination that has a well-established infrastructure.
And for someone who already works in the area, living there would give people what has been described as the "ultimate New York perk" -- the ability to walk to work.
"You have 4 to 5 million square feet of unrentable office space down there," said Raymond O'Keefe, the president of Grubb & Ellis New York. "So the alternative vision of a 24-hour community was developed, and it is actually happening. Buildings are being renovated, or sold and emptied out in preparation for renovation."
"Downtown is going to work because there is no place else to put people," said David Gialanella, manager of the New York office of Cushman & Wakefield. "But you can't measure progress in quarters; you have to measure in years."
Outside Manhattan
Brooklyn will get its first large hotel since the 1930's as part of the Renaissance Plaza project that is considered a key to renewing the borough's downtown area. The 385-room Marriott Hotel will occupy the first seven floors of the 32-story, 810,000-square-foot building on Adams Street, which will also have an underground parking garage. The project is scheduled to open in the summer of 1998.
Joshua L. Muss, the developer, said the hotel is key to the redevelopment of Brooklyn's downtown area. "There is not a business district in any city in the world that does not have a hotel," he said.
He said the underground parking was critical for attracting out-of-towners, who tend to arrive in cars. "The reason the old hotels in Brooklyn went down the drain was that there was no place to park a car," he said. He said the long delay was caused by difficulties in getting tenants and financing all in alignment at once.
In New Jersey, Hoechst Celanese's decision to lease an entire building being built on speculation "was kind of an eye-opener," said Donald P. Eisen, a senior managing director with Cushman & Wakefield. "People have been asking if prices have gone up enough that you can make money building, and the answer is a resounding 'yes.' You have to anticipate that others will follow suit."
In Queens, another long-pending project appears about to go forward at Jamaica Avenue and Parsons Boulevard. An 11-screen movie theater bearing the name of the basketball star Magic Johnson has been announced as the anchor tenant of an $80 million office and commercial complex being developed by the Mattone Group of Whitestone.
New construction is not expected for Westchester and Fairfield Counties, to the northwest of the city.
"In Stamford you can rent Class A space for $30 or $31 a square foot and in Greenwich you can get it in the mid-30's," said Anthony E. Malkin, the president of W&M Properties. "That's better than it was, but its still a good $10 to $15 below what you need to justify new construction."
If few new buildings are likely anytime soon, existing properties are changing hands and being upgraded. Recently Reckson Associates Realty Corporation agreed to buy Landmark Square, a six-building office park in downtown Stamford.
Reckson, a real estate investment trust based in Melville, L.I., is paying the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company about $79 million for the properties and is planning to invest $11.5 million in a five-year capital improvement program.
Earlier this year Reckson purchased 1 million square feet of office space in Tarrytown and White Plains in Westchester.
 The data, supplied by a concern called RE/Locate, omitted four transactions. They were a lease for the New York City Agency for Children's Services of 309,454 square feet at 150 William Street, which would have been No. 5 on the list; Dillon Read & Co., 205,818 square feet at 535 Madison Avenue, No. 8; Sony Retail Entertainment, 82,930 square feet at 711 Fifth Avenue, No. 24, and REFCO Inc., 56,631 square feet at 1 World Financial Center, No. 46.
The data also omitted renewal space in two deals. Including renewal space, the figures for News America Publishing at 1211 Avenue of the Americas should have been 501,300 square feet. The total for Zurich Reinsurance Centre at 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza should have been 162,723 square feet.

HEADLINE: Business Districts

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Elaine Rosenberg, a Madison Avenue art gallery owner, calls for limits on New York City's business improvement districts (letter, Sept. 9). In fact, the city's oversight of the districts begins with a complex formation process during which a plan outlining expenditures and salaries is approved by the City Council, the state comptroller and the mayor. 
 Ms. Rosenberg's contention that Madison Avenue does not need improvement does not reflect the support expressed by the majority of 700 property owners and 300 merchants in the Madison Avenue Business Improvement District's two-year formation process. Since the district's establishment, Madison Avenue is the only 26-block stretch in the city that is graffiti-free.
The Madison Avenue B.I.D. president earns $55,000 a year, a salary considerably lower than that paid to directors of comparable-size districts. This compensation to administer an organization with 30 employees, operating 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year can hardly be called excessive.
 
E. WILLIAM JUDSON
Chairman, Madison Avenue
Business Improvement District
New York, Sept. 12, 1996
