HEADLINE: New York Has (a) Too Many Pupils (b) Empty Seats (c) Both

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK 

 BODY:
It's a matter of simple arithmetic, isn't it?
The severity of the overcrowding in New York City's public schools should be easy to measure: How many classrooms have too many children? How many have desks to spare? 
 But the pitched debates between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the central Board of Education since school opened 10 days ago show something that children in grade school are unlikely to be taught in math class: that numbers can be a matter of interpretation.
The school system says there are 91,000 students in crowded conditions in some schools, but yesterday a deputy chancellor said there were 67,000 empty seats in others.
Interpretations of these numbers can make a big difference in the solution to school overcrowding. Are new schools the only answer? Or can other adjustments be made?
The issue became even more charged this weekend when Mayor Giuliani said he believed the overcrowding problem was being exaggerated because, in his view, the numbers provided by the Board of Education were confusing and could easily be misread. Even Board of Education officials agree the counting is complicated.
"This is not simple stuff," said Lewis H. Spence, the school system's deputy chancellor for operations. "You always have to clarify the assumptions behind the numbers."
Schools officials say that schools are more overcrowded this year than they have been in decades. They say 55 percent of the city's 1,100 schools have too many students.
But the Mayor, who has resisted allocating more money for school construction, said yesterday that "a lot of the problem" had been "misstated."
"It gives the impression that there is disorder in a large number of schools," he said. "The fact is there are certain districts that have problems they're addressing. Then there are a lot of districts that don't. And that part of the message hasn't gotten out."
Essentially, there are three different numbers in the school crowding equation.
First, there is the number of students that the schools cannot comfortably accommodate and who are therefore being grouped in extra-large classes or being taught in places like locker rooms, oversized storage closets or teachers' cafeterias.
These students have desks and chairs, but they are in inferior classroom conditions. They may be in classes with more than the 32 to 34 students per class allowed under the current teachers' contract, which sets different limits depending on the grade. Some students are taking classes in trailers, in Manhattan's Town Hall, in an old torpedo factory.
The Board of Education has said that 91,000 children in 13 of the system's 32 school districts are in this circumstance, many in neighborhoods in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens that have been flooded with immigrants in recent years. Put another way, nearly 10 percent of the school system's 1.06 million children are in classes with too many other students or in rooms and buildings that were not designed for teaching Shakespeare or chemistry.
And some education experts say that a figure of 91,000 students is misleadingly low, reasoning that when a classroom is overflowing, all the children in the room suffer, not just the extra students.
Second, there is the number of students who are actually without desks, who may be sitting on the floor or sharing a corner of another child's desk. Mayor Giuliani said this weekend that this is the number that matters when measuring school overcrowding. The Mayor has said that large classes do not have to be detrimental, pointing out that the Roman Catholic schools he attended had classes of 50 students or more.
"When I went to grammar school and high school, I was in classes of 40 or 50," the Mayor said earlier this month. "I think one class I was in had 52 students in it. And I think that what we've done with students is to sometimes give them excuses for not learning."
The Mayor has put the number of children without desks at 2,000 to 6,000, and has expressed frustration that school officials cannot come up with an accurate count for this.
In fact, Mr. Spence said yesterday, the Mayor's number is merely an estimate, based on projections the school system made before school started this year; he said the actual figure would not be known until October, when new enrollments and transfers between schools slow down and attendance numbers are tallied.
He said daily totals were not available because the central school board did not have the enrollment system adequately computerized.
The projections work like this, Mr. Spence said: Last year, 86,500 students were taught in places like the school gym or were otherwise sandwiched into large classes. This year, the Board of Education predicts about 21,000 additional students are entering the schools, meaning the schools would be "over capacity" by roughly 107,500.
But, by the end of last year, the school system had added 16,500 new seats to the system by building or leasing classroom space. That means 16,500 of the 107,500 students theoretically have seats, leaving the system about 91,000 over capacity. Most of those -- 86,500 -- have desks and chairs, school officials reason based on last year's situation, even if they are not being taught in optimal conditions. The remaining 3,500 to 5,500 may not have desks, he said, depending on whether schools are able to create more space or shuffle students to other schools.
"It's an estimate," Mr. Spence said. "When we get to October, it may prove to be wrong."
Third, there is the number of empty seats in other districts, like District 1 on the Lower East Side, where the number of students has been declining in recent years. Many of the 19 districts that are not considered overcrowded have extra space in some of their schools.
Yesterday, the Mayor said there were 30,000 to 40,000 empty desks in these districts.
"You're trying to correlate somewhere between 2,000 and 6,000 on an emergency basis with somewhere between 30,000 and 40,000 empty desks," Mr. Giuliani said. "That's a very different task than trying to correlate 91,000 children without desks with 35,000, which is the way in which a lot of people believe it is happening."
Mr. Spence said the number of empty desks was even higher, about 67,000. But he stressed that empty desks alone are not a solution.
Many of the vacant seats are in junior high schools, he said, while the greatest overcrowding problems are in high schools and elementary schools. And, he said, "large numbers of those seats are not available because they're in the wrong geographic locations," meaning they would require students to be bused great distances from one district to another, a solution that is not popular with many parents, especially parents of young children.
Mr. Spence also said that the central Board of Education cannot order individual school districts to move children from an overcrowded school to an undercrowded school in the same district. The districts themselves are legally entitled to make their own decisions about that.
Given the numbers, what are the solutions?
To the teachers' union, which is beginning a newspaper and radio advertising campaign this week, the only long-term solution is more money for new schools.
"The real answer is bricks and mortar," said a union spokesman, Bert Shanas. "Government has to find the money to fund a good education. A decent education starts with a chair and a desk."
Mayor Giuliani has said the solution is planning and organization, not money. "Just throwing money into this system will not work," he told reporters yesterday.
Mr. Spence said the system was looking at options that did not involve spending to build new schools.
For example, he said, school officials will be looking hard at the undercrowded districts, especially those that are adjacent to overcrowded districts, to see if any of the empty space can be used. They will also be looking to see if any large classrooms are being used by special education classes, which are legally required to have fewer students. If so, those classrooms might be partitioned so that two special education classes could be held in the same space.
Another option is split-session schedules, where half the students go to school in the morning and the other half in the afternoon, a system a handful of high schools are already using. And if the problems of air-conditioning, staff salaries and New York State law can be dealt with, school officials are hoping to introduce year-round education.
"Before we try to look for capital," Mr. Spence said, the schools should make sure "that we've used existing capacity that is politically, geographically, economically and programmatically feasible."

SECTION: Section A; Page 15; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 703 words

HEADLINE: Essay;
Brush Off the 'Pollbearers'

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
After the New Hampshire primary, the pundit-pollster pack wrote off Bob Dole's candidacy.
After he came back to win nomination, the pack decided in June he had no chance against Bill Clinton. 
 Then, after a supposed 20-point gap disappeared overnight during the Republican convention, the pack drew a horrified breath -- until the "bounce" unbounced.
But now, with the campaign barely begun, the finger-to-the-wind set, with Thomas E. Dewey certitude, declares Election Day to be a mere formality. Rose Jacobius, a Washington Post night editor, aptly labeled the funereal crowd "Dole's Pollbearers."
This earlier-than-ever stampede toward self-fulfillment favors the favorite and insults the voters. Forgive us contrarians for daring to suggest the delicious possibility of upset.
Don't we realize that it is impossible for an incumbent to lose in the absence of hard times or national humiliation? Why don't we get with the program?
The answer is that this month's wisdom is next month's folly. Nearly half the electorate likely to vote is undecided. Pollsters will increasingly stress "likely voters" rather than blowhards, and press the "leaning toward" to a decision. This will tighten the race because much of the front-runner's support is demonstrably soft, and the tightening -- "erosion" -- will become part of the story.
I predicate this not only on congenital contrarianism but on four assumptions and a key decision.
Assume that the general euphoria about the economy, which helps the incumbent, is offset by the general conservative drift of the swing voter, which works for the challenger.
Assume that both ad campaigns are now equally adept and financed, erasing the early Democratic advantage. Mr. Clinton's Mediscare theme -- they'll throw Grandma out in the snow -- can be countered with a Dole fear theme, that the recent doubling of teen-age drug abuse is caused by slipshod anti-drug enforcement and is symbolic of the lax moral example set by the Clintons.
Assume that Dole's positive life-style theme -- trust me to provide you more control of your life, symbolized by a big tax cut -- has more lift than the Clinton positive theme, which has become "me too but not so fast."
Assume that the hard edge of the G.O.P. campaign -- against racial preferences, against illegal immigrants, against teachers' union rigidity, against lawyers' harassment -- has greater resonance than the Democrats' hard-edged assault on pro-lifers and the gun lobby.
The key decision affecting the campaign is to be made this week: whether to insert Ross Perot as a buffer into the TV debates, as Clinton wants, or to set up a direct confrontation with the two electable candidates.
Got a call over the weekend from Harvard Professor Richard Neustadt. He's doing his job, surveying pundits and pols, before joining four other academics in recommending who should debate to the 10-person commission making the decision.
I held to my opinion expressed here last week: Perot has no "realistic" chance of being elected President, which is the central criterion in the judgment. Does he have a realistic chance of carrying one state that, in a squeaker, could throw the election into the House? No.
Some Clinton supporters argue that Perot would add entertainment value to the debates, or educational value, or even news value. Maybe just one (which would automatically boost his ratings, keeping him on). Most people say sure, to hell with the "realistic" criterion, let him in, what's to lose?
To lose is the electoral value of the debates. When we put two men in the arena, one of whom is sure to be elected, we force ourselves to face reality. Which one will I make President? That is the essence of the debate process, not to be perverted by putting on a show that helps one candidate.
The pack, of course, is certain that Clinton -- with his memorized barrage of figures, his oratorical skill, and with the experience of the first five-year campaign -- will clobber the plain-spoken Dole in the debates. A few White House aides worry that some Americans might find the underdog role appealing.
We'll see. Ain't over. Who would have thought that Miss Kansas would become Miss America?

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Bozell Worldwide joins in a venture to reach black consumers with nontraditional marketing.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
A GIANT agency has helped form a company that offers marketers a chance to reach black consumers outside the boundaries of conventional advertising.
Bozell Worldwide in New York, the nation's 11th-largest agency with billings of $2.3 billion, joined with two partners to start Graham Gregory Bozell, which develops sponsored projects aimed at African-Americans. Bozell took an undisclosed minority stake in the company. 
 Graham Gregory Bozell, with offices in Chicago and New York, focuses on cultural, entertainment and sports events. Its specialty is nontraditional efforts that include event marketing, like staging arts festivals; producing television programs; cause-related marketing, which raises money for organizations like the United Negro College Fund, and life-style marketing, such as associating advertisers with celebrations of Kwanzaa, the annual cultural festival patterned after an African harvest festival.
Bozell's interest in Graham Gregory Bozell is indicative of two trends. One is the increasing prevalence of tactics to pitch products that range far afield of standard ploys like 30-second commercials or print ads.
"We've tried to look for opportunities like this that go beyond our traditional business," said Charles D. Peebler Jr., president and chief executive at the Bozell parent, Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.
The other trend is the growing ardor for niche marketing, which addresses narrow consumer segments sorted on traits like ethnicity.
One appeal of the black market, according to a study by Target Market News, a market research company in Chicago, is that spending last year by black households outpaced spending in white households in categories like children's apparel and foods prepared at home. And though median income for black households, at $21,000, trails that for all households, at $32,300, American Demographics magazine reported, black households tend to spend more on average for personal-care services, hosiery and jewelry.
"My interest to focus on African-Americans is because there's a lot of opportunity to create value in that market," said Stedman Graham, president and chief executive at Graham Gregory Bozell.
Mr. Graham, 45, is also president and chief executive at S. Graham & Associates, a sports marketing firm in Chicago. He discussed Graham Gregory Bozell, in which he holds the majority stake, in a telephone interview Friday; at a news conference scheduled for today, he and other company principals will present their projects.
"My goal was to form a partnership with a large, well-known advertising agency," Mr. Graham said, "because what they do better than anyone else is taking an idea and making it ready for the market."
"I pitched this to a couple agencies," he added, "but they weren't really receptive." He then connected with Bozell through W. Grant Gregory, chairman at Gregory & Hoenemeyer, a merchant bank in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Graham knew Mr. Gregory, a former chairman at Touche Ross & Company, from serving together on the board of Junior Achievement. Mr. Gregory -- also on the board of Bozell, Jacobs -- arranged for Mr. Graham and Mr. Peebler to meet.
"Chuck said, 'Let's do it,' just like that," recalled Alfred L. Schreiber, a senior partner at Bozell, referring to Mr. Peebler. Mr. Schreiber, 50, who has been responsible for Bozell's external and internal communications, is executive vice president and general manager at Graham Gregory Bozell; he hopes to draw on his experience with marketing events like Olympic torch relays and Hands Across America. (Mr. Gregory is a director and owns a minority stake that is smaller than Bozell's.)
If Mr. Graham's name is familiar, it may be because he is also known as the fiance of Oprah Winfrey, who has agreed, with her company, Harpo Productions, to participate in a Graham Gregory Bozell project, a television special titled "What's Right With America."
Mr. Graham had this to say to anyone who assumes that Ms. Winfrey's participation was assured because of their relationship: "That was no easy sell. That was harder for me than anything else."
Mr. Schreiber agreed. "I figured we'd go in there and bingo," he said. "But it was not a foregone conclusion. We made four presentations."
Other projects for Graham Gregory Bozell include a pan-African cultural event, planned for 1998; another television special, "Kwanzaa: Capture the Spirit!," and helping create a sports marketing curriculum for black colleges.
One marketer with which Graham Gregory Bozell is working is Heritage Collection Inc., a New York company that designs, imports and sells "Afrocentric" products like lamps, rugs and pillows.
"With Stedman's ability to develop marketing approaches and our ability to develop products," said Reginald Powe, president at Heritage, "we can create jobs for African-Americans and for Africans."
Graham Gregory Bozell also plans projects aimed at the general market, particularly those that capitalize on the so-called crossover appeal of black arts and celebrities.
"Today, the whole world is on a first-name basis with Oprah, Whitney, Whoopi, Michael, Shaq, Hak and Tiger," Mr. Schreiber said.
(For those who are popular-culturally challenged, those stars, in addition to Ms. Winfrey, are Whitney Houston; Whoopi Goldberg; the basketball players Michael Jordan, Shaquille O'Neal and Hakeem Olajuwon, and the young golfer Tiger Woods.)
"The only color" that should matter, Mr. Graham said, "is green."

HEADLINE: Lotus Gears Up To Get a Slice Of Internet Pie

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
Colleen Griffiths, a product developer at the Lotus Development Corporation, had to suppress a laugh recently when an executive at a large bank asked her why he should risk his business on new Lotus Internet software when he could choose "mature technology" from the two-year-old Netscape Communications Corporation.
Less than a year ago, Ms. Griffiths and her Lotus colleagues were combating the widespread perception that Internet software from fledgling companies like Netscape had made Lotus's 10-year-old Notes software obsolete. Now, as she demonstrates Domino, a new Internet version of Notes, she has been confronted with the view that the Lotus software is untested. 
 The situation would indeed be funny if the stakes were not so high. Barely a year after I.B.M. spent $3 billion to acquire Lotus, much of the computer industry is focused on selling networks that enable workers at medium and large companies to exchange electronic messages and collaborate on documents. It is a market that Lotus pioneered with Notes and one where it still holds a large technical advantage over its rivals in the view of many analysts.
But rather than being at the center of the action, Lotus finds itself on the sidelines. With a new marketing blitz beginning this week, the company hopes to remind the industry that there is more to the future of the Internet than the so-called browser war between Netscape and the Microsoft Corporation.
While revenues from sales of Internet software are expected to grow to $8.5 billion over the next three years from $127 million last year, according to Forrester Research Inc., about $4.4 billion of that total will be sales of software like Domino that runs on servers -- the larger computers that host and manage sites on the World Wide Web.
By comparison, the total estimated sales from browsers in 1999, according to the Cambridge-based research firm, will be $440 million, one-tenth of the server market.
Capturing its share of the revenues in future years, however, depends on how well Lotus can capture the attention of the industry now. "Lotus has been marginalized," said Geoffrey A. Moore, president of the Chasm Group, a Silicon Valley marketing consultant. "They are not in a very good position to compete for mindshare."
Without "mindshare" -- the attention of thousands of third-party software developers, industry analysts, trade journalists and customers -- even the best technologies can founder. That is a lesson that I.B.M. learned the hard way with OS/2, its operating system for personal computers. Many experts considered it to be technically superior to Microsoft's Windows, but it never caught on because of poor marketing.
"I think people who understand our products understand that we have the technology to take the industry where it is going," Michael D. Zisman, Lotus's chief executive, said in an interview last week.
But he admitted that there are still relatively few people in that category. "We have to do a lot of work and spend a lot of money," he added.
That process will begin this week. The company will promote Domino with advertising in publications and on the Internet's World Wide Web, and plans to announce a developers conference to be held in Anaheim, Calif., in November to encourage third-party software writers and computer services providers to build Web sites using Domino.
Paradoxically, Lotus faces an uphill battle trying to sell the virtues of its server software at a time when much of the industry is racing to match it.
The biggest criticism of Notes is that it is not built around Internet standards and it is expensive. Lotus recognized the problem late last year and set out to reconfigure Notes to complement the Internet rather than compete against it. The result is Domino, which was introduced in July, and is now priced below Netscape's Suitespot offering because it can be used with the Netscape and Microsoft browsers.
 The software includes many of Notes' most powerful features, including sophisticated security, the ability to limit access to information to specific workers, a data base for electronic discussions, and the ability to easily synchronize different versions of the same document residing on different computers.
Many of these same features have been promised by Netscape for the next version of its software due out next year. Microsoft and Novell Inc. are also trying to match Domino with their products. And Radnet, a year-old company also based in Cambridge, advises people to think of its Webshare product as "Notes for the rest of us."
But a July report by the Yankee Group, a Boston consulting firm, put Domino 12 to 18 months ahead of Netscape and Microsoft in developing server software.
Indeed, Netscape's co-founder and chief technologist, Marc L. Andreessen, was so impressed with Domino when he first saw it last June that he and other Netscape executives approached Lotus about a partnership that would link the Netscape browser with the Domino server, according to an executive familiar with the talks. The brief discussions ended when both sides realized that there was no way around the fact that they were competing head-to-head for the server market.
In public, Netscape officials are not complimentary about Domino. "They are trying to layer on Internet compatibility on top of what they have and you pay a very big price when you do that," Eric Hahn, a senior vice president at Netscape, said last week. The price, he said, would come in diminished performance by the software. It might also mesh poorly with other Internet programs, he asserted.
As Lotus gears up to promote Domino, friction with Netscape has increased. The two companies recently clashed over a cost comparison in a Netscape advertisement that Lotus said inaccurately inflated Domino's price. Mr. Zisman said that Lotus had been considering suing Netscape until late last week when Netscape executives agreed to withdraw the comparison.
Domino has been well received so far by the estimated 6.3 million users of Notes because it gives them a seamless link to the Internet. The challenge now is to sell Domino to the much larger universe of companies that do not have Notes and do not intend ever to buy the software because they think it is out of date.
"Notes is not cool," said David Marshak, an analyst with the Patricia Seybold Group in Boston. "It's looked at as proprietary even though it supports all the Internet standards. It's looked at as expensive even though it is a lot cheaper than Netscape. It's essentially a bad rap."
Mr. Zisman said the company hoped to focus its efforts on establishing Domino as a superior way to manage Web sites, or as a way to play host to on-line discussion groups.
A good example is a new site called Harvard-Square.com (http://harvard-square.com), which is a virtual representation of the Cambridge neighborhood. Dozens of shops, restaurants and other businesses have a presence on the site. With Domino, each business can update its Web page remotely using any common browser. So a restaurant can change its list of daily specials on the Web without the help of a software engineer, who might charge $100 an hour.
"Without a tool like Domino, we would not be able to support 700 Web sites and hope to make any money," said V. A. Shiva, president and chief executive of Millennium Productions Inc., which built and maintains the Harvard Square site.
To attract more interest from the Internet community, the company is also considering breaking Domino's features into components and giving some of them away piecemeal over the Internet, even though one of Domino's main strengths is that it offers an integrated set of features that form a powerful package.
Mr. Zisman said he had come to realize that Domino might be too far ahead of the market, so Lotus will give customers what they want today even though he is convinced that the demand for Domino's full capabilities will soon grow.
"There is nothing more frustrating," he added, "than trying to sell someone a solution to a problem that they don't know they have."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;
Clinton Presses Tax-Cut Issue, Saying His Plan Is Paid For

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: INDIANOLA, Iowa, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Blending a prairie populist's fervor with a New Democrat's fiscal decorum, President Clinton pledged today that his was a party that could be trusted with people's money and to balance the Federal budget while providing targeted tax cuts to help the middle class.
"I'm telling you, folks, there is a new Democratic Party," Mr. Clinton told a cheering crowd of partisans at Senator Tom Harkin's annual steak and pork-chop fry fund-raiser in a rolling farm field here. "We have proved that we are the party of responsibility when handling people's money." 
 For months, Mr. Clinton has sought to co-opt Republican issues like crime, welfare, family values and fiscal responsibility. Today he made one of his more pointed defenses of his strategy of modest tax breaks for education and families with children in the face of Bob Dole's proposal for a 15 percent income tax cut.
"I'll tell you something, folks," he said of the competing tax proposals. "Mine are paid for, and we've got to pay for them. We don't want to go back to that old time when we promised you a tax cut on the one hand and wrecked the economy on the other."
The White House believes that taxes are one of the Republicans' few strong issues, though polls also show the public is deeply skeptical of Mr. Dole's ability to deliver on his plan. So Mr. Clinton misses few chances to attack the Republican proposal as likely to "explode the deficit" and force higher interest rates that would only hurt taxpayers in the end.
Campaigning here in the middle of middle America, Mr. Clinton offered his listeners a little bit of everything today, lambasting the Republican record on the environment, taxes, education and crime and touting his own.
With a hand-painted backdrop of a Madison County-style covered bridge and bulletproof barrier of hay bales behind him, Mr. Clinton vowed for the umpteenth time to lead the country into the 21st century."
At another point, the President said, "This is a huge election, this is the last election of the 20th century to elect the first President of the 21st century."
A listener shouted out, "And you're going to win!" to which Mr. Clinton laughed and replied, "I am if you keep that same attitude for the next 51 days."
Mr. Harkin, who is the state's only elected Democratic Federal office holder and is running for his fourth term in a competitive race against Representative Jim Lightfoot, rallied the faithful with a fistful of old-fashioned firebrand attacks on Republican plutocrats and pundits.
"Trickle-down economics doesn't work," Mr. Harkin declared at one point. "We here in Iowa know that you can't fertilize a tree from the top down. Gotta stick it in at the roots."
But Mr. Harkin, too, warned that it was the Government's responsibility to provide a ladder of opportunity to help people help themselves, not "an escalator."
For Mr. Clinton, today was a chance to appear in a Midwestern swing state that he wants to win, albeit one that seems comfortably in his column at the moment. But mainly, it was repayment to Mr. Harkin, who opposed Mr. Clinton in the Democratic Presidential primaries in 1992, but then dropped out and promptly and enthusiastically supported the Arkansas Governor.
Before leaving the White House this morning, Mr. Clinton placed a call to another old friend, President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, to wish him well on his planned heart surgery.
The traveling White House spokeswoman, Mary Ellen Glynn, said that the two men talked for about 10 minutes in what she described as a "friendship call to touch base" and that Mr. Clinton had told Mr. Yeltsin he had taken a "bold stroke" by confiding his surgical plans to the Russian people.
Besides the steak fry, the President appeared at two other fund-raising events, collecting a total of $400,000 for the day, half of it for the Democratic National Committee and the other half for Mr. Harkin's re-election campaign.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Clinton with Senator Tom Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, at a fund-raising rally for the Senator in Indianola, Iowa, yesterday. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: The Internet as an Influence on Urbanization

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
For years, experts have warned that computer technology could bring the demise of old bricks-and-mortar cities. In "The Third Wave" in 1980, the futurist Alvin Toffler sketched out a vision of legions of workers liberated from the traffic and hassle of urban areas by computers and telecommunications. Instead, he predicted, they would work from homes soon to be transformed into far-flung "electronic cottages."
Recently, the rise of the Internet has added weight to the theory of technology-led urban decline. The global computer network, after all, is seen as a powerful tool that could decentralize work and living patterns. 
 But to date, the impact of the Internet has been mainly to reinforce the economic and intellectual leadership of a handful of urban centers and nearby suburbs, according to an analysis by the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University.
The New York University study, released today, focuses on the Internet as an engine of economic and regional development. The university researchers examined the location of computers directly connected to the Internet, or "host" computers. They worked from data supplied by two consulting firms, Matrix Information and Directory Services Inc. and Netwizards Internet Domain Surveys.
Entitled "Leaders and Losers on the Internet," the study used the host count as a measure of where the infrastructure of the Internet is concentrated. Host computers are typically more powerful machines, each with its own Internet name and address, and a count of them by location is assumed to be an indication of where private and public investment in the Internet is greatest. The study did not try to measure the number of people using the Internet.
The central measurement in the study was a county-by-county analysis. The five regions with the most Internet host computers were Silicon Valley, the Boston-Cambridge, Mass., area, Los Angeles, Manhattan and Fairfax County in Virginia.
In the rankings of the top 25 counties, the areas embracing several major American cities make the list, including San Diego, Chicago, Minneapolis, Seattle, San Francisco, Dallas and Washington.
But the study observed, "Some of the nation's major cities, like Houston, Miami, Detroit and New Orleans are not major participants in the Internet."
These cities have not yet nurtured a large number of Internet-related businesses in the way that New York has become a center for developers of World Wide Web sites, Los Angeles has become the capital of high-technology special effects for movies, or the Seattle area has benefited from new companies started in the shadow of the Microsoft Corporation.
"The location of Internet hosts," the study said, "suggests that there is a new pattern of leaders and losers in modern metropolitan growth."
The Internet, to be sure, is merely the latest wave of technology that affects cities unevenly, helping some and punishing others. Deep-water ports, railroads, the telephone and the automobile all brought changes in the geographic distribution of wealth and people.
In the future, the New York University study asserts, access to the Internet and technical know-how to exploit computer technology may well be the keys to economic development. "The future is going to belong to those cities and regions with the information-driven industries and people with the skills to thrive in those industries," said Mitchell Moss, director of the urban research center at New York University. Mr. Moss was the co-author of the Internet analysis with Anthony Townsend, a research assistant.
The regions doing well in the high-technology development race, Mr. Moss says, are likely to extend their lead. Telecommunications deregulation, he believes, will mean that new investment will increasingly go into the existing high-tech clusters. The accelerating concentration of skilled people, investment and innovation -- the Silicon Valley model -- will more and more become the pattern of economic development nationally, according to Mr. Moss.
Paul Saffo, a director of the Institute for the Future, agrees that Silicon Valley will be the model. But he says it is a model that suggests that new high-technology clusters will develop.
Computer engineers, Mr. Saffo notes, gathered in Silicon Valley partly because of Stanford University and the nearby Government research laboratories. Yet the weather, landscape and life style also made it a place where people wanted to stay. Once the industry took root, he notes, the business advantages of clustering grew in important.
Already, he sees evidence of computer professionals settling in new areas, attracted by the life style and high-speed telecommunications links in places like Santa Fe, N.M., and Telluride, Colo.
"The Internet won't mean the death of urban centers," Mr. Saffo said. "It will mean the reinvention of urban centers.
"But," he added, "it could also eventually mean an explosion in some exurban areas, leading to a migration not seen since the suburbanization of the 1950's."
Computer experts point out that trying to count host computers by location is difficult to do precisely. The method used for the New York University study does not count the machines on internal corporate networks, known as intranets. In addition, the address listed for an Internet computer may not always be where the machine actually is.
Yet David Gelernter, a computer science professor at Yale University, questioned not the methodology, but the significance of counting clusters of Internet host machines. The results of the study, he said, showed that Internet connections are spreading beyond their university and computer-company origins (Silicon Valley and Boston-Cambridge) and into centers of affluent, well-educated people (Manhattan and Los Angeles).
"The Internet today is about high-powered consumerism," said Mr. Gelernter, who writes about technology's impact on society. "Most people now use it for hanging out, shopping and browsing. Nobody's really making money on it yet. Culturally, the Internet is trivial.
"This may change, but I'm not sure that having a lot of Internet connections is any great economic or cultural advantage," Mr. Gelernter said.
"Leaders and Losers on the Internet" will be posted at the New York University urban research center site on the World Wide Web (http:// www.nyu.edu/urban). The Web site for Matrix Information and Directory Services Inc. is http://www.mids.org. The site for Netwizards Internet Domain Surveys is http:// www.nw.com.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE REFORM PARTY;
Perot, in Video Lecture, Renews Attack on Trade Accord

BYLINE: By ERNEST TOLLERSON 

 BODY:
Ross Perot says that when he cocks his ear toward Mexico, he still hears that "giant sucking sound" of American jobs headed south of the Rio Grande.
"Yes, folks, we predicted it, and there is a giant sucking sound coming out of Mexico," Mr. Perot, the Reform Party's Presidential candidate, said in a new 30-minute "infomercial" that was broadcast on Saturday evening on the Fox network. 
 "They're sucking your jobs down there, they're sucking our dollars down there, and both political parties were locked arm in arm and bound at the hip to make that happen," Mr. Perot said, as the campaign advertisement showed photographs of President Clinton, who led the fight for Congressional approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement in late 1993, and his Republican opponent, Bob Dole, who strongly supported the measure. "I'd like to see them defend it now."
Mr. Perot's video lecture reiterated his long-held belief that Nafta, which gradually abolishes nearly all trade barriers between the United States, Mexico and Canada, is an unfair, lopsided agreement that results in companies moving jobs in the United States to overseas sites, and American consumers buying foreign-made, tariff-free products.
To increase the number of higher wage jobs available to Americans and to increase prosperity in general, Mr. Perot proposes three policies: renegotiating Nafta, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and the Most Favored Nation status for China; increasing the amount of money invested in domestic manufacturing plants, and improving the creation of new technologies.
"I want to make one point absolutely clear regarding international trade," Mr. Perot said in the campaign advertisement, which includes his newly named running mate, Pat Choate, a political economist. "I am for fair, intelligent international trade that does not produce huge trade deficits and job losses in our country."
Mr. Perot framed the nation's trade deficit as a problem that America created for itself. "We have only ourselves to blame for our trade losses," he said. "They come from unfair, one-sided trade deals that encourage shipping our jobs overseas to get the cheapest labor possible, and then sending the foreign-made products back into the American market with no tariffs."
One of the charts that Mr. Perot uses in his new infomercial -- an advertising device that has become his preferred method of campaigning, as opposed to making personal appearances and giving stump speeches -- shows that the United States has a $61 billion trade deficit with Mexico and Canada in the last 27 months. Mr. Perot contends that the United States has "lost more than a half million American jobs to Mexico alone in this time period."
In 1993, before Congress approved legislation implementing Nafta, Mr. Perot predicted that the trade accord would cost the United States more than five million jobs.
After discussing the trade deficit, Mr. Perot posed a number of rhetorical questions, all of which underscored his contentions about Nafta's negative effects: "Did the average citizen in Mexico benefit? No. Did anyone benefit from Nafta? Oh, yes -- the people who poured tens of millions of dollars into Congressional campaigns benefited by moving their factories to Mexico, where they pay low wages, have little or no employee benefits and sell the goods back into the United States with no import tariffs."
In the advertisement, titled "Made in the USA . . . Again," Mr. Choate provided the intellectual underpinning for Mr. Perot's assertions about job creation and trade policy. In an indirect criticism of Mr. Clinton's campaign themes, Mr. Perot asked his running mate why some Americans are having a tough time "making ends meet" if the economy has produced 10 million jobs, low inflation and a robust stock market.
Mr. Choate replied: "In today's global economy, workers are abundant, jobs are scarce and corporations are highly mobile. The problem is one-sided trade deals. Our workers are in a race to the bottom with workers from the developing third-world countries."
Responding to Mr. Perot's observation that "people are working harder but making less," Mr. Choate said the United States was letting itself become a service economy.
"America is deep into the process of swapping good jobs for poor jobs," he said. "The numbers tell the story. Between 1985 and 1996, the United States created more than 23 million new jobs. But the vast majority of them were in part-time, low-wage service work. This is minimum-wage work, which is immune from international competition."

HEADLINE: Flags Flying, North Italian Secession Rally Falls Short

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: VENICE, Italy, Sept. 15

 BODY:
Unfurling the banners of the still-mythical state of Padania, Italy's small but flamboyant secessionist movement steamed into this northern lagoon city this evening, stepping up its improbable challenge to Italian unity with a mix of medieval pageantry and political bombast.
Borrowing phrases from the American Declaration of Independence, Umberto Bossi, the movement's leader, who had just completed a three-day "March to the Sea," delivered a tirade against the "colonialists" in Rome who, he said, have robbed the north of Italy of its hard-earned money and its cultural identity. 
 But the long-awaited independence day rally by his Northern League fell far short of expectations, as an estimated 10,000 supporters gathered on the banks of the Grand Canal here. As the crowd milled below a sea of colorful flags, shopping for Padania memorabilia, the mood was more of a small town party than the beginnings of a separatist rebellion.
The lower-than-predicted turnout for Mr. Bossi's elaborately staged spectacle, which began on Friday with a flotilla down the Po River, did not shield him from attack by a full array of Italian political leaders who have mounted an all-out effort to halt his secessionist bid.
Speaking in the southern city of Bari on the eve of Mr. Bossi's symbolic declaration of independence, President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro warned the secessionists: "The state guarantees freedom of expression, but cannot tolerate incitement to illegal acts. A democracy that is afraid to apply the law when the need arises would not be worthy of the name."
And at a counterdemonstration held today in Milan by the far-right National Alliance party, an estimated 150,000 people sang the Italian national anthem after listening to the party leader, Gianfranco Fini, declare: "Italy is here, it will not be insulted, and it will not be divided. Secession and division are an insult to history, and an insult to reason."
The birth of Padania -- the name chosen by Mr. Bossi for an undefined area stretching north of the Po River -- is the latest expression of a protest movement that began in the mid-1980's as a regional revolt against the corruption, mismanagement and inefficiency that for many northern Italians have become synonymous with Italy's central Government.
To listen to Mr. Bossi is to hear how divided Italians remain. He sprinkles his rambling speeches with crude insults against southern Italians, taunting their accents and their economic backwardness. He calls them "mafiosi" and accuses them, and their political patrons in Rome, of dragging Italy down and dashing its hopes of joining a united Europe on an equal footing with France and Germany.
After last spring's parliamentary elections, which saw Mr. Bossi's Northern League win 10 percent of the national vote but as much as 40 percent in some of Italy's richest northern regions, he redefined its goals, moving away from calls for greater federalism to a battle cry for outright independence.
In the weeks building up to today's declaration, Italy's mainstream political leaders struggled to come up with an appropriate response to Mr. Bossi's challenge, alternating between ridicule and alarm.
Even the Roman Catholic Church -- which a century ago was one of the major obstacles to Italy's new-born unification -- weighed in against secession, with a pastoral letter by Milan's popular Cardinal, Carol Maria Martini, branding any attempt to break up Italy "demagoguery and adventurism."
But as many political observers noted in the steady stream of commentary issued in anticipation of Mr. Bossi's next move, the 55-year-old former hospital orderly has succeeded in placing himself at center stage and shaking the political establishment out of its complacency.
In making the argument for a "free Padania," Mr. Bossi and his small circle of advisers have argued that in an era of an increasingly united Europe, regions -- rather than traditional states -- need to be better represented.
The three-day "March to the Sea" began Friday on a high mountain plateau where Mr. Bossi, in one of his symbolic gestures, held high a Venetian-made flask containing water from the source of the Po River, to represent a baptism of Padania.
Like the Northern League's flag, which shows a medieval warrior raising a broadsword against the background of a red-on-white cross, the flask -- and the accompanying emblem of Padania's green six-rayed "Alpine Sun" -- is designed to give his proposed new state the trappings of a mythology.
"These rituals are not about discovering the past, but about building a new identity," said Ilvo Diamanti, a sociologist at the University of Padua and Urbino who has closely followed the emergence of the Northern League.
Mr. Bossi's ambitious 400-mile journey along one of Italy's most historic river valleys was greeted along the banks of the Po, and at various stops along the way, by small bands of enthusiastic supporters, wearing the green shirts of his movement and waving the banners of his cause.
It had its moments of farce, when water levels at one point were too low to keep the Bossi entourage afloat, forcing them to resume part of the trip by car. At another point, lights that were to flash the word Padania onto a night sky failed to turn on.
But judging from the relatively low turnout for his voyage and the rally in Venice, Mr. Bossi may have tried the patience of his supporters, few of whom share his love of medieval legends and theatrical gestures.
"Mr. Bossi has figured out that the only way to get attention is to be outrageous," said Patrick McCarthy, a professor at the Johns Hopkins University School of Advanced International Studies in Bologna. "But Bossi's support doesn't come from people like Bossi."
For the small and medium-sized businesses of northern regions like the Veneto, where Mr. Bossi scored his biggest success in the last elections, Italy's high tax rates and poor public administration have hampered their ability to compete on European markets. Many of them support Mr. Bossi because he was the first Italian politician to promise greater federalism. Since then, federalism has become a widely accepted goal, in particular of Italy's current center-left Government.
But the federalist reforms promised by Prime Minister Romano Prodi have been slow in coming, and many political observers have said Mr. Bossi's latest antics have gained attention, if only because of his opponents' shortcomings.
"The League has to be taken seriously because it belies deep dissatisfaction, particularly of an economic nature," said Prof. Aurelio Lepre, who teaches history at the University of Naples. "Basically the rich north no longer wants to support the poor south, because the north is afraid that it will not be able to enter into Europe. The racist ideology the League has adopted is there to cover economic dissatisfaction. But racism mobilizes people; it gives them a symbolic objective."

HEADLINE: West Coast Naval Base Belatedly Stirs Passions

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 12

 BODY:
This past Wednesday, Patricia Fink went through a routine she had followed for four years, locking the door of her office on the elegant, campuslike naval base here, initialing a form against the back of a sailor who had been waiting in the breezeway, then walking toward her car for the ride home.
The only difference was that it was the last time she would make the trip. 
 Ms. Fink, who first saw the base 13 years ago when her father became its commander, was one of many people taking home little more than memories as the once-thriving Long Beach Naval Station, a mainstay of the local economy for five decades, moved closer to being shut down.
The Department of Defense decided to close it as part of a nationwide cost-cutting program, and the ships that had carried sailors to and from wars around the globe pulled out for good last year.
But what has made the experience particularly melancholy for workers and residents is the proposed fate of the historic, 130-acre naval station: the City of Long Beach has been aggressively pushing a plan to raze every structure on the site, including 11 handsome, International style buildings whose designers included Paul Revere Williams, one of the country's most prominent black architects. The site would be paved for a shipping container terminal.
The decision has come as a shock to many people familiar with the site, an oasis of greenery in the middle of the country's busiest commercial port, and it has blown up into a major civic protest, with some people demanding a recall of the Mayor, Beverly O'Neill.
"Economically, they think it's best for the city, but I think it's a shame," said Capt. Joseph Innes, a dentist in the base clinic whose first posting was at Long Beach and who locked up for the last time today. "This was one of the best-kept secrets in the Navy. It was a very nice place. I can't believe they can't use it for a little college campus or something."
For several years now, cities around the country have been forced to deal with base closings and their economic repercussions, a combination of lost jobs and, for creative local governments, new opportunities. But few communities have felt the issues as poignantly as Long Beach, a depressed industrial city of 440,000 just south of Los Angeles.
A hearing on the proposed terminal Wednesday drew several thousand people and dragged on until 1 A.M., with many people hooting derisively as Mayor O'Neill described plans to create what she said would be as many as 650 jobs at the site. No matter that the city is suffering an unemployment rate of 8.3 percent, more than three percentage points higher than the rest of the country.
"I've been in this field 20 years, and this is without a doubt the biggest turnout I've ever seen for something like this," said Cherilyn Widell, the state's historic preservation officer and part of the effort to determine whether the buildings should be saved as architectural landmarks.
What is striking is that residents here seem suddenly energized by a sense of civic pride rather than raw economic need, even though it is pride in a group of structures that few of them had seen or even known of until a few months ago.
Because the base was always closed to outsiders, "we had no idea what was there; no one let us know," said Peter Devereaux, vice president of Long Beach Heritage, an organization that is trying to rescue the buildings. "We had no time to work on any alternative plans."
In fact, opponents of the terminal concede that they do not have a well-thought-out counterproposal, and at the least are asking for more time.
During California's recent recession, Long Beach was betrayed by what had been the two pillars of its economy. The city lost 30,000 aerospace jobs, and then it was hit with the devastating news that the Pentagon was closing the Navy base and several other military installations, with a loss of about 27,000 jobs.
The city has placed its hopes on trade. Long Beach harbor is an endless vista of spindly cranes, bulky vessels and stacks of containers, most bearing the names of Chinese, Korean and other Asian companies.
The port, which is adjacent to its competitor, the Port of Los Angeles, handled the equivalent of 2.8 million 20-foot containers last year, trade valued at $82 billion.
The city's plan is to immediately level everything on the site, not just the Williams buildings, but also the $50 million worth of structures put up in the last decade, including apartment buildings and a medical center. The more than 100 acres of blacktop would then be leased to the China Ocean Shipping Company, which is owned by the Chinese Government.
The city has said that the company is threatening to move if the additional space is not provided. A company official confirmed that it had been wooed aggressively by the Port of Los Angeles and would take the best deal offered.
"I don't think it's any secret that there's a lot of competition from other ports for these jobs," said Jim Hankla, the city manager. "We don't intend to lose them."
The focus of concern is not the whole naval station, but a 60-acre portion known as the Roosevelt Base that was rushed to completion in 1942, after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor. It contains 11 buildings, among them offices and a huge gymnasium, designed by Mr. Williams and another architect, Adrian Wilson.
The base is still in excellent condition, with trimmed lawns, clipped rosebushes and huge ficus and olive trees. One complaint is that destruction of the base would eliminate the habitat for numerous birds, including herons. Ms. Fink said she had rescued perhaps a hundred baby herons that had fallen from nests.
Mr. Williams, who died in 1980, is well known for many local landmarks, including the Los Angeles County Courthouse, a Jetsons-like structure at the Los Angeles airport and homes for celebrities.
The city has said that it will try to preserve the memory of the base buildings by producing a documentary film, ordering some drawings and salvaging some artifacts. The audience at the hearing on Wednesday heckled city officials mercilessly when they described the plan.
The Long Beach port commission, which is proposing to build the new terminal, has made its own peace offering. It said it would donate $2 million toward construction of soccer fields near downtown to make up for the destruction of the recreational offerings at the base, which some residents had proposed turning into a public park. At the hearing, protesters shouted "payoff!" when the offer was mentioned.
"People are looking at the price they are being asked to pay for those jobs, and they think it's too high," Mr. Devereaux said. "People want to be proud of their community, you know."

Workers recently moved furniture from the administration building, with its elaborate terrazzo floor. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE CONTROVERSIES;
Perot's New Campaign Propels Unanswered Questions Back to Surface

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

 BODY:
Four years after Ross Perot took his first run at the Presidency, a remarkable odyssey that saw him capture nearly one in every five votes cast in the 1992 election, the Texas billionaire is once again a candidate for the White House, atop the ticket of a party he founded and bankrolled.
As he did last time, Mr. Perot has embarked on a campaign that relies on spare public appearances, scripted infomercials and his usual litany of Texas homilies. But his re-entry on the political stage last month also brought a fresh round of something else that marked his last Presidential run: controversy. 
 Within only days of Mr. Perot's official entry into the race for the Reform Party nomination, his chief rival, former Gov. Richard D. Lamm of Colorado, asserted that he had such iron control over the party machinery that the balloting might be rigged.
When the voting was over and Mr. Perot had indeed won handily, Mr. Lamm refused to support his Presidential bid. "I will endorse Ross Perot as a prophet," he said. "I will endorse Ross Perot as Paul Revere. I will endorse him as prescient. I will not endorse him as President."
Although Mr. Lamm did not elaborate on his decision, he is not the first to raise questions about whether Mr. Perot is suited to be President. In the 1992 campaign, Mr. Perot was dogged by questions not only about his temperament, but also about decisions he had made as a politician and, earlier, as a businessman.
Mr. Perot has, his critics say, an inordinate need for control, which is perhaps not unusual for a man who is a self-made billionaire. The critics have also suggested that he has a penchant for intrigue and conspiracy theories, which has at times caused him to threaten those whom he sees as his enemies. They also have questioned whether Mr. Perot has followed and benefited from the same standards of corporate behavior that he has insisted are corrupt and should be changed.
As the Texan runs again for the Presidency, a number of such questions remain:
*Despite railing against the corrupting evils of political donations, Mr. Perot has given many tens of thousands of dollars to political candidates over the years and was once the single largest contributor to Congressional candidates in the nation.
*Even though he has denounced lobbyists in their "alligator shoes," he and his top aides have successfully lobbied to advance his own fortunes; his successes include securing tax breaks for a huge airport project on land owned by his family and fighting off a Texas state plan to cancel a major contract with one of his companies.
*His apparent fondness for hiring private investigators has brought him an unwanted nickname, Inspector Perot, and he has raised eyebrows by detailing conspiracy theories, some involving threats to his own life, like a bizarre and never-proven accusation that a group of Vietnamese-backed Black Panthers had once sneaked onto his property to kill him.
*Perhaps most damaging of all, many voters say they remain deeply bothered by Mr. Perot's abrupt exit from the Presidential race in the summer of 1992, followed by a surprise re-entry and the shocking explanation that he had left in the first place because of a Republican-backed "dirty tricks" campaign to disrupt his daughter's wedding.
*Even as Mr. Perot insisted for nearly three months that he had pulled out of that race, he continued to spend heavily at that time to get his name on the ballot.
Only this week did Mr. Perot choose his Vice-Presidential candidate, Dr. Pat Choate, an economist. So far, public opinion polls suggest that his campaign has not generated the same curiosity or enthusiasm it did four years ago. Various polls show that Mr. Perot is the preference of as few as 4 to 7 percent of the voters, and even his paid television commercials have drawn ratings that are a bare shadow of what his wisecracks, aphorisms and famous charts drew four years ago.
During the political season so far, Mr. Perot has shown no inclination to address the doubts that have been raised about him.
"You can't confront it head on," said Gordon S. Black, a Rochester, N.Y., pollster and informal Perot adviser. "It's sort of like having to say, 'I'm not a liar; I'm not a cheat; I'm not a philanderer.' The very fact you have to do that reinforces the idea that you might be. What is he supposed to say: 'I am not crazy; I am not unstable?' You can't do that."
Gerald Posner, author of "Citizen Perot" (Random House, 1996), a new, unauthorized biography of the Texan, said Mr. Perot "wants to be a sort of climate-controlled candidate." Mr. Posner continued: "He gets short-tempered. He knows he doesn't handle these questions well. So his solution this time is to stay above it all, and nobody yet seems to be raising a ruckus that he isn't really dealing with these issues."
But the questions are there. Here is a guide to many of them, with comments that Mr. Perot has made about them in the past. He declined requests for an interview for this article.

The 1992 Race
Political Decisions And Consequences
On July 16, 1992, still riding high in the polls, Mr. Perot abruptly pulled the plug on his campaign. He said he believed that the Democrats were responding to his campaign themes and that a three-way election would wind up being settled in the House.
Still, he quietly encouraged his volunteers in the next few months to maintain their efforts for him and to get him on the ballot in 50 states. On Oct. 1, he was back in, telling his supporters: "I thought that both political parties would address the problems that face the nation. We gave them a chance. They didn't do it."
About four weeks later, just as he was coming back up in the polls, he went on the CBS News program "60 Minutes" and revealed his reason for getting out in July: what he called a Republican-backed plot to disturb his daughter's wedding in August, in part by creating fake photographs of her that would embarrass her.
"I found myself in a situation where I had three reports that the Republican Party intended to publish a false photograph of my daughter," he elaborated in a speech to supporters, saying the photograph involved a "head on another body" and was to be distributed to supermarket tabloids. "This is one of the most important days of her life, and I love her too much to have her hurt."
The accusation, dismissed by a spokesman for President George Bush as "all loony," was exhaustively researched by reporters and the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who were unable to establish a credible basis for it. Mr. Perot admitted on "60 Minutes" that he could not prove the bizarre charge, but he said he had heard it from reliable sources.
The incident is treated at length in Mr. Posner's new book, which says Mr. Perot's chief source for the accusation was Scott Barnes, a twice-dismissed police officer from California whom Mr. Perot had spoken to on the telephone for years about various intelligence matters.
Mr. Barnes now says no such photographs existed. In a recent letter to Time magazine, he expressed remorse over the whole incident and said: "There was never any G.O.P. plot against Perot. It was all a political hoax to remove Bush."
A caller to "Larry King Live" on CNN two months ago asked how people could be sure that Mr. Perot would not suddenly pull out of the race this year. Mr. King, paraphrasing the question, said to Mr. Perot, "If there is a threat again to family, as you perceived the last time, would that cause you----"
"It was not perceived," Mr. Perot interrupted. "I don't want to go into that." He added, "The point is, Larry, can someone just stop and take a few minutes and look at what I have done, night and day, for the last five years?"
The incident hurt Mr. Perot's standing. Newspapers in his home state called him the Yellow Ross of Texas, and Newsweek put him on its cover as "The Quitter," a headline that friends say galls him to this day.

In the Service
Explaining the End Of a Navy Career
Mr. Perot's 1992 campaign was also beset by a controversy over at least three different explanations he gave for abandoning his Navy career in the 1950's.
Mr. Perot unsuccessfully sought an early discharge in 1955, writing to his father that the Navy was a "fairly Godless organization," and that he was offended by "being subjected to drunken tales of moral emptiness" and "seeing promiscuity on the part of married men."
In a 1971 article in The New York Times Magazine, Mr. Perot said he loved the Navy but had wanted to get out because "the promotion system and the seniority system and the waiting-in-line concept were just sort of incompatible with my desire to be measured and judged by what I could produce."
Then, in the midst of the 1992 race, he offered for the first time what he said was the real reason for wanting to leave: He said he had bridled at inappropriate requests for money and liquor from the commander of the destroyer on which he was serving. The commander, in interviews in 1992, called Mr. Perot's assertions "hogwash."
Mr. Perot was subjected to withering criticism that he had changed his story about trying to get out of the service to make it more politically palatable.
But he has ignored the controversy. "It's just another little spitball flying through the air as far as I'm concerned," he said in 1992.

The P.O.W. Issue
Some Friction With Government
Mr. Perot's public and political profile grew over his determined advocacy on behalf of American servicemen believed to be missing in Vietnam.
But while political proponents of the P.O.W-M.I.A. issue hailed the Texan as a hero, Mr. Perot's campaign to take control of the Government's investigation resulted in a bruising confrontation with members of the Reagan Administration in the 1980's, including Vice President George Bush.
Although the Administration had enlisted Mr. Perot's assistance, critics say he soon fixated on the notion that a Government conspiracy was thwarting him. Mr. Perot even argued that his life was in peril from a team of Black Panther assassins hired by Vietnam.
Administration officials say Mr. Perot also used questionable tactics to discredit a chief rival, Richard L. Armitage, a senior Pentagon official who had negotiated with the North Vietnamese about missing Americans and who was once Mr. Bush's nominee for Secretary of the Army.
Using information from several sources, including James (Bo) Gritz, a former Green Beret turned right-wing survivalist and officials of the Christic Institute, a group that supports leftist causes, Mr. Perot served as a conduit for assertions involving Mr. Armitage. Among them, critics say, was information from an undercover police officer in Virginia suggesting that Mr. Armitage's friendship with a Vietnamese-American woman had compromised the Government's effort on behalf of the missing servicemen.
An F.B.I. investigation determined that the accusation and others were unfounded and cleared Mr. Armitage of any criminal wrongdoing. Mr. Perot said he had done nothing improper and had only sought to turn over information of possible illegal activity to criminal investigators.

The Businessman
Knowing How to Push Political Buttons
Critics have also pointed to apparent contradictions between Mr. Perot's political statements and the way he has conducted himself as a titan in the business world.
Mr. Perot's founding of the Electronic Data Systems Corporation, or E.D.S., the company that helped turn him into a billionaire, is part of the Horatio Alger cast that Mr. Perot has given to his own life story. The company, formed in 1962, earned a fortune by running computer programs that processed claims for Medicare and Medicaid, the two huge Government insurance programs. The business wound up with contracts with insurers across the nation; as the insurance programs ballooned in size, so did the company's profits.
Mr. Perot's business savvy in setting up E.D.S. is unquestionable. But he was criticized for a long-running feud with Federal regulators over ownership of the E.D.S. software programs that had been developed with Federal money. Mr. Perot basically prevailed, but not without a Congressional investigation into the matter and questions about his company's use of taxpayers' money.
Another episode that raised questions was the brass-knuckle lobbying campaign Mr. Perot waged in 1980 to overturn a decision by a Texas state agency to discontinue using E.D.S. to process its Medicaid claims. The agency initially concluded that an upstart competitor from New York, the Bradford National Corporation, had developed both a cheaper and technically superior program. An outside group of consultants agreed.
The home-state contract covered claims for 700,000 Texans and amounted to about 12 percent of E.D.S.'s earnings. By all accounts, Mr. Perot fought with a vengeance to preserve it.
His company compiled a huge dossier of negative information about its rival that it circulated around Austin, and Mr. Perot at one point referred to one of the officials who had recommended Bradford as "a disturbed individual." According to news accounts, he also said he thought there was a conspiracy afoot among some state officials to make the New York company fail and then take over the processing themselves. The head of Bradford said Mr. Perot and his subordinates had been "watching too many James Bond movies."
Mr. Perot also pulled strings in the Capitol, receiving private hearings with the Governor, the Attorney General and members of the board that was awarding the contract. Former Bradford officials also said in 1992 that they had received harassing anonymous telephone calls during the episode, though they were not able to prove who had made them.
After a tumultuous struggle, Mr. Perot won. He said repeatedly in 1992 that he had fought a tough but fair battle to win back the Texas contract. Nonetheless, the episode received substantial coverage in 1992, with some participants casting Mr. Perot as a ruthless infighter and others saying it showed him to be a master at pulling strings in government.
In addition, Mr. Perot faced inquiries in 1992 about how he had persuaded Federal, state and local officials to grant $200 million in cash and tax breaks for a cargo airport near Fort Worth in the middle of property owned by him and members of his family. Mr. Perot said there had been nothing inappropriate about the breaks; while they may have benefited the Perots, he said, they had also helped bring a business boom to the area.
There were never suggestions that Mr. Perot had done anything illegal in using his close ties to officials to win the tax breaks. More broadly, though, a number of people said in 1992 that the way Mr. Perot had worked the political system contrasted with his claims of being an outsider with disdain for the ways of Washington.
"When Ross Perot influences an issue, it is not lobbying," the acting Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration, Barry L. Harris, said in 1992 in reference to the airport matter. "When somebody else does it, it is. Perot has influenced legislators and lobbied as much as anyone else."
During both of his Presidential campaigns, Mr. Perot has bemoaned the influence of money in politics, but Mr. Perot has a history of generous donations to political campaigns. In at least one year, 1974, he gave more than $90,000 to Congressional candidates, making him the largest individual contributor in the country. Among the recipients were 12 members of the House Ways and Means Committee; the next year, 10 of the 12 voted for an amendment to that year's tax bill written specifically for Mr. Perot that granted his business a $15 million tax break. Mr. Perot said at the time that there was nothing hypocritical about playing by the rules, although he believed that the rules should be changed.

Seeking Information
Private Detectives Lead to Controversy
Mr. Perot's predilection for some types of conspiracy theories and his hiring of private detectives were well documented in 1992 and were another point of controversy.
He did not deny that he had hired investigators to look into his business competitors, but, he told reporters in the 1992 campaign, "my total experience of investigating people is like a grain of sand on a large beach compared to the ongoing investigations, day after day after day after day, by the Republican dirty tricks."
Mr. Perot also conceded in 1992 that he had hired private investigators from San Francisco to check into some of his own volunteers. He said he had needed to do so to explore accusations that the workers had misused money or had criminal records.
Other news reports said that Mr. Perot had hired detectives to spy on his own children and their friends and that in one instance, he had tried to dig up information on a daughter's boyfriend he disliked. He said any such cases had been misconstrued. "It is a huge gap between making sure they're safe and investigating my children and/or their friends, or whatever else some fruitcake alleges," he said.
Mr. Perot has also from time to time described elaborate conspiracies aimed at killing him or his family.
Perhaps most vividly, in the third Presidential debate of 1992, he said the Vietnamese hired a group of Black Panthers to kill him in 1969. "The Vietnamese had sent people into Canada to make arrangements to have me and my family killed," Mr. Perot told a nationwide audience watching the debate. "The most significant effort they had one night is five people coming across my front yard with rifles."
Mr. Perot later said he had not reported the incident to the police because a guard dog had managed to chase away the would-be assassins. "He worked them like a sheep dog," Mr. Perot explained in 1992.
But several news reports put the whole episode in much doubt. "Listen to me," said Paul McCaghren, the chief of police intelligence operations in Dallas in 1969, to ABC News in 1992. "It didn't happen. It did not happen."
Mr. Perot also suggested that the guard dog had bitten off a major part of one assailant's buttocks, though no hospital in the Dallas area reported treating such a wound at the time.
When reporters questioned Mr. Perot in 1992 about why he could not provide more confirmation of the incident, he said: "I'm not going to get into that with you because it's none of your business. I'm not going to -- hey, look, I don't have to prove anything to you people to start with."
Part of Mr. Perot's fascination with the intelligence field won him plaudits. Many considered him a national hero when he tried to fly into Vietnam in the late 1960's to aid prisoners of war. And his successful organization of a 1979 mission to Iran to rescue two imprisoned employees of E.D.S. became the stuff of a best-selling book, although one over which he had editorial control.
But a few contentious episodes brought less positive headlines for him in 1992. For example, while working on the prisoner-of-war issue in 1987, Mr. Perot unsuccessfully sought to persuade the Reagan White House to begin limited economic relations with Vietnam. Some Reagan Administration officials complained that he had gone to Vietnam for his own business ends, an accusation Mr. Perot heatedly denied. He said he had engaged, at the initiative of Vietnamese officials, only in several "philosophical" talks about American business opportunities in the country.

The Nafta Debate
Accusing Gore Of Cheating
In November 1993, as the Clinton Administration was furiously working to win Congressional approval for the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mr. Perot, an opponent, agreed to debate Vice President Al Gore on "Larry King Live."
The billionaire was on the defensive much of the time, and Mr. Gore goaded Mr. Perot into making disparaging and sarcastic remarks to him, such as: "You're lying -- you're lying now," and, "Please, let's have an unnatural event and try not to interrupt me."
The nationally televised debate caused Mr. Perot's poll ratings to plummet. And news coverage at the time had many people saying that Mr. Perot's impetuous performance made it harder to view him as a potential President.
In Mr. Posner's new book, Mr. Perot is quoted as saying why he thinks Mr. Gore did well in the debate. He says Mr. Gore was wearing a tiny, secret earpiece in his left ear, through which White House aides might have fed him information and debating tips.
"Watch the debate, and you will see that thing twinkle," Mr. Perot is quoted as saying. "Let's say you were being fed good answers, or good questions, or you name it. Don't boast publicly about it because that is cheating. See, the news should have been, 'They cheated.' "
Many people who have reviewed the King show tape, including Mr. Posner, said that light appeared to be glistening on Mr. Gore's left ear but that it looked like a reflection. A spokeswoman for the Vice President recently dismissed the accusation as ludicrous. "Yeah, then Scotty beamed him up to the Starship Enterprise," she said of Mr. Gore. (The Vice President did have a standard earpiece for guests on the show in his right ear.)
A spokeswoman for Mr. Perot's campaign, Sharon Holman, said Mr. Perot had not made a formal accusation of cheating in his comment to Mr. Posner but had merely been repeating "cocktail party chatter" he had heard.

The 1996 Campaign
Questions Get Little Response
Even as this year's Presidential campaign intensifies, Mr. Perot appears to be ignoring questions about these controversies.
"If he buys enough air time this fall, just on the infomercials, and sticks to friendly live television a la Larry King," said Mr. Posner, his biographer, "he thinks he can get his message across and people will say: 'You know what? He doesn't seem so wacky to me.' "
Mr. Black, the Rochester pollster, said Mr. Perot's best strategy was to let his business associates and friends talk about him. Indeed, as was established in 1992, there are many compelling tales of his loyalty and kindness to some of his employees, and of his support for inner-city schools and homeless shelters in Dallas.
In 1992, as reporters asked him about many of the questions discussed here, he responded with colorful, though cryptic, dismissals: "animal crackers," "Mickey Mouse" "tossed salad" and "fairyland."
This time around, in one of the very few times Mr. Perot has had anything public to say about these matters, he took a brief question on ABC's "Good Morning America" the morning after he became the Reform Party nominee. The interviewer said many people "worry that you don't have the temperament to be President" and then asked, "Are you going to try to address that issue at all?"
"Look at who I really am, as opposed to who two dirty-tricks teams for the two parties have tried to recast me to be," Mr. Perot said. "Look at my real life, not what people come up with and the stories they make up. Look at what I have done through my life. Look at what -- how I do conduct my life."
