HEADLINE: POLITICS;
In His Own Words

 BODY:

ROSS PEROT
From a discussion of the nation's economic future in a campaign advertisement that was broadcast on Saturday night: 
 "The second solution to restoring our job base is to increase the amount of money that we invest in U.S. manufacturing facilities. This money is typically borrowed by businesses, through banks, from the savings of millions of Americans. The interest rates that businesses are charged determine how much money can be borrowed. The lower the interest rate, the more money a company can afford to borrow to build factories. The interest rate is determined by demand for money. The greater the demand for money, the higher the interest rates.
"The U.S. Government demands a great deal of money each year just to finance deficit spending. If the Government stopped spending more than it takes in, it would not have to borrow any money. Therefore, there would be more money available to borrow, and interest rates would fall. Businesses could afford to borrow more money to invest in their facilities and more jobs could be created in our country.
"We simply must balance the budget so that we can keep the interest rates low for everyone and begin investing in jobs instead of wasting our tax money paying interest on the national debt. Have you had either of the other two Presidential candidates talk to you like this? I don't think so. Their parties created this problem."

HEADLINE: Campaign Trail;
THE PRESIDENTIAL RACE

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

 BODY:

Pools and Stars
Come and listen to a story about a man named Bill.
By now, it is well known that President Clinton went to Beverly Hills last Thursday night and picked up roughly $4 million for Democrats at a star-studded fund-raiser. But admit it. What you really want dished up is glitz -- the President's favorite Democratic celebrities, the money, the action at a big Hollywood party. So here goes: 
 The outdoors bash unfolded on the plush (Spanish stucco mansion; pool; tennis court; play area with animal-shaped topiary and a carousel, no less) hilltop estate of Ronald Burkle, owner of the Ralph's Supermarket chain.
About 1,000 people mobbed a $1,000-a-head cocktail reception with the Clintons and other Big Names, among them Rob Reiner, Kevin Spacey, Sharon Stone, Eleanor Mondale, Shirley MacLaine, Joan Collins, Richard Dreyfuss, Carrie Fisher and Calvin Klein. Five thousand dollars bought a concert featuring Chicago, the Eagles, the Neville Brothers, the saxophonist Tom Scott and Barbra Streisand, plus a poetry reading by Maya Angelou.
Paula Poundstone was the house comic. Tom Hanks was the emcee. And this was just the warm-up.
Of the masses, only about 250 made it to the $12,500 dinner. Mr. Clinton saluted Ms. Streisand ("Thank you, Barbra, for being my friend and for sharing your extraordinary gift") and joked that Mr. Hanks's labor had earned him Presidential permission to play the lead in the film version of "Primary Colors," a role Mr. Hanks has turned down.
Then the givers went home. And the recipients celebrated in time-honored Hollywood fashion.
It all ended with a late-night wager between junior White House aides and the President's press secretary, Michael D. McCurry. Mr. McCurry won $100, and presumably a damp ride to the airport, by jumping into the Burkle estate's swimming pool. Fully clothed.
Lucky 15
If anyone wonders why the book version of Bob Dole's economic blueprint, "Trusting the People," costs $15 and had a first press run of 150,000 copies, Jack Kemp says the answer is simple: fate.
On the campaign trail, Mr. Kemp has taken to humoring rally-goers by stating that the Dole campaign is mysteriously and inextricably guided by the number 15. He credits the notion to Mr. Dole, telling Republican legislators last week that his running mate first spotted the conjunction between the campaign's proposed 15 percent tax cut, the 15 on Mr. Kemp's jersey when he played professional football in San Diego and Buffalo, and the '96 election, whose digits can be added to produce the sum of 15.
That's just the start, Mr. Kemp says: The Kemps have 15 children and grandchildren. The first names of Elizabeth Dole and Joanne Kemp, the candidates' wives, together contain 15 letters. So do the names Bob Dole and Jack Kemp.
Mr. Kemp draws out the story, piling anecdote atop anecdote until it reaches a pinnacle of silliness that draws a guffaw from even jaded audiences. Unmentioned so far, however, is the latest election poll released last week by ABC News and its "Nightline" program.
Wouldn't you know it: the poll concludes that Mr. Dole trails President Clinton by 15 percentage points.

Spelling Bob Dole
Reason No. 15 to vote for Bob Dole in November: His wit is drier.
Giving out autographs at a rally, Mr. Dole told a supporter that he would bring a distinct advantage to the White House should he be the man signing legislation in the Oval Office next year. "I got a shorter name," he said. "Save a lot of ink. Save money."

Nonpartisan Nabobs
Holy Spiro Agnew: Bucking the trend, a report by a notably conservative media critic concludes that television coverage of the 1996 Presidential campaign may be -- gasp -- more balanced than in many years.
The chairman of the Virginia-based Media Research Center, L. Brent Bozell 3d, released an analysis of network reporting on the Republican and Democratic conventions last week that drew what he called "surprising" conclusions. Among them: the networks labeled Democrats as liberals or extremists more often than they called Republicans conservative or extreme.
Reporters gave Mr. Clinton the liberal tag 16 times but applied the conservative label to Mr. Dole only twice. And while television made scant reference to Whitewater and other Democratic imbroglios, it all but ignored similar controversies in the Republican camp.
The tilt was hardly all Republican, Mr. Bozell's study hastens to add. In the opinion of the study's 10 analysts, the vast majority of questions asked by reporters at both conventions tilted leftward, approaching topics like abortion, welfare and intolerance from a liberal perspective.
Nor does the study necessarily suggest a drift to the right in the broadcast business. The more likely explanation, said the executive director of the research center, Brent Baker, is that reporters are now wielding their liberal biases against both parties and not just the G.O.P.
"They criticized both parties this time for being too conservative," Mr. Baker said. "The bias in how they approach things is still there."
Still, the study's selection of the best convention reporters provides compelling evidence of a world turning upside down. Heading the list, almost impossibly, is Sam Donaldson, the ABC News reporter who was all but a conservative pariah when he covered the Reagan White House.
Mr. Donaldson, the study concludes, "refrained from gratuitous attacks on Republicans" and "offered a balanced appraisal of the party delegates."
Told of the honor, Mr. Donaldson was briefly stunned. "I'll take it wherever I can get it," he said.

Sound Bite
"Most of the stuff that comes and goes in elections is gone like chaff in the wind. It doesn't amount to a hill of beans." -- President Clinton, in St. Louis on Sept. 10, assuring listeners that his stuff is different. MICHAEL WINES

HEADLINE: Study Group Urges Preschool For Every 3- and 4-Year-Old

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 15

 BODY:
All children need access to two years of high-quality preschool, but publicly funded programs and systems supported by employers or churches are a patchwork that leaves too many children simply marking time waiting for kindergarten, a new report says.
The report, which is to be released on Monday by the Task Force on Learning in the Primary Grades of the Carnegie Corporation, proposes universal preschool to help assure success in school for youngsters. 
 Already 53 percent of the children from age 3 to 5 are in preschool programs. The nation's largest preschool program, Head Start, provides classes for about 800,000 children at a cost of about $3.5 billion a year. At the current birth rate, nearly 7.8 million children would be covered by a univeral preschool requirement, making the potential total cost more than $33 billion a year.
The co-chairwoman of the task force, Shirley Malcom, said today that she was convinced that the goal of universal preschool could become a reality for 3- and 4-year-olds.
"You know, 40 years ago, there was no universal kindergarten either," said Ms. Malcom, who directs education and human resources for the American Association for the Advancement of Science.
The report says preschool programs should not only connect with what parents try to teach their toddlers but with what kindergarten and elementary school teachers will try to accomplish once the child enters school.
Today, Ms. Malcom said, few preschool teachers even talk to kindergarten teachers.
Preschool also should complement after-school programs and what children watch on television or learn on the Internet or at community activities like Scouts, Little League and church, the report says.
"Academic self-image is shaped between the age of 3 and 10," said the report. "Children who take an early dislike to schoolwork or have doubts about their academic worth face disadvantage in all future learning."
The report, which will be considered at a two-day conference in New York that ends on Tuesday, also recommended reallocating resources to proven programs and initiating programs to teach parents in all economic groups how to be effective as their children's first teacher.
"If you have high expectations, and if you have the vision of where you want a child to be at grade 1, 6 and 12, then you have to set the course," said Marlene Guy, principal at Richardson Elementary School in Washington.
"If you have low expectations, that's what you'll get."

HEADLINE: Ford and U.A.W. Optimistic On Reaching an Agreement

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Sept. 15

 BODY:
Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers union and the Ford Motor Company were guardedly optimistic this evening that they could reach a new national labor contract, as work at factories continued despite expiration of the old contract at midnight on Saturday.
While Ford's car and truck assembly lines do not run on Sundays, maintenance workers were on the job today, as were workers at some parts factories with long backlogs. Ford officials said they expected all factories to run normally on Monday. 
 Having warm relations with Ford, the U.A.W. had not threatened to strike if the old contract expired before a new deal was reached.
Negotiators went home at 9 P.M. this evening after agreeing to reconvene on Monday morning. "Things are proceeding well, people just need some rest," Jon F. Harmon, a Ford spokesman, said.
The U.A.W. scheduled a board meeting for Tuesday in the hope that a deal would be completed by then, said a person close to the union who insisted on anonymity.
People with a detailed knowledge of the talks said several important issues were unresolved, including wage increases, the length of the contract and limits on Ford's purchase of parts from low-cost suppliers few of whose workers are unionized.
With negotiations continuing nearly around the clock, exhausted bargainers curled up to sleep on chairs and in hallways through several floors of Ford's headquarters this afternoon. When Stephen P. Yokich, the union president, went outside at 12:30 A.M. on Sunday for fresh air, he carried a plastic bottle nearly full of the unofficial beverage of the talks: Water Joe, which is artesian well water with a wallop of caffeine added.
The union's three-year contracts with the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation also expired at midnight on Saturday, but agreements were reached with both companies on Friday for workers to stay on the job while negotiations continue. Those agreements could be canceled by either side on three days' notice, G.M. and Chrysler officials said. Ford is the nation's second-largest company in sales after G.M.
The union's goal is to persuade G.M. and Chrysler to accept contracts somewhat similar to the new pact with Ford. But while Chrysler is widely expected to do so, G.M. has taken a hard line in negotiations. The world's largest auto maker has higher labor costs than Ford or Chrysler and wants nonunion outside companies to supply a much larger proportion of parts for new cars and trucks.
People close to the union said a strike was possible at G.M. in the autumn, though the union might settle instead for a vaguely worded national contract. The union would then try to work out the details through separate negotiations at more than 100 G.M. factories in the United States. That would leave the union in a position to stage local strikes that could disrupt G.M.'s introduction of new models this autumn.
The Canadian Auto Workers union is negotiating separately with Chrysler. Basil E. Hargrove, the Canadian union's president, said today that Chrysler's latest offers were unacceptable and that his union would was quite likely to go on strike at midnight on Tuesday with no postponements possible. A Chrysler strike in Canada could be serious, halving the company's minivan production and slowing the manufacture of some parts, but the Canadian union has traditionally settled strikes soon after they begin.
Ford and the U.A.W. are using elaborate computer models in the United States this year that allow its negotiators to figure almost instantly the cost of each proposal. The company's current average hourly cost of labor is $40.45, of which $21.79 represents wages, including overtime, while the remaining $18.66 covers health care costs, insurance and payroll taxes like worker's compensation and the employer-paid part of Social Security.
Ford and the union have been arguing over how much the overall hourly labor cost should rise. They have also been arguing over whether this increase should be mostly for wages or for benefits.
Whether the next contract lasts three years, four years or even longer, the union is seeking a 2 percent wage increase every year, in addition to the automatic cost-of-living adjustments workers have received since 1948, people close to the negotiations said. Ford prefers to maintain annual cost-of-living adjustments while giving a 3 percent wage increase in the first year followed by 3 percent bonuses in each successive year -- the same deal that the auto makers won in 1990 and 1993 for three-year contracts.
Bonuses are cheaper than wage increases for the auto makers because they do not permanently raise their labor costs.
Ford and the U.A.W. are also discussing the union's paramount concern this year, protecting the job security of current and future union members. Ford has expressed a willingness to guarantee that it will maintain its employment of union members at close to current levels of 105,000 workers, hiring new workers to replace retirees, people close to the talks said.
But the two sides have been negotiating escape clauses from such a guarantee, including what Ford would do if a serious recession forced it to close many factories. And the U.A.W. still wants a deal that might be accepted by G.M.
G.M. is determined to reduce its work force and expressed a willingness last Tuesday to guarantee current workers' jobs but not to replace them as they retire. G.M. has higher labor costs than Ford or Chrysler, partly because it manufactures a higher proportion of its parts.
All three auto makers two weeks ago discussed a proposal to pay permanently lower wages at any new parts factories they may build or buy. But the U.A.W. has shown little enthusiasm for the idea, and it is not receiving much attention in this weekend's negotiations, people close to the talks said.
The union has also been seeking the right to strike over outside parts purchases even while under contract.

HEADLINE: New Republic And Cuban Agree to Settle Libel Lawsuit

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN

 BODY:
The leader of the most powerful anti-Castro Cuban exile group in the United States announced yesterday that he had agreed to settle a libel suit against The New Republic for an article in the political weekly magazine that called him a mobster.
 The magazine agreed to contribute $100,000 to the Cuban American National Foundation, or C.A.N.F., for a scholarship and to apologize for an article in the issue of Oct. 3, 1994, about the foundation's chairman, Jorge Mas Canosa. The article was headlined ''Clinton's Miami Mobster.'' 
 The foundation and the magazine said in a joint statement, ''The New Republic regrets its use of the word 'mobster' on the cover of the magazine and in a headline above the article (both of which were the sole responsibility of the New Republic and not the author) and apologizes for any injury or embarrassment that may have been caused to Mr. Mas Canosa or his family.'' 
 Mr. Mas Canosa said at a news conference in Miami, ''I accept with much happiness this $100,000 on behalf of the C.A.N.F.,'' The Associated Press reported. ''I believe this represents a victory for the cause of Cuban freedom and for our community.''
 It was the second legal victory of sorts for Mr. Mas Canosa; in August, Wayne Smith, a former American diplomat in Havana who is now a university professor and a specialist in Cuban affairs, was found to have defamed Mr. Mas Canosa's foundation in a 1992 PBS documentary.
 A copy of the correction to be run in the next issue of The New Republic was attached to the joint statement. It read: ''The New Republic did not intend to accuse Mr. Mas Canosa of being in any way connected to, or engaged in, criminal activity of any kind, nor was its use of the word based on any evidence of criminal activity on Mr. Mas Canosa's part.''
 Floyd Abrams, a lawyer who is an expert on the First Amendment, said on the face of it, the settlement seemed appropriate. ''I'm all in favor of magazines apologizing when they're wrong,'' Mr. Abrams said. ''I think we have too little of that, not too much of it. There is nothing intrinsically troubling about it. If they called him that and they had no basis, then an apology is justified.''
 With the $100,000, the Cuban American foundation said it planned to establish ''The New Republic Scholarship,'' for the education of needy Cuban-American students. 
 As part of the settlement, Mr. Mas Canosa agreed to dismiss his suit against the New Republic and the article's author, Ann Louise Bardach, a freelance writer. The libel suit was dismissed with prejudice, meaning that it can not be refiled. 
 ''The New Republic and Mr. Mas Canosa are pleased to have resolved their dispute,'' the statement said, ''because, although they may have differences, they both have strongly expressed support for policies aimed at bringing an end to the Communist dictatorship of Fidel Castro and bringing democracy to Cuba.''
 Mr. Mas Canosa's exile group lobbied successfully this year for passage of the Helms-Burton Act extending the American economic embargo against Cuba, and the organization is widely regarded as a principal architect of American policy toward Cuba.

HEADLINE: Strike in Philadelphia: What Stopped the Music

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN 

 BODY:
The central issues in the strike called by the Philadelphia Orchestra on Sunday are those at the heart of virtually all labor negotiations these days: wages, health benefits and pensions. But the flash point was the orchestra's loss of its recording contract with EMI Records last month, followed by management's wish to reduce a guarantee of recording payments that was in the musicians' most recent contract.
With sales in the classical record business flat, particularly in the standard orchestral repertory, other top American orchestras may soon face the Philadelphia's situation. The Cleveland Orchestra, which is also in negotiations, was recently informed by its label, Decca-London, that its recording program would be trimmed. Other label-orchestra relationships seem sound, but executives at major record companies say they have no choice but to pare their projects. 
 The most immediate effect of the strike is the cancellation of the first week of concerts, including the orchestra's season opener tonight and the opening of its regular series at Carnegie Hall next Tuesday. The orchestra's music director, Wolfgang Sawallisch, has kept out of the dispute, as conductors often do. In a brief statement, he said only that he was "very eager to begin making music with our wonderful musicians" and urging both sides to "come to a mutually satisfying agreement so that our concerts can be performed as scheduled." The strike is the orchestra's first since a 58-day walkout in 1966.
With a vote of 100 to 0, the musicians made it clear that they did not consider the contract offered by the Philadelphia Orchestra Association on Friday to be remotely acceptable. The offer includes a proposed wage increase that would give the players a minimum salary of $83,200 in 1999, up from $75,400 this year. The salary is competitive with those of the Chicago Symphony and the New York Philharmonic, the two American orchestras that earn more than Philadelphia, but the players say that givebacks, including the loss of the recording bonus, could mean a net loss for members over the three-year contract.
The musicians blame management for letting the EMI contract slip away and for the lack of interest from other labels.
EMI's decision not to continue recording in Philadelphia has become a symbol of the disarray in the record business. Over the last 20 years, EMI had recorded the orchestra with three music directors -- Eugene Ormandy, Riccardo Muti and Mr. Sawallisch -- as well as several guest conductors. The last time a major American orchestra was dropped by an international label was during a similar slump in the early 1980's, when CBS Masterworks (now Sony Classical) dropped the New York Philharmonic. Although the Philharmonic made recordings for several labels during the 1980's, it did not have a consistent recording relationship until 1991, when Teldec began recording the orchestra with Kurt Masur conducting.
Like virtually all the major labels, EMI is grappling with two interlocking problems. One is that new orchestral recordings are not competing well with less expensive compact disk versions of classic performances from the past, often by the same orchestras and on the same labels. The second, a point about which record companies have complained loudly for two decades, is that musicians' fees have made American orchestras 40 to 50 percent more expensive to record than their European counterparts.
The Philadelphia's loss of EMI and its inability to find a sponsor for its radio broadcasts in recent seasons have led the management to reconsider a provision in the three-year contract that just expired. Called an electronic media guarantee, it promised players a minimum payment, $6,000 this year, for making recordings and radio and television appearances. Until now, this guarantee has cost the management nothing, since EMI's payments covered it. Now management is asking that the guarantee be cut to $2,000 the first year of the contract and negotiated again during the second and third years.
"None of the other 'big five' orchestras have a media guarantee," said Joseph H. Kluger, the orchestra's president, speaking of the orchestras of New York, Chicago, Boston and Cleveland. "They all compensate the musicians for recordings and other activity if it takes place. If the musicians record, they get paid. If not, they don't. This kind of activity is very volatile: it goes up and down based on factors that are out of the control of the orchestras. It is the recording companies who decide whether recordings are made, and how many."
But the musicians fault management for the loss of the the EMI contract, saying that their strike vote is also a no-confidence vote in the administration. They cited other recent problems, including the loss of longtime support from the Pew Charitable Trusts and what they consider management's greater willingness to invest in building a new concert hall than in sustaining the orchestra itself.
"We're not talking mainly about money," said Larry Grika, the chairman of the musicians' negotiating committee. "We're disturbed about management not going after recording contracts. We're known around the world by our recordings, and if we stop making them, that will have a tremendously negative effect on our worldwide tours. When management let our radio broadcasts slide, our national touring dried up. We feel that if they don't have anyone now in management or on the board who can sell us, they should hire someone who has that talent."
Mr. Kluger rejects that analysis. "The big labels -- and we've talked to all of them -- have concluded that the market is saturated at the moment," he said, "and that given the economics of making records, they can't make any money doing it."
Mr. Kluger's alternative is a plan in which the orchestra would make and market its own recordings. Under that arrangement, the players would receive advance payments lower than current union scale, but in return would be paid royalties for the first time. Currently, royalties earned on back catalogue, estimated by the players at about $1.8 million a year, are paid not to the musicians but into the orchestra's endowment and operating budget.
Management sees the plan as a partnership in which both the association and the musicians share the risks as well as the rewards. The players say they are interested.
"But obviously," said Stuart Davidson, the musicians' lawyer and chief negotiator, "there are a million and one technical and logistical questions to be answered about that kind of a plan."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Prices Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in thin trading yesterday, as the day's statistics, -- July business inventories -- had little impact on the market, where traders are looking ahead to the Fed's monetary policy meeting next week.
Traders reported some consolidation and some mild profit taking after subdued retail sales and consumer inflation data sent prices of Treasury securities surging on Friday. 
 The 30-year bond rose 3/32, to a price of 97 20/33 to yield 6.94, down from 6.95 percent on Friday.
According to the Commerce Department, the gain in July retail inventories was the biggest in one and a half years, increasing stocks of unsold goods on the shelves of wholesalers and manaufacturers. Total inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent in July to a seasonally adjusted $1 trillion after being revised to show no change in June, down from the one-tenth of 1 percent gain initially reported. Analysts said the July gain was twice what economists had expectated.
Given the lack of major indicators this week, the market is likely to focus on and be vulnerable to rumors and any comments by Fed officials that might shed some light on central bank policy, with next week's Federal Open Market Committee meeting looming. "Any hints of that the Fed is more inclined to tighten at the Sept. 24 meeting will lead traders to reconsider their bold move on Friday," said Damon Whelchel, a market analyst with MMS International.
"Like the weather," said Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors, "the market's view on what the Fed is likely to do on Sept. 24 has fluctuated quite wildly over the past couple of days."
August housing start numbers are likely to be the most important economic releases this week as investors will be watching to see whether some of the nation's most interest-sensitive sectors continues to show signs of a slowdown. "It will be difficult to continue selling the economic slowdown story without at least some signals of a pause or slowdown in the interest-sentive sectors," Mr. Chan noted. He said the consensus was for a gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent, his is for a 1.0 percent drop compared with a 1.3 percent fall.
There are a number of speeches taking place this week by Fed officials that could cause the market to react as negatively as it did early last week, including today's talk by the Fed's vice chairwoman, Alice Rivlin, in New York at an Institute of International Bankers meeting. Elsewhere a Fed governor, Susan M. Phillips, is in Washington to testify on the impact on the banking system of the Sumitomo copper trading activities. The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, is speaking at a Conference of Electronic Money on Thursday.
The supply of new Treasury issues this week is thin, with only today's regular weekly bill auction. However, the Treasury will announce tomorrow the size of next week's two- and five-year note auctions. Though the issuance is light this week, corporate and asset-backed activity is expected to remain brisk as issuers try to take advantage of low rates.environment.
Daimler-Benz A.G. plans a United States sale of $500 million in 10-year notes this week, as Ford Motor gears up to sell $1 billion in five-year global bonds.
Yesterday's bill auction saw investor demand perk up after a few weeks of lukewarm interest by investors because of fears that the Fed would raise short-term rates as much as 50 basis points. The average rate for a three-month bill dropped 10 basis points, to 5.07 percent, and the rate for the six-month bills fell 11 basis points, to 5.19 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falters as Doubts Grow Concerning Rate Rise by Fed

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday against other leading currencies as doubts grew about the prospect for a Federal Reserve interest-rate increase next week.
Reports last week on retail sales and consumer prices persuaded many traders that the Fed would refrain from raising rates when officials meet to debate interest-rate policy next Tuesday. 
 "The economic statistics of last week have led people to moderate their expectations of whether or how far the Fed will go in raising interest rates," Dennis Pettit, foreign-exchange manager at Long Term Credit Bank of Japan, said. "That has taken the shine off the dollar a little."
Higher interest rates often help the American currency by making dollar-denominated deposits more attractive to foreign investors.
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 1.5100 German marks, from 1.5134 late on Friday. The dollar slipped to 110.10 Japanese yen, from 110.35 on Friday. The British pound rose to $1.5580 from $1.5535.
 Comments by the chairman of the Ford Motor Company, Alexander Trotman, also undercut the dollar yesterday when he said that its recent rise to more than 110 yen was cause for concern for American auto makers.
"At 110 yen for the dollar, we certainly are getting concerned about the comparative costs between the Japanese-built vehicles and American-built vehicles," Mr. Trotman said at a news conference in Detroit.
The dollar has risen 2 percent against the yen and 1 percent against the mark in the last month, bolstered in part by predictions that the Fed would raise rates soon to cool economic growth and quell inflation.
Those expectations were tempered after the Government reported on Friday that retail sales rose only two-tenths of 1 percent and consumer prices just one-tenth of 1 percent in August.
Even so, many traders think the dollar will resume its ascent. "We've got a fairly healthy economy in the U.S. with low inflation," while the economies of Germany and Japan are struggling, said Stephen Flanagan, currency trader at Credit Agricole. "That's a good recipe for a strong dollar."
Moreover, even without a Fed rate increase, American rates are still higher than rates in Germany and Japan.

HEADLINE: Tough New Warning on Diet Is Issued by Cancer Society

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS 

 BODY:
Just as martinis and steaks seem to be making a comeback, the American Cancer Society, in guidelines released yesterday, warned that eating red meat and drinking even small amounts of alcohol could contribute to certain cancers.
The new warning, along with dietary recommendations, is more specific and tougher than those suggested by the cancer society in 1991 and those published by the Federal Government last January. 
 Cancer, which is expected to be the leading cause of death in the United States by the turn of the century, in part because the incidence of heart disease is declining, is now responsible for 500,000 deaths a year. Of those, one-third can be attributed to smoking and one-third to dietary factors, the society said. The others are caused by various factors, including genetics and occupations.
The society made four main recommendations yesterday, which at first glance appear to be quite similar to current dietary advice of the Government: consumption of a diet high in fruits, vegetables and whole grains; a diet low in high-fat foods, particularly those from animal sources; maintenance of a healthy weight and moderate physical activity for 30 minutes or more on most days, and limited or no alcohol.
The scientific basis for those recommendations, the guidelines say, "is very strong for cancer at many sites," particularly gastrointestinal and respiratory tracts.
In the details, however, the guidelines are very different from those provided by the Government, and some health experts attribute that difference to the pressures that are brought on the Government by groups that could be hurt financially. Dr. Marion Nestle, chairman of the advisory committee that developed the guidelines for the society, and chairman of the department of nutrition and food studies at New York University, said the advice came from a group that had no other agenda than "helping people prevent, treat and cure cancer."
Dr. Meir Stampfer, a professor of epidemiology and nutrition at the Harvard School of Public Health, said the cancer society, unlike the Federal Government, "is in a position to make guidelines based more strictly on science." The Government, said Dr. Stampfer, who was not a member of the panel, "is subject to economic pressure as well as scientific pressure."
There are two main areas of difference between the Government and the cancer society. The Government recommends eating lean meat and limiting consumption of high fat processed meats like sausage and salami. The society recommends curtailing all red meat, not just high-fat meat. It links consumption of red meats to colon and prostate cancer. Meat is generally high in fat and high-fat diets have also been associated with an increased risk of rectal and endometrial cancer.
Obesity is also a cancer culprit. The society criticized high-calorie fat-free processed foods for contributing to overweight and said obesity had been associated with colon, rectal, prostate, endometrial and kidney cancers, and among post-menopausal women, breast cancer. As an alternative to red meats, the society recommended beans, seafood and poultry, saying, "Use meat as a side dish rather than as the focus of a meal."
On alcohol, the cancer society acknowledged that studies showed a decreased risk of coronary heart disease among middle-aged adults with moderate intake of alcohol, and it suggested that for men over 50 and women over 60 the "cardiovascular benefits may outweigh the risk of cancer."
Otherwise it disagreed with the Federal dietary guidelines that say "one or two drinks daily appear to cause no harm to adults." The society noted that the "cancer risk increases with the amount of alcohol consumed and may start to rise with intake of as few as two drinks a day," or 24 ounces of beer, 10 ounces of wine and 3 ounces of 80-proof distilled spirits.
The society said that studies also noted an association between increased risk of breast cancer and the consumption of "just a few drinks per week" and suggested that women who are at an unusually high risk for breast cancer "might reasonably consider abstaining from alcohol."
Representatives of both the meat and wine businesses took exception to the advice.
"It is inappropriate to indict meat," said Dr. Janet William, the vice president of scientific and technical affairs for the American Meat Institute, a trade group. "The document is not consistent with U.S. Dietary Guidelines."
Citing several studies, John De Luca, president of the Wine Institute, an industry trade association, said that wine should not be lumped together with other alcoholic beverages. Mr. De Luca said that studies had indicated that moderate consumption of wine might reduce the risk for breast cancer.
But Dr. Stampfer said that the alcohol guidelines were reasonable for a group focused on cancer.
"We know lots of way of reducing the risk of heart disease without alcohol," he said. "For subgroups at high risk for breast cancer, why drink?"
Dr. Rachel Ballard Barbash, chief of the applied research branch at the National Cancer Institute, said, "This committee is in a very different position from a Federal committee" in that it deals only with cancer.
The guidelines emphasize, at every opportunity, that there is little or no evidence that supplements like beta-carotene, vitamins A, C and E, calcium, fish oils or garlic reduce the risk of cancer in humans.
The guidelines also answer frequently asked questions: There is no increased risk from artificial sweeteners, coffee, fluorides, irradiated foods, food additives or food substitutes, with two exceptions. Nitrites can be converted to carcinogenic nitrosamines in the stomach, which may increase the risk of gastric cancer. And olestra, the fat substitute produced by Procter & Gamble, was described by the society as worrisome because it reduces the absorption of fat-soluble substances that are potentially protective. But the overall effect on cancer risk is unknown.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Crude Oil Prices Drop Sharply On Talk of Extra Saudi Output

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The prices of crude oil futures and most other energy products fell sharply yesterday on a report that the Clinton Administration had asked Saudi Arabia to raise its output while Iraq remains barred from the world petroleum market.
Among other commodities, natural gas futures rose sharply, while grain and soybean futures prices fell. 
 Crude and oil products faced heavy selling pressure all day, reflecting talk in the market that the flow of oil from the Persian Gulf would not be affected by tensions between the United States and Iraq.
Prices weakened further late in the session on a report by Dow Jones Telerate that the United States had asked Saudi Arabia to raise crude oil production above the current ceiling of eight million barrels a day.
Saudi Arabian officials denied the report after trading had ended, as did a spokesman for the Energy Department in Washington.
"There's no substance behind that rumor," Bill Wicker, the spokesman, told Bloomberg Business News.
But investors speculated that President Clinton, during an election year, was trying to keep energy prices relatively low.
"The market is nervous enough about Iraq right now to react to any rumor that could be legitimate," said Tim Evans, an analyst at Pegasus Econometric Group.
Crude oil for October delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange fell $1.32, to $23.19 a barrel; October heating oil fell 2.65 cents, to 65.29 cents a gallon, and October unleaded gasoline fell 1.73 cents, to 62.87 a gallon.
But natural gas rose sharply as stocks remained 20 percent below the levels of a year earlier. October natural gas rose 10.9 cents, to $19.73 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Grain and soybean futures prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade as forecasts called for moderate temperatures through the end of the month, aiding the harvest.
December wheat fell 7 cents, to $4.17 a bushel; December corn fell 7 cents, to $3.145 a bushel, and November soybeans fell 9 cents, to $7.93 a bushel.

AL GORE
 
At Micro Craft Inc., contrasting the Republicans' idea of supply-side economics to balance the budget with the Administration's approach:

And then let's pay for every penny of that tax cut as the President says, line by line, dime by dime. That's the better approach."

HEADLINE: Ohio Edison Plans to Buy Another Utility For $1.6 Billion

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
In the utility industry's latest merger deal, the Ohio Edison Company said yesterday that it would buy the Centerior Energy Corporation in a $1.61 billion stock swap to create the nation's 11th-largest investor-owned utility, serving 2.1 million customers in Ohio and western Pennsylvania.
Utilities are seeking to cut costs and widen their service areas in preparation for deregulation and increased competition. With each new merger, pressure has built on many utilities, particularly weak ones, to find partners to stay competitive. 
 In this case, Ohio Edison, a financially strong utility based in Akron, Ohio, is taking on a weaker one. Centerior Energy, based in Independence, Ohio, has high rates and has had to cut its dividend to help pay for its heavy investment in nuclear plants.
Penelope Adelmann, a utility analyst for Gruntal & Company, said that "Ohio Edison is doing the state of Ohio a favor by taking over Centerior."
"Centerior has some good people," she added, "but they have not been able to find their way out of their financial difficulties."
Wall Street agreed. Centerior shares rose $1.625 to $9.25 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange, in part because many investors had believed that Centerior would not be able to find a stronger utility to help it out of its troubles. Ohio Edison shares fell $1, to $19.75, in Big Board trading.
The two companies said they would form a holding company called the First Energy Corporation. They estimated that they would save about $1 billion during the next 10 years, in part by eliminating about 900 jobs. The two utilities employ a total of 11,000 workers.
Willard R. Holland, the president and chief executive of Ohio Edison, who will become chairman, president and chief executive of the new holding company, said that "by sharing our employees' skills and each company's best practices, the combination will also enable us to realize substantial economic synergies that will further enhance our cash flow and efforts to accelerate debt reduction."
Robert J. Farling, the chairman, president and chief executive of Centerior Energy, said, "Our alliance will provide customers and shareholders with more value and our employees with more opportunities than would be possible if we did not join forces." Mr. Farling will be vice chairman of the holding company.
Mr. Holland said that Ohio Edison would extend a rate freeze to 2005 for the two utilities owned by Centerior Energy, Toledo Edison and the Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company. In 2006 there would be a rate reduction of about 15 percent.
Robert S. Tongren, a spokesman for a group that represents residential power customers, said that the "proposed rate freeze through 2005 did not provide a benefit to Centerior customers who are paying rates that are already too high." He said that the group would support the merger only if there were immediate rate cuts for the residential customers of Centerior Energy.
Both utilities have nearby rivals. The American Electric Power Company, a huge utility in southern Ohio, has many coal-fired plants that produce cheap power.
As states begin to open their energy markets to allow outsiders to sell power to customers, such low-cost producers will be in a strong position to raid customers, particularly large industrial users.
Some large customers have been able to get big reductions of rates from utilities like Centerior and Ohio Edison. This has reduced revenue and made it difficult to bring down rates for smaller energy users.
The merger, which is expected to be completed by the end of 1997, is contingent on the approval of shareholders and Ohio and Federal regulators.
Ohio Edison shareholders would receive one share of First Energy common stock for each share of Ohio Edison common stock. Centerior energy stockholders would receive 0.525 share of First Energy common stock for each share of Centerior common stock.
The combined annual revenue of the two utilities will total about $5 billion and their assets will be worth about $20 billion. The companies said that the initial annual dividend of First Energy was expected to be $1.50 a share, the same rate that is now paid by Ohio Edison.
Centerior Energy serves more than one million customers mostly in northern Ohio. Ohio Edison and its subsidiary, the Pennsylvania Power Company, serve 1.1 million customers in northeastern and central Ohio and western Pennsylvania.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Has Kemp to Dinner. Is It Just a Flirtation?

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
A remarkable thing happened last night on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's front porch. Without raising an eyebrow of protest -- in fact, while actually grinning -- the Mayor allowed a national political candidate to make a partisan statement at his side.
"Kemp and Dole have come alive in New York City," said Jack F. Kemp, the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, boldly sloganeering only inches away from a Mayor who has become famously disdainful of partisanship. Mr. Giuliani even stood by beaming as the candidate accused the Clinton Administration of having abandoned America's inner cities, and he did not rush to even the balance by putting in a kind word for the President, as he often does. 
 Finally, outside his own home, the Mayor who has raised political coyness to an art form actually allowed his hand to become entwined with Mr. Kemp's and then lofted above their heads in what might appear -- with any other mayor, in any other town -- to be a gesture of victory, or at least political alliance. Then they went inside Gracie Mansion and shared a meal of lobster and pasta in saffron sauce.
So does that mean the circle dance around the Mayor's endorsement is over? Has the endless tease that bathed Mr. Giuliani in a glow of neutrality come to a close with a concession to his own party? Certainly not. Or at least, not yet. Aides to both men insisted there was absolutely nothing political involved -- just a couple of old friends kicking around some policy ideas.
"I know you're going to read something into this," said Cristyne F. Lategano, the Mayor's communications director, "but you shouldn't. It's a frank discussion of urban policies about crime and drugs and privatization. And also they're just catching up on what's been happening in each other's lives."
But for Mr. Giuliani, a stray Republican who spends most of his time outside the party fold, Mr. Kemp may represent the path of return. No meeting with a national candidate seven weeks before Election Day is entirely unpolitical, and the Mayor's decision to dine with Mr. Kemp follows weeks of signals that he is increasingly pleased with the direction of the Republican ticket.
True, the two men have known each other for years, and Mr. Kemp campaigned for the Mayor during the last election. It was Mr. Kemp who asked for last night's dinner, not the other way around. Wayne Berman, the political director for the Kemp campaign, said that while the campaign would love to receive the Mayor's endorsement, the dinner was nothing more than a "door-opening move."
But part of the friendship between the two men is based on a shared belief in the value of tax cuts to stimulate the economy, on an interest in the fate of cities not always shared by other Republicans, and on a rejection of the party's more extreme anti-immigration wing.
Repeatedly over the last few weeks, Mr. Giuliani has praised Bob Dole's selection of Mr. Kemp as his running mate, and has gone out of his way to compliment the Republicans on the moderate shine reflected from their San Diego convention.
"I thought the Republican convention was inclusive," the Mayor said earlier this month. "And I thought particularly, if you look at the speeches that were made in comparison with four years ago, there was a tremendous difference. I'm also encouraged by the fact that Colin Powell not only made a speech at the convention, and I thought an excellent one, but also is campaigning with Senator Dole, which I think shows real historic movement in the Republican Party."
For Democratic operatives, last night's huddle -- which included William Bennett, vice chairman of Mr. Dole's campaign, and Peter J. Powers, Mr. Giuliani's closest adviser -- was a strong indication that the Mayor is moving toward an endorsement of the Republican ticket. Many of them, in fact, are openly hoping Mr. Giuliani will make such a move. Given President Clinton's popularity in New York -- and the fact that the Mayor's endorsement has almost never been much help to candidates in the past -- they feel Mr. Clinton can do without it. And they would rather not see the Mayor gain any benefit among city Democrats, as he did with his renegade cross-endorsement of Mario M. Cuomo, the ultimate Democrat, for governor in 1994.
"It is clear the Mayor, by bringing Kemp to Gracie Mansion, is at least flirting with his own Republican roots," said Henry A. Sheinkopf, a Democratic media consultant. "He knows his party will kill him if he doesn't endorse Dole, and Kemp is his excuse for going there."
But Republican regulars, knowing better than to predict Mr. Giuliani's erratic political course, are counting on nothing.
"They're just old friends," said Thomas V. Ognibene, the Republican minority leader of the City Council, speaking of the dinner partners. "I'd love to see him endorse Bob Dole, but frankly, I have no idea what he's going to do."

HEADLINE: New York's Welfare Challenge

 BODY:
With more than two million New Yorkers receiving public assistance, Gov. George Pataki and the Legislature in Albany face one of the toughest challenges ever to confront the state's government. Now that the bitter battle over welfare reform has been settled by President Clinton's signature, critics and advocates of change must work together to fashion a new system that softens the law's harshest blows to the poor without bankrupting the state. They have only about six months to transform welfare as we know it into something other than a nightmare for recipients and government officials alike.
The welfare overhaul enacted in Washington ends the 61-year-old guarantee of assistance for eligible mothers and children, replacing it with a block grant that the states may use to devise programs of their own. The law also imposes stringent new work requirements on most welfare recipients and cuts back sharply on food stamps and aid to legal immigrants. A bipartisan task force created by Mr. Pataki and headed by his budget director, Patricia Woodworth, has only begun assessing its immediate impact. 
 A few guiding principles would help the task force in its difficult assignment. The first would be to resist the temptation to cut welfare benefit levels, as Mr. Pataki has advocated in the past. The argument has always been that New York's generous benefits draw welfare recipients from other states, an argument that will be intensified if other states start cutting benefits. But the grant level of $577 for a family of three is well below the poverty line and should be kept intact.
The second guiding principle is that Mr. Pataki should begin preparing New Yorkers for the likelihood that welfare "reforms" will probably cost money, at least in the short run. First, the state has to make a considerable investment in computerizing all its records. Right now it does not even know how long welfare recipients actually stay on the rolls over their lifetimes. Before welfare reforms are instituted next July 1, Albany has to have a system enabling the state to know which families are in danger of being cut off and when.
New York State faces a budget deficit in the next year estimated at $3 billion. The new law does not require states to spend money to help people find jobs, but Mr. Pataki must join with respected community organizations to find ways of insuring that day care, job training, supervision, transportation and other forms of assistance will be available to those who need it.
Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's experience in New York City is instructive. His administration has achieved considerable success with workfare programs, which will now be required for 25 percent of all beneficiaries in the first year. The Mayor's office estimates that the city will have to spend as much as $100 million more to meet the new law's targets.
New York City and the state may get one benefit from the new law. The state's welfare caseload has gone down in the last few years, in part because the economic boom has lured welfare recipients into the work force and in part because of a crackdown on fraud and abuse. But the block grant provided to the state is to be based on caseload levels going back to 1992, meaning that there may be some extra money to channel into programs that put people to work.
A final guiding principle is to do something about the legal immigrants who are aged, blind or disabled and who are to be thrown off welfare under the new law. Punishing legal immigrants never had anything to do with the work incentives and requirements that most people associate with improving welfare. Yet City Hall estimates that it could cost $100 million to hold them harmless under the new law. All the elected leaders of the city and state should be at the forefront of reversing that particular injustice in the new law and, if necessary, studying the feasibility of using local resources to help those people certain to suffer under it.

HEADLINE: The Best Pennant Race Money Can Buy

 BODY:
The New York Yankees have tumbled since mid-July, depressing their fans and delighting their enemies. The happy result is a delectable three-game September showdown with the Baltimore Orioles this week at Yankee Stadium. While the Yankees were slumping, the Orioles were winning. As the weeks passed the Yankee lead over the Orioles in the American League Eastern Division dwindled from a July high of 12 games to just 3 as of this morning.
As fans savor tonight's pitching matchup between David Cone of the Yankees and Mike Mussina of the Orioles, they will be watching the best pennant race money can buy. George Steinbrenner and Peter Angelos, the owners of the Yankees and Orioles respectively, can claim not only two of baseball's best lineups, but the two biggest payrolls in the big leagues. Mr. Steinbrenner is dishing out $59 million this year, Mr. Angelos $55 million.
It is pointless to wish for a return to a simpler time. For one thing, such nostalgia conveniently overlooks the fact that with a few exceptions like Babe Ruth, the great players of earlier eras were grossly underpaid by miserly owners who ran professional baseball like a plantation. Many of today's owners wish they still could. The charming verities of baseball, from its arcane rules to its sunny heroes, were never the whole story about a game that has long been a big business. 
 Still, there is a prefabricated feeling to baseball these days that makes it harder for fans to develop team loyalty. Teams like the Yankees and Orioles seem to be shuffled so often by their owners that they are barely recognizable from one season to the next. Players are the beneficiaries, which is fair enough in a market economy, but owners like Mr. Steinbrenner and Mr. Angelos play the market so fast they neglect the importance of identity and continuity, which help tie a team to a community.
There was something reassuringly predictable about the championship Yankee roster of 35 years ago. Fans who followed the team then can still tick off many of the names from memory: Mickey Mantle, Roger Maris, Yogi Berra, Elston Howard, Bobby Richardson, Tony Kubek, Clete Boyer, John Blanchard, Bill Skowron and Whitey Ford.
These days the only Yankee sure to be back in future seasons is George Steinbrenner.

HEADLINE: McGeorge Bundy Dies at 77; Top Adviser in Vietnam Era

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER 

 BODY:
McGeorge Bundy, an influential foreign policy adviser to Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson who was a forceful advocate of expanding American involvement in the Vietnam War, died yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 77 and lived in Manchester-by-the-Sea, north of Boston.
The cause of death was a heart attack, said a spokesman for Harvard University, where Mr. Bundy served as dean of the faculty of arts and sciences before joining the Kennedy Administration in 1961 as national security adviser. 
 A descendant of the Boston Lowells on his mother's side, a product of Groton, Yale and Skull and Bones, and a Harvard dean in his early 30's, Mr. Bundy was the very personification of what the journalist David Halberstam, in the title of his 1969 book, labeled "The Best and the Brightest": the well-born, confident intellectuals who led the nation into the quagmire of Vietnam.
After leaving Government in 1965, Mr. Bundy became president of the Ford Foundation, serving until 1979. He was then a professor of history at New York University for 10 years. In 1990, he joined the Carnegie Corporation of New York. He was chairman of its committee on reducing the danger of nuclear war and was its scholar-in-residence at the time of his death.
"He was a man of notable brilliance, integrity and patriotic purpose," said the historian Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., who served in the Kennedy White House with Mr. Bundy and counted him among his oldest friends.
As national security adviser to two Presidents, Mr. Bundy played a role in the Cuban missile crisis and other major foreign policy decisions, but he is most remembered for his role in enlarging United States involvement in Vietnam. In 1965 he predicted that if South Vietnam, the American ally, fell, "there would be a great weakening in the free societies in their ability to withstand Communism."
A visit to Vietnam that year, in which he saw the bloody results of combat at Pleiku, only strengthened his view, resulting in a pivotal memorandum calling for a policy of "sustained reprisal," including air strikes.
In Washington, as throughout his life, he was noted for his brisk intellect and self-assurance. Journalists at the time overworked adjectives like "brilliant" and "aggressive."
Louis Auchincloss, the lawyer and author whose novels chronicled the upper classes, recalled of his Groton schoolmate that "he was ready to be dean of the faculty at Harvard when he was 12 years old."1
 
From a Family Of Prominence
McGeorge Bundy was born in Boston on March 30, 1919, the youngest of five children of Harvey Hollister and Katherine Lawrence Putnam Bundy. His prominent family had a long tradition of public service.
His father was a noted lawyer who had once been secretary to Oliver Wendell Holmes, was Assistant Secretary of State from 1931 to 1933 and was a special assistant to the Secretary of War from 1941 to 1945.
His mother was a Lowell, the descendant of John Amory Lowell, one of Boston's most powerful men of the 19th century, credited with picking at least six presidents of Harvard. Mr. Bundy's maternal grandfather, A. Lawrence Lowell, served as president of Harvard from 1909 to 1933.
Mr. Bundy was educated, along with the young John Kennedy, at the private Dexter elementary school in Brookline, Mass. At Groton, he played the lead role in a production of "Henry V."
At Yale, he was first in his class, Phi Beta Kappa, and a member of the secret society known as Skull and Bones, despite a controversial editorial he wrote for The Yale Daily News calling for the abolition of the football team.
His undergraduate degree was in mathematics, but on graduation he was named a junior fellow in Harvard's Society of Fellows -- envisioned as scholars so pure they do not acquire advanced degrees -- and he switched his field to international relations.
But war was breaking out in Europe, and the extremely nearsighted Mr. Bundy memorized the eye test chart in order to join the Army. He rose from private to captain, serving on the staff of the planners of the invasions of Sicily and France.
After the war, he was an assistant to Henry L. Stimson, who had served as Secretary of War under President Franklin D. Roosevelt from 1940 to 1945, collaborating with Mr. Stimson on his autobiography, "On Active Service in Peace and War," published in 1948.
A registered Republican, Mr. Bundy was recruited to advise Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, who ran unsuccessfully against President Harry S. Truman in 1948. He rejoined the Harvard faculty as a lecturer in government in 1949 and quickly began rising through the academic ranks.
He was named dean of the faculty of arts and sciences on Sept. 1, 1953. He was known as an anti-bureaucratic innovator, favored by students and faculty members, a man who made academic reforms and encouraged students to do independent study outside traditional academic formats.
And with the help of his colleagues, Professor Schlesinger and the economist John Kenneth Galbraith, became close to another Harvard man, John Fitzgerald Kennedy, the ambitious Senator from Massachusetts.
 
To Washington, And Into a War
When Mr. Kennedy took office in January 1961, there was a widespread, hopeful sense of a new generation come to power, a new beginning for the country. But within a few years, the country would be deeply, bitterly divided over Vietnam.
When Mr. Bundy arrived in Washington that year, Mr. Halberstam would write later, he was "perhaps the brightest star in the galaxy of brilliant young men who were going to change the course of the country, his reputation was above all else for his intellectual brilliance."
Mr. Bundy survived the transition to President Johnson after Kennedy's assassination, becoming, from his custom-paneled White House basement office, one of the central players in the evolving Vietnam debate, in large part because of his mastery of memo writing.
In 1965, Max Frankel described him in The New York Times Magazine this way:
"He is a man of sharp -- often acid -- brilliance, lean and trim of body and mind and almost collegiate at 46, agile, combative and confident, on the tennis court and in intellectual volley. He eats, drinks, dances, plays and, above all, speaks briskly; some say tartly."
As with many in Washington in those cold war years, he focused on military strength, writing once in a book on Dean Acheson, perhaps the quintessential cold warrior: "Very near the heart of all foreign affairs is the relationship between policy and military power."
In an analysis of the Kennedy years in the magazine Foreign Affairs, he wrote, "Nothing is more dangerous to the peace than weakness in the ultimate deterrent strength of the United States."
The article continued, "As important as having strength is knowing how to use it."
The concern seemed to become personal with his visit to Pleiku, which resulted in his writing a policy memorandum that is one of the pivotal documents of the American escalation recorded in the Government's secret history of the war, which became known as the Pentagon Papers when published by The New York Times in 1971.
"We believe that the best available way of increasing our chance of success in Vietnam is the development and execution of a policy of sustained reprisal against North Vietnam -- a policy in which air and naval action against the North is justified by and related to the whole Vietcong campaign against violence and terror in the South," the memorandum, dated Feb. 7, 1965, said.
"We cannot assert that the policy of sustained reprisal will succeed in changing the course of the contest in Vietnam," it went on to say. "It may fail and we cannot estimate the odds of success with any accuracy -- they may be between 25 percent and 75 percent. What we can say is that even if it fails, the policy will be worth it. At a minimum it will damp down the charge that we did not do all that we could have done, and this charge will be important in many countries, including our own. Beyond that, a reprisal policy -- to the extent that it demonstrates U.S. willingness to employ this new norm in counter-insurgency -- will set a higher price for the future upon all adventures of guerrilla warfare, and it should therefore somewhat increase our ability to deter such adventures."
 
After Government, The Ford Foundation
Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara, in his recent book "In Retrospect" (Times Books, 1995), recalls Mr. Bundy recommending "graduated and sustained bombing" and even at one point suggesting that the United States might gain ground in negotiations by threatening to use nuclear weapons.
But, finally, Mr. Bundy left the Administration, and Mr. McNamara writes: "I speculate the true reason was his deep frustration with the war. I believe he was frustrated not only with the President's behavior but also with the decision-making process throughout the top echelons in both Washington and Saigon."
After he resigned from the Government in December 1965, largely because he could no longer accommodate himself to President Johnson's style of dealing with his advisers, Mr. Bundy became president of the Ford Foundation.
He pushed the foundation into a new emphasis on race relations, and became embroiled in New York City's battle over decentralization of city schools, which was opposed by the powerful union the United Federation of Teachers. But by 1974, Ford had to cut back many of its programs because of financial difficulties.
Susan B. Beresford, the president of the Ford Foundation, said that Mr. Bundy provided leadership "in such crucial areas as civil rights, overseas development, family planning, security and arms control, and education."
Mr. Bundy, recalling his Government service years afterward in "Danger and Survival: Choices About the Bomb in the First 50 Years" (Random House, 1988), did not dwell extensively on Vietnam.
"The war was polarizing to American opinion in ways that were certainly not foreseen by Lyndon Johnson and those like me who supported him in the basic decision he made in 1965," Mr. Bundy wrote. "If Johnson could have carried the country with him, I believe he would have made the Vietnam War larger in the hope of making it shorter."
The New York Times described the book, which was a finalist for a National Book Award, as "a detailed, rigorously documented history and analysis of the political decisions in many countries that shaped the nuclear era."
Mr. Bundy is survived by his wife, Mary Buckminster Lothrop, whom he married in 1950; four sons, Stephen McGeorge, of Berkeley, Calif., Andrew, of Watertown, Mass., William, of Northampton, Mass., and James, of New York City, and six grandchildren. He is also survived by two brothers, Harvey, of Manchester, Mass., and William, of Princeton, N.J., and two sisters, Harriet B. Belin of Cambridge, Mass., and Katherine L. Auchincloss of Ho-Ho-Kus, N.J.

HEADLINE: NYC;
Patron Saint Of Street Fairs Marches In

BYLINE: By Clyde Haberman 

 BODY:
NO denying, there was a familiar hubbub on Mulberry Street as the feast honoring San Gennaro, patron saint of Naples, enjoyed what the Mayor assures us was its first mob-free weekend in a long time. But con tutto rispetto, as they would say in Naples, with all respect, the annual street fair had that look of faded grandeur Neapolitans know all too well.
Let's not even get into the quality of the air, a greasy gauze from all the burned sausage, enough grease to put a few thousand cardiologists' kids through college. Actually, that was the good news at the fair. At least it was a reaffirmation of street life. 
 Talk to the vendors, and what you mostly heard was one long lament about how the zip had gone out of the zeppole, how the mob -- and by that they meant visitors to Mulberry Street -- was much smaller than last year. It was like listening to Harry Hope's barflies grousing in "The Iceman Cometh" about how Hickey took the life out of the booze.
Who was Hickey for them? Look no further than Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who stood accused of driving the crowds away. The racket-buster at City Hall was described with so many expletives that blue-penciling them all would make any sentence of direct quotations look like a bar code. "Who wants to come all the way down here just to have a bunch of cops in their face?" a sausage vendor said (after the elimination of only a few unprintable words).
NOT everyone was down on the Mayor. "Mr. Giuliani has nothing to do with it," said Luckie Charlie Lanigan, in between asking strollers to try their luck at throwing baseballs through a circle. Bob Dole may be happy to hear that, as far as Lucky Charlie is concerned, the economy is not doing so hot, that "people just don't have enough to go around after paying the rent."
But to a souvenir seller named Salvatore, the problem with the 70-year-old feast is the feast itself. "Before, it was the octopus," Salvatore said in Italian, using a word that often means the mob as a many-tentacled creature. "Now, it's the bureaucracy. It's all the same. What's really wrong is the quality of the whole thing. It's pretty low."
Low and, increasingly, not really part of the neighborhood. Let's face it, there is no Little Italy anymore. It's more like Minuscule Italy, a shrunken enclave of passable restaurants in a widening China sea. Even during the biggest festa of the year, you heard not a single tarantella on the street, only heavy metal tapes. "It's lost its whole meaning of Little Italy and the Italian culture," said Amy Rafano, who had returned briefly from Rhode Island after a few years away from Mulberry Street.
The same could be said about many, if not most, of the 400 or so large street fairs held across the city each year. Scores of them in Manhattan alone lost their true community roots long ago, no matter how much money they may still raise for worthwhile nonprofit groups. Traffic backs up badly on surrounding streets. Avenues that could benefit from a touch of weekend calm, a precious but rare commodity in New York, never get a chance to catch their breath.
WORST of all, many fairs have become thumping bores. How huge can the appetite be for the same portable collections of tube socks, leather bags, "Aladdin" videotapes and plants from Florida that start to die four days after you take them home? Even Mort Berkowitz, who makes his living organizing fairs in Manhattan and defends them as a way for people to meet their neighbors or perhaps just dance the macarena, agrees that street fests no longer have "the same vitality" as those of yore.
No wonder the Giuliani administration has cracked down, trimming the larger gatherings and outright denying requests for "multiblock permits" in about 100 cases. "It's worked well," Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington said yesterday, adding that the policy would be re-examined, and the regulations possibly tightened still further, once the fall street-fair season ends.
Maybe he could also think up ways to give new life to the granddaddy of fairs, the San Gennaro feast, so that it can recapture some flavor of the old neighborhood. For instance, instead of the Drown the Clown game, in which players try to drop a guy into a barrel of water, you could have Dunk the Punk.
Why not start with the man labeled by some the world's dumbest crook? He's the mugger who recently robbed the mother of Chin Gigante, the supposed head of the Genovese crime family, which once knew Mulberry Street very well.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Dow Rises 50, To Still Another Record
Even without a major news development to energize trading, the stock market continued its rally. In the session after its first close over 5,800 points, the Dow Jones industrial average briefly jumped above 5,900 and closed up 50.68 points, at 5,889.20. Other major indexes also rose, though less steeply.
Driven by a new optimism about inflation and interest rates, the Dow industrials have increased by more than 280 points in seven sessions. [Page D8.]
 
Intel shares surged in after-hours trading after the company said it expected its third-quarter revenue to exceed estimates. [D2.]
 
Crestar Plans Acquisition
Crestar Financial has agreed to buy Citizens Bancorp for about $774 million, expanding its assets by 23 percent and solidifying its position in the Washington region. [D3.]
 
I.B.M. Plans Buyout Program
I.B.M. is preparing to offer buyouts and other inducements for 3,000 to 5,000 of its employees to either leave the company or find new jobs at its fastest-growing divisions. [D3.]
 
Goldman, Sachs Profit Surges
Goldman, Sachs reported pretax profit of $589 million for the three months ended Aug. 30, a 39 percent increase from a year earlier, as one of its strongest years continues. [D4.]
 
2 to Leave Archer Daniels Board
Archer Daniels said two former executives would step down as directors, as the company continues to respond to criticism that the board is dominated by insiders. [D3.]
 
Inventories Surged in July
Stockpiles of unsold goods at American businesses soared to the highest level in more than a decade in July, suggesting that businesses were betting that a surge in demand would continue. [D2.]
 
Foundation Health in Merger Talks
Foundation Health said it was discussing a possible merger, but it would not name the other party in the negotiations. [D19.]
 
States Outlaw a Curb on Doctors
In a sign of growing concern about the practices of some health maintenance organizations, 16 states have adopted laws this year to nullify efforts by H.M.O.'s to limit what doctors can tell their patients. [A12.]
 
America Online Moves to Big Board
America Online's chief, Stephen M. Case, left, posed with Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, as America Online moved to that market from Nasdaq. The stock rose $2, but that came after a 60 percent drop since May. Market Place. [D8.]
 
A Former Exchange Chief Is Fined
Zoltan Guttman, the former chairman of the New York Mercantile Exchange, was fined $500,000 and barred from trading on commodities exchanges for five years for his role in a fictitious-trading scheme. [D5.]
